Full text: - The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the president, Cyril Ramaphosa, to complete a first term in 2024 and run for a second term, but a week of serious civil disorder in July, sparked by the jailing of his predecessor as-president, Jacob Zuma, for defying the Constitutional Court, underlines the risks ahead.
- The debilitating socioeconomic impact of the Covid-19 pandemic, exacerbated by July's unrest, highlights the need for urgent remedial action and will help to build support within the ANC for the president's reformist agenda, albeit reluctantly in some cases. Policy will focus on vaccine rollouts, reconstruction, infrastructure investment (led by the private sector) and boosting electricity supply. Fiscal constraints point to an increased reliance on public private partnerships. The fightback against corruption will gather momentum in 2021, as shown by Mr Zuma's jailing and the ANC's suspension of its secretary-general, Ace Magashule, in May, for defying orders to step aside.
- Following a severe recession in 2020, with real GDP shrinking by 7% because of the pandemic, we expect a modest growth rebound in 2021, to 3%, helped by low interest rates and higher commodity prices, although power shortages, a slow vaccine rollout and unrest-linked damage will preclude a more rapid rebound. We envisage growth averaging 2.7% a year in 2022-25, underpinned by structural reforms, but unemployment will continue to weigh on aggregate demand.
- The budget deficit soared to 11% of GDP in fiscal year 2020/21 (April March), but will trend lower, helped by wage restraint and revenue gains from higher commodity prices. Debt risks remain high but will subside if fiscal consolidation plans are fulfilled. Cumulative interest-rate cuts in 2020 took the benchmark to 3.5%, providing relief to borrowers, but the next move will be upwards, either later in 2021 or early in 2022, reflecting global trends.
- After easing to a multi-year low of 3.2% in 2020, average inflation will rise to 4% in 2021, owing to costlier oil, electricity and logistics, but weak demand will keep price growth subdued. Inflation will quicken to 4.5% a year on average in 2022 25 as economic growth stages a gradual post-pandemic recovery.
- South Africa recorded a rare current-account surplus in 2020, of 2.2% of GDP, as exports fell more slowly than imports, pushing up the merchandise trade surplus. Trends in 2021, including buoyant exports, point to another (albeit smaller) current-account surplus, before the return of a deficit in 2022-25 as imports regain traction.

- South Africa's business environment score improves for 2021-25, although its global ranking drops by two positions, and its regional ranking is unchanged from 2016-20. Market opportunity and infrastructure gains will be partly offset by deteriorations in macroeconomic stability and taxation.

Country forecast overview: South Africa's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2021-22: A post-pandemic investment drive, focused on infrastructure, facilitates public-private partnerships. Challenges include tighter competition laws and stricter black economic empowerment (BEE) rules.
2023-25: Expropriation without compensation, to speed up land reform, applies in limited circumstances only, reducing the threat to property rights. Investment incentives in selected industries (such as automotive manufacturing) remain in place.
Policy towards foreign investment 2021-22: A reworked mining charter offers some concessions to business. A new foreign investment law limits access to international arbitration by giving local courts the primary responsibility for handling disputes.
2023-25: The government continues to encourage foreign investment and public-private partnerships, but resists the full privatisation of state assets in most cases.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2021-22: The government implements a further relaxation of capital controls on outward investment and other flows.
2023-25: Progress towards regional economic integration in Southern Africa makes some advances, but barriers persist.
Taxes 2021-22: Despite tough fiscal conditions, the government avoids major tax increases to shield households and firms.
2023-25: Efforts to streamline and modernise the tax system and expand the tax base continue.
Financing 2021-22: Special pandemic liquidity measures are phased out in 2021, but interest rates remain low, before edging higher in 2022. Local banks remain sound and a major source of corporate financing, despite profits being squeezed by the pandemic.
2023-25: The continued independence of the South African Reserve Bank (the central bank) helps to preserve financial system stability. Monetary policy remains prudent and interest rates edge higher. The proposed nationalisation of the central bank is put on hold.
The labour market 2021-22: Pandemic-induced job losses oblige trade unions to accept a mild relaxation of currently inflexible labour laws.
2023-25: The labour market remains tough, owing to skills shortages and BEE targets.
Infrastructure 2021-22: Investment in transport and electricity, led in many cases by private firms, boosts capacity.
2023-25: Private-sector-led investment in renewable energy gathers momentum under the government's long-term energy plan, adding diversity to power supplies and cutting reliance on coal. Rising power tariffs drive energy efficiency.
Technological readiness 2021-22: The rollout of domestic fibre-optic cables boosts capacity and cuts costs. Investment in digital technology gathers momentum, including in 5G, cloud computing and high-end data analysis. The allocation of new spectrum boosts capacity
2023-25: Work advances on the Square Kilometre Array-a powerful radio telescope with multinational support-giving a wider boost to science and to information and communications technology.

Background: South Africa became a full democracy in 1994, when it first held all-race elections. The African National Congress (ANC) won and has dominated all subsequent elections-in 1999, 2004, 2009, 2014 and 2019. However, support ebbed steadily from a peak of nearly 70% in 2004, to 62.1% in 2014 and 57.5% in May 2019. The ANC feared a worse result in in 2019, but the installation of Cyril Ramaphosa as president in February 2018, replacing the scandal-tainted Jacob Zuma, provided a mild bounce. Barring shocks, Mr Ramaphosa will serve a full five-year term, ending in 2024 and would be eligible for a second term.
Political structure: South Africa is a constitutional democracy with a bicameral parliament and a president elected by parliament. The constitution is the supreme law. The National Assembly is elected by proportional representation; the National Council of the Provinces consists of indirectly elected representatives of the nine provinces. The judiciary is independent and includes an 11-member Constitutional Court. The constitution provides for an independent corruption watchdog-the Public Protector-and commissions on human rights, gender equality and restitution of land rights.
Policy issues: The main policy focus in 2021-25 will be to facilitate recovery from a severe recession in 2020 caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The need to boost post-pandemic growth, underlined by unrest in July, will allow Mr Ramaphosa to push ahead more forcefully with his reformist agenda. A new economic recovery and reconstruction plan, devised in consultation with business and labour unions, will focus on investment in critical infrastructure (such as housing and transport), led by the private sector, alongside a large-scale public works programme to create jobs. Tackling power shortages by commissioning new capacity from independent power producers, and by restructuring Eskom, the highly-indebted electricity parastatal, is another key objective. Fiscal constraints point to an increased reliance on public-private partnerships, despite resistance from vested interests. A new draft expropriation bill sets clear limits on when compensation is not payable, thus diminishing the threat to property rights and investor confidence. Challenges include skills shortages, stricter competition laws and the perennial risk of strikes.
Taxation: Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at a flat rate of 15%-after a rise from 14% on April 1st 2018-although some essentials are zero-rated. Corporation tax (of 28%), income tax and VAT were left unchanged in the 2021/22 budget, but a corporation tax reduction is earmarked for 2022/23. Some tax concessions are available, including in special economic zones.
Foreign trade: South Africa has a relatively open economy, with foreign trade (imports plus exports) accounting for about 52% of GDP. China, the EU, the US and Japan are among its largest trading partners. Trade with the rest of Africa has become progressively more important and makes a large contribution to South Africa's merchandise trade surplus.

Outlook for 2021-25: Political stability Recovering from the coronavirus pandemic and a deep recession in 2020 will confront South Africa with unparalleled challenges, aggravated by a week of serious unrest and looting in July, after a former president, Jacob Zuma, was jailed for 15 months for defying the constitutional court. Mr Zuma's incarceration underlines the supremacy of the rule of law and reinforces the authority of the president, Cyril Ramaphosa, but the violence-resulting from incitement by pro-Zuma factions and opportunistic criminality-is a serious political and economic setback, which is also disrupting the ongoing vaccination rollout, especially in Mr Zuma's home province of KwaZulu-Natal, the epicentre of disorder. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects calm to be restored fairly quickly, supported by troop deployments, but 117 lives have been lost so far, alongside many more livelihoods, and the damage costs will exceed R10bn (US$690m).
The ramifications of July's violent disorder are still not fully clear, but we expect pro-Zuma factions in the ruling African National Congress (ANC) to suffer a loss of credibility, to the benefit of Mr Ramaphosa and his allies, despite the government's initially hesitant response to the unrest. Since being elected for a five-year term in May 2019, Mr Ramaphosa has struggled to unite the ANC's disparate factions behind a reformist agenda, but a severe recession in 2020, accompanied by heavy job losses and rising poverty and compounded by shock at the recent violence, underlines the need for urgent action to repair the economy, including by working more closely with private business. Resistance to reforms by powerful interest groups (such as labour unions and left-wing interventionists in the government) is fading because of the state's financial and technical capacity constraints, and the absence of any other coherent strategy to revive the economy. The pending privatisation of a slimmed-down South African Airways, announced in June, underlines an acceptance by the left (albeit reluctant) of a more prominent private-sector role.
Despite the violence unleashed by Mr Zuma's imprisonment, his allies in the ANC-the so-called radical economic transformation movement-will lose influence and political authority. Mr Zuma's imprisonment is a significant step in the fightback against impunity and corruption, which he nurtured during his presidency (2009-18) and will be followed by his next hearing in a separate corruption trial, on long-standing charges, which resumed on July 19th. Reinforcing the message, the ANC suspended its secretary-general, Ace Magashule (Mr Zuma's key ally) in May, because of corruption allegations against him. Given the powerful role played by the secretary-general in choosing election candidates and organising key summits, Mr Magashule's suspension (ahead of his next court appearance, in August), gives Mr Ramaphosa a valuable opportunity to reshape party structures and policies, and to carry out a long-proposed cabinet reshuffle. Policy debates will continue, but Mr Ramaphosa's tighter grip on the ANC improves the outlook for the key structural reforms needed to bolster economic growth and job creation.
Outlook for 2021-25: Election watch The next major political event is the ANC's five-yearly National General Council (NGC)-a policy implementation review-which will give a clearer indication of the balance of forces in the party and the extent of Mr Ramaphosa's control. After being delayed by more than a year by the pandemic, the NGC's timing is still uncertain, although we expect it to take place before the next five-yearly municipal elections on October 27th 2021. The nationwide ballot will give voters the first chance to judge the government's pandemic response and will be a test of Mr Ramaphosa's and the ANC's popularity, especially in the wake of July's disorder, which will have an uncertain electoral impact. The party would be broadly satisfied by an ANC voting share in the 55-60% range in 2021 (compared with 57.5% in the 2019 general election), but a drop into the 50-55% range could see Mr Ramaphosa facing a leadership challenge at the ANC's next electoral summit in December 2022. We expect the ANC, under Mr Ramaphosa, to retain power at the next general election (in 2024), but with a smaller majority than in 2019. The implementation of the new Political Party Funding Act in April 2021 will strengthen transparency.
Outlook for 2021-25: International relations South Africa-the most advanced economy in Africa and a major business hub-will remain deeply engaged in the continent, particularly in Southern and Central/East Africa. Despite a challenging environment, South Africa will continue to attract international companies, including from the US, Europe and Asia, owing to strong institutions, sound banks and its role as the continental gateway. South Africa's commercial involvement in other African markets will remain broad-based, covering mining, banking, telecommunications, retail and hospitality. The pandemic is causing temporary disruption to regional relations because of periodic border closures and flight bans, aggravated by a third wave of Covid-19, but regional access for South African-based firms will improve in 2021-22, helped by vaccine rollouts.
Outlook for 2021-25: Policy trends The government's most immediate policy challenge is to revive the economy after a pandemic-induced contraction in 2020, which inflicted lasting damage on many households and firms. A week of serious unrest, looting and property destruction in July, after the former president, Mr Zuma, was imprisoned, will compound the difficulties and require new support measures. On the pandemic front, vaccinations are gathering pace, reaching some 4.9m (11.7% of adults) on July 15th, despite being disrupted by the recent unrest, which is helping to blunt a third wave of Covid-19. New cases hit an all-time high of 137,861 in the week ending July 9th, accompanied by 2,541 deaths, but subsequent trends point to a decline in both metrics, potentially allowing for the relaxation of tighter restrictions that were imposed in mid-June. The Covid-19 outlook remains uncertain but is showing a mild improvement, despite recent disorder.
The government will attempt to engineer a growth rebound in 2021-25, via targeted measures and deeper structural reforms, although the scope for additional monetary and fiscal intervention is limited. With the benchmark interest rate at a record low of 3.5%, there is no scope for further cuts, while several years of heavy spending and rising budget deficits preclude a broad-based fiscal stimulus. Even before the pandemic, South Africa was trapped in a low-growth trajectory-not for the want of pro-growth plans but because of policy fudges and weak implementation. The pandemic, by exposing underlying fault lines (such as widespread poverty and inequality) and highlighting the need for urgent action, will potentially be a catalyst for deeper and faster structural reforms, including a greater role for the private sector.
Devised in consultation with business and organised labour, an economic recovery plan will focus on job creation-via large-scale public works programmes-and infrastructure investment. The plan aims to channel R100bn (US$6.8bn) over ten years into an infrastructure fund with the aim of attracting a ten-times greater sum from the private sector via public-private partnerships. Target projects range from housing to network infrastructure, and include allowing private participation in the rail network and ports. Facilitating solely private initiatives (such as in mining) via regulatory loosening is another pivotal aim, but uncertainties in key areas, such as land expropriation, will weigh on business confidence.
A paramount policy objective is restoring energy security by adding new capacity (mostly solar and wind) from independent power producers and by lifting the cap on self-generation without a licence ten-fold, to 100 MW (in June). The planned auction of new broadband spectrum in 2021 could give a major boost to communication and digitalisation. Despite these encouraging signs, spectrum allocation is being delayed by a legal dispute, and electricity supply will remain tight, with a high risk of load-shedding (power cuts), before the situation improves in 2023. The restructuring of dysfunctional parastatal enterprises, especially Eskom, the heavily indebted power firm, is a central, interlinked objective. Implementation remains a challenge, but the political will to act is now stronger. Commitments to the IMF in return for a rapid financing instrument in 2020 will add impetus to reforms in the face of resistance from vested interests.
Outlook for 2021-25: Fiscal policy A surge in the budget deficit to about 11% of GDP in fiscal year 2020/21 (April-March) reflects heavy revenue losses and higher spending during the pandemic and recession. The 2020/21 outcome was, nonetheless, smaller than the 15.7% of GDP shortfall predicted by the Treasury last October, because of a belated revenue boost from higher commodity prices, alongside gains from an overhaul of the South African Revenue Service (the tax agency). The brighter revenue outlook means that planned tax increases in 2021/22 were put on hold and a vaccine rollout costing an initial R9bn (US$620m) over two years is fully funded. The 2021/22 budget, unveiled in February, outlines a path of medium-term fiscal consolidation premised on real-term cuts in the public-sector wage bill. We expect the shortfall as a percentage of GDP to ebb to 9.4% in 2021/22 and 7.6% in 2022/23, before easing to 3.4% in 2025/26. The biggest risks to fiscal consolidation are a fightback by labour unions against wage restraint (via a combination of legal action, political pressure and possible strikes) and the heavy debt burdens of parastatal enterprises.
After surging to about 78% of GDP in 2020/21 because of higher borrowing and a recession, the public debt burden will rise more slowly as fiscal revenue recovers, peaking at about 87.4% of GDP in 2024/25, before edging lower. Fiscal consolidation will reduce South Africa's risk of debt distress, as will the government's recourse to deep and liquid domestic capital markets to finance most of the budget shortfalls. Debt-servicing costs will continue rising, however, leaving limited room for slippage on either the spending or the revenue fronts. A failure to meet debt targets could oblige South Africa to undertake a formal IMF programme with strict conditions attached.
Outlook for 2021-25: Monetary policy Policy accommodation during the 2020 pandemic crisis will give way to a normalisation process in 2022, with interest rates edging higher as the economy begins to recover. The South African Reserve Bank (SARB, the central bank) cut the benchmark interest rate (repo rate) five times in 2020, by a cumulative 300 basis points to 3.5%, to help to shield the economy from the pandemic, and has kept the rate on hold in 2021 to date (most recently in May). As a further cut is unlikely, the SARB's next rate move will be upwards, possibly in late 2021 but probably in early 2022, as real GDP resumes growing and inflation edges higher. Additional small increases will follow in 2023-25, broadly tracking US trends.
Outlook for 2021-25: Economic growth Following a steep contraction in 2020, of 7%, owing to the effects of the pandemic, we expect real GDP to grow by 3% in 2021, driven by a mildly better first-quarter outcome than expected, but structural constraints will preclude a faster rebound. Factors supporting growth in 2021 include an improved outlook for vaccine provision (after the government agreed contracts with Johnson & Johnson and Pfizer), higher commodity prices, stronger export demand, another good farm season and the maintenance of low interest rates. Growth downsides that will dampen the rebound in 2021 include a 3.2% year-on-year contraction in the first quarter (because of the pre-pandemic baseline), persistent electricity supply constraints, weak tourism and hospitality, and elevated unemployment, which will sap aggregate demand. The jobless rate edged up to a new record of 32.6% in January-March. An ongoing third wave of Covid-19 and a week of violent unrest in July (after Mr Zuma was imprisoned) will also stifle the pace of recovery. A series of public-sector strikes in response to real-term wage cuts is another significant risk.
As the 2021 rebound largely reflects a very weak baseline in 2020, we expect growth to edge lower again in 2022, to 2.4%. The economy will benefit from stronger private investment in response to favourable policy initiatives (such as moves to facilitate public-private partnerships) and from a gradual relaxation of power supply constraints, although most additions to generating capacity will not come on stream until the second half of 2022 at the earliest. Other hurdles to growth in 2022 will be a global slowdown (after a 2021 rebound), persistently high unemployment and still-fragile tourism. Our growth forecast strengthens to 2.8% a year on average in 2023-25, underpinned by long-delayed reforms (such as parastatal restructuring) and the spread of digital technology, but the global backdrop will remain subdued in terms of economic growth and trade flows.
Outlook for 2021-25: Inflation After dipping to a multi-year low of 3.2% in 2020, owing to recession, cheaper imported oil and a bumper food harvest, inflation will rise to 4% in 2021, but will remain comfortably within the SARB's 3-6% target range. The primary sources of inflation in 2021 will be higher oil prices, electricity tariffs and logistics costs, although a second consecutive bumper harvest in the 2020/21 season will partly offset higher global food prices. Other factors curbing inflation are rand appreciation in 2021, weak aggregate demand (owing to unemployment and income losses), spare industrial capacity and strong retail competition. We expect inflation to quicken to an average of 4.5% a year in 2022-25, spurred by a modest revival in GDP growth, but the level will stay within the SARB's target range, temporary breaches aside.
Outlook for 2021-25: Exchange rates Stronger commodity prices and global liquidity injections will support the rand in 2021, as shown by an 18.7% year-on-year appreciation of the currency to R13.92:US$1 in June-its strongest level for over two years. Being commodity-dependent, widely traded and an emerging-market proxy, the rand will benefit from a positive global backdrop, but it remains vulnerable to any adverse shifts in global sentiment and to negative domestic developments. US signposting of faster monetary tightening alongside recent unrest in South Africa mean that the rand is losing ground in July. In conjunction with South Africa's large fiscal deficit and sluggish growth outlook, we see the rand ending 2021 at R14.92:US$1. On an annual average basis, we forecast strengthening to R14.43:US$1 in 2021 as markets normalise after disruption in 2020. The rand will remain volatile, often experiencing large daily movements in response to shifting sentiment, although South Africa's modest external debt stock and healthy foreign-exchange reserves are protective. Our forecast assumes gradual depreciation from 2022 onwards, with the rand slipping to R17.44:US$1 at end-2025, although the pace of decline will be close to the inflation rate, implying a relatively stable real effective exchange rate.
Outlook for 2021-25: External sector The impact of the pandemic on the external accounts will persist in 2021, and we expect another rare current-account surplus and a net contribution to GDP growth. The pandemic led to a much steeper fall in imports than in exports in 2020, generating a large merchandise trade surplus, which offset the perennial deficit on invisible trade to produce a current-account surplus of 2.2% of GDP. In 2021 a healthy increase in export earnings (underpinned by higher commodity prices) will be surpassed by a rebound in imports as the economy recovers (and oil prices rise), reducing both the merchandise trade surplus and the current-account surplus (to 1.2% of GDP). Our forecast for 2022-25 envisages a return to a current-account deficit, with the shortfall averaging 2.4% of GDP a year, as the invisible trade deficit (underpinned by income outflows to foreign investors) surpasses the merchandise trade surplus. The current-account deficit will be smaller than pre-pandemic levels but will leave South Africa reliant on financial inflows to plug the gap. Foreign direct investment inflows will recover from 2021, helped by structural reforms that will encourage public-private partnerships and solely private initiatives in a range of sectors. We expect inflows of US$5.2bn a year on average in 2021-25 (just under 10% of gross financing needs). South Africa will remain a key base for multinational companies with pan-African operations by offering a range of services, including banking, capital-raising and trade-related functions.

Data sources and definitions The sources for global and domestic data refer to historic data; the source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data US & OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US & OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: Dated Brent Blend
Non-oil commodity prices: IMF, IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Dollar effective exchange rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data Trade by country: IMF, Direction of Trade Statistics
Population: Based on UN data for both the historical and the forecast periods
Balance of payments: IMF, IFS
Inflation: Statistics South Africa. Based on CPIX (consumer price inflation less mortgage costs)
Exchange rate: IMF, IFS; principal rate expressed as R:US$
Real effective exchange rate index: based on consumer price index; trade partner weighted index with base period 2000=100
Interest rate: IMF, IFS; average lending rate
US$ GDP: SARB, Quarterly Bulletin; in current prices converted from local currency at annual average market exchange rate
GDP per head: US$ GDP divided by population
Foreign direct investment: IMF, IFS; UNCTAD, World Investment Report
Total external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; sum of long-term debt, short-term debt and IMF credits
Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics, year-end medium- and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding, with an original maturity in excess of one year
Short-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end debt outstanding, with an original maturity of less than one year
Total debt service: principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges paid against total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Interest payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations IFS: International Financial Statistics
IMF: International Monetary Fund
OECD: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
SARB: South African Reserve Bank
UNCTAD: UN Conference on Trade and Development

Country Forecast Venezuela July 2021 Updater

Full text: - Despite Venezuela's socioeconomic collapse and the ongoing coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the civic-military regime, led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela, to retain power throughout the 2021-25 forecast period. Mr Maduro's position will be supported primarily by his grip over a complex security apparatus and the opposition's lack of de facto power. On this basis, we expect continued deterioration of the economy, sustained outward migration, and a poorer and more violent Venezuela. Despite US sanctions (and their impact on oil production), the Maduro regime has managed internal dissent through a patronage system that rewards loyalty, as well as through its strict control over the security forces.
- The scale of the socioeconomic collapse and the elevated level of political instability will ensure that the Maduro regime continues to be challenged both economically and politically. In particular, there is a significant risk of regime change stemming from a possible breakdown in the patronage system that sustains the security forces' support of the regime. Under our baseline forecast, we assume that Mr Maduro will avoid this, as long as oil rents recover over the medium term, after bottoming out this year. However, there are substantial risks to this assumption stemming from the impact of US sanctions, weaker Chinese demand for Venezuelan crude and a fundamental lack of incentives for investment in the domestic oil industry.
- De facto dollarisation of the economy is expanding. Concurrently, the government has taken measures that have allowed the official exchange rate to float. These measures have aided price stability and therefore increased the availability of some basic goods. However, the measures are not a product of economic orthodoxy, but rather of policy decisions to ensure the regime's survival. We do not expect to see the comprehensive economic and institutional reforms that would be required to resolve Venezuela's economic crisis within the forecast period.

- Venezuela ranks 82nd of 82 countries in the global business environment rankings for 2021-25, having been in 81st place in the 2016-20 historical period, as the economic crisis deepens despite minor improvements. Reforms to institutions, economic policy and the business environment are unlikely.

Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2021-22: Enforcement of price controls remains lax, but risk of state intervention remains high. Corruption and selective application of regulations are common and continue to undermine free competition.
2023-25: Contract rights remain weak, and red tape and ad hoc interventionism continue.
Policy towards foreign investment 2021-22: Government efforts to revive foreign investment fail owing to US sanctions and political and economic instability.
2023-25: Investment flows remain low amid ongoing economic volatility. Intellectual property protection and private property rights deteriorate.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2021-22: Currency controls are weakened, but access to foreign currency remains limited. US sanctions hamper trade.
2023-25: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are undertaken on a gradual basis, and de facto dollarisation advances. Domestic supply of foreign currency remains limited as oil prices decline.
Taxes 2021-22: Risks of further unrest and political instability reduce probability of central government increasing taxes. However, municipal authorities raise taxes owing to funding shortfalls.
2023-25: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but risk of discriminatory, ad hoc tax measures declines.
Financing 2021-22: Inflation remains high, and concerns surrounding economic instability restrict financing to only short term.
2023-25: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid, sustainable growth in credit to private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market 2021-22: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage costs. Firms prohibited from firing workers until end-2022. Ongoing emigration of skilled labour aggravates skills shortages.
2023-25: Labour market rigidities persist despite some increased flexibility in hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure 2021-22: Underinvestment in water network and electricity grid leads to continued rationing and unpredictable blackouts.
2023-25: Investors remain highly cautious about committing to long-term capital projects. Infrastructure deteriorates even further.
Technological readiness 2021-22: E-government services remain almost non-existent. Telecommunications sector is opened to foreign investment, but with little interest. Local use of cryptocurrency expands among middle- and high-income households.
2023-25: Limited regulatory capacity and years of underinvestment continue to restrict internet and mobile coverage.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s, two parties-Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente-alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in support for both parties and culminated in the 1998 election of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but several attempts to remove him from power before his death in March 2013 proved unsuccessful. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, has seen his own popularity plummet, as his macroeconomic mismanagement-aggravated by wide-ranging US sanctions-has plunged the country into a state of economic collapse.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is nominally a federal republic with separation of powers, the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) has systematically eroded institutions. In December 2015 the opposition coalition, Mesa de la Unidad Democrática, won control of the unicameral National Assembly. In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature to be in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. In August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly (ANC) granted itself control over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and sidelining the National Assembly. The ANC was dissolved at end-2020, after the PSUV and its allies regained control of the legislature in an election that was widely regarded as rigged.
Policy issues: The most pressing policy issue is the need to stabilise the crisis-ridden economy. The monetisation of vast public deficits has created an ever-increasing excess of domestic currency, triggering hyperinflation. Mismanagement of PDVSA (the state-owned oil company and originator of practically all foreign-currency inflows into the country) has resulted in a sharp contraction in oil production. Attempts to address these problems through distortionary price and currency controls proved actively counter-productive and led to major shortages of both foreign currency and basic goods. The scarcity of foreign exchange also led to arrears on most of the external debt issued by the sovereign and state-owned firms. The Maduro regime is now changing tack and pursuing incremental pro-market reforms, but its efforts are hindered by chronic economic instability, a lack of confidence in the legal framework and wide-ranging US sanctions.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 50% for oil firms. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that the goods trade surplus fell to US$9.9bn in 2019, amid a long-term decline in oil exports. We estimate that the trade account deteriorated further in 2020, shifting to a US$2.9bn deficit.

Outlook for 2021-25: Political stability The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the civic-military regime, led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV, the Chavistas), to remain in power throughout the 2021-25 forecast period, despite its role in fomenting the country's ongoing socioeconomic and humanitarian crisis. A number of factors underpin our forecast; particularly significant is the regime's strict control over the military, the police and paramilitary forces. This control, which depends on a patronage system that rewards the loyalty of high-ranking officials, will allow the regime to manage internal dissent.
In our view, the domestic opposition will pose little threat to Mr Maduro's power. Having retaken control of the National Assembly from the opposition in January, the Chavistas have unchecked authority over all branches of government. Political control is nominally disputed by Juan Guaidó, the leader of the Frente Amplio Venezuela Libre (FAVL) opposition alliance and self-declared interim president, but the opposition lacks de facto power. Mr Guaidó retains the backing of most Western powers, including the US, which he has used to co-ordinate a "maximum pressure" campaign against the Maduro regime. However, with these hardline tactics failing to deliver results-and in some cases proving counterproductive-domestic support for Mr Guaidó is waning.
Against this backdrop, the PSUV has made gestures in recent weeks aimed at facilitating rapprochement with the opposition, with a view to securing sanctions relief from the US. One significant concession by the regime is the inclusion of two opposition representatives on the five-member board of the newly appointed electoral authority (CNE). Ahead of forthcoming regional and local elections on November 21st, the CNE has taken a number of steps to rebuild confidence in Venezuela's electoral system. These include a renewal of the electoral register, an audit of the automated voting system and invitations to international observers (including the EU and the UN) to oversee the November polls. The regime has also sought to launch fresh political negotiations, with a first round of talks to take place in August. However, these gestures appear to be largely cosmetic, and Mr Maduro is unlikely to acquiesce to any process that would actually threaten his grip on power. A renewed crackdown on opposition leaders in mid-July reinforces our view that Mr Maduro is not engaging in good faith. As a result, the long-running political stalemate is likely to persist.
Nevertheless, there is a high degree of risk attached to our forecast that Mr Maduro will remain in power. In our view, there are two main paths to a change of government: a negotiated transition, or some sort of internal coup. Notwithstanding the potential for increased multilateral engagement, we believe that a negotiated transition would be difficult, as trust issues between the two sides are insurmountable. Bearing this in mind, we believe that the most likely scenario for regime change is an internal coup. The regime's main weakness is the fragility of its internal finances, which are heavily dependent on revenue from PDVSA, the state-owned oil company. The government's patronage system is crucial for sustaining its security apparatus and stamping out social unrest. The regime's finances have already come under severe strain, owing to the combination of extreme macroeconomic mismanagement and US sanctions. In the near term, a recently announced Chinese policy measure will deal PDVSA's oil rents yet another blow-from mid-June the Chinese government will levy a hefty tax on imports of bitumen blends. The move is likely to hit demand from independent Chinese refineries for Venezuelan crude (which is typically rebranded as bitumen mix from Malaysia to bypass US sanctions). The regime will continue to benefit from funds from drug-trafficking and illegal mining activities, but a lack of hard currency could prove fatal to the patronage system, and will test the regime's ability to maintain cohesion among its ranks and control over the security apparatus. The regime's liquidity problems-along with the country's deepening socioeconomic and humanitarian crisis-could therefore prompt putsch attempts in the near term.
Outlook for 2021-25: Election watch A legislative election was held in December 2020 to select the 277 members of the unicameral National Assembly. The vote, which was boycotted by most opposition parties, was widely regarded as neither free nor fair. The results were therefore unsurprising: the Gran Polo Patriótico, an electoral alliance dominated by the PSUV, won an overwhelming supermajority of 256 seats in the legislature.
Next on the electoral calendar are regional and local elections (to elect governors, mayors and their legislative counterparts), which will take place on November 21st. We believe that the regime will try to use negotiations over electoral conditions as a first step towards gaining international legitimacy and some degree of sanctions relief. However, these efforts are unlikely to yield results, particularly given that the regime is not serious about allowing truly competitive polls that could put its dominance at the subnational level at risk. The PSUV's control of the majority of the CNE board and its unfettered influence over the judicial branch are designed to guard against such an outcome. In addition, the legislature is also debating a bill on "communal cities" that could be used to install a parallel governance structure if the opposition's electoral performance surprises on the upside. Despite these issues, some pragmatic members of the opposition are still likely to participate in the November polls, in a bid to make inroads into a political system from which they have been shut out. However, we do not expect a shift in the balance of power.
Outlook for 2021-25: International relations The Maduro regime's main foreign policy challenge will be managing its combative ties with the US. The administration led by the former US president, Donald Trump (2017-21), instituted several rounds of crippling oil sanctions as part of a systematic campaign designed to undermine the regime. Although the aggressive sanctions policy did not produce its intended outcome, it did accelerate the decline of Venezuela's oil industry. Mr Maduro will look to reset ties with the US under the new president, Joe Biden, but we expect little progress. US policy towards Venezuela has bipartisan support in the US, and Mr Biden is unlikely to provide significant sanctions relief unless the Maduro regime makes major political compromises and commits to democratic reform (both of which are highly improbable). Any changes to US sanctions policy will therefore be only on humanitarian grounds and aimed at improving the lives of the poorest Venezuelans, as evidenced by recent exemptions granted for coronavirus-related transactions and imports of liquefied petroleum gas.
Another major challenge for the Maduro regime comes from a traditional ally: China. Despite having previously extended significant financial aid to the regime, the Chinese government has scaled back its support in recent years, following non-payment of liabilities by Venezuela. China's surprise decision to tax bitumen imports has complicated relations further. Our baseline view is that the policy move was motivated by domestic considerations, namely China's desire to support its state-owned refineries at the cost of independent ones. Assuming that this is the case, the Chinese authorities are likely to permit Venezuelan crude to enter the country in other ways. However, we do not entirely discount the possibility that China has lost confidence in the Maduro regime. If this is the case, PDVSA could face significantly restricted access to its main export market, with wide-ranging implications for Venezuela's political and economic outlook. Although Venezuela will continue to enjoy strong diplomatic ties with Iran and Russia, neither country will be willing to provide game-changing amounts of finance in 2021-25.
Outlook for 2021-25: Policy trends The Maduro regime's immediate policy priorities will be to contain the public health crisis caused by Covid-19, alleviate ongoing diesel shortages and reverse a long-running economic collapse. However, progress (if any) on each of these goals will be limited.
To combat the coronavirus pandemic, the government is maintaining its "Fórmula 7+7 Plus" strategy, which involves alternating between a week of tighter restrictions and a week of more relaxed ones. However, this has so far failed to prevent fresh waves of the virus, increasing pressure on Venezuela's decrepit medical infrastructure. Meanwhile the country's vaccine rollout has stalled owing to problems with procurement and distribution (as at mid-July only about 10% of the population had received at least one dose). We do not expect that enough doses of the vaccine will be distributed to have a significant impact on local transmission until 2023.
In an effort to address severe diesel shortages, the government has sought to increase domestic output by restarting operations at key refineries. However, the government's fix is not a viable long-term solution, mainly because producing diesel requires light crude, which is in limited supply. To ramp up domestic diesel output, PDVSA has had to cut back on blending operations of heavy crude from the Orinoco oil belt (which is limiting overall production and exports of crude oil). The government has also sought to intermittently import diesel through intermediaries, but it has limited foreign currency to increase its imports on the scale required. As a result, we believe that a long-term remedy will hinge on the Biden administration reinstating exemptions on crude-for-diesel swaps. We believe that this is likely later this year as the local humanitarian crisis deepens, but risks to this assumption are high.
Reversing Venezuela's economic decline will be a similarly difficult task. The most pressing challenge for the government will be to retain its market share in China following the imposition of the bitumen tax (which amounts to about US$30/barrel). In the immediate term, we expect that PDVSA will offer even steeper discounts on its crude, effectively wiping out a large share of its margin. That said, even with price concessions, some Chinese refineries will probably turn to importing benchmark grades instead of Venezuelan barrels, which are subject to sanctions. The longer-term solution to Venezuela's conundrum will ultimately depend on what the Chinese authorities are comfortable with. Chinese state-owned companies could resume direct purchases of Venezuelan oil, but this would expose them to secondary sanctions by the US. A more probable outcome is that China will grant flexibility-around either enforcement of the bitumen tax, oil import quotas or both-to some select independent refiners that import Venezuelan crude.
In the medium term, the regime will seek to pave the way for recovery by boosting private investment (given that the public sector is completely overstretched). The regime has promulgated an anti-blockade law, which gives the executive branch the unchecked authority to sign new deals with private firms and countries confidentially (in order to skirt international sanctions), without going through public tender processes. Concurrently, the regime is working on a hydrocarbons reform that would incentivise greater private-sector participation in the oil industry. However, these efforts are unlikely to yield significant results; even assuming that the regime manages to sidestep financial sanctions, it will struggle to attract new investment, given the abysmal business environment and a lack of confidence in the rule of law.
Outlook for 2021-25: Fiscal policy The authorities have not published complete data on the fiscal accounts since 2011. However, we expect that a high level of inefficient current expenditure, combined with an extremely weak revenue intake, will keep the budget deficit wide and the public debt/GDP ratio above 300% throughout the 2021-25 forecast period. The sovereign's default on most of its interest and principal repayments will continue to prevent access to external finance, leaving the regime reliant on monetisation to fund its deficits. Even if the government reaches an agreement with some of its creditors (including China) to restructure debt liabilities in 2021-25, we still expect the public debt burden to remain huge, particularly as considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing-mainly PDVSA-issued debt and development funds-understate the true size of total public liabilities.
Outlook for 2021-25: Monetary policy Monetary policy will remain subservient to fiscal policy as the Banco Central de Venezuela (BCV, the central bank) continues to print money to finance the government's gaping budget deficits. In recent years the BCV has taken steps to control growth of monetary aggregates-for instance in early 2020 it lifted the cash reserve ratio (CRR) to 93%, although it has relaxed the CRR slightly since that peak, to 85% currently. Far from taming inflation, these measures have led to the complete destruction of private-sector credit, which stands at less than 1% of levels recorded four years ago. These factors have accelerated the trend towards greater use of the US dollar in the economy; almost two-thirds of financial transactions now take place in dollars.
Outlook for 2021-25: Economic growth After an estimated contraction in real GDP of 31% in 2020, we expect real GDP to decline by a further 14% in 2021. As a consequence, GDP will have contracted by almost four-fifths since its 2013 peak.
The short-term outlook for the oil sector has worsened markedly in the light of the expected drop in demand from China, Venezuela's main export market. In theory, the government could divert excess output to the domestic economy, but state-owned refineries lack the processing capacity to handle such large volumes of crude (as evidenced by the ongoing diesel crisis). Therefore, as export bottlenecks emerge, PDVSA will have little choice but to cut production at its main facilities, given its beleaguered finances. We assume that the disruption will be temporary and that external demand will creep up over time as PDVSA and its trading partners find ways around US sanctions and Chinese taxes. However, the balance of risks is tilted heavily to the downside.
For its part, the non-oil economy will show little improvement early on in the forecast period, especially as an uncontrolled pandemic limits prospects for services activities. In the medium term, however, we expect some modest gains, assuming that continued dollarisation engenders relative macroeconomic stability. Nonetheless, we expect that Venezuela's GDP (in real terms) will be only about half its 2018 level, even in 2025.
Outlook for 2021-25: Inflation A severely reduced domestic goods supply, constraints on import capacity and the monetisation of large public deficits will impede the disinflationary process in 2021-25. The regime has shown little inclination to take on the fiscal and macroeconomic reforms that would address the root causes of inflation. It has, however, lent its support to an ongoing process of de facto dollarisation, which will help to ease price pressures over time.
Outlook for 2021-25: Exchange rates Hyperinflation will sustain bolívar depreciation in 2021. Given incessant inflation and its effect on nominal values, we believe that another currency redenomination (as in March 2018) is a strong possibility. Although a number of currency regulations officially remain on the books, the regime has largely stopped enforcing them in its recent embrace of dollarisation.
Outlook for 2021-25: External sector Balance-of-payments pressures will remain severe in 2021-25, contributing to goods shortages and economic inequities. Foreign reserves stood at US$6.2bn in June-their lowest level in three decades. This steep decline, which has been several years in the making, reflects poor policymaking and a lack of economic diversification in the country's external sector.
Under our baseline forecast, we expect reserves to fall to US$5.9bn this year, before recovering to US$7.9bn by 2025. These trends will be driven entirely by transactions on the current account, as Venezuela's access to foreign direct and portfolio investment will remain extremely limited. We expect the current-account deficit to remain wide, at 6% of GDP in 2021, before the balance shifts to a surplus of 1.1% of GDP in 2022. Thereafter, the account will remain in surplus, averaging 1.8% of GDP in 2023-25. Crucially, our forecasts assume that export earnings will recover from a nadir this year. We also expect that workers' remittances from abroad will play a crucial role in propping up the current-account balance.

Country Forecast United Kingdom July 2021 Updater

Abstract: The Bank of England (BoE, the central bank) has cut its policy interest rate to an historic low of 0.1% and authorised £450bn (US$620bn) in bond purchases to keep government borrowing costs low. Full text: - At a general election on December 12th 2019 the Conservative Party, under the prime minister, Boris Johnson, won an emphatic 80-seat majority. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the government to serve its full term.
- On January 1st 2021 the UK left the EU's single market and customs union, having reached a free-trade agreement, the EU-UK Trade and Co-operation Agreement (TCA), in December. Although this provides for no tariffs and no quotas, its provisions are significantly less comprehensive than EU membership and have created substantial non-tariff barriers.
- The UK-EU relationship will continue to evolve, with many issues being deferred. Relations may come under greater strain if the UK pursues a different regulatory course, which would entail additional future tariffs. Northern Ireland is a flashpoint; grace periods limiting the extent of customs checks on goods between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK are due to expire in October. Further trade disruption would further exacerbate discontent among unionist communities, which already led to rioting in April.
- The coronavirus pandemic led to the suspension of significant economic activity for most of 2020 and into 2021. There have been three lockdowns, which involved the closing of all non-essential retail, the last of which is only now being relaxed. Real GDP declined by 9.8% in 2020. We expect it to rebound by 5.7% in 2021 and 5.6% in 2022, reaching pre-crisis levels in 2o22.
- The Treasury committed to a series of coronavirus-related support schemes for business, and a furlough scheme to pay 80% of workers' wages. In response to a rise in coronavirus cases in autumn 2020, these schemes have been extended to autumn 2021. We forecast this to cause public debt to peak at over 107% of GDP in 2021. The government has announced a rise in corporation tax from 2023, and more tax rises are probably necessary to stabilise debt as a percentage of GDP by 2025, which we expect it to do (at roughly 105% of GDP).
- The Bank of England (BoE, the central bank) has cut its policy interest rate to an historic low of 0.1% and authorised £450bn (US$620bn) in bond purchases to keep government borrowing costs low. It has also approved short-term monetary financing of government spending, given the economic costs of the counter-crisis measures. We expect interest rates to stay close to zero until 2022, even though inflation will exceed the BoE's 2% target in 2021 and 2022.

- The UK's business environment score rises slightly in the forecast period (2021-25) as Brexit- and pandemic-related uncertainty dissipates. The UK's global ranking drops by four places, owing to greater increases elsewhere, while its regional ranking falls by one place. Brexit has worsened the UK's terms of trade, but the country's strengths-a pro-business policy stance, a welcoming attitude to foreign investment, and flexible labour and product markets-will continue.

Country forecast overview: United Kingdom's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2021-22: Extraordinary state support for coronavirus-affected businesses. A 130% "super-deduction" on capital investment.
2023-25: Continued elevated state intervention in investment and innovation. New state aid rules implemented.
Policy towards foreign investment 2021-22: Continued openness to investment, although increased scrutiny in sectors considered sensitive to national security.
2023-25: Infrastructure plans offer investment opportunities. Possible changes in tax policies to bolster inward investment.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2021-22: Increased trade barriers with EU. New Northern Ireland protocol implemented. Negotiations continue with third countries. Expected decline in UK-EU crossborder trade. Bounce-back in global trade following pandemic.
2023-25: Continued UK-EU negotiations probable. New trade agreements with other countries, including potential accession to Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) trade bloc.
Taxes 2021-22: Tax holidays and deferments throughout the coronavirus crisis. Changes to the value-added tax (VAT) framework.
2023-25: Corporation tax increase from 19% to 25%. Additional tax rises, such as equalisation of self-employed and regular income taxes, likely to fund public spending and investment.
Financing 2021-22: Monetary policy remains highly accommodative, with Bank of England (central bank) asset purchases continuing. Loss of "passporting" rights and restrictions on EU services trade. Slow progress in establishing equivalence with EU.
2023-25: Modest decline in City of London's status. Steady growth in alternative forms of debt financing.
The labour market 2021-22: Increased unemployment as furlough scheme expires. Pandemic-related departure of expatriates and sharp drop in immigration from EU owing to end to free movement of labour. Increased immigration from Hong Kong.
2023-25: Greater emphasis on skills-based migration from outside EU may risk labour shortages in low-skilled occupations.
Infrastructure 2021-22: Modest rise in spending on housing, roads and digital infrastructure. Crossrail service in London begins operation in 2022.
2023-25: Increased infrastructure investment, emphasis on "levelling up" regional infrastructure and competitiveness.
Technological readiness 2021-22: High e-commerce penetration and strong research base, but research and development (R&D) spending remains below EU average. Continued high threat from cybercrime and cyber-espionage.
2023-25: Modest rise in public R&D spending. Development of state "blue skies" fund.

Background: The end of the second world war coincided with the decline of the UK as an imperial power. Residual links with former colonial territories, close relations with the US and a separate sense of identity delayed UK membership of the European Community (now the EU) until 1973. Successive governments resisted closer EU integration. The UK left the EU in January 2020, following a referendum in June 2016, although it remains in a transition period until December 31st. The future contours of the UK's relationship with the EU are uncertain, but a diminution of UK influence in the region appears to be inevitable.
Political structure: The UK is a constitutional monarchy. The head of state is Queen Elizabeth II. Parliament has an elected House of Commons (the lower house, 650 seats) and a non-elected House of Lords (the upper house, non-fixed membership of about 800). The snap general election in December 2019 produced a majority government for the centre-right Conservative Party, which won 365 seats. The main opposition Labour Party won 202 seats, with smaller parties winning the remaining 83. This government is expected to serve out its full term until the next scheduled election, in 2024.
Policy issues: The coronavirus outbreak has dominated UK politics since March 2020. After a modest level of fiscal and monetary consolidation, the government has embarked on massive fiscal expansion to support workers and businesses affected by the virus and containment measures, while the Bank of England (the central bank) has moved rates to record lows, which is likely to persist into 2021. The fallout from the Brexit vote will also dominate the policy agenda; The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the government to focus efforts managing the economic impact of its departure from the EU and on reducing the damaging effect on the economy of the uncertainty created by the coronavirus. Maintaining competitiveness in this environment will force policymakers to address structural deficiencies such as low productivity.
Taxation: The headline rate of corporation tax has been reduced steadily, from 28% in 2010 to 19% since April 2018. There are three bands of personal income tax, set at 20%, 40% and 45% (the 45% rate came into effect in April 2013, replacing the 50% rate introduced in 2010). The standard rate of value-added tax (VAT) is 20% (raised from 17.5% in 2011). Excise duties on tobacco and alcohol are among the highest in Europe.
Foreign trade: In 2020 exports of goods totalled US$399bn and imports amounted to US$548bn, resulting in a trade deficit of US$149bn. The services surplus expanded to US$138bn. The overall current-account deficit widened in absolute terms, from US$87.6bn in 2019 to US$95.4bn, widening as a share of GDP, from 3.1% to 3.5%.

Outlook for 2021-25: Political stability At the general election on December 12th 2019 the Conservative Party, under the prime minister, Boris Johnson, won an 80-seat majority. On January 31st 2020 Mr Johnson fulfilled his campaign promise to take the UK out of the EU, ending 47 years of EU membership. On January 1st 2021 the UK left the EU's single market and customs union after negotiating a free-trade agreement. The government is currently managing the implementation of a new trading relationship with the EU while addressing the fallout from the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic. Despite the challenges posed by these two issues, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the government to last a full term.
The spread of the coronavirus in early 2020 put the government on a crisis-management footing. Since March 2020 the government has implemented three lockdowns in England, with many non-essential businesses being closed. Devolved administrations in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland enacted similar restrictions during these periods. Many domestic restrictions under the third lockdown have been relaxed, but the lifting of all remaining restrictions has been delayed from June 21st to July 19th, as the more contagious Delta coronavirus variant has led to an ongoing third sharp spike in cases. Nonetheless, the success of the UK's vaccination programme (with 86% of adults having received a first dose and 64% a second as at July 7th) has meant that the increase in overall hospitalisations has been minimal, allowing the reopening to proceed.
Brexit and the pandemic have increased the medium-term risk to the integrity of the UK. Nicola Sturgeon, the leader of the Scottish National Party (SNP), has argued that Brexit represents a material change in the relationship between Scotland and the UK since the 2014 referendum on Scottish independence, in which a majority favoured the continuation of the union. Support for Scottish independence spiked during the initial phase of the pandemic, as Scottish voters viewed their devolved government's response as more effective than that of the UK government. This has ebbed since the vaccination campaign began; recent opinion polls show a lead for support for the union, although within the margin of error.
The SNP-with the support of the pro-independence Scottish Green Party-has held a majority in the Scottish Parliament since 2016. It made modest gains in the May 2021 elections, which Ms Sturgeon claims give her a mandate to pursue a second referendum. However, we do not believe that these gains will produce sufficient political pressure to force the UK government to grant a referendum in this parliamentary term. Even if it were to do so, the poll would take several years to organise. Furthermore, divisions within pro-independence parties may undermine the unity of the movement. We therefore believe that there are significant obstacles to Scotland becoming independent and do not expect this to happen during the forecast period.
Brexit has inflamed tensions in Northern Ireland. The UK and the EU agreed to a separate protocol for Northern Ireland to avoid border checks with the Republic of Ireland. Under this agreement, Northern Ireland remains within a regulatory union with the EU for most goods. Although it will stay in the UK customs and value-added tax (VAT) areas, customs and VAT checks will be conducted by the UK on the EU's behalf at ports in the Irish Sea for goods bound for the EU. This requires the checkpoints and border infrastructure between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK for all goods deemed by a UK-EU joint committee to be "at risk" of passing into the EU.
This arrangement has been difficult to implement, and is disliked by Unionist Northern Irish politicians for ostensibly creating a border between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK. Rioting broke out in Northern Ireland on April 2nd and persisted for over a week. These protests originated among Unionist communities partly in opposition to the Irish Sea border checks. The UK and the EU have intensified talks around how to implement the Northern Ireland protocol, and a series of grace periods on the implementation of border checks between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK have been delayed until October 1st in an attempt to find a solution that will satisfy Unionist communities. However, the protocol will remain a source of UK-EU friction, as the EU will resist further extensions of these grace periods to avoid undermining the integrity of the single market. Despite these tensions, we expect the protocol to remain in place, given the commitments by both sides not to re-create a hard customs border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland, and the lack of a viable alternative. Tensions will remain elevated, and there is a high risk of further violence.
Outlook for 2021-25: Election watch Under the Fixed-term Parliaments Act (FTPA), the next general election is scheduled for May 2nd 2024. The government has introduced a bill to repeal the FTPA. However, even once this is passed, a general election must be called within five years of the preceding one; they are usually held in May, to coincide with local elections. There is a risk of an early election in 2023; UK governments have often taken advantage of strong economic performance in the penultimate year of a parliament to consolidate their gains, rather than waiting for the parliament to expire.
During the pandemic, the Conservative Party's lead in opinion polls over the opposition Labour Party dropped from more than 20 percentage points at the outbreak of the crisis to a near-tie after several scandals and rapid policy reversals reduced public confidence in the government. Since the success of the vaccine rollout, the Conservatives' polling position has improved to a double-digit margin ahead of Labour, which may persist if the government is seen to manage the recovery well. Local elections on May 6th saw the Conservatives make gains on local councils, consistent with this level of polling lead.
Outlook for 2021-25: International relations The EU-UK Trade and Co-operation Agreement (TCA), which was reached on December 24th 2020, is a free-trade agreement that succeeds the UK's membership of the EU single market and customs union, following its exit from EU institutions on January 1st 2021. The TCA provides for zero-tariff, zero-quota trade between the UK and EU, at least in the first instance. However, leaving the single market and customs union has created a variety of non-tariff trade barriers in the forms of border checks and product certifications. The agreement also provides a mechanism whereby if the divergence in regulations on labour, the environment or state aid becomes sufficiently great, the other side can implement retaliatory tariffs to compensate, subject to an arbitration period.
The regulatory and tariff regimes may therefore drift apart over time. For example, the EU has found the UK's data protection regime "adequate" to allow for the free-flow of data between the UK and EU. However, the EU has committed to review this decision every four years, as the UK will not agree to remain in alignment with EU standards in any formal way. UK-EU negotiations are ongoing over the UK receiving designations of equivalence on financial services, although such an agreement looks increasingly unlikely. The UK has applied to rejoin the Lugano convention, which allows legal judgements to be enforced across borders, but several EU member states oppose non-EU countries joining the convention.
The UK government has stated its intention to be outward looking, pursuing a "Global Britain" strategy, and in March it unveiled an updated defence and security policy outlining a strategy of greater engagement in Asia, in addition to continued engagement in the Atlantic. The UK held the presidency of the G7 group of nations in June 2021 and will host the UN Climate Change Conference (COP26) in Glasgow in November. It intends to use these platforms to take an enhanced role in global climate policy. On trade, the UK has achieved continuity agreements with most countries that had agreements with the EU, and has applied to join the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), a trade bloc of 11 Pacific nations.
Outlook for 2021-25: Policy trends Even before the pandemic, the UK faced significant economic policy challenges, including low public investment, wide regional disparities, high housing costs and chronically low productivity growth. However, the scale of the disruption caused by the virus is likely to dominate the government's policy focus at least until all extraordinary restrictions and support are withdrawn in 2022.
Since becoming the Conservative Party leader and prime minister, Mr Johnson has advocated greater public-sector investment, including in infrastructure, and additional current spending on the National Health Service, education and the police. The government has also reformed the UK's immigration system to emphasise skilled labour. Long-term social care is an area of health spending that Mr Johnson's manifesto pledged to address, alongside significant investment in green and renewable energy as part of a green recovery plan, although details for both remain vague. The government is also attempting to encourage public and private investment to address the UK's chronic low productivity, most prominently in a two-year tax "super-deduction" allowing companies to write off tax up to 130% of the value of their capital investment in 2021-23, as well as expanding the scope of public borrowing for investment from 2% of GDP to 3%. These initiatives are likely to yield modest benefits, but the UK's deficits in investment and productivity are long-standing issues and will not be reversed within a single parliamentary term.
Outlook for 2021-25: Fiscal policy At the outbreak of the pandemic, the government enforced nationwide shutdowns and developed financial support packages to help workers and businesses. These included government-backstopped loans; several business tax deferments and holidays; targeted aid to the worst-affected sectors, such as travel and retail; and wage support schemes for salaried and self-employed workers. In its March budget, the government committed to extending most pandemic support measures into the autumn of 2021, only completely phasing them out by March 2022. We expect that this will lead to a fiscal deficit of 10.8% of GDP in 2021, with the debt/GDP ratio peaking at over 107%.
The budget also committed to greater fiscal consolidation, with a planned increase in corporation tax from 19% to 25% in 2023. However, this budget assumes highly ambitious increases in productivity growth and minimal increases in health, education and welfare spending from pre-pandemic levels after 2022; this is unlikely, given the government's campaign promises of greater spending and investment. We therefore expect further tax increases during the forecast period, with debt declining only marginally, to 105% of GDP by 2025.
Outlook for 2021-25: Monetary policy On March 19th 2020 the Bank of England (BoE, the central bank) cut its main rate to 0.1%-its lowest ever level. It also resumed its quantitative easing programme, committing to £450bn (US$620bn) in asset purchases, which was expanded twice more in 2020, reaching a total of £895bn.
Despite a recent uptick in inflation, we do not expect the BoE to raise rates before late 2022. The BoE has expressed a view that inflation stemming from the reopening of the economy is likely to be transitory. A premature tightening would pose significant risks to the debt sustainability of UK corporates that have borrowed heavily during the pandemic and also the UK government.
Outlook for 2021-25: Economic growth The pandemic and ensuing public health measures caused a severe economic contraction in 2020, with real GDP shrinking by 9.8%. The most recent lockdown resulted in a contraction of 1.6% in the first quarter of 2021. A significant bounce-back started in April as restrictions were lifted and government incentives to boost investment kicked in. We expect growth of 5.7% in 2021 as a whole. We forecast further catch-up growth of 5.6% in 2022, which looks set to be the first full year without social distancing restrictions; real GDP should return to its pre-crisis level during the first half of 2022. Most of the headline growth will stem from favourable year-on-year comparisons with the 2020-21 lockdowns as shut-down activities restart, rather than from robust new economic activity. The drawdown of household savings, which reached nearly 20% of income in 2020, will contribute to growth significantly. That said, in 2017-19 household savings reached historic lows of less than 7%, owing to Brexit uncertainty and slow wage growth, and we do not expect savings to return to those levels, limiting the increase in overall consumption. In 2023-25 we expect the rate of economic expansion to slow, averaging 1.8% per year, as taxes rise and catch-up growth abates.
Unemployment rose in 2020, as the pandemic caused prolonged business closures. The spike in unemployment was modest, however, at an average rate of 4.5% in 2020, owing to the government's furlough scheme. We expect the rate to average 5.3% in 2021 as the scheme is withdrawn. Unemployment will decline thereafter, reaching 4% in 2024-25.
Gross capital formation declined sharply in 2020 as the uncertain environment depressed investment. We expect a significant bounce-back in investment growth in 2021-22, driven in part by the government's investment tax super-deduction, as well as a more stable post-pandemic and post-Brexit investment environment. Investment growth should stabilise from 2023 until the end of the forecast period.
Export and import growth turned sharply negative in 2020 as global demand collapsed and coronavirus-related travel restrictions persisted. We expect growth to bounce back in 2021-22, but Brexit-related disruption will restrict the pace of expansion.
Outlook for 2021-25: Inflation Inflation declined sharply in 2020, to an average of only 1%, as the pandemic depressed demand. Prices have begun to rebound sharply in 2021, owing to increased consumer spending, as well as supply constraints both in the domestic market and internationally, which we expect to drive up inflation to an average of 3.1% in 2021 and 2.6% in 2022. From 2023 inflation will decline to a more modest level as pent-up demand is exhausted, stabilising at 1.8% by 2025.
Outlook for 2021-25: Exchange rates The value of sterling has been volatile in recent years owing to political uncertainty related to Brexit and the pandemic, as well as the UK's large current-account deficit, which requires significant international capital invest-ment to support the currency. Sterling strengthened against the US dollar in late 2020 and early 2021 as the uncertainty around a potential no-deal Brexit ended and a flight to safety in dollar liquidity gradually unwound, with sterling peaking at US$1.42:£1 in June 2021 before stabilising slightly below that level. Sterling similarly appreciated against the euro in 2021 as Brexit uncertainty dissipated and the UK economy unlocked more rapidly.
Sterling should continue to appreciate against the euro, rising from EUR1.08:£1 at end-2020 to EUR1.19:£1 by end-2021. We expect it to stabilise against the euro from 2022, averaging EUR1:21:£1 in 2022-25; both currencies will appreciate modestly against the dollar during this period as demand for the safe-haven currency decreases, with sterling reaching US$1.46:£1 by end-2025.
Outlook for 2021-25: External sector The coronavirus outbreak caused a sharp fall in global trade as demand declined, travel was disrupted and global supply chains were compromised by national lockdowns. The UK was not exempt from this, with both imports and exports declining sharply in 2020. From 2021 we expect trade to rebound, although this will primarily be the result of a recovery from the 2020 base year, and we expect Brexit to weigh on exports (as well as imports, but to a lesser extent). Most catch-up growth in trade, particularly in exports, will be likely to take place in 2022 as global markets fully unlock and UK firms become more experienced in exporting under new trading rules. The UK has run a persistent current-account deficit since 1985. We expect the deficit to widen from 3.5% of GDP in 2020 to 4.5% of GDP in 2021 as the export sector is weakened by worse terms of trade with the EU, before stabilising thereafter.
