Full text: - The president, Guillermo Lasso of the centre-right Creando Oportunidades (Creo) party, who took office on May 24th, will face a series of policy challenges over his four-year term that are likely to undermine political stability and engender public and political opposition to his government. Initially he will enjoy a period of public support as his government ramps up the rollout of coronavirus vaccines, which will limit political instability However, as his government endeavours to stabilise the public finances, improve the business environment and attract private investment, political and public pushback are likely; the government has a small minority in the unicameral National Assembly, which is dominated by left-of-centre parties. Passing unpopular measures under the auspices of the IMF will also prove difficult for the Lasso administration. Unilateral or poorly communicated measures risk sapping public support for the government and elevating risks of social unrest. Similarly, any sharp policy adjustments risk sparking widespread protests that could undermine political stability and cause the government to reverse its policies.

- Significant improvements in the business environment are likely under a more market-friendly government in the 2021-25 forecast period, particularly regarding official policy towards foreign investment and private enterprise. However, the new business-friendly administration's minority position in Congress will tame its ambitions in some areas, hampering the overall pace of improvement. Structural impediments, such as inadequate access to local finance and Ecuador's small market size, will persist and will prove difficult for the government to tackle.

- Ecuador will recover slowly from the coronavirus-induced recession that pummelled its weak economy in 2020. Domestic demand will be hampered by a lack of fiscal stimulus during the pandemic, as the government lacked the resources to support consumers and businesses. The new government will continue efforts to consolidate the public finances, but the public debt burden will remain high. Dollarisation provides a basis for macroeconomic stability and will help to keep inflation low, but a more robust economic trajectory is unlikely without a significant increase in private-sector investment.

- A falling birth rate is contributing to slower population growth, but at an average rate of 1.2% per year in 2021-25, Ecuador's population growth will be on a par with that of its Andean neighbours. In this period the growth of the labour force will exceed that of the country's overall population and the labour force growth of more advanced countries, giving rise to a demographic dividend that could help it to converge with more developed economies in the region.

- Ecuador is one of the smallest markets in The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings. We expect the domestic market to grow sluggishly after the pandemic-induced recession of 2020. Significant mineral reserves and efforts to improve the investment environment will attract oil and mining investors, but opportunities outside these sectors will continue to be restricted by low purchasing power measured in terms of GDP per head. Persistent income inequality and poverty will hinder robust growth in household consumption.

Ecuador--highlights: Long-term outlook   2021-30 2031-50 2021-50

- Low levels of productivity and a wealth of natural resources offer scope for Ecuador to catch up with more developed countries, provided that policies are implemented to transform its resource wealth into productive investment in other sectors. Ecuador will benefit from dollarisation and incremental improvements to the business environment. However, poor prospects for significant improvements to institutions do not bode well for a more stable economic policy direction. Assuming persistent structural deficiencies and impediments to governability, as well as inconsistent policymaking decisions, we forecast that long-term investment will be lacking and that income levels will continue to trail OECD levels in the long term.

Background: Ecuador restored its presidential democracy in 1979, but its institutions remain fragile. External economic shocks have contributed to the ousting of three presidents by popular protest since 1997. The former president, Lenín Moreno (2017-21), succeeded Rafael Correa (2007-17)-the longest-serving president in Ecuadorean history. In February 2018 a series of constitutional reforms introduced by Mr Moreno (including the reintroduction of a two-term limit for the presidency) were approved by referendum. Although this was a step towards deeper democratisation, social and fiscal challenges will continue to persist under the government of Guillermo Lasso, who took office as president in May 2021.
Political structure: The 2008 constitution increased executive power, but has done little to foster institutional capacity to tackle problems such as a politicised judiciary, powerful business lobbies, and mobilised grassroots and indigenous groups. Although the constitution affords the executive the power to fast-track economic legislation, a fragmented political landscape and the latent threat of sweeping protests severely hinder governability.
Policy issues: Dollarisation has provided macroeconomic stability but exposed Ecuador's underlying lack of competitiveness. Modest oil prices anticipated in the 2021-25 forecast period (relative to the previous decade) have necessitated fiscal adjustments. The Moreno administration secured a three-year IMF agreement-along with other multilateral financing-in March 2019 to meet objectives including putting the public finances on a sustainable trajectory, enhancing national competitiveness and protecting dollarisation. However, the programme was abandoned at the onset of the coronavirus pandemic and was succeeded by a new IMF lending programme that aims to achieve many of the same goals.
Taxation: Taxes have been subject to frequent changes. The main taxes in Ecuador are income tax, levied at rates of up to 35%, and value-added tax (VAT), levied at 12%. Private firms must distribute 15% of their profits among their employees.
Foreign trade: Ecuador recorded a trade surplus of US$3.3bn in 2020; petrol export earnings averaged 26% of total export revenue, compared with over 50% during the commodity boom in the 2000s.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance Ecuador has a multiparty democracy. The president, Guillermo Lasso of the centre-right Creando Oportunidades (Creo), took office in May for a four-year term after winning a run-off election against Andrés Arauz, a left-wing populist protégé of a former president, Rafael Correa (2007-17). No party achieved a majority in the 2021 elections, and Mr Lasso governs with a minority in the unicameral 137-seat National Assembly that is dominated by left-of-centre parties. The largest bloc in the legislature is controlled by the leftist Unión por la Esperanza (UNES), which is the continuation of Mr Correa's political movement; his original electoral vehicle, Alianza País (AP), split in 2018 following a power clash with his presidential successor, Lenín Moreno (2017-21) and won no seats in the current legislature. The second-largest bloc consists of the indigenous Movimiento de Unidad Plurinacional Pachakutik (Pachakutik), which secured its greatest-ever legislative representation in the 2021 elections, and the social-democratic Izquierda Democrática (ID). The conservative Partido Social Cristiano (PSC) joined with Creo to support Mr Lasso's ticket, but they did not formalise a governing coalition. The legislative landscape can be fluid, with legislators sometimes switching allegiances.

Political outlook: Political stability Mr Lasso starts his term in a surprisingly strong position: his high 71.4% approval rating at the beginning of his presidency contrasts sharply with the low 9.3% rating of his predecessor, Lenín Moreno, on leaving office. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the new government to achieve some success in ramping up the rollout of coronavirus vaccines and paving the way for economic normalisation, but the momentum and support that it currently enjoys will be dampened eventually by its weak legislative position and considerable policy challenges.
Governability will be complicated by the need to build consensus across a divided political landscape. Creo holds only 12 seats in the 137-seat National Assembly, which is dominated by left-of-centre parties that control more than 90 seats. The only other major conservative party is the PSC, which has 17 seats. Although an electoral alliance between Creo and the PSC did not translate into a legislative alliance, the PSC is unlikely to be hostile to Mr Lasso's agenda. The new president can also count on 13 legislators outside of Creo and the PSC who have aligned themselves with the government, but he will still have to garner legislative support from ideological opponents such as the alliance of the indigenous Pachakutik party and the centre-left ID, which hold 27 and 18 seats respectively. This implies that he will have to make concessions to these parties to facilitate policymaking, especially as Pachakutik controls the presidency of the National Assembly. Achieving cross-party support from the largest opposition movement, the left-wing UNES which has 49 seats, is unlikely.
Without a legislative majority, Mr Lasso will depend on ad hoc support from other parties to pass key legislation. Even if Creo successfully forms a working majority with other parties at some point, the alliance would have a short shelf-life; Ecuador has little experience with political coalitions, and many voters are suspicious that these kinds of accords will be accompanied by corruption. Furthermore, a diverse coalition would involve parties that have opposing views on tax policy, labour market regulations, social policies, oil and mining permits, the size of the state wage bill, and various other issues. We assume that Mr Lasso will make some policy concessions, but perhaps not enough to secure the long-term viability of any potential governing alliance. Managing the varying demands of diverse parties with a weak legislative position will put additional strain on the government (on top of the economic challenges posed by Covid-19 and limited fiscal space), ultimately risking what little governability can be achieved through ad hoc, cross-party support.
Mr Lasso will have executive tools at his disposal to advance his agenda unilaterally, but the risk of a political and social backlash is likely to limit his ambitions. He will be able to submit bills that eliminate taxes, set trade tariff levels, modify credit and financial policies, and sell or establish concessions for state-owned companies. Mr Lasso is likely to take advantage of the executive powers at his disposal, but he will have to balance his agenda with the public's expectations, given the risk of public and political backlash against policies that are unpopular or badly communicated. Notably, these pressures prevented Mr Lasso from introducing a tax reform on the day that he took office, as he had intended. Just as social unrest forced Mr Moreno to backtrack on changes to the country's fuel subsidy regime in 2019, any sharp policy adjustments will risk social unrest, especially bearing in mind that Mr Lasso garnered just 20% of the vote in the first round of the presidential election and clearly does not have firm public support. All of this affords Mr Lasso little room for manoeuvre on policy. However, given the challenging economic and health backdrop, we believe that there will be a latent risk of social unrest-even in the absence of sharp policy adjustments-throughout Mr Lasso's term in office.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness Politicised institutions, an inefficient bureaucracy, a complex and archaic tax system, and corruption have long undermined institutional effectiveness. Although constitutional amendments in 2008 and 2015 under Mr Correa tilted discretional power in the executive's favour, this did little to improve political effectiveness and also reduced accountability. Political effectiveness continues to be hampered by the fragmented political party system and various groups' ability to effectively veto government policies: since Ecuador became a presidential democracy in 1979, this has manifested itself several times in the form of sweeping protests and coup d'états. Barring a period of relative political stability under Mr Correa (and another brief one under Mr Moreno), no president has had a single-party majority in the legislature, which has weighed on governability. Securing cross-party support has proven difficult, and the country has little experience with political coalitions, as many voters are suspicious that these kinds of accords will be accompanied by corruption.
The Moreno administration made moderate progress in addressing institutional weaknesses. A referendum in 2018 enabled him to restructure the judicial appointment process, introduce term limits for the executive, enact stricter penalties for corruption, move to rationalise real-estate taxation and introduce market-friendly regulations regarding mining investment. Challenges to greater political and institutional effectiveness remain, however; there are bureaucratic inefficiencies, governability is weak, lawmaking is subject to the demands of an array of vested interests, and law enforcement is inadequate. These obstacles are compounded by risks of social unrest. Social groups have the ability to effectively reverse or block implementation of government policy, as demonstrated by indigenous groups' ousting of three presidents prior to Mr Correa's presidency and by widespread unrest in October 2019 that forced the government to operate briefly outside the capital and to reverse its elimination of fuel subsidies.
Deep-rooted institutional shortcomings will remain a hindrance Reforms are required to bolster the intregity of the legal system. The Moreno administration attempted to stop political interference by the judiciary and curb graft, but results have been mixed. Mr Moreno successfully installed a new panel of judges in the Constitutional Court after the previous court was terminated amid a cloud of allegations of wrongdoing; investigations into alleged malfeasance (including money-laundering and other financial crimes) intensified the court's already poor reputational standing stemming from perceptions of favouritism towards the political leadership. Nonetheless, inefficiency and corruption remain deeply rooted in the judicial system. The Council of the Judiciary has shown little progress in handling corruption cases, access to legal protection and law enforcement remains flawed, and effective protection of rights is still lacking.
We expect the Lasso administration to make piecemeal progress in bolstering institutions' capacity to tackle corruption, but significant improvements are unlikely. Anti-corruption initiatives have yielded few tangible results, and some efforts by Mr Moreno were politically complicated given his unpopular position and lack of a majority in the legislature; Mr Lasso will operate with an even smaller legislative presence, hampering any efforts to advance anti-corruption legislation that may be deemed controversial by the opposition. The misuse of funds in public institutions and networks of corruption within the state will be exceedingly difficult to root out.
Political outlook: Election watch Mr Lasso defeated Mr Arauz in the second-round presidential run-off on April 11th. His victory was not a ringing endorsement of him as a conservative candidate, but rather a rejection of the politics and governance style of Mr Arauz's political mentor, Mr Correa, who was president in 2007-17. Indeed, Mr Lasso was helped to the presidency because much of the political spectrum lent him their support to prevent a return of correísmo.
Trends that were evident in the election will remain significant and will influence the public's view of Mr Lasso's government. Specifically, voters want action on environmental protection and human rights (particularly for women), are wary of a government that quashes dissent and attacks its opposition (as Mr Correa's government did), and are not content with the status quo (null votes accounted for 16% of those cast in the second round, more than double the figure in the 2017 run-off election).
Political outlook: International relations Promoting international trade and foreign investment will be among Mr Lasso's policy priorities. In the early days of his administration, Mr Lasso will target a reduction in bureaucratic procedures and a simplification of regulations for exporters, while strengthening ties with commercial partners. We expect that his administration will seek to advance discussions with the US on a free-trade agreement (FTA) and pursue Ecuador's accession to the Pacific Alliance (a regional trade bloc), in addition to seeking agreements with other export markets. As a market-oriented president, Mr Lasso will also bolster ties with multilateral institutions and renegotiate Ecuador's debt with China. Following a deal with the US Development Finance Corporation that will be used to buy back a large chunk of Ecuador's US$5.2bn in Chinese debt, Mr Lasso is likely to maintain the Moreno government's fairly cool diplomatic relations with China. Diplomatic relations with left-leaning regional governments are unlikely to improve under the Lasso administration.

Ecuador scores poorly in The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings for the historical period (2016-20). This reflects the populist policy stance of a former president, Rafael Correa (2007-17), which deterred foreign investment. His successor, Lenín Moreno (2017-21), took a different approach, but changes were only gradual, which explains why the results for the historical period are still weak. Ecuador's score improves markedly in the 2021-25 forecast period, reflecting the impact of changes that Mr Moreno introduced towards the end of his tenure, as well as the explicitly market-friendly stance of the new president, Guillermo Lasso, who took office in May. Cognisant of the dire state of the public finances, Mr Lasso will seek to attract foreign investment as a way of engineering an economic recovery from the recession induced by the coronavirus pandemic, lifting exports and creating jobs. He will also place more emphasis on improving relations with Ecuador's main trading partners through free-trade agreements (FTAs).
New government embraces orthodox economic policymaking In view of these developments, the areas in which Ecuador's business environ-ment improves the most are mostly linked to government policy. The country's global ranking rises sharply for policy towards private enterprise and competition, foreign investment and taxes. Its score for the macroeconomic environment is set to improve only slightly, but its comparative rankings will soar. This reflects the authorities' limited scope for large-scale pandemic-related stimulus last year owing to already pressing debt concerns, which meant that the public finances did not deteriorate as much as in other countries.
This is a positive picture, but there is an unusually high level of uncertainty attached to our forecasts for the business environment, because it remains unclear how much of Mr Lasso's policy agenda will materialise. His centre-right, market-friendly stance is at odds with a significant share of Congress, where he lacks a majority. Our baseline forecast is that Mr Lasso will tread carefully to avoid stoking social unrest, pressing ahead with reforms to improve the business environment and attract investment, but doing so gradually in order to form a consensus behind his proposals. We believe that some progress will be made, but that political necessities will force him to withdraw any measures that the left-wing majority deems unacceptable. Given Ecuador's chequered political history, it is possible that the opposition could block the new president's proposals altogether, which would prompt a significant downgrade to our business environment forecasts.


Enlarge this image.
Business environment outlook: Ecuador's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2021-22: Fuel subsidies are gradually lifted. Implementation of antitrust policies is subject to politicisation. Select industries (such as mining) benefit from policies promoting supply-side growth.
2023-25: Government continues to scale back state's role in development. Nonetheless, regulation and licensing continue to favour state-run companies over private-sector firms. New public-private partnership model is trialled.
Policy towards foreign investment 2021-22: Government makes overtures to foreign firms and passes pro-business reforms in a bid to lift inward investment.
2023-25: Property rights protection improves. Investor concerns about access to foreign arbitration ease.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2021-22: Capital outflows tax begins to be scaled back. Efforts to pursue free-trade agreements (FTAs) accelerate as new government seeks to start talks with major commercial partners.
2023-25: Supply-side reforms enhance national competitiveness. Government lifts capital outflows tax altogether.
Taxes 2021-22: New administration implements measures to expand tax base and improve collection. Certain exemptions are eliminated, and other burdensome regulations are simplified.
2023-25: Efforts to increase tax collection and tackle tax evasion continue, supporting revenue growth. However, tax system remains complex.
Financing 2021-22: Weak deposit and credit growth following economic recession in 2020 caused by coronavirus pandemic.
2023-25: Financing is still below potential, as public-financing needs curb growth of long-term lending to private sector.
The labour market 2021-22: Government takes steps to lower public wage bill and reduce labour market rigidities.
2023-25: Quality of workforce remains poor. Labour reforms are slow to take effect. Educational outcomes remain weak.
Infrastructure 2021-22: Fiscal constraints lead to cancellation of several projects. Efforts to drum up large-scale foreign investment achieve limited success.
2023-25: Renewed interest in port and airport development sustains new cycle of investment.
Technological readiness 2021-22: Investment to expand 4G broadband availability.
2023-25: Increasing adoption of civic technologies by government. 5G technology remains in its infancy.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
7.5 8.0 27 11 3 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Ecuador's score for the macroeconomic environment category-the strongest area of its business environment by some distance-increases in the forecast period, and both its global ranking and regional ranking improve sharply. This may seem unusual given that the country has defaulted on its external debt a number of times (most recently in 2020), but the assessment for the macroeconomic environment is weighted towards underlying fundamentals, for which Ecuador scores comparatively well. Dollarisation keeps inflation low, reduces the risk of periods of sharp currency volatility and reduces (but does not eliminate) the risk of a balance-of-payments crisis. Although the public finances have been a weaker area for some time, financing difficulties prevented the budget deficit from swelling in 2020 (as happened in many other economies). For these governments, the 2021-25 forecast period will be a time of only gradual fiscal retrenchment, and the average budget deficit will be significantly wider than in 2016-20; in contrast, Ecuador's public finances will register a small surplus on average in 2021-25 (making it one of just a handful in the countries in the world where that will be the case). Although public debt has risen in recent years, an improvement in the budget balance will facilitate an easing of the public debt burden over the medium term. Ongoing IMF support is likely to support this process.

- The downside effect of near-term fiscal consolidation will be that GDP recovers more gradually than in other economies, where large-scale stimulus will facilitate a speedier rebound. We expect real GDP to return to pre-pandemic levels only in 2024, which is late by regional and global comparison. Average oil prices will be moderately higher in 2021-25 than in 2016-20 (West Texas Intermediate, a proxy for Ecuadorean oil export prices, is set to average US$63.1/barrel in the forecast period, compared with US$51.1/b in the historical period), but average production levels are likely to be broadly similar. A quicker economic recovery would require higher sustainable rates of growth in non-oil sectors. In turn, this would require greater legal stability and improvements in the regulatory environment, as well as expanded access to foreign markets. Although there will be progress in many of these areas in 2021-25, it will take time for these improvements to filter through to the path of GDP growth.

Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
4.0 5.3 66 52 10 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Ecuador's score and ranking for policy towards private enterprise and competition improve in the 2021-25 forecast period. Our baseline forecast is that, under Mr Lasso, there will be greater private-sector participation in some regulated sectors of the economy, including infrastructure and mining. Nonetheless, a full reversal of state ownership is unlikely, as is a deeper liberalisation of policy towards private enterprise and competition, as Mr Lasso's minority position in Congress will prevent a sharp shift in policy. As a result, monopolies and oligopolies will remain features of Ecuador's business environment, particularly in certain sectors (such as the cement, financial, supermarket and steel industries). Some improvements in efficiency are likely, but high levels of bureaucracy will constrain private investment and competition in 2021-25.
Government continues with gradual withdrawal of fuel subsidies
- Certain goods and services-such as electric power, agricultural chemicals, pharmaceuticals and telephone tariffs-are subject to government price controls. Limited price controls for some basic foodstuffs also exist. Government subsidies for fuel have traditionally proven particularly costly. In 2009-19 these placed a substantial strain on the budget, costing an annual average of US$2.3bn (equivalent to about 7% of spending and two-thirds of the overall fiscal deficit). Mr Moreno made notable progress on scaling back these subsidies, but his efforts were not without challenges. In October 2019 Mr Moreno enacted a sharp and abrupt eradication of fuel subsidies by executive decree. The move triggered intense social unrest in Quito (the capital), forcing the administration to withdraw the reform after just ten days. However, several months later the government revisited efforts to reduce fuel subsidies, and a new regime took effect in July. The authorities now set retail petrol prices monthly, with retailers allowed to sell fuel within 3-5% of this fixed rate. The rate is determined by global prices and has reduced the burden of subsidies on state finances. The gradual reform aims to align retail petrol prices with market prices by the end of 2021, when fuel subsidies will be eliminated altogether. Mr Lasso has indicated that he will keep this system in place. In order to address any public discontent related to the transition, the government plans to use the fiscal savings to expand coverage of social assistance programmes for poor families.

Stance towards private sector will be warmer under Mr Lasso
- Mr Lasso's policy stance is likely to be more welcoming towards private-sector participation in some state companies than was the case under previous administrations. In late May Mr Lasso stated that he was seeking to auction concessions for three refinery projects and a number of new highways. He is also seeking a private-sector concession partner to operate the Corporación Nacional de Telecomunicaciones (CNT, the state telephone company), and the full privatisation of Banco del Pacífico (a state bank) is also under discussion. Although Mr Lasso's more openly pro-market stance makes the policy environment more supportive in this area, we believe that progress will be slow. Mr Moreno pursued similar plans regarding the CNT, and the privatisation of other state assets, including Banco del Pacífico, was also floated in recent years. However, these plans never came to fruition owing to public opposition and weak investor demand (reflecting mismanagement of state-run companies in recent years and a lack of fully audited accounts, which complicates estimates of market value). These factors will hamper Mr Lasso's scope for action.
- The previous government pushed for all major infrastructure projects to be developed with private-sector investment, primarily using public-private partnership (PPP) agreements. However, the uptake of PPPs was weak, partly because of shaky investor confidence related to legal insecurity and partly because of a lack of staff with the necessary resources to promote and support PPP development. Mr Lasso is seeking to lift inward investment via the PPP framework by appointing a special committee tasked with setting out a project pipeline and identifying potential sources of investment partners. A planned reform to the PPP legal framework should speed up the negotiation and approval of projects. The current PPP legislative framework is based on the Regulations for the Public-Private Partnership Regime, the Law of Incentives for PPPs and Foreign Investment, and the General Regulations for the Application of the Framework Law of Incentives for PPPs and Foreign Investment. These were all introduced in 2015-16 and essentially consist of tax breaks-including breaks from import tariffs and value-added tax (VAT) during project construction-as well as a ten-year reprieve from income tax and a reprieve from tax on the repatriation of profits.

Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
4.2 6.0 72 56 10 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Vested interests will resist government efforts to lift foreign investment Ecuador's score for policy towards foreign investment improves firmly in the 2021-25 period, and its position in the global ranking rises from 72nd to 56th. The Moreno government was more willing to engage with foreign investors than its predecessor, which is an approach that will continue (and accelerate) under the newly inaugurated Lasso administration. Broadly speaking, government commitment to crafting policy that gives foreign investors transparency, clarity and predictability will be stronger in 2021-25 than in 2016-20. Despite this expected improvement, policy towards foreign investment remains a relatively low-scoring area for Ecuador. Securing legislative support for deeper structural reforms to improve the country's competitiveness is unlikely given probable opposition from the public and the left-leaning legislature. Powerful domestic vested interests will continue to resist some of the government's reform efforts.

- The state's considerable role in the economy-combined with a preference for domestic over foreign investment and frequent changes to laws-fostered general uncertainty regarding the security of foreign investments and contractual agreements, particularly under Mr Correa. Under Mr Moreno, the promotion of foreign investment became more noticeable, driven in large part by economic expediency. In 2018 legislation came into force that stipulated that disputes over investment agreements must be resolved through arbitration. Even international arbitral decisions are now deemed immediately enforceable in Ecuador, without the need for further approval by domestic courts. Mr Lasso is likely to continue this trend towards assuring a more stable foreign-investment environment and will seek to reassure investors (who are generally still jittery) about judicial security. However, given that foreign investors are often looking for long-term security about the official policy stance, radical shifts in administration in recent years will remain a cause for concern. Even if policy towards foreign investment is more welcoming under Mr Lasso, there remains a risk of reversal under a future administration.
- The World Bank's International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID) has now concluded all of the legal disputes between foreign companies and the government relating to Mr Correa's tenure; some of the proceedings had dragged on for many years, and some cases have only recently been settled. In early June the government confirmed that it would pay Perenco (a British-French oil company) US$374m after the ICSID upheld its ruling on the award in late May. Less than a month into his presidency, Mr Lasso returned Ecuador to the ICSID (Mr Correa withdrew the country in 2010), signalling a shift in the government's willingness to improve the investment environment.

Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
6.4 7.3 59 53 8 7
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Ecuador's underlying score rises moderately in the forecast period, along with its global and regional rankings. Mr Lasso will boost efforts to diversify export markets, join the Pacific Alliance (an integration project that includes Chile, Peru, Colombia and Mexico) and pursue efforts to sign free-trade agreements (FTAs) with Ecuador's main trading partners in North America, Europe and Latin America. Sporadic trade spats with regional partners will be less likely than previously. Trade policies will be open over the forecast period, and we do not expect import and capital-account restrictions to be implemented.
Relations with the US will improve further under Mr Lasso
- Ecuador's trade relationship with the US (its biggest export partner) will continue to improve under Mr Lasso, after Mr Moreno rekindled ties with that country. The weak score in the 2016-20 historical period partly reflects Ecuador's unilateral decision in 2013 to withdraw from the Andean Trade Promotion and Drug Eradication Act (ATPDEA), which granted tariff-free access to the US market for about 6,000 goods. The government failed to secure an alternative trade agreement, forcing many non-traditional sectors (such as cut flowers, fruit and vegetables) to lose competitiveness against other Latin American countries that maintained FTAs with the US. Bilateral ties improved under Mr Moreno, culminating in the signing of an agreement in December 2020 that should lay the groundwork for an eventual FTA between the two countries. The agreement includes provisions to align regulatory oversight, harmonise customs procedures and boost bilateral trade between small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). Mr Lasso is keen to begin negotiations on an FTA, but talks are likely to take some time, as each side and then both sides will need to reach a consensus over thorny issues including market access for agricultural goods, labour standards and environmental policy. Our baseline forecast is that Ecuador will sign an FTA with the US, but later on in the outlook period, with the benefits only felt in the longer term.
- There has been some progress in streamlining customs procedures in order to improve efficiency in recent years, although corruption and drug smuggling via overseas shipments remain a problem. A number of electronic procedures and automation processes have helped to speed up the delivery of goods. Given that tackling corruption is a major focus of both the IMF and the US, Mr Lasso is likely to continue efforts to crack down on corruption, both in terms of public procurement and trade-related embezzlement. In the past frequent changes to customs duties have acted as a major disincentive for legitimate businesses and fuelled contraband trade; there is likely to be a greater focus on stabilising the customs framework in 2021-25.
- The Impuesto a la Salida de Divisas (ISD, a 5% tax on capital outflows) applies to all non-cash, hard-currency transactions of repatriated capital and transfers from banks to external accounts exceeding US$5,000. The Moreno government indicated plans to phase out the tax, but the deterioration of the economy in 2020 halted progress. Mr Lasso has stated that he plans to reduce the ISD gradually over his tenure, eliminating it altogether by the time of the next presidential election, in 2025.

Business environment outlook: Taxes                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
5.3 6.1 62 54 7 4
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Ecuador's score and ranking for taxation improve in the forecast period. In the historical period official tax policy stance was volatile and prone to abrupt changes in legislation to meet short-term financing needs. This fuelled uncertainty and was a major impediment to investment. However, this began to change under the auspices of the Fund, and the Moreno administration passed a tax reform-albeit a watered-down one-in December 2019. The reform was designed to raise revenue, mainly through a 0.2% increase in the income tax rate of companies with annual revenue above US$50m, and through the introduction of income tax on dividends distributed by resident companies to non-resident businesses or individuals. As part of the IMF agreement, Mr Lasso will prioritise efforts to strengthen the tax system, including boosting the powers of the tax administration to combat widespread evasion and abuse of tax avoidance schemes. Over time the Servicio de Rentas Internas (the tax authority) is likely to establish a better reputation in terms of efficiency.
New government will resist IMF calls to raise VAT rate
- At 12%, the VAT rate is more than 5 percentage points below the average rate in South America and 3 percentage points below the average in Latin America and the Caribbean. The Fund has recommended increasing the rate, but Mr Lasso will resist these calls, preferring to try to raise tax collection by cracking down on evasion and widening the tax base. It is even possible that the VAT rate will be cut four times per year for a limited period in order to stimulate retail sales. The Fund is likely to adopt a wait-and-see approach, particularly as higher VAT rates could stoke social unrest (thereby undermining Mr Lasso's political position and potentially jeopardising other policy measures). However, if the new government's efforts to increase revenue collection fail, the Fund could press more forcefully for a hike in rates. There may be other changes to personal income taxes and consumption taxes (including reductions in personal allowances and deductions) in order to lift the tax take later in the forecast period.

Business environment outlook: Financing                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
3.6 5.1 73 69 9 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Ecuador's score for financing in 2021-25 improves noticeably (from a low base), but as similarly ranked countries will also make improvements, its global rank improves more modestly. State intervention in the banking sector was a feature of the business environment in the past but is unlikely to pose a significant risk in 2021-25. Mr Lasso-himself a former banker-will engender greater confidence among commercial banks and their customers, with deposit and credit growth picking up, albeit from a low level. However, many structural problems will continue to complicate corporate access to finance. The banking sector remains underdeveloped compared with the size of the economy; financial services are relatively rudimentary, with a small secondary market and two stock exchanges (in Quito, the capital, and Guayaquil) vying with each other for a limited pool of bond and equity issuances. In this context, financing is-and will remain-dominated by bank loans, with only large companies able to secure the lowest rates, of about 7%. Smaller companies face rates upwards of 12%, with loan maturities often capped at three years. Long-term bank finance and capital market finance remain underdeveloped and difficult to secure.

- An expected weak recovery from the sharp recession in 2020 poses risks to the financial sector that could affect companies' ability to access credit. Financial soundness indicators remain reasonable, but profit ratios are still low (although they have begun to recover), meaning that firms could find it more difficult (or costly) to borrow if banks become more cautious about lending. This risk would be elevated if banks were to experience a run on deposits (the vast majority of which are still held in instant-access accounts). However, assuming an economic recovery, this is unlikely to materialise.
- Confidence in the banking system is tied to the management of reserve requirements at the Banco Central del Ecuador (the central bank), which is central to sustaining dollarisation but has been the target of regulatory changes in the past. However, recent legislation to strengthen the central bank's authority will reduce the risk of more aggressive executive controls on bank deposits (which would weaken commercial bank lending and undermine market confidence more broadly). The recent legislation strengthens central bank autonomy by closing a loophole allowing the funding of the government and by restoring a four-system balance-sheet structure (eliminated in 2008) that facilitates transparency.

Business environment outlook: The labour market                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
4.8 5.4 78 69 12 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Despite some improvement in the underlying score and rankings for 2021-25, Ecuador's labour market will remain one of the weakest areas of its business environment. An increase in spending on education and training programmes during the oil boom years failed to raise skills levels or productivity, with lower oil prices necessitating subsequent cutbacks. Skills shortages and mismatches remain a problem, compounded by a lack of effective training programmes in both the public and private sector. Recent moves to increase flexibility in labour market regulation are a positive sign, as is Mr Lasso's focus on improving the quality of education provision, but the need for fiscal adjustment will cap public investment in these areas, meaning that long-running and structural problems (such as skills shortages) are likely to persist. Access to social security has improved for some sectors of the population, but the labour market remains highly informal, which will be difficult to tackle. Mr Lasso hopes that increased private-sector investment will boost formal job creation, but we do not expect investment to rise enough to have a meaningful impact on reducing labour market informality until towards the end of the forecast period (if at all). In comparative terms, labour costs will edge down slightly in 2021-25 but will remain high, particularly relative to productivity.

- The Moreno government sought to table a reform bill to increase labour market flexibility and promote job creation, but its plans were pushed back as negotiations between the authorities and unions and pressure groups dragged on. However, the government incorporated most of the planned changes into a broader "humanitarian support" law that was passed by emergency decree in May 2020 in response to the coronavirus outbreak. The changes make it easier to renegotiate labour contracts between employers and employees. Both sides can agree to salary reductions to avoid lay-offs and can negotiate changes in the number of working hours (and how these are spread, allowing employees more flexibility), with social security obligations and benefits adjusted accordingly. The initial limit for this flexibility in contracts is two years, but contracts can be renewed annually for two more years.

Mild US dollar depreciation will not boost competitiveness much
- The strength of the US dollar will compound competitiveness problems in the short term (Ecuador's minimum wage is among the highest in Latin America in dollar terms, although its productivity lags that of most of its neighbours). We expect that some mild depreciation of the US dollar during 2021-25 will be insufficient to boost competitiveness significantly.

Raising educational outcomes will be a slow and difficult process
- The new president is seeking to expand access to education (by reopening 900 schools that were shut in rural areas in 2013-16), improve the quality of education provision (by increasing training opportunities), and boost digital skills (by investing in computer equipment). He is also planning to reform the admissions system for higher education to make the process more equitable and to give universities more autonomy. However, efforts to improve education will progress only slowly, owing to the government's difficult fiscal position, which will preclude any significant increase in public spending. Structural problems in the education system will be difficult to rectify. Although net secondary school enrolment has risen in recent years, student results still trail those of other countries in the region. Raising standards will require a sustained and long-term commitment from the government; even assuming that the quality of education policies improves, student results are unlikely to pick up until the end of our 2021-25 forecast period.

Business environment outlook: Infrastructure                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
4.3 5.3 63 62 5 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Infrastructure was one of the stronger areas of Ecuador's business environment in the historical period. Although some improvements in 2021-25 are likely, these will be moderate (reflecting fiscal constraints), so Ecuador's global ranking improves only marginally, and faster progress by other Latin American countries pushes Ecuador's regional ranking down slightly. A large public investment programme put in place by Mr Correa means that, following decades of underinvestment (and frequent electricity shortages), the quality of transport, energy and road infrastructure is now comparable with the Latin American median, and telecoms development (measured by mobile and internet penetration) is above the regional average. However, given the need for fiscal consolidation, government efforts to modernise infrastructure will be reined in. The authorities will seek to attract private investment for infra-structure projects, but Ecuador lacks the solid track record of fostering successful PPPs that have helped to upgrade infrastructure in other countries in the region. Some progress is likely, but it will not lead to a material improvement in this area of the business environment.

- A major focus of infrastructure investment has been the development of new hydroelectric power plants to avoid importing costly energy for gas-fired and thermoelectric plants. In the medium term, there is potential to expand energy exports. However, there are valid concerns that hydroelectric plants will fail to reach expected generation levels owing to design issues, potentially misleading estimates about power generation and debt service, which could lead to supply bottlenecks and the need to import electricity.
- Recent investment has led to road infrastructure improvements and the creation of new road networks. This should help to boost domestic and intraregional trade, but it will also create challenges including congestion, as advances in traffic management have been more limited. Moreover, seasonal heavy rains that are costly and difficult to mitigate continue to cause seasonal disruption in some areas. There has been much slower progress on developing mass transport systems to relieve urban congestion, including an underground rail system in Quito that began construction in 2012 but has been repeatedly delayed (and is now likely to open in 2022) and a tram project in Cuenca (the third-largest city), which was delayed but finally began operating in mid-2020.

Business environment outlook: Technological readiness                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
3.0 3.5 76 74 12 11
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Although Ecuador's score for technological readiness increases in 2021-25, it does so only marginally, and its global and regional rankings remain weak. Its global ranking of 74th makes this area the weakest of the business environ-ment, reflecting low smartphone penetration and a lack of spending on research and innovation, which undermine the overall score. However, Ecuador scores relatively well for preparedness for e-commerce and cyber-security.
Internet access and penetration will improve over the forecast period
- The Lasso administration will seek to accelerate efforts to expand the telecoms and information technology sectors. Internet access through mobile phones will drive wider mobile-phone usage during the outlook period as handsets and data tariffs become more affordable and mobile phones are used increasingly in place of personal computers (PCs). We expect data services to be the fastest-growing segment of the mobile market. However, coverage remains inadequate and costs are high, limiting access. Despite efforts to improve competition in the mobile market, a complicated regulatory environment for foreign companies will remain impediments. Internet penetration, particularly of broadband, has been limited, but we expect it to grow over the forecast period as technology becomes more widely available and connectivity improves. The number of overall internet subscriptions will continue to grow.
- The expansion of 4G technology has been relatively slow, even by regional standards. The Correa government imposed high costs on new contracts for mobile-telephony firms in 2008, which slowed rollout as companies worked to recover costs. Smartphone adoption was relatively late, reflecting low income levels and high tariffs on imported handsets (classified as luxury goods under Mr Correa). In July 2019 the Moreno government launched its Ecuador Digital programme, which aimed to increase penetration indicators (particularly in rural areas), improve internet speeds, expand 4G broadband and accelerate the allocation of new telecoms bandwidth, with a view to beginning 5G testing. The Lasso government will continue these efforts, offering incentives for the private sector to boost 4G coverage more rapidly. It is likely to roll out a spectrum allocation plan, with a view to auctioning 5G bands.

E-commerce will grow owing to rising internal penetration and Covid-19
- Rising internet penetration and smartphone usage will foster growth in online retail, albeit from a low base. According to the Cámara Ecuatoriana de Comercio Electrónico (CECE, the e-commerce chamber), e-commerce generated US$2.3bn in sales in 2020, up by about 44% year on year, as coronavirus-related shop closures saw demand for e-commerce soar. In 2021 CECE anticipates sales growth of at least 10% as more people become regular e-commerce customers.

Economic forecast: Policy trends The government, led by Guillermo Lasso, will pursue an orthodox macroeconomic policy agenda. However quickly the new president would like to address the structural shortcomings in Ecuador's business and investment environment, he will first need to make tangible progress on ramping up the country's Covid-19 vaccination programme. He has set a target of vaccinating 9m people (60% of the population) within his first 100 days of office (by early September). This is likely to prove too optimistic given the delivery and distribution challenges that the outgoing government encountered, but the rollout should still speed up following the procurement of 6m single-dose vaccines produced by Sinovac (China), which will give Mr Lasso's government early momentum. As at June 20th 7% of the population had been fully vaccinated; given that only 6.1% had had one dose as at June 15th, this represents a clear acceleration.
In parallel to his push on the vaccination front, Mr Lasso will pursue his campaign pledges to promote investment and create employment. Initially, he will try to reduce taxes and simplify the tax regime. Over his four-year term he will also seek to reduce trade barriers, ease labour market rigidities, modify financial regulations (partly to attract more international banks) and stabilise the public finances. In 2022 Mr Lasso may well pursue a substantial 25% rise in the minimum wage as part of a campaign pledge. He is also likely to offer oil contracts (using enhanced production-sharing agreements) and state-owned assets through a concessionary programme (including the Esmeraldas oil refinery and the Sacha oilfield) to boost state revenue, as he is not inclined to raise taxes.
The Economist Intelligence Unit's economic forecasts assume that Mr Lasso will achieve only modest success in his policy agenda. Some areas of his agenda that do not require legislative approval (such as lowering trade barriers) stand a good chance of materialising during his term, but we expect the government's weak legislative position to complicate progress on liberalising economic reforms that do require legislative support (such as labour reform). Mr Lasso is likely to exercise his ability to submit fast-track economic legislation (if the National Assembly does not approve or reject a bill submitted as fast-track legislation, the bill goes into effect automatically after 30 days) in an effort to make speedy progress on his agenda. However, given his party's weak position in the National Assembly, the leftist parties that dominate the legislature could amass enough support to reject bills that they deem incompatible with their views. Although ad hoc support garnered through policy concessions is likely to reduce obstacles to some facets of his liberalising agenda, Mr Lasso will still have to tread carefully (and moderate his ambitions) to maintain support from other parties.
The new president's view on tax increases puts him at odds with the IMF's recommendation to the former government to raise the value-added tax (VAT), but he is nonetheless likely to maintain a good relationship with the Fund. He is committed to the overarching objectives of the former government's front-loaded, US$6.5bn, 27-month extended fund facility (EFF) agreement signed in September 2020: putting the public finances on a stable trajectory; improving fiscal transparency; and strengthening the independence of the Banco Central del Ecuador (BCE, the central bank). His economic team is likely to seek a recalibration of how the government shores up the public finances and bolsters dollarisation, but communication has so far been positive. The Fund disbursed US$4bn in October-December 2020 and is likely to disburse another US$800m in the second half of 2021, after legislation to strengthen the autonomy and governance framework of the BCE was approved in April.
Governability challenges will give rise to sustained programme implementation risks, especially owing to the lack of popular support for continued austerity measures. Nonetheless, we anticipate that strong communication between the Lasso government and the Fund-coupled with Mr Lasso's policy objectives-will result in continued multilateral support. We do not expect a subsequent lending arrangement to follow the current EFF programme (which ends in December 2022), but we do not discount the possibility of this occurring, especially in the event of policy slippage.
Economic forecast: Fiscal policy Fiscal indicators
(% of GDP)
  2020 2021 2022 2023 2024 2025
Government revenue 30.3 31.4 32.9 33.8 34.4 34.8
Government expenditure 35.9 34.1 33.2 32.8 32.8 33.0
Budget balance -5.6 -2.7 -0.4 1.0 1.6 1.8
Over the course of his four-year term Mr Lasso will work to restore health to the public finances after years of sustained fiscal deficits. The president will be reluctant to raise taxes and will seek to boost fiscal revenue through enhanced collection and concessions of state assets, including refineries and the state-owned telecommunications company.
Notwithstanding substantial implementation risks to the government's EFF programme, we forecast that the non-financial public-sector (NFPS) deficit will narrow to 2.7% of GDP in 2021, from an estimated 5.6% of GDP in 2020. We expect that the reduction will be driven primarily by an increase in revenue, supported by a recovery in economic activity and firmer oil prices. Contained spending-partly due to reduced debt-servicing costs stemming from significant debt relief secured by restructuring of the government's US$17.4bn in bonded external debt in 2020-will also contribute to a narrower deficit. However, despite efforts to reduce the NFPS deficit, public debt as a percentage of GDP will rise from an estimated 63.9% in 2020 to 66.2% in 2021.
Although Mr Lasso is seeking a recalibration of targets with the Fund, our medium-term forecasts assume that the overarching policy objectives and fiscal targets will not change significantly. As such, we assume that the fiscal balance will shift into surplus by 2023 and that the public debt/GDP ratio will fall over the medium term as contained spending and an increase in revenue (on the back of a firmer economic recovery) help the government to achieve primary surpluses.

Economic forecast: Monetary policy Interest rates
(%)
  2020 2021 2022 2023 2024 2025
Lending rate (av) 8.9 8.3 8.0 8.2 8.3 8.5
Deposit rate (av) 6.3 5.5 5.4 5.1 5.0 4.9
As a dollarised economy, Ecuador lacks independent monetary policy and will be unable to generate a strong monetary policy response to support the economic recovery. Monetary conditions will continue to be determined largely by external factors, but real local rates remain elevated-real lending rates will \fall only slightly in 2021 after rising in 2020-partly owing to Ecuador's high risk premium. Against the backdrop of a slow recovery from the pandemic-induced crisis, weak confidence among domestic lenders and tepid inflows of foreign capital will hinder monetary growth. Our forecasts assume policy continuity under the auspices of the Fund, which will reduce the threat of de-dollarisation: Mr Lasso's economic policy agenda is unlikely to undermine the currency regime. Crucially, we do not expect the central bank to use international reserves to finance government spending, a policy that would threaten monetary and financial stability.

We expect real GDP to recover only modestly in 2021, expanding by just 2%, reflecting weak sequential growth over the year, as well as negative base effects (subdued growth in the fourth quarter of 2020 produced a mildly negative statistical carryover effect). A recovery in private consumption will be restrained by a lack of fiscal support for consumers amid the Covid-19 crisis and a slow improvement in labour market conditions.
Considering the scale of last year's collapse in investment, the recovery in 2021 will be extremely weak, with economic and political uncertainties dampening economic activity in the election-dominated first half of the year. Sequential economic growth in the second half of the year will be buoyed by stronger performance in major export markets and an easing of coronavirus restrictions; we forecast that investment will begin a firmer recovery in the second half of the year as election-related risks ebb. Nonetheless, the recovery beyond 2021 will be weak; even assuming modest improvements to the business environment under the auspices of the Fund, we do not expect real GDP to return to 2019 levels until 2024-making Ecuador a laggard in the region and globally.t
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends Notwithstanding efforts by the Lasso administration to diversify the economy, the oil sector will remain critically important to Ecuador. Oil export earnings collapsed in 2020 as prices tumbled, but typically account for about 40% of total export revenue and 20% of government revenue; global oil prices will be firmer in the forecast period than in 2020 (supported by the strengthening global economic recovery in 2021-22), meaning that revenue will return to pre-crisis levels. However, oil production will remain below ambitious government targets. On the campaign trail, Mr Lasso floated the lofty goal espoused by his predecessor of achieving 700,000 barrels/day, from about 500,000 b/d at present. One objective tied to this production target is improving the governance and transparency of Petroecuador (the state-owned oil firm, which recently merged with Petroamazonas, another state-owned oil firm), which accounts for about 80% of national production. Mr Lasso is likely to achieve modest success in lifting production by adapting the framework for production-sharing agreements (respecting existing contracts) to make it more attractive for private-sector players to invest. However, delays and pressure from environmental and social groups will temper production ambitions. At the same time, tangible progress on improving the management of the state oil firm is likely to be slow, partly because of administrative hitches arising from the merger.
Growth in the oil sector will come primarily from increased production at the 1.6bn-barrel, heavy crude Ishpingo-Tambococha-Tiputini (ITT) oilfield. The merger of Petroecuador and Petroamazonas is likely to enable the further development of the ITT oilfield, as there were previously disagreements between the firms pertaining to pipeline infrastructure. A factor that will slow progress, however, is that Mr Lasso has sought to assuage environmental concerns about his production ambitions by backing an audit of oil operations in the Yasuní national park, where the oilfield is located. He has also supported the use of environmental impact assessments as a way of improving transparency. Although this may help to improve compliance and valuations, it is likely to preclude a faster expansion of production.
Mining sector enters growth phase, but obstacles persist The mining sector will continue to gain prominence over the medium term. It will become increasingly important for the state finances and is poised to expand, as two major mining projects driven by foreign investors came online in late 2019: Fruta del Norte (a gold mine) and Mirador (primarily a copper mine). At the beginning of 2021 the government projected that Fruta del Norte had generated nearly US$322m in export earnings in 2020 (up from US$46m in 2019) and Mirador about US$239m. Earnings will rise over the medium term: export revenue from the Fruta del Norte mine is projected to reach US$998m in 2025, and the government estimates that the Mirador mine's export earnings will top US$1.1bn in the same year. The sector will continue to expand (buoyed by the removal in 2019 of a 70% "windfall tax" on mining profits) as a series of further projects attract major mining companies that compete for stakes.
The new government will attempt to balance its efforts to boost investment in the mining sector with the need to address environmental and social opposition to new projects. Lingering legal uncertainties and local resistance will persist, underscored by a February referendum in which voters in Cuenca (Ecuador's third-largest city) overwhelmingly chose to prohibit large-scale mining in groundwater recharge zones of five local rivers. Friction between local communities and mining firms is likely to slow investment, even as the Lasso administration attempts to design a framework that encourages private-sector participation in the sector. Many mineral deposits are located in environmentally sensitive areas, close to communities that have lodged complaints with local courts alleging that mining firms have failed to undergo consultation processes. That said, a lack of cohesion among anti-mining activists and differences in opinion within Ecuador make the imminent cancellation of major mining projects currently under construction and under advanced exploration unlikely. Our view is that the mining sector will continue to face difficulties that will prevent a more dramatic rise in extractive production.

Deflation took hold in Ecuador in late 2020, ending the year at -0.9%; we expect inflation to return in 2021, but consumer prices pressures will be extremely weak. We forecast that inflation will end the year at just 0.4%, reflecting a weak recovery in domestic demand. We expect inflation to be contained in 2022-25, averaging 0.6%. Dollarisation will play a major role in containing inflation, but the economy will remain vulnerable to food and energy price shocks.

We expect dollarisation to be maintained throughout the 2021-25 forecast period. De-dollarisation remains an unlikely political move, given high levels of support for the exchange regime, on the basis that it promotes macroeconomic stability. Under Mr Lasso, we expect the government to remain committed to restoring health to the public finances, building up reserves and adopting policies to strengthen the BCE's independence. Multilateral and bilateral financing will help to assuage concerns about financing and liquidity amid limited access to international capital markets.

We are cautiously optimistic about the health of Ecuador's external accounts; we expect the current account to remain in surplus and to average 1.3% of GDP in 2021-25, owing to two main factors. First, we expect an expansion of non-oil export earnings (as external demand recovers and mining exports gain momentum) and oil export revenue (as global prices rise) to drive a trade surplus throughout 2021-25. Secondly, the sovereign's recent debt restructuring entails a significant decline in interest payments in the medium term, which will keep the primary income deficit narrower than before the pandemic.
Current-account surpluses and multilateral financing (particularly from the Fund) will help the BCE to bolster foreign-exchange reserves, cushioning potential adverse fiscal and financial shocks. Notwithstanding Mr Lasso's plans to bolster investment, we remain sceptical that this will materialise quickly and expect foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows to remain weak in 2021-25, at an average of about 1% of GDP, and concentrated in extractive industries.


Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Ecuador Stocks and flows Ecuador has historically attracted little foreign direct investment (FDI). Annual inflows of FDI averaged US$700m in 1994-2008, driven mainly by the oil sector (which accounted for 80% of the total). After barely breaching US$1bn (1.8% of GDP) in 2008, FDI inflows fell to only US$165m in 2010. They recovered to average US$774m (0.8% of GDP) in 2011-17, during the presidency of Rafael Correa (2007-17), whose policies led to a deterioration in investor confidence. FDI inflows improved at the margin under his successor, Lenín Moreno (2017-21), reflecting a more conciliatory approach to the private sector, but inflows remained low, averaging 1% of GDP during his term. Given that FDI inflows were already quite weak before the Covid-19 crisis, there was less of a discernible affect on FDI in Ecuador than in other countries; inflows reached US$1bn (1% of GDP) in 2020. The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that the total stock of inward FDI was US$20.6bn at end-2020. This is one of the smallest stocks among the major Latin American economies, equating to 20.9% of GDP. The outlook for FDI is brighter in the 2021-25 forecast period than in the 2016-20 historical period, owing to the new government's openness to foreign investment, but a weak business environment and investor wariness about the direction of policy under future administrations will dampen inflows.
Origin and distribution US firms (historically Ecuador's main source of FDI) went through a period of disinvestment in the country in 2008-10, largely owing to uncertainty surrounding oil contract renegotiations and the global financial crisis. Investment from the US has since moderated, averaging 7% of total inflows in 2016-20. FDI from China rose after Ecuador established closer trade and diplomatic ties with that country in 2011, but inflows have tapered off recently. In 2020 Chinese FDI accounted for 6% of inflows, down from 11% in 2016. Foreign investment is primarily directed towards oil, mining and infrastructure projects, as reflected by the origin of inflows; in 2020, 29% of foreign investment originated from Canada (the major Fruta del Norte gold mine is owned by a Canadian firm). The manufacturing, agri- and aqua-culture, and retail sectors attract foreign investment, but extractive industries account for the majority, attracting about 50% of FDI inflows in 2018-20.
Determinants Although Ecuador has a wealth of natural resources, policy uncertainty and an unreliable business environment have deterred investment. The Moreno administration took a more active role than its predecessor in attracting private foreign investment; his government focused on fomenting investment in the extractive sectors, reintroducing production-sharing contracts and eliminating the 70% "windfall tax" on profits in mining. However, stronger interest from foreign investors did not materialise, as the uncertain regulatory and legal environment tempered his administration's efforts to boost foreign investment. Moreover, weak institutions, a small domestic market, a relatively high cost of labour and low income levels still deter market-seeking or efficiency-seeking investments. Investments are likely to remain largely resource-seeking given Ecuador's natural resource endowment, even assuming moderate improvements to the business environment.
Impact The impact of inward FDI on productivity and export competitiveness has been limited because most investment has been directed towards capital-intensive natural resource sectors, which have weak links to the rest of the economy. However, FDI has helped to boost export earnings in the energy sector and to create indirect employment.
Potential The country's strong endowments of natural resources will be a major source of attraction for foreign investors. There are notable FDI opportunities in Ecuador's petroleum, mining, manufacturing and services sectors. Although policy uncertainty, infrastructure deficiencies and low levels of labour productivity persist, we expect incremental improvements to the business environment under the auspices of the IMF, improving the country's competitiveness. A more pragmatic approach to attracting private foreign capital and a continuing shift away from the unorthodox macroeconomic policies of Mr Correa's government will also provide upside to the country's medium-term attractiveness. Still, ingrained opposition from powerful domestic interest groups, as well as opposition from social groups, will continue to complicate efforts to open up investment opportunities in the oil sector. Sluggishness in consumption and a tepid recovery after the pandemic in 2020 will also deter investment.

Population growth is slowing In 2020 the population reached an estimated 17.5m and is expected to rise by 1.1m people by 2024. Given a falling birth rate and continued-albeit lower-emigration, the rate of population growth is slowing. However, at an annual average of 1.2% per year in the 2021-25 forecast period, growth will be high compared with developed-country standards and on a par with neighbours in the Andean region. The rate of urbanisation is relatively high; about 64% of the population lives in urban centres, compared with 55% in 1990. This percentage is likely to rise to about 65% by the end of the forecast period. Almost half of city dwellers reside either in the capital, Quito, or in the largest city and main business centre, Guayaquil. Rapid urbanisation over the past 50 years has increased the level of informality, as the creation of full-time jobs has risen much more slowly. The unemployment rate was 5.5% at the end of the first quarter of 2021, which is high by recent standards (the unemployment rate averaged 4.5% in 2015-19), but it was down from a peak of 13.3% in the second quarter of 2020 that came amid the near shutdown of the economy amid the initial coronavirus outbreak. Underemployment remains high, affecting more than half of the workforce. The labour force is expected to continue to expand more rapidly than the overall population during the forecast period, with about 600,000 new labour market entrants by 2025. Notwithstanding efforts by the new government to boost the creation of formal jobs, the formal economy will continue to struggle to absorb new entrants, particularly as diversification away from the energy-dominant labour market will be slow (and will focus primarily on mining and agriculture). Informal employment, estimated by the government at 47% of the labour force as at March, is therefore likely to stay high.
Immigration from Venezuela poses challenges Although inflows of illegal migrants from Colombia have fallen in recent years, inflows from Venezuela will put strain on the domestic labour market. Ecuador has received more than 400,000 migrants from Venezuela, and the government has struggled to integrate them into the formal market, especially in the wake of the coronavirus-induced recession. The slow economic recovery may well lead to weaker Venezuelan migration in the 2021-25 forecast period, with Venezuelans attracted to stronger neighbouring economies. However, the Lasso government is regularising Venezuelan migrants and is likely to try to formulate a strategy to improve their integration into the labour market.
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects Ecuador's crude birth rate to fall to an annual average of 19 per 1,000 population in 2021-25 (down from 20.3 in the 2016-20 historical period). The crude death rate will remain steady, at an annual average of 5.2 per 1,000 population in 2021-25. The old-age dependency ratio, which will rise slightly, reaching 0.14 by 2025, will remain low by developed-country standards. However, given constraints on public spending, an ageing population will place growing pressure on an already heavily indebted social security system, especially as the coronavirus pandemic has laid bare the many deficiencies in the healthcare system. Although the government plans to reduce its divestments from the state-run social security institute, we expect the state-run social security system to encounter difficulties in ending its debt woes.
Slow progress in improving education and healthcare standards The precarious state of the country's public finances will hinder improvements in education and healthcare standards. Strong oil revenue in the 2000s commodity boom allowed for improvements in poverty levels and social indicators following decades of underinvestment in these areas-public expenditure on health services and education doubled as a percentage of GDP under the previous administration. However, low standards and outcomes persist. Some gains were lost because of the 2015-16 recession; losses are also likely to occur in the wake of the Covid-19 crisis, as out-of-school learning has been limited during the pandemic. Regular labour conflicts with public healthcare and education workers, often resulting in industrial action, further hampered improvements in the quality of services. The 2008 constitution promised free universal healthcare and education, but the government will struggle to achieve these goals during the forecast period given its fiscal difficulties in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic. Improvements in education and healthcare standards will be only gradual, with progress crippled by narrow opportunities to raise spending in these areas.
