Ecuador is one of the smallest markets included in The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings, accounting for about 0.1% of global GDP and a similar share of global exports. Its oil and mineral reserves will continue to attract interest from foreign investors. The policy stance of the government led by the president, Guillermo Lasso, will encourage interest in the country, but questions about policy predictability and the government's ability to effect material improvements in the business environment are likely to preclude a sharp increase in private investment.
Market will expand modestly after coronavirus recession Boosted by a rising population but hindered by anaemic economic growth, as well as a dearth of fiscal support measures during the Covid-19 crisis, Ecuador's market size will expand modestly in the 2021-25 forecast period. GDP per head, estimated at US$6,261 in 2019, fell sharply in 2020, to US$5,643, and is forecast to reach only US$6,178 in 2025. This slow recovery in GDP per head will restrict business opportunities. Moreover, Ecuador's per-head income figures will continue to disguise wide inequalities. Despite a rise in consumption after the crisis in 2020, we expect reductions in income inequality to be marginal at best in 2021-25, as rates of unemployment-and in particular underemployment-will decrease only moderately in the wake of the crisis.
The government of a former president, Rafael Correa (2007-17), invested the proceeds of the oil price boom in upgrading the country's underdeveloped infrastructure. Substantial improvements were made in this period, particularly to the road system, but significant gaps remain. His successor, Lenín Moreno (2017-21) was unable to do the same given the need for fiscal adjustment, and attempted to attract private investors to invest in infrastructure, but with limited success. The new Lasso administration will endeavour to close infrastructure gaps by improving the legal framework to provide a moderate boost for investment (domestic and foreign), notably in the export-oriented energy and mining sectors, and related services. However, despite a strong natural resource endowment, growth in exports will remain below potential, and Ecuador's share of world exports will stagnate at about 0.1%.
As a result of dollarisation and successive years of guaranteeing a "living wage" (essentially a minimum wage), Ecuador is no longer a cheap-labour investment location. In US dollar terms, the country's minimum wage is one of the highest in Latin America. Also weighing on the country's competitiveness are low skills levels. However, dollarisation facilitates greater overall macroeconomic stability for businesses to assess investment opportunities, particularly by reducing inflation and exchange-rate risks. Investment in most areas outside the oil sector will be slow to arrive, as improvements to the business environment will be incremental, given political hurdles amid a highly fragmented political landscape. At the same time, advancements in the transparency and efficiency of the judicial system will be slow to take effect.

Business opportunities limited by low level of development As disposable incomes only rise gradually in the wake of the Covid-19 crisis, a shift in consumer attitudes towards cheaper brands and lower-cost, high-volume outlets is likely in the near term. Over the medium to long term, we expect purchasing power to pick up from a trough in 2020 as labour market conditions improve. As incomes rise, a smaller proportion of real disposable income will be spent on food and housing, shifting instead to consumer durables and other high-ticket items. The proportion of income spent on leisure and education, hotels and restaurants, and other high-end goods will remain low. Ecuador's market will remain comparatively small. Dollarisation will provide price and exchange-rate stability, but economic development will be slow, hindered by a dearth of fiscal support measures for consumers and businesses that will do permanent damage to household incomes and businesses' balance sheets.

Ample scope for catch-up but challenges persist Ecuador's wealth of natural resources, a young and expanding middle class and a push to improve educational standards offer scope to catch up with more developed countries over the next four decades. However, a series of challenges need to be addressed over the short and medium term to build on these positive conditions. Although the investment rate has improved considerably, investment remains overly reliant on public-sector spending, which is vulnerable to changes in commodity prices. Private investment is scant and overall savings are low, two factors that are likely to improve only moderately in the coming years, holding down productivity growth. Despite a more stable policy framework, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects that Ecuador's institutions will strengthen only moderately and that progress in tackling a large informal sector will be limited. Nevertheless, higher spending on health and education should help to improve labour productivity growth in 2031-50. In this context-and barring a sharp and prolonged deterioration in the country's terms of trade or a return to severe political instability-we expect the economy to expand more robustly in 2031-50 (by an annual average of 2.2%), following tepid GDP growth in the wake of the Covid-19 crisis (averaging 0.7% in 2021-30).
Initial conditions: Rapid urbanisation in the past 30 years and faster integration into the world economy have produced few long-term benefits for the population. Political instability, weak institutions and high levels of poverty and inequality-combined with an economy overly dependent on oil-have yielded a rent-seeking and unproductive economy, plagued by low education levels and productivity, and high labour informality. The government of Rafael Correa (2007-17) made efforts to address low social indicators and improve infrastructure, but failed to boost private investment and savings. The Correa government also harmed the legal framework for investment by constantly changing regulations and putting up hurdles to capital. Although dollarisation has brought macroeconomic stability since 2000, it has also made Ecuador less competitive and has accentuated the risks of inadequate fiscal management.
Demographic trends: Population growth is set to fall gradually over the long term, from an average of 1.2% in 2020-30, to 0.8% in 2031-50. The main cause will be lower fertility rates, in addition to some net migration. On the upside, we project that the growth of the working-age population will continue to outstrip overall population growth until 2040, providing a major demographic boom and keeping the dependency ratio low. The main challenge facing the country will be to create enough formal jobs for entrants to the labour market, so as to reduce informality. There has been some progress in expanding education across all levels to improve labour quality, but the lack of dynamism in the private sector means that there is a substantial risk of labour informality remaining high in the long term. An additional challenge is to tackle the pension needs of an ageing population, which could increase strains on the country's vulnerable social security system.
External conditions: As a small, open economy, Ecuador has benefited from rising global trade, although it remains vulnerable to changes in commodity prices. This in turn causes significant external and fiscal volatility, as demonstrated by the coronavirus crisis. Inconsistent trade policies and long geographical distances will dampen the potential for stronger integration with industrialised nations or blocs like the US and EU (traditionally Ecuador's main trade partners). There is scope for rising trade integration with neighbouring countries, but progress will be hindered by a lack of supply-chain strategies and infrastructure constraints. There has been some success in export diversification towards the Middle East, Russia and Asia, but Ecuador's small and distant market will act as a drag on its competitiveness profile, particularly compared with Asian emerging markets. With the economy likely to remain heavily reliant on hydrocarbons and some mineral and agricultural products, the external sector and GDP growth will hinge on the direction of terms of trade.
Future governments will struggle with a weak institutional framework Institutions and policy trends: Ecuador's institutions have long suffered from periods of instability, and despite a growing sense of macroeconomic and political stability in the past couple of years, they remain fundamentally weak. Inconsistent policymaking remains a major problem, both in conceiving and implementing new legislation. Successive administrations have changed policy directions. The current government, under Guillermo Lasso, will struggle owing to a weak legislative position and its lack of sustained support from a clear majority of the population; future governments will also find these issues difficult to overcome. Although power is concentrated in the hands of the executive, a highly fragmented political and social landscape will complicate governability. In the short term, this will be tangible as the government endeavours to restore health to the public finances after fiscal profligacy under the Correa administration. Regardless of their ideological inclination, future governments will continue to struggle with a weak legal framework, corruption and distorted policy priorities that either favour special interest groups or act as a major drag on the public finances.
Dollarisation will be protected by its persistent popularity Dollarisation: The policy of dollarisation will be retained, as it garners wide support for delivering price and exchange-rate stability. Moreover, the costs of abandonment-in particular the fear of stoking social unrest-are high. Despite risks to the currency regime posed by fiscal adjustment challenges, we expect commitment to an IMF-backed economic programme to strengthen the foundations of dollarisation; since 2019, under the auspices of the Fund, the government has approved legislation to bolster the country's medium-term fiscal framework and has strengthened the independence of the central bank. Continued IMF support augurs a more sustainable fiscal trajectory that is congruent with a fully dollarised economy. We are cautiously optimistic that, although reform progress will be complicated by sizeable barriers to governability, the long-term sustainability of dollarisation will be reinforced and that Ecuador's fiscal stance will be more stable.
Long-term performance: Unattractive investment conditions and the lack of a competitive, skilled labour force will make Ecuador a relatively unappealing destination for foreign investment in labour-intensive or manufacturing activities. However, sustained improvements in education levels, topped with productive investment in non-oil sectors and technology transfer, could make Ecuador more competitive and boost long-term growth. For this to occur, the country would need to strengthen its institutional framework and improve its business environment. Although the Lasso administration will pursue policies that strengthen private-led growth, our forecast suggests that the advancement of structural reforms will be slow and insufficient for Ecuador to catch up income-wise, with OECD countries in the long term.

Long-term outlook: Long-term trends The country is prone to earthquakes and will therefore continue to suffer from natural disaster risk, but its adaptation and readiness will improve following a particularly devastating earthquake in 2016. Climate change preparedness, however, is more lacking. Ecuador's geographical location and diversity render it particularly vulnerable to the effects of climate change. Owing to the near constant temperature year-round, rising temperatures have threatened the development of glaciers, as they have not been able to replenish lost density during colder seasons. Indeed, Ecuador has experienced a significant reduction in the size of its glaciers in the two main mountain ranges-the Cordillera Oriental and the Cordillera Occidental-which in aggregate have been reduced by about a third over the past 50 years. By 2050 this trajectory will jeopardise the water sources for the country's major urban centres, such as the capital, Quito. Rising temperatures will also affect agricultural production, as warmer winters will cause crops to sprout prematurely, and greater volatility in precipitation rates will disrupt production.
Sustainability concerns will take centre stage in the medium to long term. Renewable energy currently accounts for about 90% of electricity generation, with hydroelectric power accounting for nearly all of this. Hydroelectric and geothermal power primarily, and wind and solar power secondarily, will play an important role in the medium to long term. However, the heavy use of hydroplants will raise the risk of climate-related infrastructure risks as erosion forces costly repairs. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the government to incrementally roll back its high fuel subsidies to make way for these renewable sources, which will offer increasing business opportunities. However, in the short term, the government will continue to promote oil and mining production, which may pose long-term threats to environmental stability.
Migration and urbanisation Urbanisation in Ecuador is a relatively recent phenomenon and comparatively low for Latin America. The majority of the population has traditionally lived in rural communities in the mountainous region (sierra). Since crossing the 50% threshold in 1990, the percentage of people living in cities has grown slowly, from about 62% in 2006 to 64% in 2020. The establishment of a middle class under a social spending and consumption-driven economic policy in the 2000s, particularly by the administration of Rafael Correa (2007-17), will sustain a large urban population. Meanwhile, security concerns in the north and environmental degradation in the sierra are likely to accelerate the pace of migration from rural areas to cities in the medium term. The country's infrastructure and natural resources will be strained in the process, necessitating greater investment. There will be opportunities for public-private partnerships for infrastructure investment, but internal migration will also invite limited bouts of social unrest.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include: LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Data sources and definitions Sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data Commodity prices: IMF, IFS; non-oil
OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: Brent average import prices
US and European GDP growth: OECD
US effective exchange-rate index: IMF, IFS; nominal weighted index, 1990=100
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
Domestic data Balance of payments: IMF, IFS
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Deposit rate: average rate weighted by deposit amount on 30- to 59-day time deposits
General government debt: includes debt of the non-financial and financial public sectors
Inflation: IMF, IFS; derived from consumer price index (CPI), 2006=100Trade by country: IMF, Direction of Trade Statistics Yearbook
Lending rate: average rate charged by commercial banks on non-preferential loans. The rate is weighted by loan amounts
Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end medium- and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding with an original maturity in excess of one year, plus arrears and year-end IMF debt outstanding
Population and growth: Celade
PPP: purchasing power parity; average ratio of prices in Costa Rica to prices in the US
Real exchange rate: The Economist Intelligence Unit; a real exchange rate of less than 100% indicates that the currency is undervalued vis-à-vis relative prices and vice versa
Total debt service: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges paid against total external debt
Total external debt: sum of long-term debt, short-term debt and arrears
US$ GDP at PPP: IMF, IFS; The Economist Intelligence Unit; local-currency GDP converted to US dollars at estimated annual average of consumer products' PPP
US$ GDP: IMF, IFS; local-currency GDP converted to US dollars at annual average market exchange rate
Abbreviations Celade: Centro Latinoamericano y Caribeño de Demografía
IFS: International Financial Statistics
IMF: International Monetary Fund

Guide to the business rankings model Outline of the model The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2016-20) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2021-25). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2016-20. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2021-25 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2016-20 ranges are then used to derive 2021-25 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2021-25, not to the likely situation in 2025 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2018 or 2023). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: - The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the coalition government, led by the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI), with Imran Khan as prime minister, to serve a full term (with the military's tacit support) until the next general election, which is due in 2023. However, the ruling coalition's slim majority in the lower house of parliament will continue to pose a risk to political stability until the end of its term. The military will play a dominant role in the country's politics, particularly on issues relating to domestic security and foreign policy. The precarious security situation will remain a source of instability during our forecast period (2021-25). Despite strained ties with India over the dispute in Kashmir, we do not forecast an outright military conflict. China will remain Pakistan's main strategic and economic partner throughout the forecast period.

Pakistan--highlights: Business environment outlook                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
4.47 5.10 73 74 17 17
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.

- Pakistan's business environment will achieve a modest improvement from the historical period (2016-20), with the overall score increasing to 5.1 in 2021-25, from 4.47. It remains in last place among the 17 countries rated in the Asia-Pacific region and slips one place globally, owing to improvements elsewhere. A reduction in macroeconomic imbalances and associated risks supports the score. However, concerns about corruption and weak institutional capacity will continue to undermine the business environment. Efforts to expand power generation will provide businesses with improved access to electricity, but the associated price increases will weigh on profit margins.

- Real GDP will grow by an annual average of 4.1% in fiscal years 2021/22-2024/25 (July-June). Downside risks to economic growth for 2021-22 will come from recurrent waves of Covid-19 infection as the country is unable to vaccinate a significant share of the population. The government's efforts to rein in the fiscal deficit will weigh on investment and economic growth in 2021-25. The twin deficits on the current and fiscal accounts will pose persistent (albeit reduced) macroeconomic risks during the forecast period. Pakistan will continue to require bilateral and multilateral loans (which we expect it to receive) to stave off balance-of-payments difficulties. Although we expect the current account to register a deficit equivalent to 2% of GDP in 2022, from a slight surplus in 2020, the deficit will remain narrower-both in absolute terms and as a percentage of GDP-than it was in 2018, when Pakistan faced a balance-of-payment crisis.

Pakistan--highlights: Demographic outlook Population (m) 2015 2020 2025

Period averages (%)   2016-20 2021-25

- Pakistan's population will cross the 225m mark in 2021 and will continue to rise, putting additional pressure on scarce resources. The rate of expansion in the working-age population will outpace overall population growth. Rapid urbanisation will provide an opportunity for increased economic output, but productivity growth will remain sluggish. We expect that Pakistan will be unable to benefit fully from its "demographic dividend", owing to low female participation rates and weak investment in education. The government will have only limited ability to generate jobs for the growing workforce.

- GDP per head at market exchange rates dipped to US$1,189 in 2019/20, from US1,482 in 2017/18 and US$1,289 in 2018/19, owing to the income shock caused by the pandemic and macroeconomic imbalances. GDP per head will rise throughout the forecast period, while remaining below its 2017/18 level. Pakistan's low level of development and average income mean that food will still account for a large share of consumer expenditure in 2021-25. Wide regional differences in income mean that market opportunities for big-ticket consumer goods and luxury items will be concentrated in urban areas, where a middle class is emerging.

Pakistan--highlights: Long-term outlook   2021-30 2031-50 2021-50
Growth and productivity (% change; annual av)

Growth of real GDP 4.5 4.3 4.4

- We forecast the population to grow from 225m in 2021 to around 338m by 2050. In theory, demographic trends will be conducive to rapid GDP growth, but the authorities have not planned adequately for the expansion of the labour force and have failed to spend enough on infrastructure, education and other social services. The institutional and policy outlook will remain highly volatile, given the strong role of the armed forces. Successive governments are likely to increase development spending during the long-term forecast period, but such expenditure will continue to be hampered by fiscal constraints and the prioritisation of defence spending. Strengthened ties with China will help to address some infrastructure challenges.

Background: The Islamic Republic of Pakistan was founded in 1947. East Pakistan (now Bangladesh) seceded in 1971. There have been several coups since independence. The most recent was in 1999, when the chief of army staff, Pervez Musharraf, became the chief executive of Pakistan. He ruled first as chief executive and then as president until 2008. The general election in 2008 resulted in a new coalition government, led by the Pakistan People's Party (PPP). Pakistan witnessed the second transition between elected governments in its history after the July 2018 general election, which ushered in a new coalition government led by the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI), under the leadership of Imran Khan.
Political structure: Parliamentary supremacy over the presidency was restored in 2010, when both houses of the legislature approved a landmark amendment to the constitution. The PTI dominates a coalition government that comprises independents and smaller parties such as the Pakistan Muslim League (Quaid-i-Azam) and the Muttahida Qaumi Movement. Provinces are represented in the National Assembly (the lower house of parliament) in proportion to the size of their respective populations. In the Senate (the upper house), all four provinces have equal representation. Senators serve a term of six years, and half of the seats in the upper house come up for re-election every three years.
Policy issues: Pakistan faces an acute imbalance on its fiscal and external accounts. Large outlays for defence expenditure and debt-servicing obligations have led to wide fiscal deficits, while the balance of payments is strained because of a large financing gap. Owing to these imbalances, the country is reliant on the IMF and other bilateral and multilateral donors for fiscal and foreign-exchange reserve support.
Taxation: In the budget presented in June 2021, the standard rate of corporate income tax stayed at 29%. The rate for some companies, such as banks, remains higher. In fiscal year 2021/22 (July-June) the government also rescinded several tax exemptions previously provided to businesses. In terms of indirect taxes, the general sales tax (GST) remains at 17%.
Foreign trade: According to the IMF, merchandise exports stood at US$21.9bn in 2020, and imports totalled US$43.5bn, yielding a goods trade deficit of US$21.6bn.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance Pakistan is a parliamentary federal republic with a bicameral legislature and Islam as the state religion. The National Assembly (the lower house of parliament) holds 342 seats and the Senate (the upper house) comprises 100 members. The Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) secured the largest number of seats in the 2018 election for the National Assembly. The PTI leads a coalition government that includes the Muttahida Qaumi Movement, the Pakistan Muslim League (Quaid-i-Azam), the Balochistan Awami Party and the Grand Democratic Alliance, among other parties, and a number of independents.
Although the PTI-led coalition holds more than half of the seats in the lower house, it lacks a simple majority in the upper house. Elections for half of the seats in the Senate are held every three years. In the most recent election (held in March 2021), the PTI emerged as the single largest party. The next upper-house election is scheduled to be held in 2024.
The provincial assemblies of Pakistan each represent a very distinct political landscape. A PTI-led coalition enjoys a majority in the provincial assembly of Punjab, the country's most populous province. Its principal challenger is the Pakistan Muslim League (Nawaz), or PML (N), which has traditionally been the dominant political party in Punjab. The PTI and its allies also govern the provinces of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and Balochistan, both of which have a relatively fragmented polity. In Sindh province, however, the PTI finds itself as the opposition in the provincial assembly. The Pakistan People's Party (PPP), which has traditionally dominated the political landscape in Sindh, continues to hold a majority in the provincial assembly.
The president is chosen by an electoral college comprising the upper and lower houses of parliament and the four provincial assemblies. Arif Alvi, a founding member of the PTI, was elected as the 13th president of Pakistan in September 2018, for a five-year term. The presidency is a largely ceremonial post in Pakistan's parliamentary system, where power resides with the prime minister as head of the executive.
Although the prime minister is responsible for most day-to-day decisions, the military is in de facto charge of national security and foreign policy. In particular, the armed forces drive the most important foreign-policy relationships-those with the US, China, India and Afghanistan. The PTI, which gained electorally in 2018 from the tacit support of the military, will remain amenable to this arrangement. As a result, relations between the civilian government and the armed forces will be positive.
Militant groups are also a significant force. The most important insurgent organisations are the Tehrik-i-Taliban Pakistan (also known as the Pakistani Taliban), an alliance of around a dozen militant groups that is unrelated to the Taliban in Afghanistan, and the Balochistan Liberation Army, a militant separatist group in that province. Furthermore, there are Islamist political organisations such as the now-banned Tehreek-e-Labbaik Pakistan (TLP), which periodically lead large-scale demonstrations and campaigns on religious issues.

Political outlook: Political stability The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the government that took office in August 2018, led by the PTI, to serve its full term until 2023 under the prime minister, Imran Khan. The military (including its intelligence wing), which has a long history of political intervention, is expected to continue to support the PTI. This will help the current government to maintain its grip on power.
Opposition parties will be hobbled by legal challenges to their leaders. The PML (N) has been affected in recent years by adverse court rulings, which include the jailing in 2018 of its honorary leader, Nawaz Sharif (a former prime minister, currently abroad on expired medical bail). Nawaz Sharif's younger brother and the current president of the PML (N), Shehbaz Sharif, also faces charges over alleged corruption during his tenure as chief minister of Punjab province in 2013-18. The de facto leader of the PPP and a former president (2008-13), Asif Ali Zardari, was indicted for graft in October 2020 and faces other related investigations.
With the leadership of the PML (N) and the PPP facing legal proceedings, the two parties formed a political alliance, the Pakistan Democratic Movement (PDM), with other, smaller entities in September 2020. In March 2021 the PDM pulled off a surprise win in the Senate elections, which forced the prime minister to conduct a vote of confidence. Although Mr Khan won that vote, the opposition demonstrated its ability to raise a potentially successful no-confidence motion. However, differences between the PPP and the PML (N) on the issue of mass resignation by legislators to force a snap election led to a split in the opposition alliance in April 2021. This has removed a near-term threat to the current government, but the slim nature of the ruling coalition's majority in the National Assembly continues to represent a risk to political stability.
In the medium term Islamist groups, such as the now-banned TLP, will continue to threaten political stability and social cohesion. Demonstrations on religious issues took place in April 2021, and we expect such events to recur during our forecast period (2021-25), with the risk of associated violence posing a challenge to law enforcement. We also expect the government and armed forces to continue to struggle with a separatist movement in Balochistan, but this will not pose a significant threat to political stability at the national level.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness In July 2018 Pakistan witnessed the second transfer of power between elected civilian governments in its 71-year history. Democratic norms are far from entrenched. The parliamentary election in 2018 was marred by a number of irregularities, including vote-rigging, as well as a lack of judicial impartiality. The country's political institutions remain weak and underdeveloped. Moreover, inefficient government bureaucracy and corruption will continue to undermine institutional effectiveness.
Tensions between the military and the civilian government have subsided since the PTI-led coalition took office, as the current government has been ardent in protecting the interests of the armed forces. The military's power remains strong, and it will continue to assert itself in a number of policy areas-not only security and foreign policy, but also economic policies such as the privatisation of state-owned enterprises.
Political effectiveness varies greatly from region to region. In the Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province, moves to increase the writ of government have often triggered conflict. In addition, secessionist elements are likely to remain active in Balochistan. With the opposition PPP in power in Sindh, conflicts between the provincial and federal governments over power-sharing (and, crucially, revenue-sharing) are likely to intensify. The risk is higher given the poor relations between the PPP and PTI.
The judiciary does not have a history of impartiality, having traditionally deferred to the interests of the armed forces. It has, for example, retroactively ratified all of the country's military coups. The judiciary is highly politicised and some of its high-profile members have been overtly pro-government. Although there have been instances of the judiciary asserting its independence in 2020-21, we do not believe that the legal system is likely to become a genuine guardian of the constitution within the forecast period. Partisanship has often detracted from rather than aided political effectiveness.
Political outlook: Election watch We expect the popularity of the ruling coalition to suffer during the remainder of its term as it strives to meet the conditions of an IMF programme, which resumed in March 2021. A rise in the cost of living and increases in the tax burden will be sources of disenchantment among Mr Khan's voter base. However, we do not expect this to translate into immediate gains for the opposition parties, which will continue to be hampered by legal challenges against their leaders. We therefore expect the ruling coalition to serve a full term until 2023. Our current baseline assumption is that the PTI-led coalition will win the next general election, with the military's support. However, the risks to this forecast remain high, especially if inflation does not decelerate in 2022-23 or if the opposition parties come together against the PTI.
Political outlook: International relations Although there will be increased diplomatic activity between Pakistan and India in 2021-25, we expect bilateral relations to remain fraught. Recent events have signalled a thaw in relations, with the two countries agreeing to a ceasefire in February 2021. However, cross-border terrorism and a decades-long sovereignty dispute over Kashmir will remain major obstacles to the normalisation of relations. Tensions will remain high, and Pakistan's military may increase its support for militant groups in Indian-controlled Kashmir. This will raise the risk of terrorist activity by non-state actors, similar to the attack on India's paramilitary forces in February 2019 that led to clashes between the two countries' armed forces. However, we do not expect a full-blown military conflict. Both countries are nuclear powers and will be wary of miscalculations that could accidentally result in the catastrophic use of those weapons.
China will remain Pakistan's leading economic and strategic partner in 2021-25, with bilateral ties strengthening amid the pandemic as China provides financial support and supplies vaccines to Pakistan. The deterioration in relations between China and India will reinforce China's links with Pakistan, especially in terms of investment in Pakistan-administered Kashmir, which is claimed by India. Projects under the umbrella of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC) will be undertaken increasingly in the form of direct investment by Chinese firms. CPEC-related lending by China will continue in 2021-25, even amid fiscal constraints and concerns over debt sustainability. Lending support from China will also be forthcoming, to meet Pakistan's debt obligations and to support its balance-of-payments needs. Pakistan, in turn, will continue to supress any domestic protest against China's treatment of Muslims in Xinjiang.
Pakistan will continue to balance its relations with Turkey on one hand and with Saudi Arabia and other Gulf countries on the other, as they compete for influence in the Islamic world. Bilateral ties with Turkey will remain robust, with that country maintaining diplomatic support for Pakistan, particularly when the latter faces international pressure to act more strongly against terrorism. We do not expect Pakistan to recognise Israel officially in the near term.
The US exit from Afghanistan will challenge Pakistan's relations with the latter. We believe that Pakistan will look to support the Taliban militia in order to retain its influence in Afghanistan, while at the same time trying to ensure that instability does not make its neighbour a safe haven for its own separatist organisations. Relations with the US will remain strained. The tougher stance against Pakistan taken by the US president, Joe Biden, indicated by the absence of a phone call to the Pakistani prime minister nearly six months into his presidency, indicates a deterioration in bilateral relations. Pakistan could face punitive measures from the US for its support of the Taliban and other extremist organisations.

Pakistan's business environment will generally improve in the 2021-25 forecast period, with the country achieving an overall score of 5.10, compared with 4.47 in 2016-20. However, Pakistan remains 17th (and bottom) in the Asia-Pacific regional ranking. Globally, it slips by one place to 74th out of 82 countries, owing to greater improvements in other countries. The government, led by the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI), will remain weak because of its dependence on multiple coalition partners. However, continued tacit backing from the armed forces and a weak opposition will allow it to serve out its full term, ending in 2023. An inefficient bureaucracy will limit political effectiveness, and geopolitical tensions with neighbouring India and Afghanistan will keep instability in the political environment relatively high.
The government will continue the gradual liberalisation of rules on foreign investment, in an effort to offset investor concern about the difficult political and security environment. However, continued balance-of-payments strains mean that most bureaucratic obstacles and foreign-exchange controls will remain in place, impeding foreign trade and capital transfers. Business and policy reform efforts, under an IMF programme that resumed in early 2021, will achieve limited success because of competing political considerations. Corruption and tax evasion, often abetted by revenue officials, will remain widespread. The government will continue to expand ties with China and boost bilateral trade and investment. Projects under the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC) will shift from energy and infrastructure to industrial investment, but at a slow pace. Levels of internet and mobile-phone penetration will continue to improve, while remaining low by global standards, meaning that Pakistan's technological readiness will remain poor. The country's research-and-development spending will also remain low.

Business environment outlook: Pakistan's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2021-22: The government tries to privatise some state-owned assets to raise public revenue, but progress is very limited.
2023-25: Private companies modestly increase their share of the economy under IMF-mandated reforms.
Policy towards foreign investment 2021-22: The government promotes foreign investment in some sectors, especially infrastructure and energy. However, security and political risks and the fragility of the economy deter inward investment.
2023-25: The government makes some progress in setting up special economic zones under the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC). However, the poor business environment hinders efforts to attract non-Chinese investment to these zones.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2021-22: Exchange-rate volatility is reduced considerably in comparison with 2018-20, owing to support provided by the IMF programme and debt-service suspension by G20 countries.
2023-25: Officials relax some import controls that were introduced in 2018-19 to ease pressure on the external account.
Taxes 2021-22: The corporate tax rate remains at 29%, which is high by regional standards. Corporate tax exemptions that were granted previously are rolled back. Indirect taxes on fuel and utilities are raised to support central-government revenue.
2023-25: The tax system remains complex and inefficient. Most citizens remain outside the tax net, but the authorities maintain their efforts to close tax loopholes and increase compliance for business and industry, with limited success.
Financing 2021-22: The cost of credit remains largely unchanged as the central bank eases monetary policy only towards the end of 2022. Lending is also constrained by risk-averse banks, owing to high levels of non-performing loans.
2023-25: Stockmarkets become more important as a funding channel for medium-sized and large companies, as the external sector stabilises and attracts foreign capital.
The labour market 2021-22: The unemployment rate declines gradually but nevertheless remains high, keeping a lid on wage inflation.
2023-25: The low literacy rate and limited spending on tertiary education hamper growth in the supply of skilled labour.
Infrastructure 2021-22: The 819-km Chaman-Quetta-Karachi motorway and some other road projects are completed. The Main Line 1 (ML-1) railway project, which aims to upgrade the country's existing rail infrastructure, is delayed.
2023-25: Power plants fuelled by renewable energy are built to diversify electricity generation. However, power blackouts and high energy prices persist. Telecommunications infrastructure continues to improve, but at a slow rate.
Technological readiness 2021-22: Spending on research and development remains depressed, as a result of adverse economic conditions.
2023-25: The government rolls out 5G spectrum, but network coverage is scant, limiting demand for compatible products.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c
