a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Pakistan's macroeconomic environment score improves to 4.9 in 2021-25, from 4.1 in the historical period. While this will move it up five places in the global ranking, to 74th, Pakistan will remain at the bottom of the regional ranking. The economy will recover in 2021-22 from the downturn induced by the Covid-19 pandemic, achieving modest real GDP growth. The resumption of a US$6bn IMF reform programme in 2021 will support the external sector. However, with the next general election scheduled for 2023, politically motivated spending pressures pose a risk to the programme's completion. The current-account balance will slip into a deficit equivalent to 1.8% of GDP in 2021, from a surplus of 0.1% of GDP in 2020, owing to firming demand for imports. The current-account deficit will average 1.8% of GDP annually during the rest of the forecast period (2022-25),as modest economic growth keeps import demand in check.
Pakistan's external sector strains will be alleviated in 2021-22 by strong growth in remittance inflows and a combination of bilateral, multilateral and commercial sovereign financing. This will help it to continue to service foreign debt in 2021-25. However, vulnerabilities will remain, driven by a persistent trade deficit and high levels of public debt. Pakistan's foreign-exchange reserves will remain under pressure, leading to a progressive weakening of the currency during 2021-25. Inflationary pressures will remain high in the first half of the forecast period, owing to various tariff increases to support fiscal revenue. In the face of large debt-servicing obligations and high defence expenditure, the fiscal deficit will remain wide, averaging 5.8% of GDP during fiscal years 2021/22-2024/25 (July-June), limiting the government's ability to deliver on further development and social spending.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
4.0 5.0 66 58 14 13
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Pakistan will achieve some improvement in the policy towards private enterprise and competition category, with its global ranking rising by eight places to 58th in 2021-25, and a promotion of one place, to 13th, in the regional ranking. Indicator scores for government regulation on setting up new private businesses and freedom of existing businesses to compete have increased, as has the score for protection of intellectual property (albeit from a very low base). Gradual progress on business environment reforms and the growth of e-commerce will facilitate greater competition and new entrants to the market over the forecast period. Nevertheless, most of our gauges of Pakistan's policy towards private enterprise and competition will continue to rank below the regional average, as public entities and powerful cartels will continue to dominate key economic sectors over the forecast period. In line with this, scores for distortions arising from lobbying by special interest groups and distortions arising from state ownership/control will remain unchanged at their low levels.
The economy will slowly open up, but special interest groups will remain
- The PTI government will make some progress on its plans to restructure key loss-making state-owned enterprises (SOEs), with a view to their eventual privatisation. As a first step, in 2020 it approved plans to downsize significantly the workforces of Pakistan International Airlines and Pakistan Steel Mills-two entities that have become a major drain on the exchequer. The government also plans to open up the liquefied natural gas (LNG) import sector, which is expected to grow robustly during 2021-25, to private players. However, resistance from state monopolies in the energy sector and an inefficient bureaucracy will probably impede this process. Overall, bloated SOEs, particularly in the fuel and power sectors, will remain difficult to turn around or privatise owing to large financial liabilities and poor management.
- The Competition Commission of Pakistan is the national quasi-regulatory body tasked with preventing monopolistic practices. In 2020 it investigated the powerful sugar and cement cartels for price-fixing, but its overall effectiveness is limited; unfair business practices in the private sector will remain common in 2021-25. While Pakistan in theory boasts a favourable legal environment for private enterprise, in practice it is hampered by weak contract enforcement, an inefficient bureaucracy, burdensome regulations and policy uncertainty. Chinese investors and companies are likely to continue to receive favourable treatment from the government over the forecast period, in particular for the awarding of contracts, reducing opportunities for other businesses.

The military will continue to exert its influence in real estate and logistics
- The military will retain a significant influence on the economy during 2021-25. Its large monopolies, particularly in real estate and logistics, will continue to grow over the forecast period. Additionally, the armed forces' pension funds will continue to play a prominent role in the economy through ownership or shareholdings in industries ranging from cereals to banking. Apart from the military, politically connected business groups such as textiles exporters will continue to exercise undue market influence and receive frequent subsidies. As a result, the freedom of most companies to compete openly will remain constrained.

Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
6.0 6.0 54 56 10 11
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Pakistan's score for policy towards foreign investment will remain static in 2021-25. However, the country will drop two places in the global ranking (to 56th place) and one place regionally (to 11th) owing to improvements in other countries. The score for government policy towards foreign capital will remain above the regional average over the forecast period, but most other indicators will remain below it. The influence of special interest groups and frequent corruption in the award of public-sector contracts will remain the main reason behind the weak investment climate. In addition, the risk of expropriation will remain high for foreign investors in sectors where the armed forces have interests, with limited legal recourse in domestic courts and the absence of an effective dispute resolution mechanism. Although foreign investors are allowed to hold 100% equity in nearly all industrial sectors without prior permission, foreign direct investment is likely to remain comparatively low because of practical hindrances.

- The forecast period will see ongoing economic co-operation with China, based around the ambitious CPEC project aiming to link China's Xinjiang region with the Arabian Sea at Gwadar Port. China has pledged to invest more than US$60bn over 15 years, focused on energy and road and rail infrastructure. By the end of 2020 more than US$20bn had been invested in projects related to power generation, transport infrastructure and the development of Gwadar Port. CPEC-related investments will continue to be financed partially by the Chinese state and its banks, which lend money to Chinese companies to carry out the work, often with imported Chinese labour.

China will remain an important source of foreign direct investment
- Over the forecast period foreign investment is likely to remain concentrated in the energy, finance and telecommunications sectors and dominated by China. Nevertheless, there will still be opportunities for non-Chinese investors. The international Stellantis Group entered into an agreement with a local distributor in March 2021 for the manufacture of European brand vehicles. The following month a consortium led by Japan's Mitsubishi Corporation obtained a licence to construct a new LNG import terminal. Also in 2021, a subsidiary of the German KfW Group entered the insurance market by acquiring an equity stake in a local insurance company. After the government's approval of the country's first five-year electric vehicle policy in 2020, this is likely to be another area of future opportunity.
- The government will try to encourage investors to use the country as a base for international manufacturers to produce goods for export in 2021-25, through nine planned special economic zones (SEZs), which constitute one component of the CPEC initiative. While the government plans to offer streamlined investment facilitation procedures and tax breaks to attract foreign investors to these SEZs, none of them has been made operational so far. Foreign investment outside the SEZ framework-mainly from China-has nevertheless started to flow in, such as a China-Pakistan joint venture that launched a locally assembled passenger car in 2020, and the approval granted in 2021 to a Chinese state-owned automaker to manufacture electric vehicles at a local SEZ. However, a relatively low-skilled labour force, high energy costs and a poor overall business environment will limit the level of investment received by manufacturing in the forecast period.

Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
4.6 6.0 74 71 17 16
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Pakistan's global ranking for foreign trade and exchange controls will improve slightly in 2021-25, from 74th to 71st place, and it will move off the bottom of the regional rankings by one place, to 16th. Pakistan has lowered tariffs since it joined the World Trade Organisation in 1995. According to the World Bank, the average weighted tariff came down from 20.6% in 2001 to its lowest level of 8.7% in 2019. Nevertheless, taxes on imports, particularly on petroleum products, will remain a vital source of revenue for the government and are subject to frequent revision. We expect the government to make some progress in reducing non-tariff barriers. Nevertheless, non-tariff barriers in general, occasional import bans and restrictions in response to balance-of-payments pressure, inconsistent regulations and opaque policymaking will remain significant hurdles to international trade over the forecast period.
Trading will continue to face multiple challenges
- Exports remain dominated by textiles, which accounts for more than half of overall export receipts. Pakistan has found it difficult to diversify exports away from the sector. Textiles exports largely comprise lower-value items such as cotton cloth rather than higher-value items such as garments. Pakistan's complex and inconsistent regulations, inefficient bureaucracy and infrastructure bottlenecks will be reformed only slowly and will feed into relatively high business costs. This is reflected in low scores for openness of trade (which is well below the regional average) and ease of trading.
- In 2021-22 exports will grow strongly as global demand recovers from the Covid-19 pandemic. In the national budget for 2021/22, reduced duties on imports of raw materials for the textile industry will also aid in export growth. Exports during 2021-25 will also be aided by the elimination of duties by China on 313 products from Pakistan, which took effect in 2020. US restrictions on cotton sourced from the Chinese region of Xinjiang will also support exports. However, structural weaknesses in Pakistan's economy will weigh on export growth throughout the forecast period.
- After contracting in 2020 because of the impact of the pandemic, imports will grow robustly in 2021-22 as the economy recovers. A reduction in tariffs in the budget for 2021/22 and higher crude oil prices will further inflate the import bill. Import growth will continue to outstrip that of exports over the forecast period, leading to a continuous increase in the trade deficit and persistent pressure on the external account. Partly as a result of this, capital controls on the cross-border movement of foreign exchange will remain relatively stringent over the forecast period, making financial operations awkward for foreign businesses.

Business environment outlook: Taxes                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
5.7 5.7 51 65 12 15
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Pakistan's score for taxes remains unchanged in 2021-25. However, because of the relatively slow pace of tax reform compared with other countries, its global ranking will drop from 51st to 65th in the forecast period. Its regional position will also worsen, slipping three places to 15th out of 17 countries. Pakistan scores particularly poorly for tax complexity, and below the regional average for most other indicators in this category. By contrast, its score for the top marginal personal income tax is above the regional average. Overall, a lack of consistency in policy, patchy application and cumbersome legal procedures will remain the principal concerns for private enterprises over Pakistan's tax policy framework.
The tax system will remain largely inefficient
- In an effort to improve documentation and curb tax evasion over the forecast period, the Federal Board of Revenue (FBR) will continue to enhance its database of potential taxpayers and efforts to trace retail sales. Although this may force some tax evaders into compliance, we do not expect a widespread improvement in the efficiency of the FBR over the forecast period. Overall, these policy measures are likely to lead to some improvement in tax collection. However, we do not expect meaningful reform of the agency. Apart from inefficiency and corruption, it suffers from frequent changes in leadership and political interference, hampering institutional autonomy.

Indirect taxes are set to rise in 2021-25
- In the budget for 2021/22, the government has not imposed additional income taxes; maintained the rate of general sales tax at 17%; and lowered import duties on some items used as inputs by domestic industries. Taxes and levies on imported petroleum products-a key source of revenue-have been increased. In general, the government will continue to rely heavily on indirect means (duties and sales taxes) to expand revenue collection during 2021-25, but the tax/GDP ratio will remain low owing to a narrow tax base and relatively large informal economy. We expect increases in electricity and gas tariffs over the forecast period, as well as a gradual (though not complete) reduction in subsidies to large industrial customers such as fertiliser and power plants, owing to the fiscal constraints faced by the government. Agricultural income is unlikely to face taxation over the forecast period. The tax burden will fall mainly on the large-scale manufacturing sector, which has a relatively small share of total GDP at factor cost. This means that the rate of overall business taxation is likely to remain comparatively high during the forecast period.
- The corporate tax rate is currently 29%. It is unlikely that it will be reduced further during the forecast period, as the government will still need to increase revenue to contain the fiscal deficit.

Business environment outlook: Financing                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
5.5 5.5 50 65 11 16
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
The score for Pakistan's financing environment will stay unchanged over the forecast period. However, its global ranking will fall from 50th to 65th. In the Asia-Pacific region it will move down five spots to 16th, one off the bottom, as other countries make improvements. Although there will be an economic recovery in 2021-22, banks' balance sheets are likely to deteriorate in this period because of the effects of the Covid-19 pandemic in 2020. Commercial banks, mainly privately owned, will nevertheless remain the most important source of short-term credit in Pakistan, with overdrafts the principal form of short-term borrowing. Bank credit to fund the government's large fiscal deficit will continue to crowd out private-sector borrowing to some extent. Access to financing will improve gradually in the latter part of the forecast period as the State Bank of Pakistan (SBP, the central bank) undertakes a loosening of monetary policy and the fiscal deficit narrows. The capitalisation of the stockmarket will remain low compared to most regional economies, but is expected to grow at a robust pace over the forecast period.

- Weaknesses in the legal framework, inefficient foreclosure processes and a scarcity of information for assessing collateral quality and borrower creditworthiness will pose ongoing problems for banks over the forecast period. Nevertheless, bank credit to the private sector has increased gradually during the last decade, and is expected to maintain growth in 2021-25. The majority of this will remain directed at the corporate and industrial sectors, leaving a relatively large funding gap for small and medium-sized industries in the absence of a vibrant small finance ecosystem. The government's focus on low-cost housing finance is likely to result in an increase in banks' mortgage portfolios, albeit from a very low base.
- A dual system of Western and Islamic financing will remain in operation in 2021-25. A large section of the conservative population views the Western interest-based banking system with suspicion, resulting in rapid growth in Islamic banking; by December 2020 the sector's assets amounted to 17% of the overall banking sector, according to the central bank. Nevertheless, deposit-taking and lending with interest by Western-style commercial banks will remain the dominant form of banking during the forecast period.

Mobile banking services will become more popular
- Branchless-banking services, which use a combination of licensed agents and mobile devices, will continue to expand robustly in 2021-25 as mobile-phone penetration rises. After the SBP issued regulatory guidelines allowing non-banking companies to issue electronic money (e-money) services in 2019, numerous financial technology companies have been given approval to provide such services. The government is using branchless banking to disburse certain payments, which will spur growth further. These developments are likely to help to promote financial inclusion among small businesses and the population at large, which remains low.

Business environment outlook: The labour market                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
5.1 5.7 74 63 17 16
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
The outlook for Pakistan's labour market is positive, with steady progress pushing the country up 11 places to 63rd in the global ranking and one place (from bottom to 16th) in the region in 2021-25. The level of technical skills indicator will improve over the forecast period, as tertiary education slowly expands. Similarly, a favourable regulatory regime will lead to improvements in the restrictiveness of labour laws and extent of wage regulation indicators. The overall score is boosted in particular by the country's very low cost of labour and its low cost of living in comparison with other countries in the Asia-Pacific region. Pakistan's workforce will expand by a robust 2.2% a year on average over the forecast period. While education is considered a priority in domestic politics and by aid donors and multilateral institutions, fiscal constraints mean that we expect only very slight growth in public healthcare and education expenditure by the government over the forecast period.
Overall educational standards will remain low
- The government will continue to pursue measures aimed at raising the literacy rate, which stood at around 60% nationally in 2020-a level at which it has stagnated since 2015. The urban population has a much higher literacy rate compared with rural areas and supplies labour to the manufacturing and services sectors. There is a large gender divide in educational attainment, with the female literacy rate significantly lower than that for males. Coupled with religious conservatism, this translates into an extremely low participation rate for women in the labour force; in 2018 (latest available data) this was just 21.9%, compared with 80.3% for men, according to data by the International Labour Organisation (ILO). The government is likely to prioritise higher education at the expense of primary and secondary schooling in 2021-25, partly because investment in tertiary education is more popular among the vocal urban elite. Consequently, the country will continue to have a mass of poorly educated people and a small, well-educated elite, many of whom will emigrate.
- Pakistan will continue to face criticism over the use of child and bonded labour. Legislation passed to ban debt bondage in 1992 has failed to end the practice, owing largely to lacklustre enforcement and a large informal economy. Debt bondage is expected to remain prevalent in industries such as agriculture, brick-making, and carpet-weaving in particular. According to Child Rights Movement, an umbrella coalition of Pakistani non-governmental organisations, around 12.5m children in Pakistan were involved in labour in 2016. The ILO describes the situation in the country as one of the worst in the world.

Business environment outlook: Infrastructure                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
3.8 5.0 68 68 12 13
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Pakistan's infrastructure score will improve to 5.0 in 2021-25, from 3.8 in the historical period, following sustained investment in its road network, port infrastructure, electricity supply and mobile telecommunications network. However, its global rank will remain constant at 68th, while it will drop one spot regionally to 13th. The score for reliability of electricity supply will increase, albeit from a very low base, as will that for mobile network coverage, broadband connection speed, the infrastructure for retail and wholesale distribution and extent and quality of road network. This indicates that both digital and physical infrastructure will improve over the forecast period. Pakistan will also continue to have some of the lowest office rents in the region. Nonetheless, the country's overall infrastructure, as it relates to enabling business, will remain relatively poor, owing to decades of underinvestment.
Energy, transport and telecoms infrastructure will improve slowly
- The CPEC project will remain the cornerstone of efforts to modernise the transport, energy and power sectors in 2021-25. The US$3bn cross-country Peshawar-Karachi motorway has been mostly completed, with the last leg in Sindh province (connecting Sukkur city to Karachi) expected to be finished by 2025. In the first half of the forecast period the government aims to add road construction projects for the underdeveloped Baluchistan province under the CPEC umbrella. The development of Gwadar port, located strategically on the Arabia Sea in Baluchistan, will remain a priority CPEC project. However, progress is likely to be slow because of fiscal constraints and the unclear commercial viability of the port. A large CPEC-related infrastructure project, the US$7.2bn upgrade of the Peshawar-Karachi railway line, has yet to begin amid mounting fiscal and debt concerns. However, a mass transit rail project developed under the CPEC in the country's second-most populous city, Lahore, was successfully launched in 2020.
- Over 2021-25 the government will make further efforts to improve the reliability of electricity supply. Imported liquefied natural gas (LNG) will increasingly replace domestic natural gas and furnace oil for power generation. While coal-fired projects will be pursued, the government intends to diversify generation through renewable sources as well, releasing a national policy for this purpose in 2020. Several hydropower projects are planned under the CPEC, the largest of which will be the 1,100-MW Kohala project slated for completion in 2026. The government will also deepen nuclear co-operation with China, despite opposition by the US and India; in March 2021 the 1,100-MW K-2 nuclear power plant was connected to the national grid. While these initiatives will significantly reduce electricity supply shortages over the forecast period, the key challenge will remain the underfunded transmission and distribution segment. This has led to accumulating circular debt (the high inter-company arrears that delay payments through the electricity generation and supply chain), which is unlikely to be eliminated during 2021-25.

Water security will remain a concern
- Pakistan will face acute water shortages over the forecast period; it already has to deal with widespread seasonal shortages and chronic deficiencies in some urban areas, including the commercial capital, Karachi. The government will continue to prioritise the Diamer-Bhasha dam-a megaproject for both hydropower generation and water storage-to meet this challenge; a construction agreement was signed with a Chinese firm in May 2020. However, financing such large infrastructure projects will remain a challenge in 2021-25, owing to large fiscal deficits.

Business environment outlook: Technological readiness                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
2.4 3.5 78 74 16 16
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Pakistan's score for technological readiness will improve in 2021-25, albeit from a low base, moving the country up four places to 74th globally. However, its regional position will remain unchanged at 16th. The indicator score for Pakistan's quality of e-commerce business environment will improve, driven by rising demand and investment in the sector. The score for scope of e-government will also rise (from a very low base) as government services are slowly digitised. The SBP is working on various projects to promote the digitalisation of government payments, and we expect more of these to be moved online during the forecast period. Pakistan will continue to lag far behind its regional peers in the areas of internet use and mobile-phone subscriptions, despite growth in both areas during 2021-25.
Defence technology and e-commerce will grow
- Research-and-development spending in the private sector will remain extremely low during the forecast period, while the efforts of the Higher Education Commission to promote academic research and innovation will produce limited results because of low funding. However, defence-related research spending is likely to rise, driven by the demands of the armed forces, which are keen to modernise their systems and equipment. This will occur against a backdrop of dwindling security assistance from the US but increasing co-operation in defence technology with China. One example is the JF-17 Thunder fighter aircraft, developed jointly by Pakistan and China. In May 2021, Nigeria became the first country to purchase the JF-17, with export orders from other countries likely during the forecast period.
- Pakistan's e-commerce market has great potential, with the number of merchants and consumers expected to grow at a rapid rate in 2021-25. With Pakistan's first e-commerce policy having been approved in October 2019, we expect added momentum in the sector over the forecast period. The emergence of several online marketplaces and rising internet use have attracted the attention of foreign investors. For example, in May 2021 Facebook (US) announced co-investment plans with a Pakistani internet service provider to improve and expand the broadband fibre network. On the back of online sales growth, the logistics and delivery sector is also expected to expand and modernise. Overall, we expect e-commerce sales to grow steadily, although the limited availability of broadband internet outside the largest cities will be a constraint.

Economic forecast: Policy trends Pakistan's third wave of Covid-19 peaked in late April 2021, and cases have been on a downward trend since. However, we expect the country to face recurrent waves of infection throughout 2021-22, as the vaccination rollout will be too slow to break the chain of transmission. We expect the authorities to achieve widespread immunisation (covering more than 60% of the population) only in 2023. The government will apply short, localised lockdowns to contain the spread of the virus; we expect it thus to avoid a repeat of the large-scale shutdown imposed in the second quarter of 2020.
The government's policy priority in the near term will be to support macroeconomic fundamentals by implementing reforms under the IMF programme, such as increasing the autonomy of the State Bank of Pakistan (SBP, the central bank), withdrawing corporate tax exemptions, increasing fuel tariffs and reforming sales and income taxes. Throughout the rest of its term the coalition government, led by the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI), will focus on the ambitious policy agenda on which it was elected, including the expansion of social services, housing construction and job creation. These plans were ambitious even before the onset of the pandemic, and a wide budget deficit will constrain progress in these areas.
Economic policymaking will suffer from greater military interference during the forecast period. The armed forces will expand their sphere of influence through appointments and institutional changes such as the elevation in 2019 of the army chief, General Qamar Javed Bajwa, to the National Development Council, which is tasked with setting development policies and providing guidelines for regional co-operation. As the military wields greater influence, its own varied business interests will become further entrenched. In particular, the logistics and transport sectors, which are dominated by military-backed entities, will undergo a further decline in competition. The military's greater involvement in economic matters could also increase expropriation risks for foreign investors in the energy and extractive industries.

Economic forecast: Fiscal policy Fiscal indicators

The budget for fiscal year 2021/22 (July-June), announced in mid-June, increases expenditure only moderately but is the most expansionary budget presented by the PTI since it assumed office in 2018. The budget aims primarily to support the economy by strongly increasing capital expenditure, which had broadly stagnated in the previous three years. The government also announced a reduction in the indirect tax burden on inputs for several manufacturing sectors, the most important of which is the textile industry. To compensate for the loss of revenue and to consolidate the deficit, taxes on petroleum products and imports of non-essential items have been increased, and existing corporate tax exemptions have been revoked. We forecast the deficit to stand at the equivalent of 6.4% of GDP in 2021/22. The deficit will ensure that the public debt burden remains high and the risk of a sovereign debt crisis is elevated. However, our core forecast remains that Pakistan will be able to service its debt with financial support provided by bilateral and multilateral lenders.
The fiscal deficit will continue to narrow from 2022/23 as the government undertakes measures to expand the tax base, but will nevertheless remain large in 2022/23-2024/25, at an annual average of 5.6% of GDP, reflecting the government's slow progress. On the expenditure side, military outlay and interest payments on public debt will continue to account for a large share of total expenditure, propping up spending throughout the forecast period.
Economic forecast: Monetary policy Interest rates
(%)
  2020 2021 2022 2023 2024 2025
Money market interest rate 8.6 7.1 6.9 6.6 6.1 5.6
The SBP loosened monetary policy aggressively in 2020 by reducing the benchmark policy rate by 625 basis points to 7%. Owing to high inflation, there is a moderate risk of the central bank tightening monetary policy in the second half of 2021. However, our core expectation is that the SBP will keep policy rates unchanged throughout 2021 to support the economic recovery. As price pressures moderate in 2022, we expect the central bank to cut policy rates by 25 basis points that year to provide support for the economy. The high level of borrowing by the government to finance its large deficit will risk crowding out credit to the private sector. We expect the SBP to respond by maintaining its accommodative stance throughout the forecast period (as inflation continues to ease), in order to suppress private-sector lending rates.

Preliminary national accounts data suggest that the economy recovered significantly more strongly from the coronavirus-induced downturn than we had previously expected. We forecast real GDP to expand by 3.2% in 2021/22, after growing by an estimated 3.8% in 2020/21. The expansion will be led by private consumption, which accounts for 80% of the economy, supported by strong remittance inflows. The economy will also be supported by a large increase in government fixed-capital expenditure. Our growth forecast includes the expectation of continued short and localised lockdown measures throughout the year as the government is unable to vaccinate a significant share of the population. However, large-scale lockdown measures remain the primary risk to the forecast.
Economic growth will pick up at a gradual pace later in the forecast period, averaging 4.4% a year in 2022/23-2024/25, amid strong private consumption and fixed investment, which will be supported by the easing of monetary policy and investment by Chinese companies under the CPEC. Strong growth in exports of textiles, supported by a relocation of labour-intensive industries from China, will also support the overall economy. Nevertheless, growth will continue to be constrained by the government's fiscal consolidation moves and its efforts to address balance-of-payments pressures.


Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends Output from the industrial sector accounted for 18.7% of nominal GDP in 2019/20. The manufacturing subcomponent accounted for 64.7% of the industrial sector, within which textiles will continue to play an important role and account for the majority of total merchandise exports. The textile sector was weighed down in 2019/20-2020/21 by the pandemic and low cotton production. However, in 2021/22 we expect the sector to be supported by a reduction in costs, owing to a decrease in import tariffs for textile inputs and strong demand from Pakistan's export destinations-notably the US and Europe. Over the rest of the forecast period the textile sector will continue to expand, but the growth will be constrained by a number of factors. Garment companies have often failed to adapt to international clients' increasingly stringent requirements in areas such as labour rights. The sector is still stuck at the low end of the value chain, as modern management practices have not been widely utilised, resulting in low productivity. Moving up the value chain will be crucial, as Pakistan's textile sector is still based mainly on cotton, whereas international demand is shifting to synthetic fibre. Moreover, competitors such as Vietnam have made headway in signing free-trade agreements with Pakistan's key export destinations, which could curb growth prospects.
Output from other subsectors of the industrial sector is forecast to increase gradually. The construction sector will grow strongly in the first half of the forecast period, supported by regulatory easing. An improvement in the availability of electricity, particularly in the latter part of the forecast period, will reduce operational challenges, and firms will start to be able to take better advantage of preferential tariffs. However, the sector will continue to suffer from low levels of investment, which will result in the use of old and relatively unproductive machinery.
The services sector will be an increasingly important part of the economy over the forecast period, expanding from 57.1% of GDP in 2020/21 to 58.2% of GDP in 2024/25. Wholesale and retail trade is the largest category in the services sector, comprising around 20% of GDP. Rising household incomes and greater urbanisation will spur growth in retail. Infrastructure spending will provide a lift for the transport sector, which is set to benefit from improvements and investment under the CPEC.
Output growth in the telecommunications sector is also likely to remain strong in 2021-25. Mobile-phone use is increasing rapidly, as a result of deregulation in the sector and lower prices for handsets. According to the Pakistan Telecommunications Authority, the percentage of people in Pakistan using mobile phones stood at almost 83.9% in May 2021, when there were 183m annual mobile subscribers; this is set to rise further in the coming years. Demand for 4G services has been strong, and these will enable many more people and businesses to access high-speed internet via mobile phones, spurring further expansion. Moreover, opportunities for expansion exist in new areas such as broadband and mobile commerce. Most foreign investment will continue to come from China and the Middle East. As a significant proportion of foreign direct investment is concentrated in telecoms, maintaining the sector's attractiveness to foreign investors will remain crucial for the government.
The agriculture sector will remain susceptible to natural disasters Output from the agriculture sector (which accounts for 24.4% of nominal GDP and 36.9% of total employment) will fluctuate depending on government targets and seasonal rainfall. Major floods in 2010 and locust infestation in 2020 demonstrated the sectors' vulnerability to shocks such as natural disasters. Without a substantial increase in investment, which we do not anticipate, the sector will remain vulnerable to extreme weather conditions and water shortages. Assuming normal harvests, we expect agricultural output to increase by 2.8% a year on average in 2021/22-2024/25.

Economic forecast: Inflation % 2020 2021 2022 2023 2024 2025
Consumer prices 9.5 9.0 6.9 5.9 5.0 4.8
Consumer price inflation will remain elevated in 2021, owing to high food prices, heightened inflationary expectations, increases in fuel tariffs under the IMF programme and higher fuel prices resulting from a rise in global oil prices. An increase in inflationary pressure will be offset in part by lower imported inflation. We forecast consumer price inflation to average 9% in 2021, marking a deceleration from 9.5% in 2020.
Consumer price inflation will decelerate further in 2022 with the dissipation of domestic supply-side inflationary pressures. We forecast global oil prices to rise for a second year in 2022, but the pace of increase will be considerably slower than in 2021. Overall, we expect consumer price inflation to average 5.6% per year in 2022-25.
Economic forecast: Exchange rates   2020 2021 2022 2023 2024 2025

After appreciating between July 2020 and April 2021, the Pakistan rupee has returned to its depreciatory trend against the US dollar. We expect the local currency to maintain this trend for the rest of 2021, owing to the current-account deficit, persistently high inflation and the strengthening of the US dollar. We forecast the rupee to reach PRs162.8:US$1 at end-2021, from PRs159.6:US$1 a year earlier. This will be a much more gradual depreciation than was the case in 2018-20. The depreciation of the rupee against the US dollar in May-June 2021 has alleviated our concern about the rupee being overvalued. We believe that this, along with a rapid build-up of foreign-exchange reserves with the central bank, will help to prevent high volatility in the exchange rate.
The currency will depreciate against the US dollar throughout the rest of our forecast period, owing to the persistent current-account deficit and gradual monetary easing from 2022 (against the global trend). The rupee will also depreciate gradually in real effective exchange rate terms. We expect the SBP to continue to operate a lightly managed exchange-rate regime, which it adopted under the IMF programme, and not to adopt a free-floating regime.

The current-account balance will shift to a deficit equivalent to 1.8% of GDP in 2021, from a marginal surplus in 2020. We forecast merchandise imports (on a current-account basis) to rise by 31% in 2021, after annual contractions in 2019 and 2020. This growth rate reflects improving domestic demand conditions after the disruption caused by the pandemic, as well as a steep rise in global crude oil prices. Imports of cotton for the garment industry (to compensate for a poor domestic harvest this year) and high cereal imports (to contain food inflation) will also support growth. Import growth will be buttressed from 2022 by strengthening domestic demand and the relaxation of import controls over the medium term.
Merchandise exports will rebound by 23.7% in 2021, after two consecutive years of contraction, as economic activity normalises in major overseas markets after pandemic-induced slowdowns. We expect goods exports to maintain growth momentum throughout the forecast period. Nevertheless, the rate of expansion will remain below potential, owing to myriad supply-side constraints, including the slow adoption of technology, low labour productivity and a difficult local business environment.
Despite a subdued recovery in the Gulf economies, which are major employers of overseas Pakistani workers, we expect remittance inflows to be significantly higher than in 2019-20. This will help to support household spending, particularly in rural areas. Inflows will dwarf outflows, leaving the secondary account in surplus and partially offsetting the trade deficit.
Overall, we expect Pakistan's external position to improve over the forecast period, aided by the US$6bn, 39-month IMF extended fund facility programme. The country's external position will also be supported by the debt-service suspension initiative enacted by G20 countries and lending support from other bilateral lenders (particularly China). Although the current-account deficit will widen to 2% of GDP in 2022, it will remain significantly narrower-both in absolute terms and as a percentage of GDP-than it was in 2018, when Pakistan faced a balance-of-payment crisis. A gradual narrowing of the current-account deficit in 2022-25, along with a build-up of foreign-exchange reserves, will also help to alleviate balance-of-payments strains.


Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Pakistan Stocks and flows Foreign direct investment (FDI) stood at US$2.1bn in 2020, according to data from the IMF, slightly lower than the US$2.2bn recorded in 2019. Inflows remained relatively resilient in 2020 given the Covid-19 pandemic and the balance-of-payments strains faced by Pakistan. This is primarily the result of an increase in investment from China. FDI in Pakistan grew rapidly prior to 2008, on the back of increased incentives for investors, improved economic fundamentals and greater policy consistency. However, inflows declined sharply and have remained depressed since then as a result of domestic political instability and persistent strains on the external account. The stock of FDI in Pakistan stood at US$32.4bn at end-2020, higher than the stock of US$19.4bn in the similarly sized Bangladeshi economy.
Origin and distribution In 2020 the top net foreign investors in Pakistan were China (accounting for 39.9% of inflows), Hong Kong (9%) and Malta (6.6%, owing to its tax haven status), according to the State Bank of Pakistan (the central bank). The power sector was the largest recipient of FDI in 2020, garnering 47.5% of total inflows, while the oil and gas sector and the financial sector accounted for 14.1% and 11.4% of inflows respectively.
Determinants Between 2000 and 2007 the military government was able to maintain relative political and economic stability, and this was an important factor in attracting investment. Sustained growth in specific sectors since then has presented investors with the potential for high returns. However, the uncertain political environment since 2008 and the recurrent external-account difficulties faced by Pakistan have adversely affected investor confidence. A key source of investment finance is the Chinese government, which wants to foster political stability through investment in Pakistan's economic development. The prime example of this is the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC).
Impact FDI into Pakistan has been unable to support fixed investment significantly. FDI inflows as a share of fixed capital formation stood at 6.5% in 2019/20, as inflows have been concentrated in only a few sectors, such as oil and gas exploration, power, telecommunications and finance. Overall, the longer-term benefit will be limited given that even in these sectors the transfer of technology between foreign companies and domestic companies is minimal. However, the impact of FDI on Pakistan will be felt mostly through investments made under the CPEC in the power sector, which will significantly support the Pakistani economy by alleviating the country's electricity shortage.
Potential The main attractions for foreign investors will continue to be the telecommunications, power and hydrocarbons sectors. The government will encourage private-sector involvement in areas that were previously the preserve of the public sector, primarily through privatisation. The government resumed its privatisation programme in mid-2014 with the sale of stakes in United Bank and Pakistan Petroleum, in order to shore up its fiscal position. Progress on privatisation over the forecast period will be slow, and the process of reforming public-sector companies such as Pakistan International Airlines has been gradual. This will make attracting buyers for these troubled entities a challenge. In general, political concerns have had a greater impact on portfolio inflows than FDI, but Pakistan's myriad domestic woes indicate that investment prospects (with the exception of projects under the CPEC) will remain relatively subdued.

Population growth will start to put pressure on scarce resources We forecast the population to grow by 1.9% a year in 2021-25-a slight deceleration from the pace of 2.1% recorded in 2016-20. Nevertheless, Pakistan will add 17m people to its population over the forecast period. Population growth will put increasing pressure on scarce resources such as water and energy. The Water and Power Development Authority forecasts that the amount of water available will fall to around 800 cu metres/person by 2025, compared with around 5,000 cu metres/person in 1951. (The UN's Food and Agriculture Organisation considers a level of 1,000 cu metres per person to be the threshold below which a country faces water scarcity.)
The government hopes to slow population growth and plans to encourage medical practitioners, religious leaders and private organisations to work with it to reduce the birth rate. Officials also intend to focus on slowing population growth in rural areas, where around 60% of Pakistan's citizens live. However, previous family-planning campaigns have not been markedly successful, and a plethora of other pressing issues, such as reviving the economy from the effects of the coronavirus and easing the strains on the fiscal and external accounts, means that population control will not be a priority over the medium term.
The population will remain young. While the proportion of people aged up to 14 will shrink, that of people aged between 15 and 64 is projected to grow over the next five years. The proportion of the total in the oldest group (those aged 65 or over) will rise slightly. During our five-year forecast period the number of Pakistani people of working age will increase sharply. This development presents Pakistan with an opportunity to enjoy a "demographic dividend" as the higher level of output facilitated by the increased labour force supports stronger overall economic growth. Moreover, Pakistan will not have to combat the financial problems associated with an ageing population (in particular, higher medical costs and pension liabilities) that are facing north-east Asian countries, where the decline in birth rates in the past three decades has been more pronounced.
However, Pakistan will not be able to reap the full potential benefits of its demographic dividend because of low female participation in the workforce, due to social and religious restrictions. According to the International Labour Organisation, only 22% of women in Pakistan participated in the labour force in 2018. This is lower than the global average and is behind Pakistan's regional peers, Bangladesh and Sri Lanka, where 36% and 34% of women were in employment respectively.
Barriers to entry in the education system will remain high Pakistan's GDP per head (in US dollar purchasing power parity terms) is the lowest of the four South Asian countries covered by our Country Forecast reports. The figure for Pakistan in 2020 is estimated at US$4,730, compared with US$6,510 for India, US$13,570 for Sri Lanka and US$5,208 for Bangladesh. Unlike Bangladesh, Pakistan has not made significant progress on reducing barriers to entry in the education system. According to data provided by the UN, the gender difference in primary school attendance is wide in Pakistan, at 11.6 percentage points: 73.2% of boys and 61.6% of girls attended school in 2018 (latest available data). There is also a wide discrepancy between the poor and the rich; only 39.5% of all children in the poorest quintile attended primary school in 2018, compared with 76.6% for the richest quintile. Progress in the improvement of education will be slow, partly because Pakistan lacks qualified teachers. Those teachers who are qualified are unlikely to find employment in rural or poor areas an attractive proposition.
Despite the weakness of its key social indicators, development spending will remain less of a priority than debt repayment and military spending. As a result, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects social indicators in areas such as health and education to remain poor. We expect that life expectancy will rise slowly, from an average of 67.2 years in 2021 to 67.8 years in 2025. Infant mortality will fall from 55.3 deaths per 1,000 live births to 50.3 over the same period. The relatively fast rate of population growth will put increasing strain on the provision of healthcare services, even after the Covid-19 pandemic.

The consumer market has been affected by a fall in incomes in 2019-20 caused by balance-of-payments strains and the Covid-19 pandemic. The government's efforts to address balance-of-payments pressures and consolidate fiscal expenditure will dampen economic activity throughout the period, weighing on purchasing power. GDP per head at market exchange rates is estimated to have fallen from US$1,482 in 2017/18 to US$1,189 in 2019/20, and we forecast that it will recover to US$1,459 only in 2024/25. Nevertheless, the country's young and growing population will support growth in aggregate domestic demand. Household consumption will remain the primary engine of economic growth, creating opportunities for retailers. We expect consumer market growth and opportunities to be stronger in urban areas. However, most Pakistanis will remain poor, with limited income for spending on discretionary items.
Outside cities, the development of the agricultural sector will drive much domestic demand; a large part of Pakistan's industrial sector is involved in processing agricultural products, and the agriculture sector directly employs close to half of the labour force. Manufacturing growth will also play a role, but will be constrained by chronic power supply problems. Nevertheless, we expect that a pick-up in power generation over the forecast period will provide new investment opportunities for businesses and should create openings for companies in supply-chain and service fields, such as logistics and finance.
The services sector will contribute more to overall economic growth As the population becomes increasingly urban, the services sector is likely to provide a growing contribution to the economy, particularly in telecommunications. There will also be continued opportunities in the healthcare sector. Annual budgets will continue to allocate resources for healthcare and welfare, particularly in rural areas, in an attempt to reduce poverty and as part of the government's policy agenda. However, social spending by the government will be constrained by insufficient revenue and high expenditure on the military, as well as debt repayments. Such military spending may offer opportunities for firms in the armaments sector, although the risk of technology leakage will probably deter suppliers from offering more advanced military equipment.
While the country will face an increase in the poverty rate in the short term (as shown by the fall in income), we expect a slow decline to take hold from 2021 onwards. Nevertheless, poverty in rural areas (which account for the majority of the population) will remain widespread and will constrain demand for big-ticket consumer goods in these areas. According to the World Bank, poverty in urban areas affected 18% of the overall population in 2018 (latest available data), while the level in rural areas stood at 36%. A wide divergence in income across Pakistan will also contribute to differences in consumption patterns. We expect the provinces of Sindh and Punjab to pace ahead, while Balochistan and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa remain characterised by widespread poverty.

The consumption basket will remain largely unchanged in 2021-25. Pakistan's low level of development and low average income ensure that consumer expenditure in 2021-25 will be dominated by food, housing and fuel. The low levels of average income reflect the fact that half of the population is reliant for employment on the agriculture sector, which we expect to grow at a relatively slow pace in 2021-25. We do not anticipate a significant shift in consumption patterns over the forecast period. Spending on food, beverages and tobacco will continue to account for the largest share of overall spending. This will be supported by the fact that consumers are likely to continue to prioritise spending on essential items over non-essential items at the start of the forecast period, as per capita income remains depressed compared to 2017/18. Changes in consumption among Pakistan's elite make little impact on overall expenditure. We expect spending on food, beverages and tobacco, combined with housing and fuel, to remain largely the same as a percentage of total household spending, edging up from 69.5% in 2021 to 69.9% in 2025. Spending on leisure and education will remain steady over the forecast period even as incomes recover slowly. Spending on healthcare will also remain steady as the government makes some progress on the public health infrastructure.

Initial conditions: Political and social instability has long held back economic development, undermined democratic institutions and weakened the judiciary. The military influence over civilian administrations has historically been strong and there is little sign that the armed forces will desist from driving a number of key policy areas, including foreign affairs and national security. There have been a number of military coups; the most recent was in 1999, when the army chief, Pervez Musharraf, ousted the then prime minister, Nawaz Sharif. Economic growth was strong under Mr Musharraf, but public protests prompted a return to democracy (and a parliamentary election) in 2008.
The country's first transition of power between two democratically elected governments occurred in 2013, when Mr Sharif once again assumed power. In a positive move, in 2016 General Qamar Javed Bajwa replaced General Raheel Sharif as the chief of army staff-the first time in 20 years that an army chief in Pakistan had ended a single three-year term as planned. However, tensions were heightened between the government-led at the time by the Pakistan Muslim League (Nawaz)-on one side and the military and judiciary on the other. These tensions have persisted even since the administration was ousted from power in July 2018.
Ties between the military and the current civilian government, led by the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf, are positive, but institutional stability will continue to come under strain as opposition parties push for a more impartial and non-partisan judiciary and military. Although Pakistan entered an IMF programme in July 2019, which will help to counter the ongoing balance-of-payments and fiscal difficulties, meaningful structural reforms that could put the country on a fast and sustainable macroeconomic trajectory will be rare.
Demographic trends: Pakistan's population is forecast to grow fairly rapidly. At the current growth rate, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects it to reach around 338m by 2050, compared with an estimated 225m in 2021. In theory, the country's favourable demographic trends will be conducive to rapid GDP growth, but unemployment and weak labour productivity will constrain growth. Previous governments have not planned adequately for the expansion of the labour force, failing to spend enough on infrastructure, education and social services. Successive administrations are likely to increase development spending in the long-term forecast period, but the process will be hampered by limited revenue and challenges in ensuring that increased development funding results in improved outcomes. The need for improvements in infrastructure, education and social services, combined with the low participation rate of women in the labour force (even by regional standards), will limit Pakistan's ability to benefit from its demographic dividend over the longer term.
External conditions: Pakistan's economic outlook will be shaped increasingly by financial and technical support from China. The two countries share deep and long-standing ties in both the military and civilian spheres. China will remain keen to reinforce its influence in the region by funding infrastructure projects under the multi-billion-dollar China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC). These projects will bind the two countries closer together, with the Pakistani military particularly keen to deepen this relationship.
The dispute over Kashmir will inhibit trade with India Pakistan's ties with the US will remain complex. Successive US administrations will be reluctant to cede influence to China. However, the US is likely to prioritise ties with India, weakening its co-operation with Pakistan in the process. Still, owing to the need to create sufficient employment opportunities, Pakistan will seek to deepen trade ties with Western countries in the coming decades. Shared economic interests between Pakistan and India would have the potential to bolster growth in Pakistan if they were to result in trade liberalisation. However, in the light of the intractable territorial dispute between the two neighbours over Kashmir, as well as other issues such as cross-border terrorism, there will only be limited progress in this area in the next two decades or so.
Institutions and policy trends: Notwithstanding the grim current state of democratic freedoms and processes, Pakistan's democratic institutions are likely to become gradually more entrenched in the long term. However, the overall institutional and policy outlook for Pakistan will remain highly volatile, given the strong role of the armed forces. The military is not expected to relinquish control over its key interests and policy areas such as national security or foreign affairs for at least another decade. On the positive side, since 1999 Pakistan has made some progress on economic and structural reforms. However, the country's volatile political situation affects the quality of its underlying institutions and will determine the policies that are adopted.
Improved management and technology will enhance institutional strength Institutions and policy will improve slowly as civil servants and economists continue to strengthen their management and technology skills. Engagement with the IMF in 2019-23 will help the authorities to make some progress on key areas of reform, including privatisation, revenue collection and the move towards a more lightly managed exchange-rate regime. However, significant structural reforms will be hard to come by as the momentum of reform dwindles once the IMF programme ends. Similar engagements with other multilateral institutions will result in the same back-and-forth incremental progress on reform over the next few decades.
Long-term performance: Pakistan's labour force will grow rapidly, driven by a rise in the population. However, skill levels will not increase substantially. The average number of years of schooling will remain low, even by the standards of developing countries. It has taken nearly three decades for Pakistan to increase the mean years of schooling to 5.2 (in 2019, latest available from the UN), compared with 2.3 in 1990. Labour productivity will rise by around 2.1% a year in 2021-50. Pakistan's efforts to maintain rapid economic growth will continue to rely on textiles, low-end manufacturing and some services subsectors. A growing middle class and an increasingly dynamic private sector will spearhead this effort. An increased level of sophistication in managing the economy, as well as a gradual decoupling of political and economic administration as democratic institutions mature, will support growth rates, even in times of political turmoil. Successive governments will continue to increase spending on healthcare and education, while trying to contain the fiscal deficit at a level that does not threaten macroeconomic stability. Military expenditure will remain high. We expect real GDP growth to average 4.4% a year between 2021 and 2050. We expect GDP per capita (at purchasing power parity) to reach US$21,495 in 2050, compared with US$39,110 in Bangladesh and US$45,780 in India.

Long-term outlook: Long-term trends Climate change and sustainability Pakistan is likely to be particularly vulnerable to the effects of climate change. Water scarcity problems are likely to intensify as higher global temperatures accelerate glacial melt in the Himalayas, disrupting the traditional flow patterns in some of the country's key river systems. The negative effects on agricultural productivity of a rise in extreme weather events will be amplified by the country's burgeoning population, which will drive increased demand for food. A Ministry of Climate Change has been mandated to put an action plan in place. However, high levels of poverty and the government's weak underlying fiscal position will limit the country's ability to mitigate the impact of extreme weather events, particularly on the important agriculture sector. They will also limit the authorities' capacity to invest in infrastructure to adapt to climate change. In 2019 we developed a model to calculate the impact of climate change on long-term growth, and we find that the Pakistani economy will be 3.7% smaller in 2050 than it would have been without this hit to growth.
Urbanisation Pakistan is one of the most urbanised countries in South Asia. Besides high birth rates, rapid migration from rural areas over the years has swelled the number of people in and around the urban centres of the country. According to the World Bank, the number of people living in the country's cities and towns will grow to 155.7m in 2045, from an estimated 82m in 2020. The actual levels of urbanisation are likely to be even higher as a large number of people live in informal settlements, as well as spillover urban belts that fall outside the formal administrative boundaries of major conurbations. Even as migrants are attracted to cities for better employment opportunities and access to services, Pakistan's urban centres will face serious challenges-particularly in the delivery of public services and infrastructure. Despite the government's efforts to address problems such as power shortages, poor sanitation and a lack of healthcare services, we do not expect these to be completely resolved for at least the next two decades. There is likely to be growing demand for transport-related investment as the country seeks rapid transit systems to solve the problem of public transport in its major urban centres. Massive infrastructure investments in housing and water are also likely to be required across the country in the next three decades.
Energy demand Pakistan's energy needs are vast. According to the International Energy Agency, nearly 57m people lacked access to electricity in 2019. For those who do have access, daily power cuts can be routine. In the next decade the country will continue to suffer from a significant imbalance between energy demand and supply, owing partly to poor electricity production facilities and low domestic oil and gas reserves. Nevertheless, the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC) has the potential to alleviate (partly) strains in the energy sector. There are more than 15 priority energy projects under the CPEC, which are part of a so-called Early Harvest Programme. The bulk of these will near completion by the first half of the forecast period, boosting the capacity of the country's power sector. However, the positive impact of the projects will be constrained by persistent problems that include a leaky distribution system, regulatory inefficiencies and a lack of skilled professionals in the sector-factors that we do not expect to be resolved in the coming decade. As a consequence, we expect the energy deficit to remain a key feature of the economy until at least 2030.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include: LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.
