Data sources and definitions The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregates
OECD and US consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent Blend
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data GDP: expenditure on GDP at constant market prices on a fiscal-year basis (ending on June 30th of year indicated)
GDP growth: Ministry of Finance, Economic Survey
US$ GDP: IMF, IFS
Population: Federal Bureau of Statistics, Pakistan Statistical Yearbook; Ministry of Finance, Economic Survey; UN, World Development Report
GDP per head: growth in real GDP deflated by population growth
Inflation: based on a combined cost-of-living index for industrial, commercial and government employees; Ministry of Finance, Economic Survey; Prime Minister's Secretariat, Consumer Price Index Data
Exchange rate: IMF, IFS; Financial Times
Balance of payments: IMF, IFS
Foreign debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics
Foreign direct investment: UNCTAD, World Investment Report
Abbreviations IFS: International Financial Statistics
UNCTAD: UN Conference on Trade and Development
Guide to the business rankings model Outline of the model The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2016-20) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2021-25). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2016-20. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2021-25 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2016-20 ranges are then used to derive 2021-25 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2021-25, not to the likely situation in 2025 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2018 or 2023). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: - The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the president, Cyril Ramaphosa, to complete a first term in 2024 and run for a second term, but he could face a challenge for the leadership of the ruling African National Congress (ANC) at its five-yearly electoral summit in December 2022 in the absence of a post-pandemic economic rebound, with victory not assured.
- The economic and social damage wrought by the global coronavirus pandemic, alongside the need for urgent remedial action, will help to build support within the ANC for the president's reformist agenda, albeit reluctantly in some cases. Policy will focus on vaccine rollouts, infrastructure investment (led by the private sector) and combatting electricity shortages. Fiscal constraints point to an increased reliance on public-private partnerships for key projects. The fightback against corruption will gather momentum in 2021, as shown by the ANC's suspension of its secretary-general, Ace Magashule, in May, for defying orders to step aside.
- Following a severe recession in 2020, with real GDP shrinking by 7% because of the pandemic, we expect a modest growth rebound to 3% in 2021, helped by low interest rates and higher commodity prices, although power supply constraints, still-weak tourism and jobs lost to the pandemic will preclude a more rapid rebound. We envisage growth averaging 2.7% a year in 2022-25, underpinned by structural reforms, but unemployment will continue to weigh on aggregate demand.
- The budget deficit soared to about 11% of GDP in fiscal year 2020/21 (April-March), but will trend lower, helped by wage restraint and revenue gains from higher commodity prices. Debt risks remain high but will subside if fiscal consolidation plans are fulfilled. Cumulative interest-rate cuts in 2020 cut the benchmark rate to 3.5%, providing relief to borrowers, but another reduction is unlikely. We expect interest rates to remain on hold until a small rise in late 2021 or early 2022.
- After easing to a multi-year low of 3.2% in 2020, average inflation will rise to 4% in 2021 (revised from 3.7%), owing to costlier oil and electricity, but weak demand will keep price growth subdued. Inflation will quicken to 4.5% a year on average in 2022-25 as economic growth stages a gradual post-pandemic recovery.
- Current-account prospects for 2021 point to another (albeit smaller) current-account surplus, before the return of a deficit in 2022-25 as imports regain traction.

- South Africa's business environment score improves for 2021-25, although its global ranking drops by two and its regional ranking is unchanged from 2016-20. Market opportunity and infrastructure gains will be partly offset by deteriorations in macroeconomic stability and taxation.

Country forecast overview: South Africa's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2021-22: A post-pandemic investment drive, focused on infrastructure, facilitates public-private partnerships. Challenges include tighter competition laws and stricter black economic empowerment (BEE) rules.
2023-25: Expropriation without compensation, to speed up land reform, applies in limited circumstances only, reducing the threat to property rights. Investment incentives in selected industries (such as automotive manufacturing) remain in place.
Policy towards foreign investment 2021-22: A reworked mining charter offers some concessions to business. A new foreign investment law limits access to international arbitration by giving local courts the primary responsibility for handling disputes.
2023-25: The government continues to encourage foreign investment and public-private partnerships, but resists the full privatisation of state assets in most cases.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2021-22: The government implements a further relaxation of capital controls on outward investment and other flows.
2023-25: Progress towards regional economic integration in Southern Africa makes some advances, but barriers persist.
Taxes 2021-22: Despite tough fiscal conditions, the government avoids major tax increases to shield households and firms.
2023-25: Efforts to streamline and modernise the tax system and expand the tax base continue.
Financing 2021-22: Special pandemic liquidity measures are phased out in 2021 but interest rates remain low, before edging higher in 2022. Local banks remain sound and a major source of corporate financing, despite profits being squeezed by the pandemic.
2023-25: The continued independence of the South African Reserve Bank (the central bank) helps to preserve financial system stability. Monetary policy remains prudent and interest rates edge higher. The proposed nationalisation of the central bank is symbolic.
The labour market 2021-22: Pandemic-induced job losses oblige trade unions to accept a mild relaxation of currently inflexible labour laws.
2023-25: The labour market remains tough, owing to skills shortages and BEE targets.
Infrastructure 2021-22: Investment in transport and electricity, led in many cases by private firms, boosts capacity.
2023-25: Private-sector-led investment in renewable energy gathers momentum under the government's long-term energy plan, adding diversity to power supplies and cutting reliance on coal. Rising power tariffs drive energy efficiency.
Technological readiness 2021-22: The rollout of domestic fibre-optic cables boosts capacity and cuts costs. Investment in digital technology gathers momentum, including in cloud computing and high-end data analysis. The allocation of new spectrum boosts capacity
2023-25: Work advances on the Square Kilometre Array-a powerful radio telescope with multinational support-giving a wider boost to science and to information and communications technology.

Background: South Africa became a full democracy in 1994, when it first held all-race elections. The African National Congress (ANC) won, and has dominated all subsequent elections-in 1999, 2004, 2009, 2014 and 2019. However, support ebbed steadily from a peak of nearly 70% in 2004 to 62.1% in 2014 and 57.5% in May 2019. The ANC feared a worse result in 2019, but the installation of Cyril Ramaphosa as president in February 2018, replacing the scandal-tainted Jacob Zuma, provided a mild bounce. Barring shocks, Mr Ramaphosa will serve a full five-year term ending in 2024 and would be eligible for a second term.
Political structure: South Africa is a constitutional democracy with a bicameral parliament and a president elected by parliament. The constitution is the supreme law. The National Assembly is elected by proportional representation; the National Council of the Provinces consists of indirectly elected representatives of the nine provinces. The judiciary is independent and includes an 11-member Constitutional Court. The constitution provides for an independent corruption watchdog-the Public Protector-and commissions on human rights, gender equality and restitution of land rights.
Policy issues: The main policy focus in 2021-25 will be to facilitate recovery from a severe recession in 2020, caused by the damaging impact of the coronavirus pandemic. The need to boost post-pandemic growth will allow Mr Ramaphosa to push ahead more forcefully with his reformist agenda. A new economic recovery and reconstruction plan, released in October after consultation with business and labour unions, will focus on investment in critical infrastructure (such as housing and transport), led by the private sector, alongside a large-scale public works programme to create jobs. Tackling power shortages by commissioning new capacity from independent power producers, and by restructuring Eskom, the highly-indebted electricity parastatal, is another key objective. Fiscal constraints point to an increased reliance on public-private partnerships, despite resistance from vested interests. A new draft expropriation bill sets clear limits on when compensation is not payable, thus diminishing the threat to property rights and investor confidence. Challenges include skills shortages, stricter competition laws and the perennial risk of strikes.
Taxation: Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at a flat rate of 15%-after a rise from 14% on April 1st 2018-although some essentials are zero-rated. Corporation tax (of 28%), income tax and VAT were left unchanged in the 2021/22 budget, but a corporation tax reduction is earmarked for 2022/23. Some tax concessions are available, including in special economic zones.
Foreign trade: South Africa has a relatively open economy, with foreign trade (imports plus exports) accounting for about 52% of GDP. China, the EU, the US and Japan are among its largest trading partners. Trade with the rest of Africa has become progressively more important and makes a large contribution to South Africa's merchandise trade surplus.

Outlook for 2021-25: Political stability Recovering from the coronavirus pandemic and a deep recession in 2020 will confront South Africa with unparalleled challenges, but the growing authority of the president, Cyril Ramaphosa, has positive implications for political stability and economic reform. On the pandemic front, new cases and deaths picked up again in May, heralding a possible third wave of Covid-19 during the southern hemisphere winter (June-August). A mass public vaccination campaign also launched in May, but a range of global bottlenecks in the vaccine production supply chain mean that the targets of inoculating the 60-plus age range by end-June and all adults by end-2021 will be hard to meet. A rise in new Covid-19 cases and deaths in May and into June, alongside bottlenecks in the vaccine production supply chain, underlines the risk of moving restrictions one rung higher to a modified level three (on a five-level scale).
Since being elected for a five-year term in May 2019 Mr Ramaphosa has struggled to unite the disparate factions of the ruling party, the African National Congress (ANC), behind a reformist agenda, but a severe recession in 2020, accompanied by heavy job losses and rising poverty, is changing the political dynamic. After several years of policy fudges to appease powerful interest groups (such as labour unions), the need for urgent action to repair the economy-including by working more closely with the private sector-is boosting support for the president's agenda. The two main sources of resistance to Mr Ramaphosa within the ANC are left-wing interventionists-who will remain wedded to a strong state role in the economy-and the so-called radical economic transformation movement that emerged during the presidency of Jacob Zuma (2009-18), which is blamed for facilitating corruption and patronage under the guise of black economic empowerment.
In a key victory for Mr Ramaphosa over the pro-Zuma faction in early May, the ANC's National Executive Committee suspended the party's secretary-general, Ace Magashule, after he defied a new rule requiring members formally charged with corruption (and other serious crimes) to stand aside from their positions. Given the powerful role played by the secretary-general in choosing election candidates and organising key summits, Mr Magashule's suspension (ahead of his next court appearance, in August), gives Mr Ramaphosa a valuable opportunity to reshape party structures and policies. In a further blow to the radicals, Mr Zuma risks being jailed either for defying a Constitutional Court order to appear before an inquiry into state capture (being led by the deputy chief justice, Raymond Zondo) or on long-standing corruption charges linked to an arms deal: a formal trial started on May 26th with Mr Zuma pleading not guilty.
Relations between the ANC's left and centre are more complex, but the impact of recession and the state's financial and technical capacity constraints mean that the left is now resigned to a more prominent role for the private sector. Resistance to wage restraint will be harder to overcome, but heavy job losses are inevitably weakening trade union influence, obliging the unions to compromise in many cases. Policy debates will continue, but Mr Ramaphosa's tighter grip on the ANC improves the outlook for the key structural reforms needed to bolster economic growth and job creation.
Outlook for 2021-25: Election watch The next major political event is the ANC's five-yearly National General Council (NGC)-a policy implementation review-which will give a clearer indication of the balance of forces in the party and the extent of Mr Ramaphosa's control. After being delayed by more than a year by the pandemic, the NGC's timing is still uncertain, although The Economist Intelligence Unit expects it to take place before the next five-yearly municipal elections on October 27th 2021. The nationwide ballot will give voters the first chance to judge the government's pandemic response and will be a test of Mr Ramaphosa's and the ANC's popularity. The party would be broadly satisfied by an ANC voting share in the 55-60% range in 2021 (compared with 57.5% in the 2019 general election) but a drop to the 50-55% range could see Mr Ramaphosa facing a leadership challenge at the ANC's next electoral summit in December 2022. We expect the ANC, under Mr Ramaphosa, to retain power at the next general election (in 2024), but with a smaller majority than in 2019. The implementation of the new Political Party Funding Act in April 2021 will strengthen transparency.
Outlook for 2021-25: International relations South Africa-the most advanced economy in Africa and a major business hub-will remain deeply engaged in the continent, particularly in Southern and Central/East Africa. Despite a challenging environment, South Africa will continue to attract international companies, including from the US, Europe and Asia, owing to strong institutions, sound banks and its role as the continental gateway. South Africa's commercial involvement in other African markets will remain broad-based, covering mining, banking, telecommunications, retail and hospitality. The pandemic is causing temporary disruption to regional relations because of border closures and flight bans, aggravated by ongoing infections, but regional access for South African-based firms will improve in 2021, helped by vaccine rollouts.
Outlook for 2021-25: Policy trends The most immediate policy challenge facing the government is to revive the economy after a pandemic-induced contraction in 2020, which inflicted lasting damage on many households and firms. Containment measures, initially tight, were loosened to level one, the most relaxed, on March 1st-after a deadly second wave of infection in December/January faded-but a rise in new cases and deaths in May and into June underlines the risk of shifting restrictions to level three. Vaccination rollout is gaining momentum since an official launch on May 17th, which could soften a third-wave impact on health and economic activity, although vaccine supply bottlenecks mean that the target of inoculating all adults by end-2021 will be hard to meet, leaving the outlook uncertain.
The government will attempt to engineer a growth rebound in 2021-25, via targeted measures and deeper structural reforms, although the scope for additional monetary and fiscal intervention is limited. With the benchmark interest rate at a record low of 3.5%, there is little prospect of further cuts, and several years of heavy spending and rising budget deficits preclude a broad-based fiscal stimulus. Even before the pandemic South Africa was trapped in a low-growth trajectory-not for the want of pro-growth plans but because of policy fudges between left-wing and pro-business factions, and weak implementation. The pandemic, by exposing underlying fault lines (such as widespread poverty and inequality) and highlighting the need for urgent action, will potentially be a catalyst for deeper and more rapid structural reforms, including a greater role for the private sector.
Devised in consultation with business and organised labour, an economic recovery and reconstruction plan will focus on job creation-via large-scale public works programmes-and infrastructure investment. The plan aims to channel R100bn (US$6.8bn) over ten years into an infrastructure fund with the aim of attracting a ten-times greater sum from the private sector via public-private partnerships. Target projects range from housing to network infrastructure, and include allowing private participation in the rail network. Facilitating solely private initiatives in numerous sectors (such as mining) via regulatory loosening is another pivotal aim, but the slow pace of reform and ongoing uncertainties in key areas, such as land expropriation, will weigh on business confidence.
Other critical policy objectives are restoring energy security by adding new capacity (mostly solar and wind) from independent power producers, alongside the planned auction of new broadband spectrum in 2021, which will boost communication and digitalisation. Despite these encouraging signs, spectrum allocation is being delayed by a legal dispute, and electricity supply will remain tight, leading to a high risk of load-shedding (power cuts) and constraining the growth rebound, before the situation improves in 2023. The restructuring of dysfunctional parastatal enterprises, especially Eskom, the heavily indebted power firm, is a central, interlinked objective. Implementation remains a challenge, but the political will to act is now stronger. Commitments to the IMF in return for a rapid financing instrument in 2020 will add impetus to reforms in the face of resistance from vested interests.
Outlook for 2021-25: Fiscal policy A surge in the budget deficit to about 11% of GDP in fiscal year 2020/21 (April-March) reflects heavy revenue losses and higher spending during the pandemic and recession. The 2020/21 outcome was, nonetheless, smaller than the 15.7% of GDP shortfall predicted by the Treasury last October, because of a belated revenue boost from higher commodity prices, alongside gains from an overhaul of the South African Revenue Service (the tax agency). The brighter revenue outlook means that planned tax increases in 2021/22 were put on hold and a vaccine rollout costing an initial R9bn (US$620m) over two years is fully funded. The 2021/22 budget, unveiled in February, outlines a path of medium-term fiscal consolidation premised on real-term cuts in the public-sector wage bill. We expect the shortfall as a percentage of GDP to ebb to 9.4% in 2021/22 and 7.7% in 2022/23, before easing to 3.5% in 2025/26. The biggest risks to fiscal consolidation are a fightback by labour unions against wage restraint (via a combination of legal action, political pressure and possible strikes) and the heavy debt burdens of parastatal enterprises.
After surging to about 78% of GDP in 2020/21 because of higher borrowing and a recession, the public debt burden will rise more slowly as fiscal revenue recovers, peaking at about 87.4% of GDP in 2024/25, before edging lower. Fiscal consolidation will reduce South Africa's risk of debt distress, as will the government's recourse to deep and liquid domestic capital markets to finance most of the budget shortfalls. Debt-servicing costs will continue rising, however, leaving limited room for slippage on either the spending or the revenue fronts. A failure to meet debt targets could oblige South Africa to undertake a formal IMF programme with strict conditions attached.
Outlook for 2021-25: Monetary policy Policy accommodation during the 2020 pandemic crisis will give way to a normalisation process in 2022, with interest rates edging higher as the economy begins to recover. The South African Reserve Bank (SARB, the central bank) cut the benchmark interest rate (repo rate) five times in 2020, by a cumulative 300 basis points to 3.5%, to help to shield the economy from the pandemic, and has kept the rate on hold in 2021 to date (most recently in May). With a further cut unlikely, the SARB's next rate move will be upwards, possibly in late 2021 but probably in early 2022, as real GDP resumes growing and inflation edges higher. Additional small increases will follow in 2023-25, broadly tracking US trends.
Outlook for 2021-25: Economic growth Following a steep contraction of 7% in 2020 because of the pandemic impact, we now expect real GDP to grow by 3% in 2021 (revised from 2.4%), informed by a mildly better first-quarter outcome than expected, but structural constraints will preclude a faster rebound. Growth in 2021 will be supported by an improved outlook for vaccine provision (after the government agreed contracts with Johnson & Johnson and Pfizer), higher commodity prices, stronger export demand, another good farm season and the maintenance of low interest rates. Several factors will dampen the growth rebound in 2021, however, including a 3.2% year-on-year contraction in the first quarter (because of the pre-pandemic baseline), electricity supply constraints, weak tourism and hospitality, and elevated unemployment, which will sap aggregate demand. The jobless rate edged up to a new record of 32.6% in January-March. Other downside risks include public-sector strikes in response to a pay freeze, and a third wave of Covid-19 during the southern hemisphere winter (June-August), which would stifle the pace of recovery.
Given that the 2021 rebound largely reflects a very weak baseline in 2020, we expect growth to edge lower again to 2.4% in 2022. The economy will benefit from stronger private investment in response to favourable policy initiatives (such as moves to facilitate public-private partnerships) and from a gradual relaxation of power supply constraints, although most additions to generating capacity will not come on stream until the second half of 2022 at the earliest. Other hurdles to growth in 2022 will be a global slowdown (after a 2021 rebound), persistently high unemployment and still-fragile tourism. Our growth forecast strengthens to 2.8% a year on average in 2023-25, underpinned by long-delayed reforms (such as parastatal restructuring) and the spread of digital technology, but the global backdrop will remain subdued in terms of economic growth and trade flows.
Outlook for 2021-25: Inflation After dipping to a multi-year low of 3.2% in 2020, owing to recession, cheaper imported oil and a bumper food harvest, inflation will rise to 4% in 2021 (revised from 3.7%), but will remain comfortably within the SARB's 3-6% target range. The primary sources of inflation in 2021 will be higher oil prices and costlier electricity tariffs, although the prospect of a second consecutive bumper harvest in the 2020/21 season will partly offset higher global food prices. Other factors curbing inflation are rand appreciation in 2021, weak aggregate demand (owing to unemployment and income losses), spare industrial capacity and strong retail competition. We expect inflation to quicken to an average of 4.5% a year in 2022-25, spurred by a modest revival in GDP growth, but the level will stay within the SARB's target range, temporary breaches aside.
Outlook for 2021-25: Exchange rates Stronger commodity prices and global liquidity injections will support the rand in 2021, as shown by a 22.7% year-on-year appreciation of the currency to R14.06:US$1 in May, its strongest level for almost two years. Being commodity-dependent, widely traded and an emerging-market proxy, the rand will benefit from a positive global backdrop, but it remains vulnerable to any adverse shifts in global sentiment and to negative domestic developments. We see the rand weakening from current levels, in view of South Africa's large fiscal deficit and sluggish growth outlook-alongside potential global tensions-ending 2021 at R14.91:US$1 (revised from R16.16:US$1). On an annual average basis, we forecast strengthening to R14.43:US$1 in 2021 (revised from R15.39:US$1) as markets normalise after disruption in 2020. The rand will remain volatile, often experiencing large daily movements in response to shifting sentiment, although South Africa's modest external debt stock and healthy foreign-exchange reserves are protective. Our forecast assumes gradual depreciation from 2022 onwards, with the rand slipping to R17.4:US$1 at end-2025, although the pace of decline will be close to the inflation rate, implying a relatively stable real effective exchange rate.
Outlook for 2021-25: External sector The impact of the pandemic on the external accounts will persist in 2021, and we expect another rare current-account surplus and a net contribution to GDP growth. The pandemic led to a much steeper fall in imports than in exports in 2020, generating a large merchandise trade surplus, which offset the perennial deficit on invisible trade to produce a current-account surplus of 2.2% of GDP. In 2021 a healthy increase in export earnings (underpinned by higher commodity prices) will be surpassed by a rebound in imports as the economy recovers (and oil prices rise), reducing both the merchandise trade surplus and the current-account surplus (to 1.5% of GDP). Our forecast for 2022-25 envisages a return to a current-account deficit, with the shortfall averaging 2.4% of GDP a year, as the invisible trade deficit (underpinned by income outflows to foreign investors) surpasses the merchandise trade surplus. The current-account deficit will be smaller than pre-pandemic levels but will leave South Africa reliant on financial inflows to plug the gap.
Foreign direct investment inflows will recover from 2021, helped by structural reforms to boost public-private partnerships, including private investment in parastatal enterprises. We expect inflows of US$5.2bn a year on average (just under 10% of gross financing needs). South Africa will remain a key base for multinational companies with pan-African operations by offering a range of services, including banking, capital-raising and trade-related functions.

Data sources and definitions The sources for global and domestic data refer to historic data; the source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data US & OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US & OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: Dated Brent Blend
Non-oil commodity prices: IMF, IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Dollar effective exchange rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data Trade by country: IMF, Direction of Trade Statistics
Population: Based on UN data for both the historical and the forecast periods
Balance of payments: IMF, IFS
Inflation: Statistics South Africa. Based on CPIX (consumer price inflation less mortgage costs)
Exchange rate: IMF, IFS; principal rate expressed as R:US$
Real effective exchange rate index: based on consumer price index; trade partner weighted index with base period 2000=100
Interest rate: IMF, IFS; average lending rate
US$ GDP: SARB, Quarterly Bulletin; in current prices converted from local currency at annual average market exchange rate
GDP per head: US$ GDP divided by population
Foreign direct investment: IMF, IFS; UNCTAD, World Investment Report
Total external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; sum of long-term debt, short-term debt and IMF credits
Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics, year-end medium- and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding, with an original maturity in excess of one year
Short-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end debt outstanding, with an original maturity of less than one year
Total debt service: principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges paid against total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Interest payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations IFS: International Financial Statistics
IMF: International Monetary Fund
OECD: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
SARB: South African Reserve Bank
UNCTAD: UN Conference on Trade and Development

Abstract: The Bank of England (BoE, the central bank) has cut its policy interest rate to an historic low of 0.1% and authorised £450bn (US$620bn) in bond purchases to keep government borrowing costs low. Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+United+Kingdom&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+United+Kingdom+June+2021+Updater&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2021-06-07&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+United+Kingdom&amp;rft.issn=09669280&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: - At a general election on December 12th 2019 the Conservative Party, under the prime minister, Boris Johnson, won an emphatic 80-seat majority. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the government to serve its full term.
- On January 1st 2021 the UK left the EU's single market and customs union, having reached a free-trade agreement, the EU-UK Trade and Co-operation Agreement (TCA), in December. Although this provides for no tariffs and no quotas, its provisions are significantly less comprehensive than EU membership and have created substantial non-tariff barriers.
- The UK-EU relationship will continue to evolve, with many issues being deferred. Relations may come under greater strain if the UK pursues a different regulatory course, which would entail additional future tariffs. Northern Ireland is a flashpoint; the EU is pursuing legal action against the UK's extension of grace periods on customs checks for goods travelling across the Irish Sea, and discontent among Unionist communities erupted into rioting in April.
- The coronavirus pandemic led to the suspension of all non-essential retail activities in March 2020. After a relaxation in the summer, restrictions were tightened from October, with two further lockdowns, the latter of which is only now being relaxed. Real GDP declined by 9.9% in 2020. We expect it to rebound by 5.8% in 2021 and 5.5% in 2022, reaching pre-crisis levels in the latter year.
- The Treasury has committed to a series of coronavirus-related support schemes for business, and a furlough scheme to pay 80% of workers' wages. In response to a rise in coronavirus cases in autumn 2020, these schemes have been extended to autumn 2021. We forecast this to cause public debt to peak at over 108% of GDP in 2021. The government has announced a rise in corporation tax from 2023, and more tax rises are probably necessary to stabilise debt as a percentage of GDP by 2025, which we expect it to do (at roughly 107% of GDP).
- The Bank of England (BoE, the central bank) has cut its policy interest rate to an historic low of 0.1% and authorised £450bn (US$620bn) in bond purchases to keep government borrowing costs low. It has also approved short-term monetary financing of government spending, given the economic costs of the counter-crisis measures. We expect interest rates to stay close to zero until 2022 even though inflation will exceed the BoE's 2% target in 2021 and 2022.

- The UK's business environment score rises slightly in the forecast period (2021-25) as Brexit- and pandemic-related uncertainty dissipates. The UK's global ranking remains constant, but its regional ranking rises by one place. Brexit has worsened the UK's terms of trade, but the country's strengths-a pro-business policy stance, a welcoming attitude to foreign investment, and flexible labour and product markets-will continue.

Country forecast overview: United Kingdom's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2021-22: Extraordinary state support for coronavirus-affected businesses. A 130% "super-deduction" on capital investment.
2023-25: Continued elevated state intervention in investment and innovation. New state aid rules implemented.
Policy towards foreign investment 2021-22: Continued openness to investment, although increased scrutiny in sectors considered sensitive to national security.
2023-25: Infrastructure plans offer investment opportunities. Possible changes in tax policies to bolster inward investment.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2021-22: Increased trade barriers with EU. New Northern Ireland protocol implemented. Negotiations continue with third countries. Expected decline in UK-EU crossborder trade. Bounce-back in global trade following pandemic.
2023-25: Continued UK-EU negotiations probable. New trade agreements with other countries, including potential accession to Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) trade bloc.
Taxes 2021-22: Tax holidays and deferments throughout the coronavirus crisis. Changes to the value-added tax (VAT) framework.
2023-25: Corporation tax increase from 19% to 25%. Additional tax rises, such as equalisation of self-employed and regular income taxes, likely to fund public spending and investment.
Financing 2021-22: Monetary policy remains highly accommodative, with Bank of England (central bank) asset purchases continuing. Loss of "passporting" rights and restrictions on EU services trade. Slow progress in establishing equivalence with the EU.
2023-25: Modest decline in City of London's status. Steady growth in alternative forms of debt financing.
The labour market 2021-22: Increased unemployment as furlough scheme expires. Pandemic-related departure of expatriates and sharp drop in immigration from EU owing to end to free movement of labour. Increased immigration from Hong Kong.
2023-25: Greater emphasis on skills-based migration from outside EU may risk labour shortages in low-skilled occupations.
Infrastructure 2021-22: Modest rise in spending on housing, roads and digital infrastructure. Crossrail service in London begins operation in 2022.
2023-25: Increased infrastructure investment, emphasis on "levelling up" regional infrastructure and competitiveness.
Technological readiness 2021-22: High e-commerce penetration and strong research base, but research and development (R&D) spending remains below EU average. Continued high threat from cybercrime and cyber-espionage.
2023-25: Modest rise in public R&D spending. Development of state "blue skies" fund.

Background: The end of the second world war coincided with the decline of the UK as an imperial power. Residual links with former colonial territories, close relations with the US and a separate sense of identity delayed UK membership of the European Community (now the EU) until 1973. Successive governments resisted closer EU integration. Following a 2016 referendum on EU membership, the UK left the EU single market and customs union in January 2021. The future contours of the UK's relationship with the EU are in flux, but a diminution of UK influence in the region appears to be inevitable.
Political structure: The UK is a constitutional monarchy. The head of state is Queen Elizabeth II. Parliament has an elected House of Commons (the lower house, 650 seats) and a non-elected House of Lords (the upper house, non-fixed membership of about 800). The snap general election in December 2019 produced a majority government for the centre-right Conservative Party, which won 365 seats. The main opposition Labour Party won 202 seats, with smaller parties winning the remaining 83. This government is likely to serve out its full term until the next scheduled election, in 2024.
Policy issues: The coronavirus outbreak has dominated UK politics since March 2020. The government embarked on massive fiscal expansion to support workers and businesses affected by the virus and containment measures, while the Bank of England (the central bank) has cut interest rates to record lows, which are likely to persist into 2022. The government expects to begin fiscal consolidation in 2022, although headline debt will remain high as a percentage of GDP. Supporting industries affected by increased Brexit-related trade frictions will dominate UK policymaking. Maintaining competitiveness in this environment will force policymakers to address structural deficiencies such as low productivity.
Taxation: The headline rate of corporation tax has been reduced steadily, from 28% in 2010 to 19% since April 2018. There are three bands of personal income tax, set at 20%, 40% and 45% (the 45% rate came into effect in April 2013, replacing the 50% rate introduced in 2010). The standard rate of value-added tax (VAT) is 20% (raised from 17.5% in 2011). Excise duties on tobacco and alcohol are among the highest in Europe.
Foreign trade: In 2020 exports of goods totalled US$399bn and imports amounted to US$548bn, resulting in a trade deficit of US$149bn. The services surplus expanded to US$138bn. The overall current-account deficit widened in absolute terms, from US$87.6bn in 2019 to US$95.4bn, widening as a share of GDP, from 3.1% to 3.5%.

Outlook for 2021-25: Political stability At the general election on December 12th 2019, the Conservative Party, under the prime minister, Boris Johnson, won an 80-seat majority. On January 31st 2020 Mr Johnson fulfilled his campaign promise to take the UK out of the EU, ending 47 years of EU membership. On January 1st 2021 the UK left the EU's single market and customs union after negotiating a free-trade agreement. The government is currently managing the implementation of a new trading relationship with the EU while addressing the fallout from the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic. Despite the challenges posed by these two issues, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the government to last a full term.
The spread of the coronavirus in early 2020 put the government on a crisis-management footing. Since March 2020 the government has implemented three lockdowns in England, with many non-essential businesses being closed. Devolved administrations in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland enacted similar restrictions during these periods. The easing of the third lockdown is under way, with all remaining restrictions scheduled to be lifted on June 21st. There is a risk that this may be delayed if the more contagious Delta variant of the virus, which was first identified in India and is now the dominant strain in the UK, results in an increase in hospitalisations and deaths. The government has accelerated its vaccination programme, which has achieved among the highest coverage rates in the world; more than 75% of the adult population had received their first vaccine dose and more than 50% their second as of June 4th.
Brexit and the pandemic have increased the medium-term risk to the integrity of the UK. Nicola Sturgeon, the leader of the Scottish National Party (SNP), has argued that Brexit represents a material change in the relationship between Scotland and the UK since the 2014 referendum on Scottish independence, in which a majority favoured the continuation of the union. Support for Scottish independence spiked during the initial phase of the pandemic, as Scottish voters viewed their devolved government's response as more effective than that of the UK government. This has ebbed since the vaccination campaign began; recent opinion polls show a lead for support for the union, although within the margin of error.
The SNP, with the support of the pro-independence Scottish Green Party, has held a majority in the Scottish Parliament since 2016. It made modest gains in the May 2021 elections, which Ms Sturgeon claims give her a mandate to pursue a second referendum. However, we do not believe that these gains will produce sufficient political pressure to force the UK government to grant a referendum in this parliamentary term. Even if were to do so, the poll would take several years to organise. Furthermore, divisions within pro-independence parties may undermine the unity of the movement. We therefore believe that there are significant obstacles to Scotland becoming independent and do not expect it to happen during the 2021-25 forecast period.
Brexit has inflamed tensions in Northern Ireland. The UK and the EU agreed to a separate protocol for Northern Ireland to avoid border checks with the Republic of Ireland. Under this agreement, Northern Ireland remains within a regulatory union with the EU for most goods. Although it will stay in the UK customs and value-added tax (VAT) areas, customs and VAT checks are to be conducted by the UK on the EU's behalf at ports in the Irish Sea for goods bound for the EU. This requires the construction and implementation of checkpoints and border infrastructure between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK for all goods deemed by a UK-EU joint committee to be "at risk" of passing into the EU.
This arrangement has been difficult to implement, and is disliked by Unionist Northern Irish politicians for ostensibly creating a border between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK. Rioting broke out in Northern Ireland on April 2nd and persisted for over a week. These protests originated among Unionist communities partly in opposition to the Irish Sea border checks. The Unionist first minister of Northern Ireland was forced to resign, and has been replaced by a more fervently anti-protocol politician. The UK and the EU have intensified talks around how to implement the Northern Ireland protocol, but it is likely to remain a source of UK-EU friction. Despite these tensions, we expect the protocol to remain in place, given the commitments by both sides not to re-create a hard customs border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland, and the lack of a viable alternative. However, tensions will remain elevated, and there is a high risk of further violence.
Outlook for 2021-25: Election watch Under the Fixed-term Parliaments Act (FTPA), the next general election is scheduled for May 2nd 2024. The government has introduced a bill to repeal the FTPA. However, even once this is passed, a general election must be called within five years of the preceding one; they are usually held in May, to coincide with local elections. There is a risk of an early election in 2023; UK governments have often taken advantage of strong economic performance in the penultimate year of a parliament to consolidate their gains, rather than waiting for the parliament to expire.
During the pandemic, the Conservative Party's lead in opinion polls over the opposition Labour Party dropped from more than 20 percentage points at the outbreak of the crisis to a near-tie after several scandals and rapid policy reversals reduced public confidence in the government. Since the success of the vaccine rollout, the Conservatives' polling position has improved to a double-digit margin ahead of Labour, which may persist if the government is seen to manage the recovery well. Local elections on May 6th saw the Conservatives make gains on local councils, consistent with this level of national polling lead.
Outlook for 2021-25: International relations The EU-UK Trade and Co-operation Agreement (TCA), which was reached on December 24th 2020, is a free-trade agreement that succeeds the UK's membership of the EU single market and customs union, following its exit from EU institutions on January 1st 2021. The TCA provides for zero-tariff, zero-quota trade between the UK and EU, at least in the first instance. However, leaving the single market and customs union has created a variety of non-tariff trade barriers in the forms of border checks and product certifications. The agreement also provides a mechanism whereby if the divergence in regulations on labour, the environment or state aid becomes sufficiently great, the other side can implement retaliatory tariffs to compensate, subject to an arbitration period. The regulatory and tariff regimes may therefore drift apart over time. The TCA leaves several areas unsettled. UK-EU negotiations are ongoing over the UK receiving designations of equivalence on financial services, allowing for greater access to the EU market; and a draft finding of "adequacy" on the UK's data standards, which would allow the free flow of data. The UK has applied to rejoin the Lugano convention, which allows legal judgments to be enforced across borders, but this is also opposed by several EU member states.
The UK government has stated its intention to be outward looking, pursuing a "Global Britain" strategy, and in March it unveiled an updated defence and security policy outlining a strategy of greater engagement in Asia, in addition to continued engagement in the Atlantic. The UK holds the presidency of the G7 group of nations in 2021 and will host the UN Climate Change Conference (COP26) in Glasgow in November. It intends to use these platforms to take an enhanced role in global climate change policy. On trade, the UK has achieved continuity agreements with most countries that had agreements with the EU, and has applied to join the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), a trade bloc of 11 Pacific nations.
Outlook for 2021-25: Policy trends Even before the pandemic, the UK faced significant economic policy challenges, including low public investment, wide regional disparities, high housing costs and chronically low productivity growth. However, the scale of the disruption caused by the virus is likely to dominate the government's policy focus at least until GDP returns to its pre-crisis level, which we forecast will occur in 2022.
Since becoming the Conservative Party leader and prime minister, Mr Johnson has advocated greater public-sector investment, including in infrastructure, and additional current spending on the National Health Service, education and the police. The government has also reformed the UK's immigration system to emphasise skilled labour. Long-term social care is an area of health spending that Mr Johnson's manifesto pledged to address, alongside significant investment in green and renewable energy as part of a green recovery plan, although details for both remain vague. The government is also attempting to encourage public and private investment to address the UK's chronic low productivity, most prominently in a two-year tax "super-deduction" allowing companies to write off tax up to 130% of the value of their capital investment in 2021-23, as well as expanding the scope of public borrowing for investment from 2% of GDP to 3%. These initiatives are likely to yield modest benefits, but the UK's deficits in investment and productivity are long-standing issues and will not be reversed within a single parliamentary term.
Outlook for 2021-25: Fiscal policy At the outbreak of the pandemic, the government enforced nationwide shutdowns and developed financial support packages to help workers and businesses. These included government-backstopped loans; several business tax deferments and holidays; targeted aid to the worst-affected sectors, such as travel and retail; and wage support schemes for salaried and self-employed workers. In its March budget, the government committed to extending most pandemic support measures into the autumn of 2021, only completely phasing them out by March 2022. We expect that this will lead to a fiscal deficit of 11.5% of GDP in 2021, with the debt/GDP ratio peaking at over 108%.
The budget also committed to greater fiscal consolidation, with a planned increase in corporation tax from 19% to 25% in 2023. However, this budget assumes highly ambitious increases in productivity growth and minimal increases in health, education and welfare spending from pre-pandemic levels after 2022; this is unlikely, given the government's campaign promises of greater spending and investment. We therefore expect further tax increases during the forecast period, with debt declining only marginally, to 107% of GDP, and stabilising at that level in 2022-25.
Outlook for 2021-25: Monetary policy On March 19th 2020 the Bank of England (BoE, the central bank) cut its main rate to 0.1%-its lowest ever level. It also resumed its quantitative easing programme, committing to £450bn (US$620bn) in asset purchases, which was expanded twice more in 2020, reaching a total of £895bn. From April 2020 until the end of that year, the BoE allowed the government access to its overdraft account, the so-called Ways and Means facility, to directly finance day-to-day costs, although this facility was not tapped.
Despite a recent uptick in inflation, we do not expect the BoE to raise rates before mid-2022. The BoE has expressed a view that inflation stemming from the reopening of the economy is likely to be transitory. A premature tightening would pose significant risks to the debt sustainability of UK corporates that have borrowed heavily during the pandemic and also the UK government.
Outlook for 2021-25: Economic growth The pandemic and ensuing public health measures caused a severe economic contraction in 2020, with real GDP shrinking by 9.9%. The most recent lockdown resulted in a contraction of 1.5% in the first quarter of 2021. A significant bounce-back is likely from the second quarter as restrictions are lifted and government incentives to boost investment kick in; we expect growth of 5.8% in 2021 as a whole. We forecast further catch-up growth of 5.5% in 2022, which looks set to be the first full year without social-distancing restrictions; GDP should return to its pre-crisis level during the first half of 2022. Most of the headline growth will stem from favourable year-on-year comparisons with the 2020-21 lockdowns as shut-down activities restart, rather than from robust new economic activity. In 2023-25 we expect the rate of expansion to slow, averaging 1.7% per year, as taxes rise and catch-up growth abates.
Unemployment rose in 2020 as the pandemic led to business failures and lay-offs. The spike in unemployment was modest, however, with an average rate of 4.5% in 2020, owing to the government's furlough scheme. We expect the rate to average 5.2% in 2021 as the scheme is withdrawn. Unemployment will decline thereafter, reaching 4% in 2024-25.
Gross capital formation declined sharply in 2020 as the highly uncertain global business environment depressed investment. We expect a significant bounce-back in investment growth in 2021-22, driven in part by the government's investment tax super-deduction, as well as by a more stable post-pandemic and post-Brexit investment environment. Investment growth should stabilise from 2023 until the end of the forecast period.
Export and import growth turned sharply negative in 2020 as global demand collapsed and coronavirus-related travel restrictions persisted. We expect growth to bounce back in 2021-22, but Brexit-related disruption will restrict the pace of expansion.
Outlook for 2021-25: Inflation Inflation declined sharply in 2020, to an average of only 1%, as the pandemic depressed demand. Prices have begun to rebound sharply in 2021, owing to increased consumer spending, as well as supply constraints both in the domestic market and internationally, which we expect to drive up inflation to an average of 3% in 2021 and 2.6% in 2022. From 2023 inflation will decline to a more modest level as pent-up demand is exhausted, stabilising at 1.8% by 2025.
Outlook for 2021-25: Exchange rates The value of sterling has been volatile in recent years owing to political uncertainty related to Brexit and the pandemic, as well as the UK's large current-account deficit, which requires significant international capital investment to support the currency. Sterling has strengthened against the US dollar in late 2020 and early 2021 as the uncertainty around a potential no-deal Brexit ended and a flight to safety in dollar liquidity gradually unwound, with sterling reaching US$1.42:£1 in June 2021. Sterling has similarly begun to appreciate against the euro in 2021 as Brexit uncertainty dissipates and the UK economy unlocks more rapidly.
Sterling should continue to appreciate against the euro this year, rising from EUR1.08:£1 at end-2020 to EUR1.19:£1 by end-2021. We expect it to stabilise against the euro from mid-2022, averaging EUR1:21:£1 in 2022-25; both currencies will appreciate modestly against the dollar during this period as demand for the safe-haven currency decreases, with sterling reaching US$1.46:£1 by end-2025.
Outlook for 2021-25: External sector The coronavirus outbreak caused a sharp fall in global trade as demand declined, travel was disrupted and global supply chains were compromised by national lockdowns. The UK was not exempt from this, with both imports and exports declining sharply in 2020. From 2021 we expect trade to rebound, although this will primarily be the result of a recovery from the 2020 base year, and we expect Brexit to weigh on exports (as well as imports, but to a lesser extent). Most catch-up growth in trade, particularly in exports, will be likely to take place in 2022 as global markets fully unlock and UK firms become more experienced in exporting under new trading rules. The UK has run a persistent current-account deficit since 1985. We expect the deficit to widen from 3.5% of GDP in 2020 to 4.5% of GDP in 2021 as the export sector is weakened by worse terms of trade with the EU, before stabilising thereafter.

Full text: - Promises by the government to tackle corruption, improve stability and boost living standards will largely not be fulfilled. The economic scar left by a recession in 2020 will be identifiable in high levels of unemployment (at 33% by end-2020), lower GDP per capita in US dollar purchasing power parity terms, and a breakdown of law and order in many regions as widespread poverty encourages the expansion of criminal gangs and terror groups. The government has a miniscule footprint in many parts of Nigeria, which has become an unsustainable model. Non-oil tax rises are unavoidable, but the revenue/GDP ratio will remain among the world's lowest, in turn anchoring public investment and the provision of basic services. High levels of unemployment will combine with the country's ethnic and religious divisions to ignite outbreaks of serious violence. Nonetheless, Nigeria has a high tolerance for political instability, mainly because much of it is localised and away from key cities. There is little significant threat to the government's position outside of election seasons.

Nigeria--highlights: Business environment outlook                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
4.36 4.03 74 78 12 14
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.

- The business environment in Nigeria is expected to deteriorate during the forecast period (2021-25), compared with the previous five years. Systemic problems in infrastructure and the labour market mean that Nigeria remains near the bottom of the global business environment rankings for 2021-25, at 78th out of the 82 countries assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit. On a regional basis, Nigeria is ranked 14th out of 17 countries for 2021-25, down from 12th in 2016-20 as the country stalls behind emerging-market peers. Efforts to create a more attractive business environment are not expected to deliver lasting results, owing to parliamentary divisions (which reflect societal divisions more widely); corruption; a legacy of market distortions, which are too entrenched and widespread to be undone without unpalatable price corrections; and the absence of effective government institutions and a lack of civil service capacity.

Exchange rate N:US$ (av) 356.3 409.7 422.5 423.7 424.3 458.1

- We expect real GDP to return to growth in 2021, but only, marginally given high inflation, limited credit growth, foreign-exchange illiquidity and rampant instability. High inflation is the product of interventionist policies by the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN), such as currency restrictions, which has untethered price expectations. This will need to be dealt with in later years by means of tightening, preventing monetary policy from propelling faster growth, and the government will need to repair the fiscal damage wrought by the downturn in 2020. Tax hikes are likely, which will fall mainly on consumers as the government attempts to lure foreign investment into the oil sector. In the medium term we do expect some improvement in macroeconomic conditions, predicated on higher oil prices and eventual exchange-rate stability controlling inflation.

- At an average of 2.5% a year in 2021-25, Nigeria's population growth rate will remain high enough to retain a relatively stable age profile. However, the formal economy will not grow quickly enough to provide the employment needed to absorb 3.1% annual growth in the working-age population. This will limit the population dividend and jeopardise attempts to reduce poverty and instability.

Household consumption per head (US$) 1,460 1,390 1,480 1,550 1,630 1,570

- Nigeria remains an important market for many multinationals because of its abundant natural resources and the size of its population (the largest in Africa), despite the very low level of income on average. In absolute terms, Nigeria has more people in extreme poverty than any other country in the world. However, the wealthy elite and middle class-concentrated in major cities such as Lagos-have typically comprised important submarkets. Nigeria has the potential to be a profitable market for multinational companies that know how to operate in its complex and chaotic regulatory environment and can overcome the logistical difficulties posed by the almost non-existent infrastructure.

Nigeria--highlights: Long-term outlook   2021-30 2031-50 2021-50

- We expect Nigeria's real GDP growth rate to be quicker in 2031-50 than in 2020-30, as growth over the next ten years will be dragged down by recession in 2020 (the deepest since the 1980s) and a slow recovery in 2021. However, reforms to improve the business environment and increase investor confidence are unlikely to be sufficient to promote fundamental diversification of the economy, meaning that Nigeria will remain dependent on the oil and gas sector over the long term, exposing Nigeria to the pursuit of decarbonisation strategies by oil majors.

Background: Nigeria gained independence in 1960, and multiparty democracy was restored in 1999 after a protracted period of military rule. The first two presidential elections (in 1999 and 2003) were both won by a former military ruler turned civilian politician, Olusegun Obasanjo. Mr Obasanjo was unable to change the constitution to allow him to serve a third term in office, so in the 2007 election power passed to his handpicked successor, Umaru Yar'Adua. After Mr Yar'Adua's death in May 2010, his vice-president, Goodluck Jonathan, assumed the presidency and went on to win the 2011 presidential election. Mr Jonathan was defeated by Muhammadu Buhari in 2015, and Mr Buhari secured a second term in early 2019.
Political structure: Under the constitution adopted in May 1999, a strong executive presidency appoints a Federal Executive Council, comprising government ministers and ministers of state from each of Nigeria's 36 states. The executive is accountable to the bicameral National Assembly. Political parties tend to lack clear ideologies; in practice, personal and ethnic ties predominate. The People's Democratic Party (Mr Jonathan's party) had historically been the predominant political force, but the merger in 2013 of three large opposition parties to form the All Progressives Congress gave them, with Mr Buhari at the helm, the reach that they needed to take power in 2015 and secure re-election in 2019.
Policy issues: Successive governments have sought to improve macroeconomic stability and develop the nation's dire infrastructure, with mixed results. The government is struggling to end insecurity in various parts of the country. These tensions are stoked by the underlying problems of poverty and unemployment. Management of the naira by the authorities is a contentious issue, with important subsidy programmes hinging on an overvalued official exchange rate.
Taxation: Corporate profits in most non-oil sectors are taxed at 30%. Planned changes to the tax system for the oil and gas sector have been repeatedly delayed, creating uncertainty, but are expected to be approved in 2021. Most revenue comes from the oil sector, with the total tax take very small as a share of GDP. As oil prices and output will be lower in 2021-25 than in 2010-14, and as the economy is now far larger, it is likely that amendments to consumer taxes will be made, specifically in value-added tax (VAT, currently 7.5%).
Foreign trade: Exports are dominated by oil, but in recent years (owing to limited productivity) earnings from crude have been insufficient to provide adequate foreign exchange for the rest of the economy. The non-oil export base has been rendered globally uncompetitive by massive infrastructure deficiencies and currency overvaluation.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance Muhammadu Buhari-a former military dictator turned civilian politician-first became president in 2015 and won a second four-year term in office in February 2019. Mr Buhari's ruling All Progressives Congress (APC) also retained a majority in both houses. The ascendancy to power of Mr Buhari and the APC in 2015 ended the period of domination of politics by the People's Democratic Party (PDP), which had begun at the start of civilian rule in 1999. The PDP's support is now concentrated in the country's south, with the north being a stronghold of Mr Buhari. The cabinet must contain representatives from each of Nigeria's 36 states, although very few are elected politicians. Governance by Mr Buhari and his ministers are scrutinised by an elected bicameral National Assembly. State governments enjoy considerable fiscal and policy autonomy under governors and elected state assemblies.
The cracks in the APC are expected to widen ahead of the 2023 election The APC is far from a united entity, however. It is an amalgamation of the three largest former opposition parties and a faction of a fourth (all with separate geographic and ethnic power bases, as well as varying ideologies), together with PDP defectors. Political appointments have therefore been based in numerous instances on distributing power among the APC's constituent elements rather than on merit. In late 2018 there were mass defections from the APC, with many crossing the floor to join the PDP. Although in a sense this refreshed the party for Mr Buhari's second term, dissension within the ranks is likely to re-emerge as the administration struggles to turn around Nigeria's struggling economy and as the next election approaches in 2023, for which a successor APC candidate needs to be selected for the presidency.
Political outlook: Political stability The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the president, Muhammadu Buhari, to remain in power until his second (and final) term expires in 2023, but the security situation in many parts of Nigeria is in a state of continuous deterioration. The president will be under immense pressure to stabilise Nigeria, but myriad security threats will prove unmanageable. The military and police are overstretched and unable to tackle simultaneous security crises. Emergencies will be triaged, with military resources deployed to whichever is considered the most pressing. Our belief is that Nigeria's federal government will focus on protecting "core" regions, such as the capital, Abuja, and other areas of economic or political importance, at the expense of the "periphery"-regions that have been mired in conflict for many years. This system is resilient enough to keep the government in power, but will leave many parts of Nigeria highly dysfunctional. Eventually, neglect of the periphery could reach an implosion point for overall stability, but we do not expect this within the 2021-25 forecast period. Nonetheless, the government will remain embroiled in a drawn-out conflict with two well-armed Islamist terrorist groups-Boko Haram and Islamic State of West Africa Province. In recent years both groups have been confined mainly to the north-east, but Boko Haram has expanded into central Nigeria, not far from Abuja. Although this agricultural "Middle Belt" has for several years been affected by violent conflict between farmers and herdsmen over land and water resources, it is newer territory for Boko Haram. Security challenges will also increase in other areas of the country, with unrest in the south-east attributed to Biafran secessionist groups and a broader surge in kidnappings by established groups such as Boko Haram and by organised criminal networks.
The security forces will be unable to fully stamp out these crises, and regional attempts to counter Boko Haram have been undermined by political crisis in Chad, which has typically provided a large number of troops for counter-terrorism initiatives but is now expected to become more inwardly focused, at least in the near-term. The north-east-particularly Borno state-will remain a low-level conflict zone, and banditry and kidnapping will remain pervasive. Other areas of the country could begin to resemble the highly insecure north-east as, in essence, "no-go" zones. Broader problems such police corruption and judicial impunity will remain unaddressed and compound the precarious security situation.
The near- to medium-term outlook is made more uncertain by the scars of recession in 2020 and by rising unemployment (at about 33%-one of the highest levels in the world) and poverty. Declining living standards arguably exacerbated and prolonged the protests over police brutality that broke out in cities across southern Nigeria in October 2020. The risk of fresh bouts of violent protest will be elevated in the near term given growing security problems and the still-weak economy. We currently do not expect this to jeopardise Mr Buhari's leadership; there have been rumours that junior elements of the military could be plotting a coup, but the president appears to retain solid support from the army. However, if major protests erupt over policies such as market reform, concessions would need to be made.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness The National Assembly is very slow at reviewing and approving new legislation, owing both to inefficiency and tensions between the executive and legislative branches of government, although crucial bills such as the national budget have been approved on time in recent years (in Mr Buhari's first term there were repeated delays). With the APC largely a coalition of convenience, competing ideologies and priorities nonetheless hinder the legislative process, as does tension over spending priorities between the federal government and powerful state governors. Vested political interests, inefficiency and corruption have also slowed reform in Nigeria for several decades, and these issues are unlikely to change in the forecast period.
Corruption will prove impossible to tackle comprehensively Nigeria has traditionally had a relatively strong economic team, led by able technocrats generally in favour of structural reform. This has remained the case during Mr Buhari's second term, with an Economic Advisory Council having been formed to tackle unemployment and poverty. However, as always, the team's capacity to translate good intentions into action will be hampered by Nigeria's complex political environment, entrenched rent-seeking interest groups, repeated public opposition to pro-market reform and a sclerotic administrative system. Despite some reforms of the civil service-including the removal of so-called ghost workers by the new administration-the public sector will remain overstaffed, highly bureaucratic and largely ineffective, given internal resistance to reform and a lack of desire among the leadership to upset deep-seated patronage networks. Mr Buhari has won two mandates centred on stamping it out. Nonetheless, in practice graft has proven hard to identify and eliminate. It exists as a daily phenomenon at low levels of the public sector, and in the past has pervaded to the top echelons of government. It is highly likely to still be prevalent, albeit well hidden from public view. The perception will remain that corruption is widespread and extends across state institutions. Economic reform is mainly restrained by public objection to free-market policies. Aversion to such reform fits into a wider narrative about governance; because the state's provision of basic services is both slim and often mishandled, many Nigerians are resistant to those contributions that the government does make to daily life-such as petrol subsidies-being rescinded.
A weak judiciary will undermine the fight against corruption Allegations of political score-settling are often levelled at the authorities in their anti-corruption efforts-something that will stoke acrimony and prevent greater co-operation across the political, legal and social spheres. The judicial system is still deeply undermined by corruption and underfunded. This has resulted in poor administration of justice, including long delays in the hearing of cases-aggravated in 2021 by a strike of court-workers demanding financial independence (as per the constitution) from state government, which they claim would avert the abuse of judicial funds. There are checks and balances on the executive, however, and the independence of institutions is broadly respected across the political spectrum.
Political outlook: Election watch The next national elections are due in 2023. In the most recent presidential election, in 2019, the candidates of both main parties were from the north, and custom dictates that the candidates in 2023 will be from the south. This should lead to an improvement on the abysmally low turnout in 2019 in the south, which is a stronghold of the main opposition party, the People's Democratic Party (PDP). Frustration with high prices, declining living standards and perpetual instability will be directed at the ruling party, the All Progressives Congress, giving the PDP a winning edge.
Political outlook: International relations Nigeria will remain a major player in Africa, given its size, but its domestic challenges tend to distract from internationalism and skew policy towards protectionism. Land borders that were closed to goods since late 2019 have reopened, but recent instability in Chad has meant increased restrictions, with only Nigerians allowed to enter the country from Chad. Nigeria's approach to encouraging regional trade will be minimalist, beyond its obligations under the African Continental Free Trade Agreement. The trade pact compels Nigeria to eliminate 97% of tariff lines over the next five to ten years. This deadline will not be met early, given high prices in Nigeria and declining external competitiveness for industries that could otherwise benefit from regional market access.
