a See Guide to the business rankings model at the end of this report. b Out of 10. c Out of 82 countries. d  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Nigeria's business environment will remain among the most challenging in the world over the next five years. Burgeoning market opportunities as the population expands will not be enough to prevent the country dropping by four places in the global rankings, to 78th (out of 82 countries) as the macroeconomic and policy environment deteriorates. Similarly, in the regional rankings Nigeria slips by two places, from 12th to 14th (out of 17 countries).
Efforts to create a significantly more attractive business environment in the country will continue to be hindered by the slow pace of market-oriented structural reforms, the ongoing problem of corruption, the absence of effective government institutions, the weak capacity of the civil service to implement changes and extremely poor infrastructure. In the face of public demand for action to address the socioeconomic devastation caused by the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic, policymakers will propose radical reforms to accelerate economic growth and arrest rising poverty. However, as evident in past attempts at structural reforms during previous periods of economic downturns, policy changes are mainly superficial with the system reverting to near status quo when economic growth picks up.
Efforts to diversify economy away from oil will require pro-business reforms Although during the 2021-25 forecast period Nigeria will continue to slowly recover from the economic downturn triggered by the global coronavirus outbreak, prices for its export and fiscal mainstay, oil, will remain well below the peaks seen in the early 2010s. Sections of the non-oil economy suspended by the government's Covid-19 containment measures will struggle to return to normality, let alone recapture the rapid growth achieved in the first decade of the 21st century. This will place ongoing strain on the economy. However, the situation has made the administration more mindful of the business environment, even if reforms fall well behind intentions or rhetoric. The Economic Sustainability Plan, approved by the cabinet in June 2020, includes bold undertakings to unify multiple foreign-exchange rates, deregulate petrol pricing and rationalise government agencies within 12 months. The context of a recession in 2020 had sharpened resolve for reform and was a rare opportunity to correct macroeconomic imbalances, but officials have since indicated that their idea of deregulation falls well short of giving free rein to market forces, while the prospects of a major downsizing of the bloated public sector are slim. The draft Medium Term National Development Plan (MTNDP) 2021-2025, which will replace the expired 2017-2020 development blueprint, the Economic Recovery and Growth Plan, is far less ambitious. For example, the plan does not outline plans for a more liberal currency regime (although there has been some progress towards unifying Nigeria's various exchange rates), and petrol subsidies have made a covert return. However, on the positive side, the MTNDP contains land reform, including title acquisition, registration and transferability to establish clear property rights. Developing a more effective and transparent land management system is crucial for increasing capital flows into the housing and agricultural sectors, which have been constrained by the abysmally low percentage of land in the country that are formally registered.


Enlarge this image.
Business environment outlook: Nigeria's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2021-22: Progress on market-oriented reforms remains slow, given various vested interests and inefficiencies. The upstream oil sector remains characterised by joint ventures between the state oil company and multinationals.
2023-25: Improving prospects for the non-oil private sector are slowed by a weak business environment.
Policy towards foreign investment 2021-22: In 2021 the government aims to enact a modified Petroleum Industry Bill with more generous fiscal terms for oil companies in the hope of recovering some of the lost or deferred investment, owing to the delay in implementing the oil sector reforms.
2023-25: Higher global oil prices and the resulting easing of fiscal pressures lessen the need for a divestment programme. Energy firms remain hesitant to increase their presence in a difficult operating environment, especially onshore.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2021-22: Despite the adoption of NAFEX (used by investors and exporters) as the official exchange rate, a spread between the official and parallel-market exchange rates persists, owing to various currency controls and US dollar sales by the central bank.
2023-25: Notwithstanding the operation of the African continent free trade zone movement of goods remain highly regulated to stem smuggling and protect local industries.
Taxes 2021-22: Focus intensifies on boosting tax compliance and repairing the public finances without obstructing investment. Value added tax (VAT) is raised from 7.5% to 10%.
2023-25: VAT is raised twice again to 15% by end-2025 as the government grapples with an enduring fiscal deficit.
Financing 2021-22: In 2021 the government returns to the sovereign debt market and capital projects are restarted.
2023-25: Credit conditions become easier for businesses as the current-account surplus boosts savings and investment.
The labour market 2021-25: Employers face major problems, including a shortage of skilled manual workers, restrictive visa regulations and poor health indicators.
2023-25: Employers continue to struggle to find suitably qualified staff; unemployment remains high and the market loose.
Infrastructure 2021-22: Infrastructure spending picks up in 2022 more than 2021 as the government phases out consumer subsidies.
2022-25: Expenditure on infrastructure increases, but white-elephant projects hold back the productivity of investment.
Technological readiness 2021-22: Nigeria continues to have a vibrant technology sector for an economy at its stage of development, but infrastructure is weak outside urban hubs.
2023-25: Research spending remains low compared with global averages, but some home-grown technology firms looking to adapt global technology trends to the Nigerian market continue to do well.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
6.9 6.1 49 63 5 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
The economy will suffer because of instability early in the forecast period Nigeria was deeply affected by the twin shock of the coronavirus and a crash in world oil prices, which exposed underling economic weakenesses-many related to active government and central bank policies. The after-effects of the 2020 crisis will continue to suppress the performance of the economy in 2021, with real GDP growth of just 1.2% expected owing to recovering world oil prices. Lower inflation and greater foreign exchange availability will engender faster growth in 2022, of 3.3%. However, the pace of the recovery will be insufficient to reverse the decline in the country's real GDP per head and corresponding rise in poverty. Indeed, Nigeria's ranking for this category actually deteriorates in 2021-25. Nigeria's macro-economic environment will remain constrained by market distortions-protectionist policies in particular-that keep inflation structurally high and limit manoeuvrability for the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) to meaningfully loosen monetary policy. Public debt is enormously costly to service against the backdrop of a low revenue base, limiting the scope for productive fiscal policy. Moreover, insecure property rights, an inefficient civil service, confusion caused contradictions between local, state and federal government actions, and deeply entrenched vested interests opposed to free-market competition will all combine to keep economic performance below potential.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
4.5 3.3 58 76 8 14
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
During his time as military leader in the 1980s, the current president, Muhammadu Buhari, demonstrated a penchant for heavy state intervention at the expense of private-sector endeavour, and his leadership since 2015 confirms he still sees a large regulatory role for the state. The CBN governor, Godwin Emefiele, also promotes policies that lean towards interventionism. Pro-business reformers feature in Mr Buhari's inner circle, but market distortions have reached a scale whereby periodic efforts to liberalise the economy crash against the political implications of overturning an entrenched web of consumer subsidies, particularly regarding electricity. The net result is likely to bring only modest policy improvements, and not quickly enough to affect Nigeria's global ranking.

- The 2021-25 MTND, which was released in draft form in March 2021, advocates a mixture of market-oriented reforms and economic self-sufficiency, as in the 2017-2020 Economic Recovery Growth Plan it replaces. However, the ability of the state to rein in its interventionist tendencies will continue to be hindered by public opposition to market reform, vested interests, including politicians seeking to protect patronage networks, consumers used to price controls and large subsidies, and powerful rent-seeking business interests.
- Given the small number of politically connected companies operating in many formal parts of the economy, as well as the existing barriers to entry into many sectors, competition is expected to remain limited. Companies in the formal sector have been dependent on state subsidies and have been shielded by protectionist policies for so long that many are unlikely to respond favourably to government implementation of fundamental free-market reforms. This is particularly with regard to foreign trade, which is heavily restricted for manufactures and agricultural imports.

Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
5.1 4.6 66 73 11 13
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
An opaque and slow-moving policy environment has historically put off many would-be foreign investors in Nigeria. The government is keen to attract foreign capital to augment economic development, especially given low fiscal resources for infrastructure upgrades. Some important steps have been taken to attract investment, such as introducing a visa-on-arrival for business visitors and a market-driven investors and exporters (I&E) foreign-exchange window, which was established in 2017 following a brief period of capital controls in 2016. Although this has helped to rekindle the interest of foreign portfolio investors, foreign direct investment (FDI) remains negligible, largely because of slowness in tackling issues that make production costs in Nigeria extremely high and the enduring scarcity of foreign exchange in the economy.
Various factors will limit investor interest
- The high cost of manufacturing in Nigeria and infrastructure deficiencies-in particular electricity shortages-will rule out a large non-oil export base for global markets. The hydrocarbons sector has typically comprised the bulk of FDI into Nigeria, although flows have stagnated in recent years, partly owing to a lack of clarity around fiscal terms for upstream producers. The Petroleum Industry Bill (PIB) was designed to finalise the tax regime, but the process has itself become damaging to sentiment; it was first submitted to the National Assembly (parliament) in 2008, encountering repeated delays. Eventually, after several years of delay and billions of US dollars in postponed investment, in September 2020 Mr Buhari submitted a refashioned version of the comprehensive bill, which is expected to be passed by the end of 2021. The latest iteration of the PIB proposes the replacement of the NNPC with a newly created limited liability corporation, known as the Nigerian National Petroleum Company Limited (NNPC). The assets and liabilities of the NNPC will be transferred to the new company. The government will pay cash for the shares of NNPC, forming its initial paid-up capital. All the shares will belong to the government and be held by the Ministry of Finance. However, the company will function as an independent profit-driven commercial entity without recourse to state funds. The idea is that as an incorporated body, the new company will be able to raise money at local and international capital markets and, perhaps most importantly, better fulfil its financial obligations in joint venture operations. Implementation will be a challenge for the authorities once enacted, with politicians from all sides of the spectrum arguing that Nigeria needs to maximise its take from its resource endowment, but it is clear that without reform the oil sector would fall into a state of secular decline, which will sharpen resolve within the executive.
- Of particular concern to investors are joint ventures between the NNPC and oil majors operating in Nigeria. The Deep Offshore and Inland Basin Production Sharing Contracts (Amendment) Act in late 2019 significantly raised the government take of oil profits, although the administration is seeking to partly reverse some of the increases as part of an endeavour to make Nigeria's oil sector more competitive. There is an element of urgency to this, with oil majors having proposed withdrawals from Nigeria. The PIB proposes to cut royalty for offshore fields producing below 15,000 barrels/day (b/d) to 7.5% (from 10%). For fields producing above 15,000 b/d, it would cut tax to 35% (from 50%) and leave royalties at 10%. The level at which an additional, sliding scale price-based royalties kick in will be raised to US$50/barrel from US$35/b. Moreover, oil profit tax for non production-sharing contract onshore fields would be cut to 72.5% from 85%, and royalty payments cut to 18% from 20%. While welcoming the proposed charges to the PSC terms, oil executives maintain that the overall fiscal terms in the PIB remains too tilted in favour of the government. The government-being conscious of the imperative to balance short-term revenue requirements with the need to lock in long-term investment in a fast-changing global economic environment-has revised the PIB to further lower royalty rates on offshore fields (to 5%, for production up to 50,000 b/d) and on converted leases to better accommodate the demands of investors. This should reassure majors involved in deep-water production, and some new investment in an offshore basin has since been announced, but it might not provide an answer to other challenges that onshore producers face, such as persistent instability in oil-producing regions, which costs the industry up to 200,000 b/d through theft, vandalism and sabotage. Hence it will be a mixed picture for the oil sector, with investment falling well short of highs during the 2011-14 commodity super-cycle.
- More pressingly, given a challenging business environment, Nigeria will struggle to contend with a global trend of multinational oil companies reassessing their upstream asset holdings around the world, in part driven by uncertainty about the future of the fossil fuel industry. Competition between oil-producing nations for investment in their petroleum sectors will become increasingly intense. Shell, the first and the biggest international oil company to enter Nigeria, is actively in consultations for divestment, although this is predominantly onshore, and other producers such as France's Total and the US's Chevron and Exxon have also considered divestment in recent years (for a range of reasons). Given all of this, it is difficult to envisage any rapid improvement in the investment environment in the hydrocarbons sector.

Legal disputes will also deter would be investors
- Given the government's desire to attract foreign capital, outright expropriation of foreign-owned assets is unlikely. However, legal disputes can easily ensnare investors. An ongoing dispute that highlights the issue is between the government and Process and Industrial Developments (P&ID), a small hydrocarbons producer, over an aborted gas projects has further undermined investor confidence in Nigeria. In August 2019 a judge in the UK granted P&ID the right to seek to seize US$9bn worth of assets from the Nigerian government as compensation for the latter reneging on a 2010 agreement to supply gas to a natural gas processing plant to be built and run by P&ID. In September 2020 the court granted Nigeria an extension of time to challenge the award. The government is arguing that Nigeria has been a victim of an elaborate fraud committed by P&ID, including the bribery Nigerian officials. The country's anti-corruption agency is investigating the alleged fraud. Whatever the final outcome of the trial in the UK (and a separate proceeding in the US), the saga will be seen by many investors as highlighting the risk of conducting business with the Nigeria government.

Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
2.8 2.4 80 81 16 16
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Near-term exchange-rate convergence is unlikely to be permanent Nigeria remains among the worst-ranked countries for foreign trade and exchange controls. Limited currency controls are in place and are likely to be permanent, while the exchange-rate regime itself opens the possibility of capital controls being imposed, as they were de facto since 2020, with some investors still waiting long periods to repatriate capital, which has negatively affected the score and ranking for the category. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the administration to continue to struggle with the management of the foreign-exchange system in an economy prone to fluctuations in supplies of hard currencies, largely owing to a reliance on volatile crude oil sales. The Buhari administration has inched towards relaxing the foreign-exchange regime with the creation in April 2017 of a special I&E window for trading currencies at more market-determined rates, which is now the official rate, although the CBN still intervenes regularly to guide pricing and there is a wide (+15%) spread with the black market conversion.

- The government has committed to unifying the multiple foreign-exchange rates as part of its coronavirus-induced (Covid-19) Economic Sustainability Plan and the Medium Term National Development Plan (MTNDP). In mid-May 2021 the CBN ceased publishing its exchange rate on its website, signalling the end of the official rate which had become redundant as a reference price for private-sector currency transactions. The apparent adoption of the Nigerian Autonomous Foreign Exchange Rate Fixing (NAFEX) rate that is used by the I&E window, as Nigeria's official rate will not result in a free-floating naira or alignment with the parallel market rate. The CBN's aim is still to manage the exchange rate in a "sustainable manner". This will not prevent it from continuing to seek to channel scarce hard currencies to preferred sectors of the economy, and policymakers are not expected to abandon the mindset that views a strong national currency as an indication of economic strength. Moreover, import restrictions aimed at curtailing domestic demand for foreign exchange will remain in place and continue to fuel demand for hard currencies in the black market. The result will be a dual exchange-rate regime, with significant proportions of transactions carried out on the parallel market, which will further complicate the already challenging business environment. In the longer run we do expect the NAFEX exchange rate to stabilise, but this is based on new domestic refinery capacity coming on stream from late 2022, reducing the petroleum import bill, and a current-account surplus, which will enable CBN interventions on the sale side. The government has also sought to reverse a decline in remittances with the "Naira 4 Dollar Scheme", introduced in March 2020 that pays beneficiaries N5 for every US$1 received as remittance. Nonetheless, continued use by the CBN of foreign-exchange restrictions will ensure a wide spread between the NAFEX and parallel-market rates, and the legacy of foreign exchange illiquidity in 2020 will also undermine long-term confidence in the exchange-rate regime, which has repeatedly proven to become highly dysfunctional during times of low global prices.

Protectionist sentiment will be a major barrier to regional trade
- Protectionist sentiment will remain strong in Nigeria, and it is unlikely that the Buhari administration will have either the political will or the ideological inclination to promote free trade. Currency restrictions on imports have caused structurally high inflation, and thus real effective exchange-rate appreciation. This has squashed export competitiveness for the non-oil sector, but the official strategy appears to counteract the impact of this on the current account (and the value of the naira) by further curbing imports and working towards self-sufficiency. Cultivating a new export base is not currently a priority, given this approach.
- The government maintains high import tariffs and import bans on several dozen goods, including many foodstuffs, with the view of promoting local production and development of the non-oil sector. Nigeria reopened its land borders with neighbouring countries to goods trade in December 2020-more than a year after closing them to curb smuggling, especially food items entering the country and petroleum products leaving it. The reopening marks a return to business as usual at most crossings (except Chad, where political crisis has erupted following the killing of the president there in April). Nigerian officials will remain concerned about illicit inflows of goods from neighbouring countries and the impact of the Africa Continental Free Trade Area (AfCFTA) which commenced operation in January 2021. Nigeria ratified the AfCFTA agreement in November 2020-less than a month before the deadline for endorsing the accord. The government will not rush the AfCFTA agenda to eliminate tariffs on at least 90% of products categories (over the next 5-10 years) and to create institutional structures to eradicate non-trade barriers because of fears, shared by local businesses, that Nigeria will become a dumping ground for goods coming from outside the continent.

Business environment outlook: Taxes                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
5.3 5.1 62 74 12 15
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Widening the tax net is a priority With the tax/GDP ratio at just 6% across all tiers of government, Nigeria has one of the lowest tax takes in the world. The Finance Act 2020, signed into law at end-December 2020, proposes reform of Nigeria's major tax laws with the aim of boosting fiscal revenue while simultaneously reforming the tax system to encourage private investment, support growth of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and reduce the impact of taxation on low-income earners. The government hopes that changes in the finance law will help to raise the tax/GDP ratio to 15% by 2023.

- Although low oil revenue will incentivise the authorities to improve their efforts to boost tax compliance and reduce tax exemptions, it is doubtful that the federal tax/GDP ratio will rise much above 5% of GDP by 2025. This will continue to put pressure on the government to find new ways of improving revenue. For example, we expect the VAT rate to rise from 7.5% to 15% by 2025.

Business environment outlook: Financing                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
4.8 4.0 64 75 10 13
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Nigeria's banking sector exhibited considerable resilience during the dual shock of coronavirus-related lockdowns in 2020 and a crash in global oil prices. Non-performing loans (NPLs) surpassed 15% of total loans during 2017, but the ratio has been coming down (to 6% at end-2020). Despite this, SMEs are and will continue to be excluded from credit, either through rationing or a high risk-premium charged (the maximum lending rate is above 28%, limiting access to highly profitable ventures). An exception is agriculture and manufacturing enterprises: the CBN operates a system of selective credit controls to route lending towards these sectors, and can point to a positive impact. Credit to manufacturers rose by 22% in 2020 and to the agriculture sector by 35% (although from a low base), and both sectors performed relatively well in early 2021.
The CBN is subordinating financial sector stability to economic growth Regulations in place to encourage a wider direction of loans to SMEs actively put commercial bank balance sheets at risk: the CBN has been enforcing a minimum loan-to-deposit (LTD) ratio since 2019, with the threshold raised to 65% towards the end of that year. The regulation initially encouraged a spell of high credit growth to the private sector, although this has since abated, and the LTD ratio was just above 60% by end-December 2020. Commercial banks are evidently viewing under-compliance with the LTD minimum and associated penalties as being preferable to a deterioration in asset quality, given an uncertain backdrop since the coronavirus crisis began. High inflation is at the same time preventing cuts to the policy rate (of 11.5%), despite flagging economic growth (of 0.5% year on year in the first quarter of 2021), which will continue to lock small businesses out of the credit market, especially those in sectors not targeted by the CBN's selective credit schemes.

- Nonetheless, as the forecast period progresses, greater competition in the banking sector should drive down the cost of banking and improve the availability of lending in the longer term, especially for corporate clients. Moreover, the government's efforts to create a long-term government bond market, as seen in its maiden issue of 30-year federal government bonds in April 2019, with another issue in March 2020, will help with the pricing of corporate debt and might allow the development of a more active corporate bond market in the future.

Business environment outlook: The labour market                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
5.0 5.0 75 77 11 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
The government of Mr Buhari has made reducing unemployment and boosting job creation one of its top priorities, particularly in agriculture and manufacturing. However, the risk is that, rather than attempting to make liberalising changes to the economy as a means to improve job creation, the administration will instead adopt a more nationalistic approach, attempting to boost local employment through restrictions on foreign trade. Furthermore, government efforts to create new jobs to counter the negative effects of the coronavirus pandemic, including a special public works programme, will increase the number of workers in jobs that are precariously dependent on scarce government funding. This prospect has led to a deterioration in the global and regional ranking for this category for the forecast period.
Unions often stand in the way of reform
- Although labour law reform in 2005 weakened the capacity of the unions to organise political or sympathy strikes, the labour movement remains powerful, capable of organising paralysing national strikes. Partly as a result of union pressure, the government has been forced to increase the minimum wage significantly in recent years, with the latest rise (of 66%) enacted in early 2019. Although such increases have been required to offset the rising cost of living over the past decade, and should not affect the more skilled jobs in much of the private sector, where pay is already above this level, they are likely to diminish any prospects of rapid growth in the formal economy for lower-skilled and labour-intensive sectors such as manufacturing.

Business environment outlook: Infrastructure                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
1.8 1.8 81 82 16 17
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Nigeria's dire infrastructure is a major hindrance to sustained economic growth. Indeed, Nigeria is the worst ranked country for infrastructure in both regional and global terms. Poor infrastructure has been a major constraint on growth since the mid-1970s. Successive governments have failed to deliver on promises to improve and expand basic services in key areas such as power, water, transport, healthcare and education. Gains will be made where the private sector becomes more involved, although significantly developing private-sector investment in many parts of the economy will require politically difficult changes, such as establishing pricing systems that are cost-reflective and adequately allow for earning a profit. For example, notwithstanding the ongoing construction of a 650,000-barrels/day oil refinery near Lagos by a Nigerian billionaire, Aliko Dangote, which is expected to come on stream by 2022 (and is likely be export-oriented), there is little prospect that other private investors will commit to building new refineries in Nigeria as long as petrol subsidies remain in place. The MTNDP proposes the privatisation of the nation's four government-owned oil refineries, but after spending large sums of money repairing these dysfunctional plants, it might find it difficult to finds buyers willing to pay prices that will not entail the state incurring huge and politically unsavoury financial losses.

- Nigeria will probably remain beset by inadequate power supply over the forecast period. A lack of private investment in the development of power infrastructure and the failure of privatised electricity companies to invest more in upgrading and expanding their deficient facilities are largely the government imposing energy price ceilings that do not allow for cost due to recovery. Similarly, the main reason that thermal power-generating stations have been hampered for years by shortages of gas supplies-in a country with abundant natural gas reserves-is that official gas prices have been too low to entice companies to invest in developing the costly infrastructure needed to harness gas for domestic use.
- Under the Presidential Power Initiative, the government signed an agreement with the German engineering company Siemens to upgrade and expand Nigeria's electricity grid to increase reliable power supply to 7,000 MW by 2021 and to 11,000 MW by 2023 and ultimately to increase overall grid capacity to 25,000 MW. The administration has promised to further liberalise power generation and supply and seek to establish an efficient cost-recovery tariff system. A tariff increase was announced in September 2020 and implemented in January 2021. In April the Nigerian Electricity Regulatory Commission said that it was concluding a minor tariff review that would reflect changes in inflation, foreign exchange, gas prices, available generation capacity and the capital needs of the industry. The Power Sector Recovery Programme aims to eliminate government tariff support by the end of 2021, but government concerns about the economic and social consequences of large tariff hikes make it unlikely that it will muster the political courage to allow market-driven pricing by 2022. However, such a system is needed to make electricity production and distribution viable businesses and to improve the creditworthiness of existing utilities so that they are able to invest. Furthermore, the finance ministry observed in July 2020 that the government lacks the fiscal space to accommodate further intervention in the power sector, making tariff review inevitable.

Railways are expensive in a challenging business environment
- After several decades of decline in the railway network, the revival at the start of 2013 of the 1,126-km Lagos-Kano line, after a ten-year closure, marked the first significant result of multiple government plans aimed at improving rail transport. However, Nigeria's railway revival has not been fast or cheap. In his first term, Mr Buhari asked parliament for approval to borrow US$5.9bn from China to continue the modernisation of the network. The administration has since awarded several large railway contracts to Chinese companies to be largely funded by concessionary Chinese credit, including US$6.7bn for work on the Lagos-Kano rail ink, US$3.9bn for the Lagos-Calabar coastal railway project and US$2.3bn for Abuja-Itakpe-Lokoja rail line. Actual concluded loan agreements between the government and the Export-Import Bank of China cover only a small portion of the costs of these projects. An additional issue is that although China might provide infrastructure funding, past experience suggests that many projects will become bogged down in Nigeria's difficult operating environment.

Business environment outlook: Technological readiness                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
3.3 3.0 74 79 14 15
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Nigeria scores poorly in this category, reflecting a lack of formal-sector innovation compared with its more developed peers. Patent applications and research and development expenditure are low, and linkages between universities and the corporate sector in the field of technology are lacking. Mobile-phone ownership and internet usage are high, but these are largely concentrated in urban hubs; millions of Nigerians in rural areas lack a reliable telecommunications network. Few-if any-of these shortcomings are set to improve much in the coming years.
Mixed prospects for mobile services
- Mobile-phone subscriptions reached a peak of 207.6m in October 2020-up by 15.3% year on year. Subscriptions dropped to 192.1m in March 2021, suggesting that the market is close to saturation. After several years of phenomenal growth, from only 19m subscribers in 2005, the development of the telecoms industry now hinges on the challenge of expanding services profitably beyond largely urban markets, and many rural markets are relatively unpenetrated. For example, Lagos state, with a population of 12.1m people, had 22.6m active subscriptions in 2019, up from 21.3m a year earlier. In contrast, fewer than 60% of the populations of Bayelsa state (in the oil-producing Niger Delta region), Ebonyi state (in the south-east) and Borno state (in the north-east) had subscriptions, and the number of subscriptions in Jigawa state (in the north-west) was equivalent to just 38.6% of the population. Less progress has been made in expanding fixed-broadband access that provides high-speed connectivity vital for industrialisation in a digital age. According to the latest data available from the International Telecommunication Union, fixed broadband subscriptions in Nigeria dropped to 83,360 (just 0.04% of the population) in 2019, from a peak of 110,834 in 2017. The challenge of expanding infrastructure (profitably) to often remote locations blighted by insecurity will remain a limiting factor.

Economic forecast: Policy trends Nigeria's government and the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) will aggressively promote local industry, but some elements of policy are contradictory and will contribute to macroeconomic imbalances. An important theme will be management of the naira. Bans on foreign-exchange access for imports of certain manufactures and agricultural goods (covering some 50 items) is being enforced to protect local industry and support the currency, but has some major flaws. Most notably, restrictions are elevating inflation and undermining the currency regime through sustained real effective exchange-rate (REER) appreciation. Despite this, currency restrictions are expected to last throughout the forecast period, with import-substitution being central to the CBN's development strategy, as opposed to encouraging non-oil exports, which are circumscribed by high inflation and REER appreciation.
Faced with hard-currency shortages in 2020, the CBN also allowed a backlog of foreign-exchange orders from investors and importers to accumulate. Because of currency controls and these de facto capital controls, there is a wide spread between the official (NAFEX) and parallel-market exchange rate. Although this is expected to narrow as the foreign-exchange backlog is cleared (market turnover has broadly increased in 2021), the process will be gradual in order to modulate a reserve draw-down, and the adoption of a fully market-determined currency is anyway not expected in 2021-25, and the CBN is adamant that such a move would lead to an overshoot (whereby the currency depreciates) and an inflationary spiral. A pattern of inflexibility by the CBN when encountering hard-currency shortages will have a long-term impact on confidence, and partly explains our projection that foreign direct investment (FDI) will equal 1% of GDP or less throughout 2021-25.
Over time, the contradiction between protectionism and the AfCFTA's principles will grow increasingly conspicuous, but we do not expect an immediate change in strategy given that non-tariff barriers will be phased out over several years. Developing local manufacturing and agriculture is likely to be viewed as a means of preparing for the eventual elimination of tariffs, with currency controls expected to play a role in hastening the process. However, an infrastructure deficit, REER appreciation and instability in agricultural heartlands mean that Nigeria will struggle to acquire new comparative advantages in 2021-25, leaving the fiscal and external accounts and the naira exposed to oil price swings.
Price controls will be another important area of economic policy. Astonishing strides towards the deregulation of petrol and electricity pricing were made in 2020, but the goal of reaching market prices has already been scaled back, in the face of political pressure and now that crude oil prices are rising. A permanent reinstatement of petrol price controls is made unlikely by a new Petroleum Industry Bill (PIB) expected to pass in late 2021. The legislation is likely to streamline sector-wide regulation in the process of creating a new, profit-oriented national oil company, which by definition could not be weighed down by subsidising the retail market. The downstream industry should become commercially viable from this reorganisation of the sector, allowing Nigeria to wean itself off petrol imports, with a new 650,000-barrel/day (b/d) refinery expected to come on stream in 2022. The PIB will also encourage upstream oil investment by making fiscal terms clearer for multinationals (the terms are currently being reviewed and possibly revised to reduce taxation as well). However, we do not expect the sustained electricity price increases that are needed for the power sector to become financially sound, and pricing in the sector remains regulated de jure. Electricity undersupply will therefore continue to hinder industrialisation.

We expect the public finances to stay in deficit in 2021-25. Crude oil receipts make up more than 50% of the federal government's retained income, and an average global oil price of US$63.8/barrel in 2021-25 will be insufficient to balance the budget.
The federal government's tax take is among the world's lowest, undermined by widespread evasion and a large informal sector. The authorities view value-added tax (VAT, currently at 7.5%) as an effective means of increasing fiscal receipts, and we expect three equal VAT rate increases, taking the rate to 15% by 2025. The first is expected in 2022, prior to the next elections but seemingly inevitable given a rising debt burden, with further rises in 2024 and 2025. Even then, we expect fiscal revenue to peak at just 5% of GDP in 2024, which also assumes that fuel subsidies are removed (costs for which are deducted from revenue) from 2021 onwards.
Set against this, high debt-servicing costs, a large public wage bill and healthcare commitments, including purchase of coronavirus (Covid-19) vaccines, will elevate expenditure. Capital investment will be emphasised to compensate for the disappearance of petrol subsidies, once the PIB is enacted (which is expected in late 2021). The government justified price deregulation by promising to invest the savings in infrastructure and will face pressure to match rhetoric with action.
We expect the fiscal deficit to narrow to 3.3% of GDP in 2021 (from 3.7% of GDP in 2020) as international oil prices rise. VAT increases and rising oil prices will lead the ratio to fall to 2.6% of GDP in 2024, but a decline in average global oil prices in 2025 will cause the shortfall to widen to 3% of GDP in 2025. The government has raised its public debt limit to 40% of GDP to incorporate higher budget shortfalls over the medium term and to accommodate securitisation of CBN deficit financing as long-term debt. We expect public debt to reach only 36.9% of GDP in 2025.

The CBN will fail to keep inflation below a target ceiling of 9%, and its policy decisions are likely to remain erratic. Since a 100 basis-point cut to 11.5% in 2020 the policy rate has been kept steady, despite high year-on-year inflation (18.1% in April). The current strategy is to boost the supply side of the economy and thereby control inflation. We believe this is misguided; high and rising inflation will frustrate an economic recovery, and issues such as inadequate public infrastructure, hard-currency shortages and rampant instability need to be addressed before the supply side can moderate the price level. We expect high inflation to persist, compelling the CBN to raise interest rates in 2022, despite still-weak economic growth. There is a distinct chance that the CBN could tighten earlier, given escalating inflation. Monetary easing will resume only in 2024, when inflation has fallen appreciably.

The economy is expected to exit recession in 2021 as the impact of lockdown in 2020 fades, but high inflation will impede improvements in business sentiment and dampen real purchasing power amid high unemployment (at more than one-third of the labour force) and low wage growth. Fiscal stimulus will be an inadequate counterforce, given budget constraints, and the current monetary stance will put pressure on the naira, creating foreign-exchange scarcity and further undermining macroeconomic stability. Oil export volumes will rise slightly, however, as quotas agreed by OPEC+ (comprising OPEC and a group of non-OPEC countries) are relaxed, contributing to real GDP growth of 1.2% in 2021.
The CBN is expected to tighten monetary policy from 2022, circumscribing the nascent economic recovery, but the exchange rate should stabilise and cause inflation to ease, firming up household buying power. As non-business financial penetration is low, private consumption will recover in the second half of 2021-25 alongside disinflation even as interest rates rise. New refining capacity is expected to come on stream in earnest, boosting net exports (with some output for the regional market, and Nigeria's import dependency for fuel falling). Crude oil exports are also expected to grow as prices rise, again supporting the naira. As refinery output continues to ramp up, inflation falls and real spending power recovers, growth will pick up to an annual average of 3.8% in 2023-24. However, these rates of growth are well below potential. The economy will continue to lack dynamism given high interest rates, low FDI, high unemployment, pervasive instability in agricultural regions and infrastructure deficiencies, particularly regarding stable power supply. A more challenging year is forecast for 2025 as oil prices fall and macroeconomic uncertainty rises, with growth slipping to 1.8%.


Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends Even amid a lower price environment compared with the boom years of the early 2010s, Nigeria's oil and gas sector will remain crucial to the prospects of the wider economy, dominating the export profile and accounting for about half of government revenue. Nonetheless, despite the best intentions of reformists in government, oil production is unlikely to stage a rapid recovery following a slump in investment in recent years. Fiscal terms are expected to be clarified by a new PIB, which could grant tax concessions from rates introduced in 2019. However, oil majors operating in Nigeria face high costs related to instability (notably theft, vandalism and sabotage), as well as corruption and environmental concerns. A difficult business environment in this respect means that the country is likely to be singled out for divestment by international producers as they gradually implement decarbonisation plans. Sell-downs by oil majors will probably result in acquisitions by local companies or an increased stake by the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC), but neither of these options will replace investing-power by multinationals already in the sector. We do not expect oil production, excluding concentrate, to reach 2014 levels by 2025 (with our forecast being short by around 100,000 b/d).
The latest version of the PIB includes provisions to turn the NNPC into a self-financing, de-politicised and profit-driven company (NNPC Limited); to enshrine greater transparency and openness in the management of oil resources; to protect the environment; and to alter revenue-sharing. A redesigned NNPC should be better able to respond to cash calls, which the current organisation is in arrears for worth billions of US dollars, and revitalise investment on this point alone. Regarding fiscal terms, the legislation focusses on royalty rates indexed to price and taxing production rather than profits. In response to concerns about the operational risk this carries for more costly offshore fields, revisions were proposed in April 2021 to reduce some of the royalty rate increases implemented in 2019 under the Deep Offshore and Inland Basin Production Sharing Contracts Act, potentially cutting offshore royalties to 5%, from 7.5% and increasing the output needed to activate higher royalties. These concessions reportedly followed consultation with some investors, and evinces awareness within government that attracting investment into hydrocarbons is becoming increasingly complex given a global push towards green energy, and that Nigeria is currently an uncompetitive destination. If passed on the latest terms, the PIB will support limited productivity gains over the forecast period. In a sign of increasing confidence about offshore prospects (possibly because of the proposed PIB revision), British-Dutch Shell, US-based Exxon and France's Total signed a deal to develop an offshore oil basin in April 2021, although new onshore investment is likely to be far more limited. Moreover, some Nigerian officials and civil society groups have long complained that their nation has been under-rewarded for its oil production, particularly from offshore deposits. As Nigeria continues to run budget deficits and encounter urgent developmental challenges, the oil sector will remain a politically charged subject even after the PIB is enacted.
Gas production could be scaled up if pricing issues are resolved Nigeria's proven gas reserves, both oil- and non-oil-associated, are among the largest in the world. In the gas sector the key issue is flaring; a succession of deadlines to end wastage has been missed in recent years, with many firms still employing the practice. There is therefore intense competition to find commercial outlets for gas. The government hopes to use much of the new gas production coming on stream to fuel domestic power stations, thus easing the electricity crisis. However, pricing remains an issue, as despite government pledges to increase the price that it pays for gas, prices on the export market remain more attractive for companies in the sector.

We expect inflation to average 17% in 2021, with increases on both core and non-core levels over 2020, albeit a decline from a rate of 18.1% in April. Foreign-exchange restrictions on various imported goods, including staple foods, and currency movements are inflation-driving factors, but domestic food prices have edged down in annual terms, and the government is protecting consumers from global crude oil price increases by using subsidies (expected to remain in place throughout 2021). Assuming that the exchange rate stabilises and the CBN tightens monetary policy, we expect the annual inflation rate to begin to fall from 2022-slowly, owing to rising fuel prices-to an average of 10% in 2024. Foreign-exchange controls on imported goods, conflict in the Middle Belt-Nigeria's breadbasket-and an eventual return to market-pricing for fuel will prevent a faster fall. Currency devaluation in 2025 will cause the average rate to increase again, to 12.5% in that year.

Nigeria now uses the NAFEX as an official rate, ending the use of the CBN window. The NAFEX rate, which was established in 2017, is more flexible than the defunct CBN rate but is nonetheless tightly managed, as demonstrated by a parallel rate of N481:US$1 compared with N410:US$1 for the NAFEX.
Foreign reserves are again declining after a brief rise in early April and the CBN is yet to clear a backlog of hard-currency orders, indicating that the drawdown is partly being caused by a net outflow on current transactions, despite firmer oil prices. REER appreciation is a leading factor behind the external imbalance, and in the CBN's defence of reserves, we expect the naira to end 2021 at N422:US$1. Following this we expect the current account to return to surplus in 2022-25 while monetary tightening in Nigeria attracts hot-money inflows. This should allow the CBN to keep the exchange rate broadly stable. Increasing currency misalignment means that REER appreciation will nonetheless resurface and, with oil prices expected to slide again in 2025, another devaluation is expected in that year, to N485:US$1.

Assuming that devaluation moderates import demand for goods and services, and with global crude prices rising and inward transfers increasing as the global economy returns to growth, we expect a current-account deficit equal to 1.1% of GDP in 2021, down from 3.9% of GDP in 2020. Over the remainder of the forecast period we expect a small current-account surplus. Oil prices are projected to remain relatively high in 2022-23, supporting exports. Lower petroleum import volumes as new domestic refinery capacity comes on stream will constrain growth in the import bill (otherwise driven by real naira appreciation). Remittances from the large Nigerian diaspora should also recover to pre-pandemic levels, encouraged by exchange rate incentives introduced by the CBN in early 2021. This will all contribute to an annual average current-account surplus of 1.3% of GDP in 2022-24. The surplus will then narrow to 0.5% of GDP in 2025 as falling oil prices push down export earnings. The deficit in 2021 will be financed largely by debt, with investment inflows limited by a dysfunctional foreign-exchange market.
Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Nigeria Stocks and flows Flows of foreign direct investment (FDI) into Nigeria in 2020 totalled US$2.4bn (0.6% of GDP), compared with US$6.1bn (1.7% of GDP) a decade earlier and US$3.2bn (0.7% of GDP) in 2019. A broad decline has been occurring since the partial liberalisation of the exchange rate in April 2017; although exporters and investors access foreign exchange at an ostensibly market-determined rate-the NAFEX (the official exchange rate since early 2021)-the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) has repeatedly demonstrated an inflexibility in managing the naira when oil prices are low, resulting in temporary capital controls. A backlog of foreign-exchange orders built up in 2020, and there were still delays in accessing hard currency in early 2021, with the CBN clearing the logjam only gradually to modulate a reserve draw-down. Although the use of the NAFEX for government foreign-exchange transactions since early 2021 has brought an end to use of the CBN's more overvalued official rate, which presented arbitrage opportunities and was widely regarded as being a flawed system, the naira's pathway remains heavily managed, with a large spread vis-à-vis the black-market rate. Our expectation is for the foreign-exchange regime to continue holding back long-term, illiquid forms of investment such as FDI. Divestment by existing players in the oil sector is also holding the level of inflows back, with Shell being the latest multinational to announce an intention to slim down its operational footprint in Nigeria.
Origin and distribution Most FDI inflows into Nigeria are from the oil multinationals. Until the oil price crash in 2015-16 there had been a modest surge in non-oil sector foreign investment after it became clear that civilian democracy and macroeconomic stability had become established. Although much of the investment was by large multinational companies that were already operating in the country, South African companies strongly increased their presence, with Asian companies leading the next wave. However, the challenging market has seen some prominent withdrawals by South African firms and international banks and greater caution by Asian investors. In sum, the initial flurry of interest peaked some time ago.
Determinants The main factors attracting investment by oil firms are low production costs and high-quality crude oil, both of which offset economic problems and political instability. A number of gas projects have moved ahead, and the government is in the process of finalising fiscal terms for the hydrocarbons sector, which includes some concessions on royalty rates for deep-water basins and taxes for converted leases. Meanwhile, privatisation has been a stop-start process. The opening-up of the mobile-phone market has been a success, but otherwise the main rationale for investment by multinationals is to establish a presence in Africa's largest market, which could be highly profitable despite the difficult operating environment.
Impact The energy sector, which has received most foreign investment to date, provides the majority of government revenue and the vast majority of foreign-exchange earnings. However, it is also a capital-intensive sector with limited linkages to the rest of the economy and little effect on employment. One area in which FDI has had a high-profile impact is mobile-phone networks, led by MTN of South Africa. However, MTN fell foul of regulators over its failure to register SIM card users during 2015 and again in 2018 over alleged non-compliance with capital repatriation requirements. That said, the company went ahead with a listing on the Nigerian Stock Exchange in 2019, as a precursor to a major expansion plan, and the tax dispute has been dropped.
Potential With the largest economy and population in Africa, Nigeria is an important market, although the awkward business environment-characterised by impenetrable bureaucracy and idiosyncratic regulation-is likely to keep FDI inflows below potential. Established multinationals that have mastered operating in the complex and chaotic regulatory environment make substantial profits, despite the country's low income levels and the logistical difficulties caused by the almost non-existent infrastructure, which obliges companies to provide their own power and water supplies and to distribute goods on a road system that is in poor repair. The government will continue to promote Nigeria as a rewarding target for foreign investment, especially for the commercial exploitation of a range of minerals. Privatisation will have a relatively high profile over the next few years, but progress is likely to remain erratic. Parastatals are an important source of patronage, and privatisation faces considerable political opposition, as it is often associated with large-scale job losses. However, the failure of public enterprises to provide an adequate level of service, notably in the electricity and water sectors, and the successful liberalisation of the telephone market make privatisation almost inevitable.

The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts that Nigeria's population will exceed 233m in 2025, ensuring that it remains by far the most populous nation in Africa; it accounts for almost half of the population of West Africa and about 20% of Sub-Saharan Africa. Nigeria has a very young population, with over 40% under 15 years of age and almost 2m entering the job market each year.
Underemployment is more of an issue than unemployment The population growth rate will be high enough to retain a relatively stable age profile, but such a youthful population will have difficulty in finding suitable employment within the formal economy. However, it is not unemployment that is the main issue; few Nigerians in the labour force can afford not to work in a country with no government social security support for the unemployed. Instead, the main challenges are underemployment and low pay. For this reason the local definition of unemployment is working less than 20 hours a week, and underemployed is between 20-39 hours worked. This suggests that the task facing the government is not so much job creation as the implementation of reforms to help to raise productivity and enable employers and employees to upskill existing jobs. Indeed, the country's ability to capitalise on this demographic opportunity will depend on raising health, employment and educational standards, on which insufficient progress can be expected. With the participation rate increasing gradually, largely as a result of more women entering the workforce, the pressure on the job market will be keenly felt throughout the forecast period.
Much will depend on the manufacturing, agriculture and services sectors, but the prospects are mixed. The oil and gas sector will remain capital- rather than labour-intensive, and a gradual switch from subsistence to commercial farming is likely to result in less employment in agriculture rather than more (owing to mechanisation), as hoped by the government. Many young Nigerians will have to resort to low-paid work in the informal sector, but others are likely to turn to crime or militancy-another challenge for policymakers.
Rapid urbanisation will present a challenge A further problem will be to provide enough housing for young Nigerians leaving home. House-building programmes are small relative to demand (at 300,000 new homes annually). This issue will be intensified by ongoing urbanisation. The urban population is expected to surpass 56.6% of the total population by 2025, up from 36% in the 1991 census. This will strain the capacity of municipal authorities to provide adequate services. At the same time, because of absolute population growth there will be an intensified competition for agricultural and grazing grounds in important agricultural regions-notably Plateau state. Access to land has been a driver of repeated conflict, which has been significant enough to interrupt food supply and drive up inflation nationwide.
Weak infrastructure compounds health challenges Although the reported incidence of HIV/AIDS is relatively low in Nigeria, with UNAIDS putting the prevalence rate in 2015 at 3.1%, the country's large population means that Nigeria has one of the highest numbers of sufferers of the disease in the world. Furthermore, there are geographical pockets of infection where the level is above 20% of the sexually active population, and there are major differences in the prevalence rate between states. Other health concerns include the high incidence of malaria, tuberculosis and Guinea worm disease. Nigeria has undergone two waves of coronavirus infections, with a peak of a little over 2,300 cases daily (likely an underestimate). To avoid a meltdown in the healthcare system, a lockdown was implemented in early 2020. However, the economic damage was enormous and would probably not be repeated in the future. Nigeria is currently rolling out an inoculation programme, but a low uptake of vaccines, owing largely to hesitancy, as well as limited distribution and storage capacity, points towards no full or "herd" immunity for several years to come. Furthermore, there have been outbreaks of measles and cholera across parts of northern Nigeria that have led to local healthcare infrastructure being decimated by insecurity. Internally displaced persons' camps often have poor hygiene and are lacking in medicines and medical equipment.

Market potential is high, but the operating context will be unfavourable Being Africa's joint-largest economy and with the highest population on the continent, Nigeria will be a market in which multinationals from a range of sectors (such as agro-processing, healthcare, telecoms and consumer goods) will theoretically be interested. However, its actual attractiveness over the next five years should not be overstated. Extremely low income levels for the majority of the population, coupled with high inflation, mean that most people have little to spend on goods other than basic necessities. Furthermore, owing to low economic growth, GDP per head in US dollar terms adjusted for purchasing power parity, will only recover to 2014 levels by 2023. Nonetheless, Nigeria's growing middle class and wealthy elite-the sizes of which dwarf those in most other African countries-will remain important sub-segments of the market. Nigeria thus has the potential to be a profitable market for multinational companies, but this will involve surmounting its complex and chaotic regulatory environment and over-coming the logistical difficulties posed by the almost non-existent infrastructure, for example by providing their own (expensive) power and water supplies.

As the problems associated with working in Nigeria substantially push up the cost of operations (particularly given low productivity), competition from low-cost imports will remain an issue. Providing goods through imports might seem an attractive option for many companies seeking to exploit the market. However, given the authorities' desire for control over the exchange rate, foreign-exchange restrictions on various banned import categories will continue to impede business operations that depend on inputs from abroad (particularly in agro-processing and manufacturing).
There will be little shift in spending patterns amid economic hardship Given Nigeria's low level of income, consumer expenditure is dominated by the purchase of foodstuffs. Food, beverages and tobacco account for more than half of household expenditure. When spending on essentials such as fuel and food is stripped from the calculation (and given that households also face emergency outlays, for example on healthcare during the coronavirus pandemic), little disposable income is left for expenditure on luxury consumer goods or hospitality. These trends will broadly continue in 2021-25, with inflation being high and nominal wage growth relatively low, particularly in the early years of the forecast horizon. The middle class is also likely to have shrunk since the recession in 2020, and the vast majority of Nigerians are, and will remain, poor. The middle class is almost exclusively located in urban areas, with a geographic concentration in the south-west of the country, around the commercial capital, Lagos.

Initial conditions: Although the hydrocarbons sector accounts for just 8% of GDP (and was only about 10% of GDP during oil price boom), its performance has a major bearing on overall economic conditions, given its domination of export earnings (on which the large non-oil economy depends for imported inputs) and government revenue. Consequently, the lower price environment since late 2014-with deep crashes in 2015-16 and 2020-has severely undermined living standards and the economy. The government's ability to spend what oil revenue it does still earn in a way that would benefit the majority of Nigerians is hugely constrained by debt service (which in early 2020 accounted for over 80% of retained revenue), endemic corruption and the requirement that a large proportion of revenue be allocated to states, which are even less accountable than the federal government and are equally (and in some cases more excessively) burdened by debt repayments. Interventionist policies by the Central Bank of Nigeria and the government that keep inflation high, such as restricted access to foreign exchange for various consumer imports (including staple foods), will prevent concerted monetary loosening. Without fiscal or monetary stimulus powering the economy out of the coronavirus (Covid-19) crisis, Nigeria's growth path in the medium term will fall behind the long-term trend.
Population changes bring opportunities, but also threats Demographic trends: One factor in Nigeria's favour is its large and young population. However, most indicators of the health of the population are low, reflecting decades of underinvestment in healthcare facilities, which will take years to turn around even if the commitment is found. Increasing urbanisation will also put strain on service provision in the cities, as well as housing. An additional problem for the government is provision of education and training facilities for the rapidly growing population, as well as long-term employment opportunities. Internal migration, as Nigerians search for jobs in the urban centres, and climate change and environmental degradation (which is fuelling conflict in Nigeria's Middle Belt agricultural heartland) put strain on natural resources and will add to population pressures. Access to land is already a major driver of unrest in central Nigeria, and this phenomenon is only likely to intensify in the coming years. Overall, it is difficult to be optimistic about the outlook without a substantial improvement in economic governance and policy implementation. There is time to turn the situation around over the timeframe to 2050, but the precedent is not positive.
External conditions: There has been a structural shift in Nigeria's export markets in recent years, away from the US, which is steadily reducing its oil imports as a result of its shale boom, and towards Asia, particularly India. Oil reserves will not be exhausted by 2050 but are likely to have peaked before then, especially with a global shift away from fossil fuels and towards renewable energy. Finding external markets for the growing non-oil economy will be crucial, but is not yet on the radar for inward-looking policymakers, whose current priority centres on import substitution and supplying to the domestic market. Heavy management of the naira (repeatedly engendering real effective exchange-rate appreciation) implies the non-oil sector would need to lower wages in order to devalue "internally" to promote competitiveness, but powerful unions and structurally high inflation would make this a challenge. In sum, Nigeria is a long way from developing a globally competitive non-oil export base, and first needs to finalise a coherent strategy for doing so.
Institutions and policy trends: The real challenge for successive governments is to raise average incomes and living standards through a sustained period of economic reform and to deliver a real improvement in governance. However, the omens are not good. Nigeria remains one of the most corrupt and poorly governed countries in Sub-Saharan Africa. Considering how ingrained these problems are, they will be hard to resolve, even in a long-term timeframe. The gap between economic policy rhetoric and implementation will remain huge, and improvements will continue to be slow, given that the vast range of vested interests that benefit from the chaotic status quo remain opposed to change. In addition, policy formulation will continue to be hampered by the country's federal structure; even if a positive reform agenda is promoted at the national level, it is often not implemented or is openly contradicted at the state level.
Long-term performance: Nigeria's long-term economic performance will pick up during 2020-50, although real GDP growth will be slower in 2020-30 than in 2031-50, given the impact of the coronavirus shock to output in 2020 (in which year GDP contracted by 1.8%). Indeed, average growth in real GDP per head will be slightly negative (at -0.1%) until 2030. Although some non-oil sectors will perform well, others, such as manufacturing and agriculture, are likely to struggle to become internationally competitive, especially given Nigeria's long-standing preference for a managed exchange rate, which can be assumed to continue stifling external competitiveness. A large market and a continued rise in Asian GDP will be important factors driving growth, however. Barring a secular decline in oil prices, exchange-rate overvaluation will support income per head in US dollar terms, and rapid population growth will cause the economy to triple in size between 2030 and 2050. As the economy leans heavily towards private consumption (with government spending being a small proportion of GDP, at less than 10%), this means a huge expansion in Nigeria's market in terms of household spending.
