a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Unpredictable policymaking has become a major source of instability Turkey's score and global ranking improve slightly during the forecast period, but from a low starting point during the historical period when the quality of economic policymaking and its institutional underpinnings deteriorated sharply. The score improvement in this category reflects our expectation of lower inflation, a gradual moderation of exchange-rate volatility and narrower current-account deficits during the forecast period compared with previous years. However, these parameters will remain vulnerable to both negative domestic and external economic developments. Policy shortcomings and failure to dampen inflation expectations could lead to a continued slide in the external value of the Turkish lira and another sell-off of Turkish financial assets. We expect the pace of Turkish real GDP growth to pick up moderately following the slowdown in 2019-20 trigged by the late 2018 currency crisis and the coronavirus pandemic, but more volatility cannot be ruled out given the government's preference for credit-fuelled expansion. Turkey's fiscal position has deteriorated in recent years. Although the budget deficit and government debt will remain relatively low in GDP terms and ease gradually during the forecast period, credit guarantees have increased contingent liabilities. Credit-driven economic growth and the accompanying high inflation will eventually feed through into higher levels of household and corporate indebtedness, although these remain will relatively low by European standards. The financial system will remain vulnerable to political interference, high levels of private-sector foreign-currency debt, bouts of lira weakness, volatile global liquidity conditions and a further rise in non-performing loans (NPLs).
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
6.0 6.0 39 43 15 17
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Turkey has a large and dynamic private sector, and private property is generally well protected. However, the country's score and ranking remain low in this category in the forecast period owing to the significant role of the state in many sectors, widespread political patronage and corruption, and politicisation of regulatory bodies and the judicial system. The failed coup in 2016 led to the seizure or closure of firms, which in turn increased uncertainty, particularly because access to legal redress was limited. Although the state of emergency imposed in the aftermath of the attempted coup has been lifted, the erosion of the independence of state institutions will continue to cause uncertainty in the medium term and state intervention may increase over the coming years. The World Economic Forum's Global Competitiveness Report 2019 ranked Turkey 61st of 140 countries in terms of the burden of government regulation. The 2020 report focused on the priorities for recovery and revival after the coronavirus crisis. Turkey ranked last out of 37 countries in terms of economic transformation readiness. Starting a business in Turkey generally requires more time, procedures and funding than in an average high-income OECD country. Paying taxes also carries a greater burden, but registering property is simpler.
The government will continue to support private-sector investment
- We expect government support for private-sector investment and employment to continue. This will come through incentives such as tax breaks, social security and credit subsidies, and loan guarantees, with an emphasis on underdeveloped regions, technology, small and medium-sized enterprises, production of currently imported intermediary goods and "strategic" sectors (such as defence, aerospace, automotive and pharmaceuticals). Widespread use of government loan guarantees has allowed banks to lend to riskier customers, increasing the risks to banks from higher NPLs in the wake of the economic slowdown triggered by the coronavirus crisis.
- Free competition is likely to remain the norm in most sectors. The Competition Board has power over mergers and acquisitions, price-fixing and abuse of market position. Like most other regulatory agencies, however, the Competition Board will have limited effective independence, as it is appointed by the president. The state is also likely to remain dominant in many of the sectors in which it plays a leading role, such as gas and water, rail transport, tea and sugar production, infrastructure, and social services (including healthcare and education). The state also has a significant position in banking (about 35% of total assets), mining, the defence industry, postal services and legal gambling, and retains large stakes in Turk Telekom (30%) and Turkish Airlines (49%). There is a state-owned broadcaster (TRT) and a state-owned home-builder (TOKI). There are also sectors in which one or more private firms, including privatised companies, hold strong market positions.

The wealth fund will play a larger role in the economy
- Privatisation is well advanced in several sectors, including oil refining, parts of the energy sector, steel, mobile telecommunications, and tobacco and alcoholic drinks. However, we expect the slow pace of privatisation since 2014 to continue during the forecast period, owing to market volatility and the government's focus on retaining control and enhancing the value of strategic assets. Assets that have been slated for privatisation include operating rights for more ports, the national lottery and horse racing concessions, shares in toll roads and bridges, TOKI, VakifBank, more power plants, Istanbul's municipal companies, and some state-owned land. However, control of the three main state banks-Halkbank, Ziraat and VakifBank-looks set to remain in state hands. These banks may sometimes be used as a source of patronage.
- The establishment in 2016 of the Turkey Wealth Fund (TWF) has removed some government assets from the control of the privatisation agency. The fund was initially designed to help to finance large public works by using its assets as collateral, making sales of the assets under its control less likely. It now includes assets such as the state's stake in Turkish Airlines, Turk Telekom, Ziraat Bank, Halkbank, VakifBank, Borsa Istanbul and Botas-an oil and gas pipeline operator-and the recently formed Turkey Insurance and Turkey Life Pension as a result of the merger of six insurance and pension fund firms in September 2020.
- TWF's role in the economy is likely to expand further, if, as we expect, the fund is used to inject cash and take controlling stakes in companies facing difficulties arising from the coronavirus pandemic. Besides Turkey Insurance and Turkey Life Pension, TWF acquired a controlling 26% stake in the previously privately owned mobile phone operator, Turkcell, in June 2020, and may raise its 6.7% stake in Turk Telekom, which was sold to Dubai-based Oger Telecom in 2005. The three private banks that took over a 51% stake from Oger in 2018 are seeking to sell their participation.
- Price controls operate for various reasons in electricity, gas, petroleum, telecoms and pharmaceuticals. However, despite public ownership of major energy sector assets, privatisation, new investments, the Electricity Market Law of March 2013 and changes in regulations have increased liberalisation, helping to widen consumer choice over power providers. Competition will continue to be constrained in other sectors by the large shadow economy; the smuggling of petroleum products, cigarettes and many other items; and the violation of intellectual property rights in many sectors, from software to fashion.
- Political patronage and exclusive business networks will continue to play a significant role in business life. Companies close to government circles may be boldest in entering public tenders or operating in sectors where major decisions are taken by politicians, regulators or bureaucrats. Industrial policy may facilitate favouritism or uncompetitive arrangements. Some companies may face higher bureaucratic obstacles or tougher tax inspections than others.
- Build-operate-transfer or public-private partnership schemes will increase the role of the private sector in the management of airports, water and irrigation facilities, and hospitals. The railways are being restructured, and the rail network has been separated from train services. The state will continue to play a dominant role in the sector for some time to come, as so far only a few freight rail transport licences have been granted to private operators.
- There is scope for further improvement in the protection of intellectual property. Legislation has been gradually brought in line with EU practices. In particular, a single, unified industrial property law came into force in January 2017 that replaced a patchwork of decrees regulating trademarks, patents, designs and geographical indications. Both Turkish and foreign companies are increas-ingly sensitive to this issue, so there is also likely to be progress in enforcement.

Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
6.4 6.4 48 47 17 17
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Heavy reliance on foreign-capital inflows increases incentive to attract FDI Turkey's low savings rate and heavy dependency on foreign-capital inflows makes attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) a priority, and in principle the government and most sections of Turkish society have generally accepted and respected foreign ownership in industry and services. However, Turkey's score in this category is unchanged in the forecast period, as we expect little progress on reforms aimed at reducing macroeconomic instability risk and removing the main deterrents to foreign investment. Foreign ownership is restricted in a few areas, including broadcasting and civil aviation, and the government has become more suspicious of foreign capital. The courts and sections of the public are also occasionally hostile towards foreign investors when environmental issues or natural resources are at stake. Turkey's politicised judicial system, corruption and political patronage also act as deterrents for potential foreign investors.

- Privatisation in energy and other sectors may provide opportunities for foreign investors, often in conjunction with local partners. The government will especially promote FDI in greenfield and expansion projects that can further its industrial policy goals, including import substitution and technological inno-vation. Low asset valuations as a result of the weakness of the lira may also attract investors, particularly to export-oriented firms that have receipts in US dollars.
- In principle, foreign investors will continue to have the same access to government incentives as domestic investors do. Plans to cut red tape and streamline the legal system would benefit both foreign and domestic businesses. There have been no restrictions on repatriation of profits, even at times of financial market stress. We do not expect even temporary restrictions to be imposed (Turkey has never done so in the past), as it would deter future investments into Turkey, but the risk of capital controls being introduced at some point during the forecast period has increased.

Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
8.2 7.8 37 45 17 18
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Capital-account controls cannot be ruled out given renewed lira weakness Turkey's score and rankings deteriorate in this category in the forecast period, reflecting our assessment of the possibility of capital-account controls being introduced at some point given the renewed sharp depreciation of the lira in 2020-21 and the unpredictability of economic policymaking. The currency has been fully convertible since 1989, and the authorities have not considered the use of capital controls, even during periods of severe exchange-rate and financial market volatility, being keenly aware of the reputational damage that this could cause, including potentially impeding Turkey's access to international financial markets for several years. As a member of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) with a customs union with the EU, Turkey is committed to a broadly open trading regime. However, global trade tensions and political rifts between Turkey and some of its trading partners, notably the US, have periodically caused disruption to bilateral trade and exacerbated exchange-rate volatility. Under the 1996 customs union with the EU, Turkey has customs-free trade in manufactured goods with EU member states and has adopted the EU common customs tariff. However, the country has refused to grant Greek Cypriot ships and planes access to its ports and airports unless the EU facilitates direct trade between the EU and the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus (TRNC), which is only currently recognised by Turkey. Turkey's import regime reflects the EU's free-trade agreements (FTAs). It has bilateral FTAs with the European Free-Trade Association (EFTA).

- The coronavirus crisis depressed global trade flows in 2020, which has hurt Turkey's export sectors. However, lira weakness has made exports more competitive, positioning them well to benefit from the global recovery from 2021. Beyond the crisis, we also believe that Turkey may benefit from "near-shoring" trends: European companies may increase investment in manufacturing plants in Turkey in order to reduce the fragility of global supply chains.
- We believe that the government is unlikely to resort to outright protectionism, despite its efforts to encourage domestic production of items currently imported in large quantities. However, short-term protective measures will continue to be employed to limit imports of textiles, petrochemicals and other items from lower-cost countries. Some restrictions on agricultural imports exist, but, concerned by high food price inflation in recent years, the authorities have tinkered with tariffs and quotas in order to lower prices.
- Turkey and the EU have agreed to revisit the current customs union agree-ment with a view to expanding it to potentially cover agricultural goods, services and public procurement, but talks have not yet started seven years since the agreement. Some EU politicians have suggested that talks should be linked to political criteria. If this were to be the case, the chances of reaching an agreement during the forecast period would be low. Turkey is negotiating or pursuing FTAs with several other economies, especially countries such as Canada, Mexico and Japan, which have signed FTAs with the EU. Prompted by the UK's departure from the EU, Turkey and the UK signed an FTA, which took effect in 2021.
- In the absence of a Cyprus settlement, Turkey is likely to resist EU pressure to open ports and airports to Greek Cypriot ships and planes. Similarly, without progress in its EU accession negotiations, Turkey is unlikely to lift restrictions on EU meat and used-car imports, eliminate discriminatory taxes on alcoholic drinks and tobacco products, or open up trade in services.

Business environment outlook: Taxes                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
6.1 6.4 42 48 10 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Corporation tax rate set to rise to 25% in 2021 and 23% in 2022 Turkey's global rank in this category has fallen six places to 48th in 2021-25, despite a slight improvement in the score. As a percentage of GDP, tax revenue is low by OECD standards, owing to high levels of evasion and limited administrative capacity. According to OECD figures, tax revenue (including social security contributions) comprises about 23% of GDP, compared with an OECD average of about 34% (2019 data). In response to the 2018 currency crisis, the corporation tax rate was raised from 20% to 22% for a period of three years to 2020. It was due to fall to 20% again in 2021, but in April 2021 the government decided to increase it instead to 25% in the 2021 tax year (corporation tax declarations are due in July 2021) and 23% in 2022. Personal income tax rates range from 15% to 35%. Turkey's tax structure has changed only moderately over the last decade. According to central government budget figures, corporation tax now accounts for around 12.5% of total tax receipts, up from just below 10% up to 2017. However, a high proportion-around two thirds-still comes from indirect taxes, including value-added tax (VAT). VAT is levied at a standard rate of 18% (with lower rates of 8% and 1% for some items), and special consumption taxes apply on some goods and services such as petroleum, alcohol, tobacco products, motor vehicles and telecoms services. Obligatory social security contributions consist of 20.5% of gross salary (up to a certain limit) from the employer, 14% from the employee and a combined total of 3% to the Unemployment Insurance Fund from both parties. Tax breaks, social security premium reductions and incentives are available to encourage investment in underdeveloped regions, strategic sectors and technological innovation.

- In response to the economic downturn caused by the coronavirus outbreak, the government announced a range of temporary tax measures in 2020 in order to support businesses, including the deferral of payments of social security premiums and cuts to VAT rates in hard-hit sectors such as retail, automotive and logistics. However, the corporation tax rate was left unchanged, and will be increased in 2021-22. Given Turkey's widening budget deficit, the government is unlikely to lower the corporation tax rate substantially in 2023-25.

Frequent changes in tax regulation and evasion are likely to continue
- Frequent changes in tax regulation are likely to continue, as will wide-spread tax and social security evasion, which is encouraged by frequent amnesties and opportunities to restructure arrears. One such amnesty was introduced in mid-2018, mainly to garner political support ahead of presidential and parliamentary elections that year. Another in 2019 focused on encouraging the repatriation of undeclared foreign assets. Plans to simplify the tax system have been on the agenda for some time, but have been consistently postponed.
- Foreign firms will continue to be treated in the same way as Turkish companies. During the forecast period Turkey is expected to expand the already large number of double-taxation agreements that it has with other countries.

Business environment outlook: Financing                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
7.0 6.3 24 45 11 17
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Turkey's financing score and rankings deteriorate sharply during the forecast period. The country slips to 45th (compared with 24th in our historic period) in the global ranking and ranks second last in the regional category, down from 11th in 2016-20. This reflects the banking sector's increased vulnerability in recent years to political interference, financial market volatility, currency weakness and high levels of private-sector foreign-currency debt. Reforms introduced under the guidance of the IMF and the World Bank in the wake of the financial crisis in Turkey in 2000-01 transformed the banking sector to become well regulated, well capitalised and highly profitable. Three state-controlled banks and four large private banks dominate the sector, accounting for about 75% of total assets. The state banks have largely operated on a commercial basis, and direct government intervention in the private sector has been rare. There have been periodic surges in bank lending growth since 2010, driven by lower government borrowing needs, strong domestic and global liquidity, steadily expanding government credit guarantees, and pressure on banks to lend more and at lower interest rates.
Major banks are well capitalised, but higher NPLs pose risks
- Volatile global liquidity and high levels of corporate debt will restrict credit to the private sector, especially households and small businesses. The strongest Turkish companies, like banks, are likely to continue to have access to loans from foreign banks and to local and international bond markets, but the cost of financing is likely to be high by international standards.
- With economic activity slowing sharply in 2019-20 and debt servicing more onerous owing to the weakness of the lira, NPLs have risen sharply, more than doubling in 2018-19, pushing the NPL ratio to a peak of 5.4% of total credit at end-2019, up from 2.8% in mid-2018. NPL levels stabilised in 2020 and the ratio gradually declined to 3.8% in March 2021, reflecting strong lending growth-total credit to the private sector expanded by an average of about 36% in 2020-and government policy requiring banks to treat debtors more leniently. This has caused Turkish banks to become increasingly vulnerable to the risks from higher NPLs.
- Low domestic savings will also remain a constraint. The government has pledged further changes to the private pension system, which if implemented would help to increase the availability of finance with longer maturities, albeit only over the medium term.
- Difficult financial conditions are likely to slow further the pace of share offerings on the volatile Borsa Istanbul, the country's main stock exchange. Market capitalisation in US dollar terms is low, at 36% of GDP at end-2020, up from 24.6% of GDP at end-2019, mainly reflecting a sharp contraction in dollar nominal GDP. About two-thirds of the free float is foreign-owned during periods of financial stability, but this figure had declined to below 50% in the first quarter of 2021, as a result of a sell-off of Turkish assets since 2018.
- Changes in bank ownership may occur, particularly among smaller banks, without changing the sector's overall structure. The AKP's antipathy towards private bank owners and sympathy for consumers and credit customers will encourage tighter regulation of certain activities, such as credit-card issuance.

Business environment outlook: The labour market                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
6.4 6.4 31 39 12 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Turkey's labour market score remains unchanged in the forecast period, but its global ranking in this category falls sharply. The country has a large, young labour pool, but workforce participation is only about 52%, partly owing to traditions that discourage female employment. Despite a greater number of years of formal education, the average level of education and skill remains below average European standards, and mismatches between education and the needs of the labour market persist. Employment of foreigners is rare, and obtaining work permits can be problematic, but some restrictions have been eased. Informal employment and subcontracting are commonly used to avoid tax, legal obligations and rigidities, but they create unfair competition, undermine safety standards and hinder productivity gains. In formal employment, hours and conditions are generally regulated and inflexible.
Impact on employment will emerge when pandemic support is lifted
- Turkey's official unemployment rate has remained broadly unchanged during the coronavirus crisis at 12.9% in the first quarter of 2021 compared with annual averages of 13.1% in 2020 and 13.7% in 2019, owing mainly to temporary government measures largely aimed at limiting redundancies among workers in formal paid employment, including an near-total ban on lay-offs. However, the full extent of the impact on the labour market of the pandemic is likely to be clearer when support is withdrawn from June 2021. Unemployment is likely to be much higher than official figures show as some of those who lost their jobs are likely to have dropped out of the workforce altogether, while young people may have postponed their entry into the workforce, discouraged by the lack of job opportunities. The government aims to make the labour market more flexible while improving access to unemployment benefits. We expect the use of flexible contracts in the formal sector to increase only slowly. Current labour market activation and education policies are likely to raise skills levels and workforce participation only gradually.
- In response to employers' complaints about high labour costs, the government has sought to lighten the burden of social security contributions, especially for underdeveloped regions and the employment of young people, women and people with disabilities. Following rises in lira terms of 14.2% in 2018, 26% in 2019 and 15% in 2020, the monthly gross minimum wage was raised by almost 22% at the beginning of 2021 to a relatively high TL3,578 (US$430).
- Firms complain that the system of severance pay, under which employers are liable to pay substantial lump sums to employees who retire, resign or are made redundant, is too generous, hindering formal hiring. A reform has been on the government agenda for many years. As of mid-May 2021, no major changes had yet been enacted. The government's plan is for firms to establish a severance pay fund for employees, which will sit alongside their personal pension fund into which employers also pay contributions. The proposal was met with resistance from unions, so may take several more years to implement.
- Restrictions on union membership, strikes and lock-outs that are incompatible with international norms promoted by the International Labour Organisation (ILO) and the EU are unlikely to be lifted.

Business environment outlook: Infrastructure                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
4.8 5.8 55 54 18 18
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Major infrastructure projects are under way, but shortcomings persist In recent years investment by national and local governments, as well as the private sector, have led to some visible improvements in Turkey's infrastructure, ranging from rapid growth of domestic air travel to the gradual extension of the natural gas pipeline network to almost all provinces, and the spread of broadband internet access and mobile-phone services. The government's preference has been for large infrastructure projects, with several grandiose projects in the pipeline. The construction of a 3.9-km-long suspension bridge over the Dardanelles is on track to open in early 2022. However, tenders have yet to be issued for the controversial Canal Istanbul, a canal linking the Black Sea to the Sea of Marmara, and an ambitious three-tier undersea tunnel across the Bosphorus and raising finance for these larger projects could be challenging.

- Fixed-line broadband internet access has grown rapidly, but at an estimated 19% in 2020 the penetration rate is well below an average of 30-40% for most other European countries. When including large and rapidly rising numbers of mobile broadband subscriptions, the penetration rate is much higher. However, the coronavirus pandemic has delayed the introduction of fifth-generation (5G) networks, compared with the government's original target of June 2020.

Infrastructure shortcomings-including urban overcrowding, congestion, earthquake risk, and strains on water supply, waste disposal systems and the energy network-will persist. Improvements in road and rail transport infrastructure will be piecemeal, and as a whole will continue to lag EU standards, especially given the long distances between cities. Public and private investment will ensure that seaport capacity expands, despite bottlenecks and incomplete privatisation of management rights at some state-owned ports.

- Energy sector privatisation and market liberalisation will continue gradually. Private investment (coupled with limited public investment) may be enough to increase power-generation capacity, cut transmission and distribution losses, and prevent blackouts.
- In addition to domestic onshore activity, Turkish Petroleum, a state-run firm, has been exploring and drilling in the Black Sea and the Mediterranean. However, drilling operations in the latter have fuelled tensions with Cyprus, Greece and the EU. Plans to construct two nuclear plants are also highly controversial. The first reactor of the four planned at the Akkuyu site in Mersin province should come on stream in 2023.

Business environment outlook: Technological readiness                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
6.6 6.6 38 42 16 16
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
E-commerce is growing rapidly, but growth is from a low base Turkey ranks 42nd in the global rankings for technological readiness in the forecast period, well behind Russia (20th), but ahead of Bulgaria (58th) and Romania (56th)-some of its main competitors for FDI. E-commerce is growing rapidly, reflecting rising internet and credit-card use, as well as high mobile-phone penetration and steady improvements in the online environment in areas such as security and after-sales service. Online sales rose by an annual average of about 40% in 2018-20. However, growth has been from a low base of about 5% of total retail sales, compared with about 10% in developed economies.

- Intense competition in the mobile-telecoms sector should ensure that infrastructure remains adequate and up to date, although there may be delays in adopting the latest technology, or it may initially be expensive or concentrated in major cities. Computer ownership has risen rapidly. According to the Turkish Statistical Institute (TurkStat), an estimated 90.7% of households had access to the internet in 2020, up from about 30% in 2009.
- Research and development (R&D) spending in Turkey amounted to 1.1% of GDP in 2019, broadly unchanged on the two previous years. However, given that nominal GDP growth averaged 17% in that period, R&D spending rose strongly in nominal terms, which we expect to continue during the forecast period. R&D spending is greater than in Romania or Bulgaria (0.5% of GDP and 0.8% respectively in 2018) and is broadly in line with that in Greece, Poland and Russia (1-1.2% of GDP). As in most emerging economies, large, export-oriented private-sector firms account for the bulk of R&D spending in Turkey.

Economic forecast: Policy trends The economic downturn in 2020 led to the biggest credit growth boom in a decade, facilitated by Turkey's state banks and a politicised central bank. This has kept inflation high, owing to lira depreciation against all other major currencies. In November 2020 the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, made a step towards policy normality and transparency by appointing a former finance minister, Naci Agbal (who is known for championing orthodox monetary policies), as central bank governor. However, he was replaced in March 2021, adding to the unpredictability of Turkey's policies and damaging financial market sentiment. The new governor, Sahap Kavcioglu, a former member of parliament and official of Halkbank, a Turkish state bank, is a critic of Mr Abgal's policies. Mr Kavcioglu has stated his commitment to reducing inflation, but his appointment has triggered expectations of early rate cuts. Although the new central bank governor looks set to loosen policy, we do not expect cuts as large as the market fears.
A fresh lockdown came into force in April onwards in response to the recent increase in coronavirus cases. Mr Erdogan has announced that the redundancy ban introduced last year, and the related employment subsidy, will be extended until end-June. He also promised a one-month extension of monthly payments to small traders affected by the virus, the postponement of some debt repayments and an increase in the amount of cash support to poor households.
Turkey's economy has displayed resilience during previous bouts of political instability and market volatility, owing to a prudent approach to the public finances, effective capitalisation of the banking sector, and a dynamic and diversified private sector. However, other shortcomings, such as cronyism and corruption, skills mismatches and tax evasion, are unlikely to be effectively addressed in the forecast period. Reforms to address the structural imbalances that underlie Turkey's recurring boom-and-bust economic cycle are needed. There is a risk of the government reverting to its preferred policy of unsustainable rapid credit growth, which could cause a sudden credit stop and a potential balance-of-payments crisis. There is also a risk of US financial sanctions, which would further impede Turkey's ability to attract foreign-currency inflows and restrict its access to global debt markets.

Budget balance -3.4 -2.8 -3.3 -3.3 -2.7 -2.4

Under the Justice and Development Party (AKP), the public finances used to be one of the economy's most reassuring aspects. However, since 2018 the budget deficit has widened significantly, driven by higher government spending on defence, security, infrastructure, public employment and social benefits, eroding this credibility. The budget deficit reached 3.4% of GDP in 2020, as coronavirus-related restrictions negatively affected revenue growth and the government deferred collection of some tax and social security premium payments. In 2021 the deficit will ease to 2.8% of GDP. We expect the finance minister, Lutfi Elvan, to reintroduce a more prudent approach to the public finances in an effort to recover policy credibility and reassure investors. Further rises in indirect taxes, a restructuring scheme for tax payments and a proposed rise in corporate income tax to 25% should also benefit the budget this year.
Ahead of the election in 2023, we expect the deficit to stay elevated, averaging 3.3% of GDP per year in 2022-23. It will then narrow to an average of 2.5% of GDP in 2024-25 as the government reins in spending to reassure investors. Government debt reached 39.7% of GDP in 2020, and will peak at 39.9% in 2021, before gradually falling to 35% in 2025.
Economic forecast: Monetary policy Interest rates
(%)
  2020 2021 2022 2023 2024 2025
3-month money market rate (av) 11.2 18.4 16.7 10.0 10.5 10.5
Deposit rate (av) 10.8 16.1 8.5 10.5 10.0 10.0
The central bank adopted an ultra-loose policy in the early stages of the coronavirus crisis and cut the main policy rate by 300 basis points to 8.25% in the first half of 2020, pushing real rates firmly into negative territory. This helped economic activity to recover via a credit boom, but also contributed to a lira sell-off, a rapid loss of foreign-exchange reserves and high inflation. From August the bank reversed course and began to tighten policy, although the initial tightening was conducted via the back door. It raised rates by a total of 1,075 basis points to 19% between September 2020 and March 2021, and minimised exchange-rate interventions. In addition, the banking regulator abolished the "asset ratio" for banks, which had forced lenders to extend credit and buy sovereign bonds, and which had been partly responsible for Turkey's credit boom.
The appointment on March 20th of a new central bank governor has caused a loss of investor confidence and has triggered expectations of early rate cuts. We expect the first rate cut to come in June, but this will be small and further easing will be gradual. We expect a policy rate of 15% at end-2021, with real rates remaining in positive territory, which should help to keep investors on board. We expect a continued decline of foreign-exchange reserves as the bank tries to defend the currency, as well as a renewed increase in the dollarisation rate of lira deposits. In 2022 we expect rates to be raised again in an attempt to fight inflationary pressures.

Turkey's economy grew by 1.6% in 2020, making the country one of only two of the G20 major economies that recorded growth amid the coronavirus pandemic (the other one being China). In 2021 we expect further modest economic growth, of 3.9%. Economic activity appears to have held up well in the first quarter of 2021. In the second quarter indicators of economic activity benefited from a strong base effect. However, there are downside risks to our forecast stemming from a volatile lira, high interest rates, high inflation (with negative consequences for input costs for businesses), rising risk premiums and the continuing effects of the pandemic. Turkey's vaccination campaign has slowed, and insufficient supply of vaccines may persist for another few months. As at May 26th 14.4% of the population was fully vaccinated, which is comparable with France (15%) or Italy (18%), but well below the UK (34.8%) and the US (39.4%). Further uncertainties stem from Turkey's macroeconomic imbalances, the country's economic policy, geopolitics and the coronavirus situation globally.
To strengthen investor confidence beyond 2021, additional reforms-such as guaranteeing the independence of the central bank and reducing government involvement in the banking sector-would be required. Nonetheless, despite its structural shortcomings, Turkey's catch-up potential is considerable, and the economy is competitive, which underpins our view that growth will be 3.8% in 2022. In 2023, when the next general election is scheduled, we expect a stronger credit impulse to reappear and forecast real GDP growth of 3.4%. In 2024-25 we forecast average annual growth of 3.4%, which we believe is close to Turkey's medium-term potential.

Economic forecast: Sectoral trends As in most developing countries, the share of agriculture in nominal GDP has declined steadily in Turkey in recent decades, but, at an estimated 7.2% of gross value added in 2020, it remains an important sector, especially considering the input that it provides to Turkey's food, beverages and tobacco manufacturing industry. In addition, agriculture still accounts for a substantial share-17.6% in 2020-of total employment, although almost half of those employed in the sector are classified as unpaid family workers. We expect the share of output of the primary sector to remain broadly stable during the forecast period, but it will remain large compared with most other European countries, at just under 7% of GDP in 2025. In 2016 the sector was hit by Russian sanctions on agricultural imports from Turkey, but most were lifted by mid-2017 following the rapprochement between the two countries in June 2016. The sector would benefit from investment in irrigation in the south east of the country and in some other regions, but investment is likely to remain on hold in areas affected by the conflict with the outlawed Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK). More generally, the importance of modern, large-scale agricultural enterprises will spread gradually, but the problems of traditional agriculture and unclear policymaking are likely to persist.
Manufacturing will continue to play a central role in the Turkish economy Industry, including manufacturing, mining and construction, accounted for about 30.3% of GDP in 2020. The collapse in investment and export demand during the 2008-09 global crisis hit the manufacturing and construction sectors hardest. Since then manufacturing, and particularly construction, has re-bounded. In 2020 manufacturing accounted for nearly 25% of GDP, relatively unchanged since the end of the 1990s. In 2020 industrial production growth was a sluggish 1.6%, as a result of the coronavirus induced global recession and plunging external demand, but in 2021-25 we expect the sector to rebound strongly.
Construction was a significant driver of economic growth in 2010-17. In 2017 real value added in the sector, which is dominated by housing construction and mega infrastructure projects, expanded by 9%, following growth of about 5% in the previous three years. The pace of housing construction outstripped demand for several years, even after allowing for strong demographically driven growth in the number of households and the continued replacement of existing buildings. In 2017 growth was bolstered by a strong expansion in credit as a result of pressure by the president on banks to lower mortgage rates; the indirect effect of the credit guarantee fund; the relaxation of macroprudential measures and ample global international liquidity. This has resulted in a reported 1.5m-2m new homes being unoccupied, a situation that has weakened developers' finances and reduced the incentive for new investments. Infra-structure and building investments via public-private partnerships, which had picked up significantly over the past five years, have also contributed to robust construction growth. In 2018-20 construction output plunged, given the oversupply of housing, the high ratio of non-performing loans (NPLs) in the sector, the depreciation of the lira against the US dollar, high interest rates and a slowdown in economic growth.
Several manufacturing subsectors will rebound from 2021 Several manufacturing subsectors, such as automotive, and textiles and clothing, are strongly export-oriented and suffered from low export growth in 2020, but continued to be an important source of foreign export earnings, and will rebound from 2021 onwards. Turkey's manufactured exports are generally import intensive. A large portion of the inputs-including energy, intermediates and capital goods-are imported, adding to Turkey's external imbalances, especially when international commodity prices are high or the lira is weak, as it has been since mid-2013. This structural situation is unlikely to change much during the forecast period, as reducing the import intensity of exports and moving up the value-added chain will take time, even though these were explicit goals in the government's investment-incentive system, which was introduced in 2012.
Vehicle production in 2019 was 15% below record production levels in 2017 The automotive sector tends to be Turkey's biggest export. In 2020 the total production of Turkey's automotive industry amounted to 1,297,854 vehicles, according to the Automotive Manufacturers Association (OSD)-11% lower than the previous year. Exports fell by 27% to 916,543 in parallel with the coronavirus-related slump in the European car market. Turkey runs a considerable trade surplus in its automotive sector, and this surplus has expanded owing to strong export demand alongside import restrictions and the weak currency. That said, according to the Turkish Statistical Institute (TurkStat), earnings from exports of automotive vehicles and parts declined by 18% to US$22.1bn in 2020, whereas the value of imports rose 53% to US$15.3bn.
Most vehicle manufacturers will maintain facilities in Turkey While uncertainties related to the coronavirus pandemic persist, vehicle production can be expected to grow by up to 10% in 2021. The trade surplus in the automotive sector may also improve. Almost 80% of motor vehicles produced in Turkey are exported, and the bulk of these go to the EU (Turkey accounts for almost 30% of vehicles imported by the EU). As a result, vehicle production will fluctuate in line with demand in Europe, which we expect to recover from 2021. The significant depreciation of the lira against the dollar and euro will be likely to support firm export volumes over the medium term. Given its location and its trade agreement with the EU, Turkey will remain an important automotive hub, but political uncertainties will weigh on investor confidence. Over the medium term, considering the growth potential of the automotive market in Turkey and the wider region, manufacturers with production plants in Turkey may start to focus more on the Turkish, Middle Eastern and North African markets. The domestic market will be supported by rising incomes and replacement demand. In the domestic market, a total of 796,200 vehicles were sold in 2020, including 610,109 passenger cars. These figures represented increases of 61.9% and 57.6% respectively over the low levels of 2019.
We believe that most manufacturers will maintain their production facilities in Turkey. These facilities are technologically advanced, and labour costs are much lower in Turkey than in core European countries, and most central and east European countries, where wages have risen strongly following accession to the EU. However, if Turkey is to remain a major automotive production location in the medium to long term, manufacturers will have to move away from exporting low-end passenger cars, light commercial vehicles and components to north European markets, and towards developing and producing alternative-energy engines and vehicles. There are signs that this transition is already happening. The market will be supported by cuts to taxes on hybrid and electric vehicles.
The textiles and clothing industries remain important The textiles and clothing industries remain important to the Turkish economy. The industries have undergone restructuring under the intense pressure of competition from low-cost producers in Asia, including China, Bangladesh and Pakistan. The government has also been looking at ways to improve investment incentives and target higher value-added products. Both these industries suffered from subdued demand in 2020 amid the global recession. However, over the medium term a more competitive currency and ample growth potential will underpin robust growth prospects. Competitive pressures from lower-cost centres of production will remain a risk.
Reduced security concerns will drive tourism growth Tourism, one of the most important services sectors of the Turkish economy-an important source of economic activity, employment and foreign exchange-witnessed rapid growth in the past decade, but is highly vulnerable to geopolitical developments and changes in the exchange rate. Istanbul, the largest city, remains the top destination and accounts for a third of all arrivals. It seems that security concerns are no longer deterring visitors from important markets. Tourism came to a complete halt in the second quarter of 2020, and suffered severe losses in the remainder of the year by comparison with the record performance of 2019, reflecting the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on international tourism. Based on TurkStat data, annual visitor numbers (including non-resident Turks) plunged by 69.5% to 15.8m and revenue dropped by 65.1% to US$12.1bn. This decline continued in the first quarter of 2021. Turkey has introduced a compulsory "safe tourism" certification programme for tourism enterprises, prioritised tourism workers for vaccinations and exempted foreign tourists from curfews. However, countries such as the UK and Germany currently ban foreign holidays altogether or warn strongly against travel to Turkey. Quarantine and testing requirements also remain in place for people returning from abroad. For EU citizens, travel to alternative destinations within the EU, such as Greece and parts of Spain, is likely to be easier than travel to Turkey this summer. Russia, Turkey's largest single market, has halted almost all flights to and from Turkey until the end of June-a step expected to result in the loss of an estimated 800,000 visitors. From 2021 we expect the sector to recover. We expect tourism revenue to make a larger contribution to the current-account balance than in 2020, but to remain 40-50% lower than in 2019.

Inflation averaged 12.3% in 2020 as a result of excessive lira depreciation against the dollar and the euro. Although bases of comparison will be favourable and monetary policy has tightened since late 2020, rising global prices, persistent inflationary expectations, potential monetary loosening and further expected lira depreciation will keep inflation high in 2021, at an average of 14.5%-well above the central bank's 5% target. In 2022 we expect inflationary pressures to remain elevated, at 10.1%, mainly because of continued lira volatility. We expect inflation to dip in 2023 as price controls are imposed ahead of the election, before picking up again in 2024-25.

Overall, the lira depreciated by about 19% against the dollar on average in 2020, despite central bank interventions. The lira was bolstered by the appointment of a new central bank governor, who promptly embarked on an explicit tightening of monetary policy. However, since Mr Agbal's sudden dismissal by the president in March, the lira has weakened again, and is currently trading at around TL8.5:US$1. His successor as governor, Mr Kavcioglu, has increasingly sought to reassure markets that interest rates will not be cut prematurely. However, investors remain wary, owing to Mr Erdogan's known preference for low rates.
Foreign-exchange reserves fell from US$77.4bn at end-February 2020 to about US$49bn at end-May 2021, with net central bank reserves increasingly negative. The bank's new governor is likely to start loosening monetary policy in June 2021. Internal and external imbalances, renewed policy unpredictability, poor international relations, foreign investors' concerns regarding the central bank's independence, and a reliance on short-term capital inflows will all contribute to a depreciation of the lira against the dollar. As a result, we expect the lira to end the year at TL8.79:US$1.
In 2022-25 we forecast that the lira will continue to follow a depreciatory path (weakening by 1.6% in nominal terms on average) amid elevated current-account deficits and high inflation in Turkey, together with a gradual normalisation of monetary policy in the US and the euro area.

The current-account deficit amounted to 5.2% of GDP in 2020. Still-subdued domestic demand and pressure on the lira will temper imports in 2021, while tourism earnings will partly recover. The current-account deficit will narrow sharply, to 2.2% of GDP, this year as the economy begins to rebalance. Attracting sufficient capital inflows to cover the deficit and service foreign debt, without further drawdowns of already inadequate foreign-exchange reserves, will be complicated by the renewed uncertainties relating to monetary and foreign policy. We expect conditions for borrowing from abroad to deteriorate, given the widespread lack of investor confidence.
The outlook for capital inflows remains uncertain, given global financial conditions and investor concerns about Turkey's economic management, which increases the risk of a balance-of-payments crisis. However, Turkey has faced several balance-of-payments crises in the past without resorting to capital controls, which Mr Erdogan strongly opposes. Furthermore, a balance-of-payment crisis is not our core forecast, as many banks will opt for short-term syndicated loans, which will allow them to roll over external debt.


Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Turkey Stocks and flows Foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows rose dramatically in 2005-08, to 2.9% of GDP, after averaging a modest 0.5% of GDP between 1990 and 2004. In the context of the global economic and financial crisis, they slowed again in 2009-10 and have remained below the average level of 3.2% of GDP reached in 2006-08. Inflows of FDI, including sales of real estate to non-residents, declined to about US$13.5bn, or 1.5% of GDP, per year in 2012-14, before picking up to about US$19.3bn, or 2.2% of GDP, in 2015. In 2016-18 FDI inflows fell to an average of US$12.6bn, or 1.5% of GDP. In 2019 FDI inflows were subdued, at US$9.3bn, owing to high economic and policy uncertainty. In 2020 FDI inflows plunged again to US$7.8bn (or 1.1% of GDP, the lowest since 2004) amid the global recession and rising investor risk aversion towards emerging markets such as Turkey. The stock of inward FDI stood at just 29.3% of GDP in 2020 (US$210.2bn)-well below levels in regional competitors such as Romania and Poland (between 40-50% of GDP), and Bulgaria and Slovakia (75-80%). Turkish outward FDI jumped to US$7bn in 2014 (from US$3.6bn in 2013), largely reflecting a small number of large transactions, notably the acquisition of the UK-based United Biscuits by Yildiz Holding, a Turkish conglomerate of food manufacturers. The figure has eased since then, falling to a yearly average of US$3.1bn in 2019-20, presumably owing to high domestic funding needs.
Origin and distribution The traditional sources of foreign capital in Turkey have been multinational companies based in major European countries, especially the UK, the Netherlands, Luxembourg, Spain and Germany, and in other OECD countries such as the US, Switzerland and Japan. Individual large investments from several smaller EU countries, the UAE, Saudi Arabia, Russia, Kazakhstan, Azerbaijan and Brazil have amended this pattern in recent years, and there have also been some significant purchases by private-equity funds. A majority of foreign investment appears to go to Istanbul-the commercial capital where most national Turkish companies have their headquarters. Investment projects of foreign capital companies are overwhelmingly concentrated in the Marmara region (which includes Istanbul), the Aegean region, the Mediterranean and Ankara, the capital. Historically, manufacturing (particularly the chemicals, food and automotive industries) and financial services attracted the most FDI. In late 2018 BP, a British energy company, and the State Oil Company of the Azerbaijan Republic (SOCAR) signed an agreement to form a joint venture to build and operate a petrochemicals plant in Turkey for US$1.8bn (construction is expected to be completed by 2023). Problems in developed economies, and the euro zone crisis in particular, together with the more recent deterioration in economic prospects in Turkey, have led to divestments by foreign financial institutions, many of which entered the Turkish market in 2005-08. As part of a plan to shore up its capital base, the National Bank of Greece has sold its 99.8% stake in Finans Bank, but because the sale, which was completed in mid-2016, was to Qatar National Bank, it did not affect net inward FDI figures in 2016. In 2017 OMV, an Austrian energy group, sold off its 100% stake in Petrol Ofisi, a Turkish petrol retailer. A neutral impact will also result from the planned sale of Denizbank by Sberbank to Emirates NBD (agreed in 2018). The Turkish lira crisis in 2018 delayed completion of the deal, but it was finalised in July 2019.
Foreign property purchases, which are included in balance-of-payments statistics for FDI, have been making a solid contribution to net inflows since 2005. In 2005-13 net inflows averaged a solid US$2.5bn per year, before picking up to an average of US$4.6bn in 2014-18. Amid excess supply, lira weakness and the deteriorating economic outlook, real estate inflows in US dollar terms continued to decline in 2019-20.
Determinants Foreign investment is mostly motivated by the size and potential of the Turkish market, but also increasingly because it offers access to neighbouring markets. The sharp rise in FDI in 2005-07 was partly driven by favourable global financial conditions, which have since evaporated. However, the upsurge was also made possible by the conjunction of several country-specific factors. The Justice and Development Party (AKP) was more willing than its predecessors to sell majority stakes in state-owned companies to foreigners. The economy was relatively stable and grew strongly, and EU accession talks, which were expected to lead to further reform of the business environment, got under way. The private sector was also more willing to seek foreign partners than in the past. This may have reflected the thinking of a new generation of management, strategies of specialisation in certain sectors, a desire to raise capital for privatisation bids, fear of increasing foreign competition, lost appetite for bank ownership and temptingly high company valuations. From 2008, although the government remained willing to privatise, market conditions deteriorated, resulting in less interest from foreign investors. Since 2013 potential deterrents have multiplied: less buoyant economic growth, mass anti-government protests, financial market volatility, government corruption allegations, the spillover of violence from the conflict in Syria, the collapse of the peace negotiations with the outlawed Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK), an attempted military coup in July 2016 and increased social and political polarisation over the shift to a presidential system of government. Other significant structural deterrents, which vary by the sector, size and type of investment, include regulatory uncertainty, a slow and unpredictable judicial system, weak intellectual property (IP) protection and unfair competition from smuggled goods and the large informal sector. Such determinants are unlikely to change much over The Economist Intelligence Unit's forecast period (2021-25), although in order to attract much-needed FDI inflows, Turkey may start improving IP protection and clamp down on its large informal sector for tax revenue purposes.
Impact The FDI stock as a percentage of GDP is relatively low when compared with other emerging markets such as Brazil or Russia. However, FDI has accumulated over many decades, and the outlook compared with several central and east European countries has improved. Several leading multinationals, such as Unilever (UK-Netherlands) and Ford (US), have had a long-standing presence in Turkey, and companies with foreign partners play a significant role in the economy, helping to spread modern management and business practice. In the automotive industry, foreign investment has ensured expansion, technology transfer and access to global markets, although some lament the lack of national technology or a national trademark and the focus on production of low-end vehicles. By contrast, much recent FDI has taken the form of acquisitions of existing assets in domestically oriented sectors, and has therefore had a limited direct impact on fixed investment or exports. Foreign ownership of banks has not demonstrably improved either access to international funds or services and productivity, which were already advanced, and nor have fears been realised that foreign-owned banks may attach a greater risk premium than local banks to lending to the Turkish government or Turkish companies. The arrival of Vodafone (UK) has gradually helped to increase competition and investment in telecommunications, where Turkcell and Turk Telekom are dominant players. From a macroeconomic perspective, Turkey has relied on capital inflows, including FDI, to cover its large external financing requirement. In the years prior to the 2008-09 crisis, a growing share of FDI in capital inflows comforted the financial markets by reducing the vulnerability of the lira to trends in short-term capital inflows. In 2020 this ratio declined as FDI inflows dried up, but the share of FDI in capital inflows will improve during the latter part of our forecast period, helped by smaller-albeit still-large-external financing needs.
Potential Our baseline forecast is that, assuming security and policy concerns are addressed during the forecast period, there will be a moderate pick-up driven by further privatisation and other crossborder mergers and acquisitions, as well as foreign interest in residential and commercial property, following the easing of restrictions on foreign ownership of real estate in 2012. Although the surge in foreign acquisitions in telecoms and banking of 2006-07 is unrepeatable, private corporations in many sectors may still be open to foreign investment, and several major assets are yet to be privatised. We assume that the government will make further progress in creating conditions for private-sector investment in infrastructure in order to support economic growth over the longer term. The energy sector in particular has the potential to attract large amounts of foreign investment. Existing investors are likely to increase their investment through further acquisitions or projects, and some greenfield investment may take place. Subdued income growth may dampen foreign investors' earlier interest in retailing, but they may also become more active in other services, such as tourism, as well as in mining and agriculture. Investors from Asia and parts of the Middle East may play a larger role, in addition to Western multinationals and funds.

Population growth remains high by European standards Turkey is the third-largest country by population in Europe, after Russia and Germany. Official population figures have been compiled using an address-based registry since 2009. These figures are lower than previous estimates from door-to-door censuses, but are believed to be more reliable. The total population is projected to rise from 84.3m in 2020 to 86.7m in 2025, with the female population continuing to outnumber that of males. The total population is expected to grow by 0.6% per year during the forecast period (2021-25), compared with 1.4% during the historical period (2016-20). The pace of population growth has slowed in recent decades, mostly owing to the declining birth rate, which in turn reflects the combined impact on fertility rates of urbanisation, an improvement in the education level of women and wider use of birth control. Nevertheless, population growth remains high by European standards and the average age remains one of the lowest, at an estimated 32.8 years in 2020.
Infant mortality will continue to decline, but will be high From an average of 16.6 births per 1,000 inhabitants in 2016-20, the crude birth rate is expected to fall to an average of 15.4 per 1,000 in 2021-25. The infant mortality rate will continue to decline, but will remain high compared with European countries, as the national average is pulled up by the south-eastern and eastern regions, as well as by rural areas. The crude death rate will remain broadly unchanged, at an average of 5.5 per 1,000 population in 2021-25.
Although ageing, the Turkish population is young in a European context and will remain so throughout the forecast period. In 2020 those aged 14 and under were estimated to comprise 23.4% of the total population, and the 65-plus age group accounted for just 8.4%. In 2025 the share of under-15s will still be high, at about 21.5% of the population, and over-65s are expected to account for 9.9%.
Urban population will rise further owing to better conditions in cities The urban population, which is currently estimated at 76.2%, will rise further as rural families, insufficiently supported by agriculture, continue to seek better living standards in towns and cities. The drift of population from smaller and poorer urban settlements to larger and richer ones will also continue. As a result, all major cities in the west and south (including Ankara, the capital) will continue to grow rapidly. Although earthquake-prone, Istanbul and its surrounding area is likely to become the largest conurbation in Europe-the population was 15.5m at end-2020, up from about 12.6m at end-2007. Other cities and towns to witness particularly strong population growth include prosperous industrial centres like Bursa and Konya, and Antalya, on the Mediterranean coast.
The population of the mostly Kurdish-inhabited south-east, which accounts for about 10% of the total population, has increased steadily, despite strong outward migration. The still-high natural population growth rate in the region will contribute to the rapid expansion of the populations of cities like Gaziantep, Sanliurfa and Diyarbakir. By contrast, the populations of many rural areas in northern, eastern and central Turkey will dwindle. Even some of the larger urban centres in these poorer and more remote regions could lose population as birth rates slow and migration westwards and southwards continues. Some western and southern areas that are still classed as rural may maintain their populations as a result of intensive agriculture, tourism and/or proximity to major cities. This may also be true of lowland parts of the south east benefiting from irrigation schemes.
Participation rates will remain well below the OECD average Despite solid growth in the working-age population, Turkey has the lowest labour force participation rate of any OECD country. According to the Turkish Statistical Institute (TurkStat), it averaged 53.2% in 2018 (72.7% for men and just 34.2% for women), compared with an OECD average rate of more than 70%. Participation rates in urban areas are lower than in rural areas, reflecting that rural women are typically classified as "unpaid family workers" and are, therefore, counted as workforce participants and employed persons. Low workforce participation rates among urban women probably reflect inadequate job opportunities and the persistence of traditional gender roles. This situation is changing slowly, as illustrated by a gradual rise in recent years in the urban female participation rate. However, the rate is expected to remain low by European standards throughout the forecast period.

Overall spending power will rise, but income distribution will remain uneven The large consumer market is one of Turkey's chief attractions as a place to do business. The population is young, growing and inclined to consume rather than save, and average incomes are rising steadily in local-currency terms. In 2020 GDP per head was US$8,491 at market exchange rates (down from US$9,106 in 2019, reflecting Turkish lira weakness) and US$30,515 at purchasing power parity (PPP) rates (up from US$30,003 in 2019). Relative to other emerging markets, at PPP rates Turkey's GDP per head is broadly in line with that of Russia and Romania, and above that of Brazil and China. We expect Turkey's GDP per head to reach US$38,986 at PPP rates in 2025. At this level, GDP per head in Turkey will be broadly unchanged, at around 60% of the EU average.
Income distribution is uneven by European standards. According to the survey of incomes and living conditions by the Turkish Statistical Institute (TurkStat), the highest-earning 20% of households accounted for 46.3% of total income in 2019 (latest available data), up from 45.9% in 2014; the lowest-earning 20% of households accounted for 6.2%, down from 6.4% in 2014. Geographical factors contributed to the discrepancies. In general, the regions with the highest and most rapidly growing concentrations of population were also the wealthiest regions, except in the south-east, where spending power is low, partly as a result of continued confrontation between the central government and the Kurdish forces. Greater Istanbul, which accounts for about 20% of the population, represents about 25% of household consumption expenditure. By contrast, the statistical region of south-east Anatolia, with about 10% of the population, generated only about 6% of household consumption. Income and consumer expenditure also vary widely between urban and rural areas. These patterns are unlikely to change significantly in the forecast period (2021-25).
The household will remain the main consumption unit. Households typically consist of an average of 3.6 people, and more than 90% of households are made up of married couples. These patterns will change only slowly, the number of households will tend to rise faster than the population, underpinning medium-term demand for housing construction and household durables.
Majority of Turkish consumers aspire to Western-style consumer society A large majority of consumers aspire to "Western style" consumer society, in so far as their incomes permit, although local factors affect lifestyle aspirations. The country has wide variations in geography and climate, which affect diet, leisure activities and demand for certain goods.

The proportion of total household spending allocated to food, beverages and tobacco is high and expected to remain broadly stable during the forecast period. Turkish households have suffered from slow growth in 2020, resulting in a softer labour market and depressing purchasing power in US dollar terms. However, we expect Turkish households, which are dynamic by most European standards, to rebound to 2019 levels by 2023 and to grow strongly in 2024-25. The wealthiest households, which enjoy standards of living close to those in western Europe, spend significant amounts on entertainment, education and catering, as well as on transport, because of the high cost of running a car. These households will remain an important target market for environment-friendly and wellness products and services, which are relatively new. Other population segments are starting to provide additional demand for items that have been the prerogative of upper-income groups. Rising car ownership will continue to encourage supermarket shopping, residence in suburban areas and related lifestyle trends. Demand for branded fashion items, fast food, air conditioning and holidays is also spreading. That half of the population is under 30 will encourage the introduction of new products and services in communications, information and entertainment technology. Tourists constitute a significant addition to the consumer market. Assuming that perceived security risk does not increase again in the coming years, we expect the weaker lira to boost arrivals once the risks associated with the coronavirus abate.
