Initial conditions: Some of the obstacles to solid and stable growth were removed in the decade to 2010, but in recent years the government has focused on domestic power struggles and the foreign policy challenges arising from turmoil in the wider region, putting economic reforms designed to boost investment and employment on hold. Given the deterioration of Turkey's institutions of governance and the likelihood that the current domestic political tensions will continue for some time, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects only limited progress on reforms in the near term, damaging Turkey's longer-term growth potential. For similar reasons, we do not expect Turkey's EU membership bid to make significant progress, making accession a remote prospect. A relatively low level of skills and quality of the workforce compared with Turkey's main competitors for foreign direct investment (FDI) in central and eastern Europe will continue to act as a deterrent to FDI, although Turkey will enjoy substantially more favourable demographics.
Working-age population growth turns negative in 2040 Demographic trends: On current projections, Turkey will have the second-largest national population in Europe (after Russia) by 2050, and, unlike in most European economies, Turkey's working-age population will continue to grow until the early 2040s and shrink thereafter amid a weaker demographic profile. Turkey's positive demographic dynamic is expected to start deteriorating from about 2030. In 2021-30 the difference between growth in the working-age population and that of the total population will be close to zero, before turning negative in 2031-50, which will dampen economic growth as it is not mitigated by improvements in productivity growth. This trend could be delayed if the bulk of 3.6m Syrian refugees currently being hosted in Turkey are integrated into the population.
Throughout the long-term forecast period (2021-50), we expect an upward trend in the labour force and employment because of rises in participation rates, given the low starting levels. With the workforce continuing to expand at a steady rate, it will be a challenge to produce sufficient jobs to lower the unemployment rate.
External conditions: International developments-particularly in international financial markets, the EU (Turkey's main export market) and in global terms of trade-will continue to affect Turkey's long-term economic performance. The coronavirus pandemic may result in higher risk aversion among investors over the long term, boding ill for Turkey, which highly relies on attracting capital inflows to support growth. We expect export-led industries to play an increasing role in growth. Turkey would benefit from greater global trade liberalisation, but the process of liberalisation is faltering and trade flows have slowed. In addition, over the long term Turkey may benefit from "near-shoring" trends, as the coronavirus pandemic is demonstrating that overly complex supply-chains can negatively affect growth. As a supplier of the developed economies, Turkey will face intense global competition, as low and medium value-added manufactured goods are likely to remain its main product lines. Its technology potential is relatively limited, and the country is not well placed to become a major supplier of services other than tourism and, to a lesser extent, construction, although improvements in (and diversification of) the domestic financial sector over the past decade may enable Turkey to develop as a provider of banking and insurance services in the wider region. Because of completed and planned pipeline construction, Turkey is expected to become a major energy hub between Russia, the Caspian region and western Europe. As Turkey shares borders with countries such as Iran, Syria and Iraq, its immediate regional environment is challenging, in particular from a security perspective.
Problems in the EU will dampen Turkey's interest in membership We do not expect Turkey to join the EU in our long-term forecast period, and there is a high probability that the accession negotiations may even be abandoned by one or both sides in this period. Given the limited progress so far in Turkey's EU accession negotiations, the strength of public opposition in most EU member states to Turkish membership and the economic and political challenges still facing the EU, we believe that Turkey's commitment to the goal of full EU membership will diminish even further. This increases the risk that government commitment to political and economic reform will weaken further. Harmonisation of Turkey's domestic legislation with EU norms is significantly more important for Turkey's long-term economic stability than actual member-ship. If the EU were to loosen its structure-the UK's vote to leave the EU could prompt such a move-opposition in the EU to Turkish accession might ease, increasing Turkey's chances of joining. However, this is not our core scenario.
Institutions and policy trends: Recep Tayyip Erdogan's victory in Turkey's first direct election of the president in August 2014, the approval of his presidential reform plan in a referendum in April 2017 and the presidential election of 2018 have shifted the political system from a parliamentary to a presidential system. The shift carries major implications for the country's future institutional and policy-setting framework. The constitutional reform allows Mr Erdogan to run for president for two five-year terms. However, discussions have begun on a new constitution, to be enacted next year. Details are not yet available, but it could include processes to ensure that Mr Erdogan stays in power beyond 2028, when his second term as president would end (assuming that he is re-elected in 2023). The issue of Mr Erdogan's succession as leader of the Justice and Development Party (AKP) and president of the country could become a source of instability during the long-term forecast period.
Considerable risk that economic policy is increasingly political The broadly positive management of the economy by the AKP since coming to power in 2002 has been one of the main reasons for its electoral successes. However, there is a considerable risk that economic policy will be increasingly tailored to political purposes rather than to maintain macroeconomic stability and further improvement of the business environment. Nevertheless, Turkey's public finances are structurally sounder following a decade of IMF-backed reforms in 1999-2008, which may allow the government more room to increase public investment in infrastructure and possibly to reduce tax rates. Given the little progress that we expect to be made in Turkey's EU accession negotiations, the problems of unpredictability and inefficiency in Turkey's legal and regulatory environment is expected to continue beyond 2025. Legislation is likely to remain under the scrutiny of the EU and international bodies, such as the IMF, the World Bank, the Council of Europe and the European Court of Human Rights, although Mr Erdogan's assertive approach to foreign relations is likely to limit their influence over the direction of policies.
The government's peace negotiations with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) collapsed following the June 2015 election, and neither the PKK nor Mr Erdogan have shown any indication that they are willing to revive them any time soon. If the situation continues on its current trajectory, there is a real risk that the PKK and its affiliates will spread the conflict from the predominantly Kurdish-inhabited south-east of the country to Turkey's main cities in central and western regions, where the Kurdish population has grown rapidly in recent years. The mounting death toll will probably encourage Mr Erdogan to resort to increasingly authoritarian means to retain control.
Long-term performance: Turkey's economic growth performance is expected to exceed that of other emerging markets such as Brazil and Russia (but to be on a par with that of China) as a result of its more favourable demographic profile alongside large productivity increases. However, at a forecast average of 2.9% a year in 2021-50, real GDP growth will be well below average growth of 4.8% per year recorded in 2000-20. Average growth in GDP per head will be substantially lower, reflecting the expected rise in the total population. Income levels will remain well below the EU27 average, but some catch-up is likely. Improvements in the policy environment could produce substantially better results, but the changes in the political environment have created significant downside risks to the implementation of the necessary reforms.

Long-term outlook: Long-term trends Climate change and sustainability Global land and ocean temperatures have been rising quickly since the 1980s, a trend that is widely attributed to growing greenhouse gas emissions from expanding human activity and population. This rise in average temperatures implies a higher number of extremely hot days in the summer period, as well as higher minimum temperatures that will lead to greater electricity consumption and a heavier burden on health services due to temperature-related illnesses and parasitic diseases that thrive in warmer climates.
Precipitation in the eastern Mediterranean has been declining steadily over the past decades and is expected to continue falling, raising the probability of extremely dry spells of weather. In 1998-2012 the eastern Mediterranean Levant (Cyprus, Israel, Jordan, Lebanon, Palestine, Syria and Turkey) experienced the worst drought in 900 years. In Turkey, in 2007 this resulted in water restrictions being imposed in the capital, Ankara, with some residents losing access for up to ten days. It also resulted in Turkey's agricultural output contracting by nearly 7% year on year and the government having to provide grants to affected farmers to compensate for the losses. In the future limited average rainfall is likely to be accompanied by torrential precipitation, such as in 2018-19, with devastating consequences for infrastructure and agricultural output.
The Turkish government has recently taken some steps to mitigate the weakness posed by the country's geographical location. In 2010 the government established a national climate change strategy that included improved disaster mitigation plans and improved efficiency in water management. Specifically, a substantial number of dams have been built, and efforts have been made to improve some of the highly inefficient irrigation and water supply systems. Although such measures may help to mitigate the effects of climate change, they may also create foreign policy challenges. The construction of several damns along the Tigris and the Euphrates rivers, which feed water into Iraq and Syria, has the potential to increase significantly tensions with these neighbouring countries. In 2019 we developed a model to calculate the impact of climate change on long-term growth, and we expect that, despite the mitigation efforts, real GDP will be 2.8% smaller by 2050 than it would have otherwise been.
Technological development The integration of advanced technologies in Turkey's economy is proceeding at a fast pace, but from a relatively low base. E-commerce, computer ownership and internet access have increased rapidly in the past decade. Yet, despite this progress, Turkey remains far behind the technological frontier. According to The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings, Turkey ranks joint 50th with Greece, Thailand and Costa Rica in the global rankings for technological readiness. According to the World Economic Forum's Global Competitiveness Report 2019, Turkey ranks 61st overall, but 69th in terms of information and communications technology (ICT) adoption, which includes criteria such as the percentage of internet users. The country ranks just 64th in internet usage and 59th in fixed-broadband technologies.
Across sectors, large, export-oriented private-sector firms tend to be the most technologically intensive. Firms in the automotive sector, usually structured as joint partnerships between Turkish conglomerates and major global auto producers, are a major driver of research and development (R&D) expenditure. Ford Otosan, the joint venture of Ford, a US-based car manufacturer, in Turkey has become a global hub for Ford's commercial vehicle development and output. In 2015 the company opened a US$25m R&D unit-Turkey's largest, employing about 1,500 engineers. Oyak-Renault, a joint venture between Renault, a French car manufacturer, and Oyak, the Turkish armed forces pension fund, won government financial support worth US$100m to support hybrid investments at its Bursa plant.
Turkey's technological prospects are unclear. The country has a young, dynamic labour pool, but Turkey's education system is inadequate at providing the skills demanded by employers. In fact, this is regularly one of businesses' top complaints. In addition, in recent years many of Turkey's most educated young people have emigrated abroad, which will make attracting top foreign talent and further foreign direct investment (FDI) more difficult.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include: LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Data sources and definitions The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data Global data
OECD growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data GDP growth and components: TurkStat
Population: UN Population database and Economist Intelligence Unit interpolation
Consumer prices: IMF, IFS; TurkStat
Industrial production: derived from OECD, Main Economic Indicators
Exchange rates and interest rates: IMF, IFS
External trade and balance of payments: IMF, IFS; Central Bank of Turkey; TurkStat
Central government financial balance: IMF, IFS; Turkish Treasury

Abbreviations IFS: International Financial Statistics

TurkStat: Turkish Statistical Institute
UNCTAD: UN Conference on Trade and Development
Guide to the business rankings model Outline of the model The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2016-20) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2021-25). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2016-20. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2021-25 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2016-20 ranges are then used to derive 2021-25 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2021-25, not to the likely situation in 2025 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2018 or 2023). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+South+Africa&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+South+Africa+May+2021+Updater&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2021-05-13&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+South+Africa&amp;rft.issn=09668683&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: - The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the president, Cyril Ramaphosa, to complete a first term in 2024 and run for a second term, but he could face a challenge for the leadership of the ruling African National Congress (ANC) at its five-yearly electoral summit in December 2022 in the absence of a post-pandemic economic rebound, with victory not assured.
- The economic and social damage wrought by the global coronavirus pandemic, alongside the need for urgent remedial action, will help to build support within the ANC for the president's reformist agenda, albeit reluctantly in some cases.
- Policy will focus on vaccine rollouts, infrastructure investment (led by the private sector) and combatting electricity shortages. Fiscal constraints point to an increased reliance on public-private partnerships for key projects. The fightback against corruption will gather momentum in 2021, as shown by the ANC's suspension of its secretary-general, Ace Magashule, in May for defying orders to step aside.
- Following a severe recession in 2020, with real GDP shrinking by 7% because of the pandemic, we expect a modest return to growth of 2.4% in 2021, helped by low interest rates and higher commodity prices, although power supply constraints, still-weak tourism and jobs lost to the pandemic will preclude a more rapid rebound. We envisage growth quickening to 2.7% a year on average in 2022-25, underpinned by structural reforms, but unemployment will continue to weigh on aggregate demand.
- Cumulative interest-rate cuts in 2020 cut the benchmark rate to 3.5%, providing relief to borrowers, but another reduction is unlikely. We expect interest rates to remain on hold until a small rise in late 2021 or early 2022.
- After easing to a multi-year low of 3.2% in 2020, average inflation will rise to 3.7% in 2021, owing to costlier oil and electricity, but weak demand will keep price growth subdued. Inflation will quicken to 4.5% a year on average in 2022-25 as economic growth stages a gradual post-pandemic recovery.
- South Africa recorded a rare current-account surplus in 2020 of 2.2% of GDP as exports fell more slowly than imports, pushing up the merchandise trade surplus. Trends in 2021, including buoyant exports, point to another (albeit smaller) current-account surplus, before the return of a deficit in 2022-25 as imports regain traction.

- South Africa's business environment score improves for 2021-25, although its global ranking drops by one and its regional ranking is unchanged from 2016-20. Market opportunity and infrastructure gains will be partly offset by deteriorations in macroeconomic stability and taxation.

Country forecast overview: South Africa's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2021-22: A post-pandemic investment drive, focused on infrastructure, facilitates public-private partnerships. Challenges include tighter competition laws and stricter black economic empowerment (BEE) rules.
2023-25: Expropriation without compensation, to speed up land reform, applies in limited circumstances only, reducing the threat to property rights. Investment incentives in selected industries (such as automotive manufacturing) remain in place.
Policy towards foreign investment 2021-22: A reworked mining charter offers some concessions to business. A new foreign investment law limits access to international arbitration by giving local courts the primary responsibility for handling disputes.
2023-25: The government continues to encourage foreign investment and public-private partnerships, but resists the full privatisation of state assets in most cases.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2021-22: The government implements a further relaxation of capital controls on outward investment and other flows.
2023-25: Progress towards regional economic integration in Southern Africa makes some advances, but barriers persist.
Taxes 2021-22: Despite tough fiscal conditions, the government avoids major tax increases to shield households and firms.
2023-25: Efforts to streamline and modernise the tax system and expand the tax base continue.
Financing 2021-22: Cuts in the benchmark interest rate and other liquidity-boosting measures help to support banks and firms during the pandemic. Local banks remain sound and a major source of corporate financing, despite profits being squeezed.
2023-25: The continued independence of the South African Reserve Bank (the central bank) helps to preserve financial system stability. Monetary policy remains prudent and interest rates edge higher. The proposed nationalisation of the central bank is symbolic.
The labour market 2021-22: Pandemic-induced job losses oblige trade unions to accept a mild relaxation of currently inflexible labour laws.
2023-25: The labour market remains tough, owing to skills shortages and BEE targets.
Infrastructure 2021-22: Investment in transport and electricity, led in many cases by private firms, boosts capacity.
2023-25: Private-sector-led investment in renewable energy gathers momentum under the government's long-term energy plan, adding diversity to power supplies and cutting reliance on coal. Rising power tariffs drive energy efficiency.
Technological readiness 2021-22: The rollout of domestic fibre-optic cables boosts capacity and cuts costs. Investment in digital technology gathers momentum, including in cloud computing and high-end data analysis. The allocation of new spectrum boosts capacity
2023-25: Work advances on the Square Kilometre Array-a powerful radio telescope with multinational support-giving a wider boost to science and to information and communications technology.

Background: South Africa became a full democracy in 1994, when it first held all-race elections. The African National Congress (ANC) won, and has dominated all subsequent elections-in 1999, 2004, 2009, 2014 and 2019. However, support ebbed steadily from a peak of nearly 70% in 2004, to 62.1% in 2014 and 57.5% in May 2019. The ANC feared a worse result in 2019, but the installation of Cyril Ramaphosa as president in February 2018, replacing the scandal-tainted Jacob Zuma, provided a mild bounce. Barring shocks, Mr Ramaphosa will serve a full five-year term ending in 2024 and would be eligible for a second term.
Political structure: South Africa is a constitutional democracy with a bicameral parliament and a president elected by parliament. The constitution is the supreme law. The National Assembly is elected by proportional representation; the National Council of the Provinces consists of indirectly elected representatives of the nine provinces. The judiciary is independent and includes an 11-member Constitutional Court. The constitution provides for an independent corruption watchdog-the Public Protector-and commissions on human rights, gender equality and restitution of land rights.
Policy issues: The main policy focus in 2021-25 will be to facilitate recovery from a severe recession in 2020, caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The need to boost post-pandemic growth will allow Mr Ramaphosa to push ahead more forcefully with his reformist agenda. A new economic recovery and reconstruction plan will focus on investment in critical infrastructure (such as housing and transport), led by the private sector, alongside a large-scale public works programme to create jobs. Tackling power shortages by commissioning new capacity from independent power producers, and by restructuring Eskom, the highly-indebted electricity parastatal, is another key objective. Fiscal constraints point to an increased reliance on public-private partnerships, despite resistance from vested interests. A new draft expropriation bill sets clear limits on when compensation is not payable, thus diminishing the threat to property rights and investor confidence. Challenges include skills shortages, stricter competition laws and the perennial risk of strikes.
Taxation: Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at a flat rate of 15%-after a rise from 14% on April 1st 2018-although some essentials are zero-rated. Corporation tax (of 28%), income tax and VAT were left unchanged in the 2021/22 budget but a corporation tax cut is earmarked for 2022/23. Some tax concessions are available, including in special economic zones.
Foreign trade: South Africa has a relatively open economy, with foreign trade (imports plus exports) accounting for about 52% of GDP. China, the EU, the US and Japan are among its largest trading partners. Trade with the rest of Africa has become progressively more important and makes a large contribution to South Africa's merchandise trade surplus.

Outlook for 2021-25: Political stability Recovering from the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic and a deep recession in 2020 will confront South Africa with unparalleled challenges, but the growing authority of the president, Cyril Ramaphosa, has positive implications for political stability and economic reform. On the pandemic front, new cases and deaths have remained low and stable since a deadly second wave faded in February, but there are risks of a resurgence. Vaccination will be rolled out in May before gaining momentum in July-December, but a range of global bottlenecks in the vaccine production supply chain means that timely delivery is not assured. South Africa consequently faces the threat of a third wave of Covid-19 during the southern hemisphere winter (June-August), which could stifle the economic recovery and aggravate social tensions ahead of nationwide municipal elections in October.
Since being elected for a five-year term in May 2019 Mr Ramaphosa has struggled to unite the disparate factions of the ruling party, the African National Congress (ANC), behind a reformist agenda, but a severe recession in 2020, accompanied by heavy job losses and rising poverty, is changing the political dynamic. After several years of policy fudges to appease powerful interest groups (such as labour unions), the need for urgent action to repair the economy-including by working more closely with the private sector-is boosting support for the president's agenda. The two main sources of resistance to Mr Ramaphosa within the ANC are left-wing interventionists-which will remain wedded to a strong state role in the economy-and the so-called radical economic transformation movement that emerged during the presidency of Jacob Zuma (2009-18), which is blamed for facilitating corruption and patronage under the guise of black economic empowerment.
In a key victory for Mr Ramaphosa over the pro-Zuma faction in early May, the ANC's National Executive Committee suspended the party's secretary-general, Ace Magashule, after he defied a new rule requiring members formally charged with corruption (and other serious crimes) to stand aside from their positions. Given the powerful role played by the secretary-general in choosing election candidates and organising key summits, Mr Magashule's suspension (ahead of his next court appearance in August), gives Mr Ramaphosa a valuable opportunity to reshape party structures and policies, and escalate the fight against corruption. In a further blow to the radicals, Mr Zuma risks being jailed either for defying a Constitutional Court order to appear before an inquiry into state capture (being led by the deputy chief justice, Raymond Zondo) or on long-standing corruption charges linked to an arms deal, which moves to a full trial in May.
The left, while still clamouring for wage rises, is now resigned to a more prominent role for the private sector and the restructuring of dysfunctional parastatal firms, in view of the state's financial and technical capacity constraints. Heavy job losses are inevitably weakening trade unions' influence in both the private and the public sectors, obliging them to compromise in many cases. Policy debates will continue but Mr Ramaphosa's tighter grip on the ANC will mean that the structural reforms needed to bolster economic growth and job creation will take place.
Outlook for 2021-25: Election watch The next major political event is the ANC's five-yearly National General Council (NGC)-a policy implementation review-which will give a clearer indication of the balance of forces in the party and the extent of Mr Ramaphosa's control. After being delayed by more than a year by the pandemic, the NGC's timing is still uncertain, although The Economist Intelligence Unit expects it to take place before the next five-yearly municipal elections on October 27th 2021. The nationwide ballot will give voters the first chance to judge the government's pandemic response and will be a test of Mr Ramaphosa's and the ANC's popularity. A voting share for the ANC in the 55-60% range in 2021 (compared with 57.5% in the 2019 general election) would be seen as satisfactory, but a drop into the 50-55% range could see Mr Ramaphosa face a leadership challenge at the ANC's next electoral summit in December 2022. We expect the ANC, under Mr Ramaphosa, to retain power at the next general election (in 2024), but with a smaller majority than in 2019. The implementation of a new Political Party Funding Act from April 2021 will strengthen transparency.
Outlook for 2021-25: International relations South Africa-the most advanced economy in Africa and a major business hub-will remain deeply engaged in the continent, particularly in Southern and East Africa. Despite a challenging environment, South Africa will continue to attract international companies, including from the US, Europe and Asia, owing to strong institutions, sound banks and its role as continental gateway. South Africa's commercial involvement in other African markets will remain broad-based, covering mining, banking, telecommunications, retail and hospitality. The pandemic is causing temporary disruption to regional relations because of border closures and flight bans, aggravated by a second wave of infections, but regional access for South Africa-based firms will improve in 2021, helped by vaccine rollouts.
Outlook for 2021-25: Policy trends The most immediate policy challenge facing the government is to revive the economy following the pandemic-induced contraction in 2020. Containment measures have been alternatively tightened and loosened since the pandemic erupted-with the latest move, to level one, the most relaxed, taking place on March 1st-but the cost of the pandemic in terms of lost jobs and income remains heavy. A second wave of infections, driven by a new, more transmissible viral variant, led to more cases and deaths in December/January than during the first peak in July/August 2020, but the figures have since remained low and stable. A vaccine rollout will gather pace from May onwards but widespread immunisation is unlikely in South Africa until later in 2021, given global shortages, which increases the risk of a third wave of Covid-19.
The government will attempt to engineer a growth rebound in 2021-25, via targeted measures and deeper structural reforms, although the scope for additional monetary and fiscal intervention is limited. With the benchmark interest rate at a record low of 3.5%, there is little room for further cuts, and several years of heavy spending and rising budget deficits preclude broad-based fiscal stimulus. Even before the pandemic South Africa was trapped in a low-growth trajectory-not for the want of pro-growth plans, but because of policy fudges between left-wing and pro-business factions and weak implementation. The pandemic, by exposing underlying weaknesses (such as widespread poverty and inequality) and by highlighting the need for urgent action, will be a catalyst for deeper and more rapid structural reforms, including a greater role for the private sector.
Devised in consultation with business and organised labour, an economic recovery and reconstruction plan will focus on job creation-via large-scale public works programmes-and infrastructure investment. The plan aims to channel R100bn (US$6.8bn) over ten years into an infrastructure fund with the aim of attracting a ten times greater sum from the private sector via public-private partnerships. Projects already identified include housing and network infrastructure. Restoring energy security by adding new capacity (mostly solar and wind) from independent power producers is a key target, as is the planned auction of new broadband spectrum in 2021, which will boost communication and digitalisation. Despite these encouraging signs, it is unlikely that the first major additional increments to power supply will come on stream until mid-2022. New renewable capacity, comprising solar and wind, will be the quickest to materialise. Nevertheless, solar projects typically take from 18 months to two years from inception to completion; the timeframe for wind schemes ranges from two to three years. Other schemes, such as those for gas, are likely to take longer. As a result, further episodes of load-shedding appear likely over the next two years, before the situation improves later in the forecast period. Restructuring dysfunctional parastatal firms is another central priority. Implementation remains a challenge, but the political will to act is now stronger. Commitments to the IMF in return for a rapid financing instrument (RFI) in July 2020 will add impetus to reforms in the face of resistance from vested interests. We expect economic policy to support medium-term growth momentum and to help the country to emerge from secular stagnation.
Outlook for 2021-25: Fiscal policy A surge in the budget deficit in fiscal year 2020/21 (April-March) reflects heavy revenue losses and higher spending during the pandemic and recession. The 2020/21 shortfall was, nonetheless, smaller than the deficit of 15.7% of GDP predicted by the Treasury, because of a belated revenue boost from higher commodity prices, alongside gains from an overhaul of the South African Revenue Service (the tax agency). The brighter revenue outlook means than planned tax hikes in 2021/22 are expected to be put on hold and a vaccine rollout costing an initial R9bn (US$620m) over two years is fully funded. The budget for 2021/22, unveiled in February, outlines a path of medium-term fiscal consolidation premised on public-sector wage restraint. We expect the shortfall as a percentage of GDP to ebb to 9.2% in 2021/22 and 7.5% in 2022/23, before easing to 3.5% in 2025/26. The biggest risks to fiscal consolidation are a fightback by labour unions against wage restraint (via a combination of legal action, political pressure and possible strikes) and the heavy debt burdens of parastatal enterprises.
After surging to about 78% at end-2020/21 because of higher borrowing and a recession, the public debt/GDP ratio will rise more slowly as fiscal revenue recovers, peaking at about 87.4% of GDP at end-2023/25, before easing to 82.9% at end-2025/26. Fiscal consolidation will reduce South Africa's risk of debt distress, as will the government's recourse to deep and liquid domestic capital markets to finance most of the budget shortfalls. Debt-servicing costs will continue rising, however, leaving limited room for slippage on either the spending or the revenue fronts. A failure to meet debt targets could oblige South Africa to undertake a formal IMF programme with strict conditions attached.
Outlook for 2021-25: Monetary policy Policy accommodation during the 2020 pandemic crisis will give way to a normalisation process in 2022, with interest rates edging higher as the economy begins to recover. The South African Reserve Bank (SARB, the central bank) cut the benchmark interest rate (repo rate) five times in 2020-most recently in July-by a cumulative 300 basis points to 3.5%, to help to shield the economy from the pandemic. However, the rate has since remained on hold, reflecting limited scope for additional loosening. We expect the SARB to maintain its current stance throughout most of 2021, but the expected resumption of real GDP growth and a mild inflation upswing point to a small rate rise in early 2022 or later. Additional small increases will follow in 2023-25, broadly tracking US trends.
Outlook for 2021-25: Economic growth Following a steep contraction of 7% in 2020 because of the pandemic impact, we now expect real GDP to grow by 2.4% in 2021 (revised up from 2%), signalling a still-moderate rebound. The upward revision reflects an improved outlook for vaccine provision (after the government agreed contracts with Johnson & Johnson and Pfizer), higher commodity prices, stronger export demand, another good farm season and the maintenance of low interest rates. Several factors will dampen the rebound in 2021, however, including a probable year-on-year economic contraction in the first quarter (because of the mostly pre-pandemic baseline), electricity supply constraints, a sluggish recovery in tourism and hospitality, and elevated unemployment, which will sap aggregate demand. In addition, downside risks include public-sector strikes in response to a pay freeze, and a third wave of Covid-19 during the southern hemisphere winter (June-August), which would stifle the pace of recovery.
Given that a rebound in 2021 largely reflects a very weak baseline in 2020, our growth forecast for 2022 is unchanged at 2.2%, implying a slight slowdown. The economy will benefit in 2022 from a relaxation of power supply constraints from mid-year (after the planned commissioning of new generating capacity) and from stronger private investment in response to favourable policy initiatives, such as moves to facilitate public-private partnerships. Hurdles to growth in 2022 will be a global slowdown (after a 2021 rebound), persistently high unemployment and still-fragile tourism. We expect growth to strengthen to 2.8% a year on average in 2023-25, underpinned by long-delayed reforms (such as parastatal restructuring) and the spread of digital technology, but the global backdrop will remain subdued in terms of economic growth and trade flows.
Outlook for 2021-25: Inflation After dipping to a multi-year low of 3.2% in 2020, owing to recession, cheaper imported oil and a bumper food harvest, inflation will edge up to 3.7% in 2021, but will remain comfortably within the SARB's 3-6% target range. The primary sources of inflation in 2021 will be higher oil prices and costlier electricity tariffs, although the prospect of a second consecutive bumper harvest in the 2020/21 season will offset higher global food prices. Other factors curbing inflation are mild rand appreciation in 2021, weak aggregate demand (owing to unemployment and income losses), spare industrial capacity and strong retail competition. We expect inflation to quicken to an average of 4.5% a year in 2022-25, spurred by a modest revival in GDP growth, but the level will stay within the SARB's target range, temporary breaches aside.
Outlook for 2021-25: Exchange rates Stronger commodity prices and global liquidity injections will support the rand in 2021, as shown by a 22.4% year-on-year appreciation of the currency to R14.41:US$1 in April, its strongest level since before the pandemic. Being commodity-dependent, widely traded and an emerging-market proxy, the rand will benefit from a positive global backdrop, but remain vulnerable to any adverse shifts in global sentiment and to negative domestic developments. We see the rand weakening from current levels, in view of South Africa's large fiscal deficit and sluggish growth outlook-alongside potential global tensions-ending 2021 at R16.16:US$1 (revised from R16.61:US$1). On an annual average basis, we forecast strengthening to R15.39:US$1 in 2021 (revised from R15.77:US$1) as markets normalise after disruption in 2020. The rand will remain volatile, often experiencing large daily movements in response to shifting sentiment, although South Africa's modest external debt stock and healthy foreign-exchange reserves are protective. Our forecast assumes gradual depreciation from 2022 onwards, with the rand slipping to R19.07:US$1 at end-2025, although the pace of decline will be close to the inflation rate, implying a drop in real effective exchange rate.
Outlook for 2021-25: External sector The impact of the pandemic on the external accounts will persist in 2021, and we expect another rare current-account surplus and a net contribution to GDP growth. The pandemic led to a much steeper fall in imports than in exports in 2020, generating a large merchandise trade surplus, which offset the perennial deficit on invisible trade to produce a current-account surplus of 2.2% of GDP. In 2021 a healthy increase in export earnings (underpinned by higher commodity prices) will be outweighed by a rebound in imports as the economy recovers (and oil prices rise), reducing the merchandise trade surplus and the current-account surplus (to 1.5% of GDP). Our forecast for 2023-25 envisages a return to a current-account deficit, with the shortfall averaging 2.6% of GDP a year, as the invisible trade deficit (underpinned by income outflows to foreign investors) surpasses the merchandise trade surplus. The current-account deficit will be smaller than pre-pandemic levels but will leave South Africa reliant on financial inflows to plug the gap.
Foreign direct investment inflows will recover from 2021, helped by structural reforms to boost public-private partnerships, including private investment in parastatal enterprises. We expect inflows of US$5.2bn a year on average (just under 10% of gross financing needs). South Africa will remain a key base for multinational companies with pan-African operations by offering a range of services, including banking, capital-raising and trade-related functions.

Dollar effective exchange rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data Trade by country: IMF, Direction of Trade Statistics
Population: Based on UN data for both the historical and the forecast periods
Balance of payments: IMF, IFS
Inflation: Statistics South Africa. Based on CPIX (consumer price inflation less mortgage costs)
Exchange rate: IMF, IFS; principal rate expressed as R:US$
Real effective exchange rate index: based on consumer price index; trade partner weighted index with base period 2000=100
Interest rate: IMF, IFS; average lending rate
US$ GDP: SARB, Quarterly Bulletin; in current prices converted from local currency at annual average market exchange rate
GDP per head: US$ GDP divided by population
Foreign direct investment: IMF, IFS; UNCTAD, World Investment Report
Total external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; sum of long-term debt, short-term debt and IMF credits
Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics, year-end medium- and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding, with an original maturity in excess of one year
Short-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end debt outstanding, with an original maturity of less than one year
Total debt service: principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges paid against total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Interest payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services

Full text: - Following the general election in December 2019, the Conservative Party led by Boris Johnson has an 87-seat working majority in parliament. This majority will be robust to any changes in parliament, and The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the government to last its full term until 2024. The UK left the EU on January 31st, 2020, and left the single market and customs union on January 1st 2021, entering into a more limited trade agreement. The outbreak of the novel coronavirus was the government's primary focus in 2020, and managing the recovery from the pandemic and ensuing recession will dominate the government's priorities in the coming years. Adjusting to a political and economic order outside the EU will also lead to significant political changes, not least in managing separatist sentiment in Scotland and maintaining the peace in Northern Ireland which is threatened by post-Brexit trade frictions.

- The UK's score in the business environment rankings rises in the forecast period (2021-25) compared with the historical period (2016-20), reflecting receding Brexit and coronavirus uncertainties. The UK rises by one place in the regional ranking, but remains in 17th place globally. The macroeconomic environment will improve as the pandemic abates, with the UK's strong consumer base driving the recovery. Increased trade barriers between the UK and the rest of Europe will constrain growth in the short term, but the UK's traditional strengths-a pro-business policy orientation, a fairly low burden of regulation, and flexible labour and product markets-will support the recovery. Structural deficits such as weak productivity and inadequate intermediate skills will probably persist.

- Real GDP fell by 9.9% in 2020 as a result of the coronavirus pandemic, one of the worst global outturns. A successful vaccination campaign and pent-up demand will lead to strong catch-up growth in 2021 and 2022, with GDP returning to pre-crisis levels in late 2022. Over the medium term, growth will be constrained by weaker export growth post-Brexit, lacklustre investment and productivity growth, and an increased tax burden.

- The coronavirus has led to significant one-off changes in UK demographics during 2020 and 2021, with a significant increase in excess deaths owing to the coronavirus pandemic, and a significant net out-migration of foreign workers, estimated at more than a million. Once these forces abate, the UK population is forecast to grow at an annual average rate of 0.4% in 2021-25, supported by natural change (an excess of births over deaths) and net immigration. The UK's rate of population growth, both in terms of natural increase and immigration, has exceeded the EU average. The government has introduced a new skills-based immigration system, which we expect to reduce net inflows of citizens from the EU, but this is likely to be offset by increased arrivals from non-EU countries. Softer labour force growth and an ageing population will imply a rising share of public expenditure on healthcare, social care and pension-related spending.

- The coronavirus is likely to lead to a significant transformation of the UK's retail sector, which will stimulate growth: there will be an accelerated shift to online services and a glut of household savings will be drawn down over several years. The departure of the UK from the single market will have a negative impact on the export sector. However, despite heightened uncertainty, the large, rich and flexible UK economy will continue to provide opportunities for inward investors and global exporters.

- Real GDP is forecast to grow by an annual average of 2.4% in 2021-30, some of which will represent catch-up growth from the pandemic. Growth will decelerate to an average of 1.8% per year in 2031-50 (1.5% in per capita terms). Longer-term changes in living standards will depend increasingly on productivity. Technological progress will be an important driver, but productivity levels will remain lower than in the US, Germany and France, reflecting a deficit in intermediate skills and infrastructure shortcomings.

Background: The end of the second world war coincided with the decline of the UK as an imperial power. Residual links with former colonial territories, close relations with the US and a separate sense of identity delayed UK membership of the European Community (now the EU) until 1973. Successive governments resisted closer EU integration. Following a 2016 referendum on EU membership, the UK left the EU single market and customs union in January 2021 The future contours of the UK's relationship with the EU are in flux, but a diminution of UK influence in the region appears to be inevitable.
Political structure: The UK is a constitutional monarchy. The head of state is Queen Elizabeth II. Parliament has an elected House of Commons (the lower house, 650 seats) and a non-elected House of Lords (the upper house, non-fixed membership of about 800). The snap general election in December 2019 produced a majority government for the centre-right Conservative Party, which won 365 seats. The main opposition Labour Party won 202 seats, with smaller parties winning the remaining 83. This government is likely to serve out its full term until the next scheduled election, in 2024.
Policy issues: The coronavirus outbreak has dominated UK politics since March 2020. The government embarked on massive fiscal expansion to support workers and businesses affected by the virus and containment measures, while the Bank of England (the central bank) has moved rates to record-lows, which is likely to persist into 2022. The government expects to begin fiscal consolidation in 2022, although headline debt will remain high as a percentage of GDP. Supporting industries affected by increased Brexit-related trade frictions will dominate UK policymaking. Maintaining competitiveness in this environment will force policymakers to address structural deficiencies such as low productivity.
Taxation: The headline rate of corporation tax has been reduced steadily, from 28% in 2010 to 19%, since April 2018. There are three bands of personal income tax, set at 20%, 40% and 45% (the 45% rate came into effect in April 2013, replacing the 50% rate introduced in 2010). The standard rate of value-added tax (VAT) is 20% (raised from 17.5% in 2011). Excise duties on tobacco and alcohol are among the highest in Europe.
Foreign trade: In 2020 exports of goods totalled an estimated US$399bn and imports amounted to US$548bn, resulting in a trade deficit of US$149bn. The services surplus expanded to US$138bn. The overall current-account widened in absolute terms, from US$87.6bn in 2019 to US$95.4bn, widening as a share of GDP, from 3.1% to 3.5%.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance The UK is a parliamentary democracy. The legislature consists of an elected lower chamber, the House of Commons (650 seats), and an unelected upper chamber, the House of Lords (about 775 members), which was partly reformed in 1999. Pending a second stage of reform, most members of the House of Lords are appointed life peers. Following the most recent election in December 2019, the centre-right Conservative Party formed a majority government under the prime minister, Boris Johnson, with 365 of the 650 seats in parliament. The opposition Labour Party suffered its worst result since 1935, holding only 202 seats. The third-largest party is the Scottish National Party (SNP), winning 48 of Scotland's 59 seats. The remainder of the parliamentary seats are held by the Liberal Democrats, the Green Party, and several Northern Irish parties. The next election is scheduled for 2024, and we do not expect an early election given the size of the Conservative majority.

Political outlook: Political stability At the general election on December 12th 2019, the Conservative Party, under the prime minister, Boris Johnson, won an 80-seat majority. On January 31st 2020 Mr Johnson fulfilled his campaign promise to take the UK out of the EU, ending 47 years of EU membership. On January 1st 2021 the UK left the EU's single market and customs union after negotiating a free-trade agreement. The government is currently managing the implementation of a new trading relationship with the EU while addressing the fallout from the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic. Despite the challenges posed by these two issues, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the government to last a full term.
The spread of the coronavirus in early 2020 put the government on a crisis-management footing. In March 2020 it instructed a strict lockdown for over three months. After a relaxation of restrictions in the summer, the government implemented a second lockdown in England between November and December. The spread of a new, significantly more contagious variant of the virus led the government to impose a third, more severe lockdown in January 2021, with schools and non-essential businesses being closed. Restrictions are now gradually being unwound, with phased reopening in five-week intervals: non-essential retail reopened on April 12th, with most hospitality to follow on May 17th and all remaining restrictions to be lifted on June 21st. The government is undertaking a mass vaccination programme; more than 67% of the adult population had received at least one dose of vaccine by May 8th. Devolved administrations in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland have enacted similar restrictions during these periods.
Brexit and the pandemic have increased the medium-term risk to the integrity of the UK. Nicola Sturgeon, the leader of the Scottish National Party (SNP), has argued that Brexit represents a material change in the relationship between Scotland and the UK since the 2014 referendum on Scottish independence where a majority favoured the continuation of the union. Support for Scottish independence spiked during the initial phase of the pandemic, as Scottish voters viewed their devolved government's response as more effective than that of the UK government. This has ebbed since the beginning of the vaccination campaign and, more recent polls now show a narrow lead for support for the union, although within the margin of error.
The SNP, along with the pro-independence Scottish Green Party have held a majority in the Scottish Parliament since 2016, and made modest gains in the most recent elections in May 2021, which Ms Sturgeon claims gives her a mandate to pursue a second referendum. The UK government has called for a summit on the future of the union; however, we do not believe these gains will provide sufficient political pressure to force the government to grant a second referendum in this parliament. Even if the UK government were to grant a second referendum, it would take several years to organise. Furthermore, divisions within pro-independence parties may undermine the unity of the movement. As a result, we believe that there are significant obstacles to Scotland becoming independent and do not expect it to happen during our forecast period.
Brexit has inflamed tensions in Northern Ireland. The UK and the EU agreed to a separate protocol for Northern Ireland to avoid border checks with the Republic of Ireland. Under this agreement, Northern Ireland is remaining within a regulatory union with the EU for most goods. Although it will stay in the UK customs and value-added tax (VAT) areas, customs and VAT checks are to be conducted by the UK on the EU's behalf at ports in the Irish Sea for goods bound for the EU. This requires the construction and implementation of checkpoints and border infrastructure between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK for all goods deemed by a UK-EU joint committee to be "at risk" of passing into the EU.
This arrangement has been difficult to implement, and is disliked by unionist Northern Irish politicians for ostensibly creating a border between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK. On April 2nd sustained rioting broke out in Northern Ireland for over a week. These protests originated among unionist communities partly in opposition to the Irish Sea border checks. This breakdown in order has intensified talks between the UK and EU around how to implement the Northern Ireland protocol. This had become a source of friction, with the EU launching legal action against the UK for unilaterally extending a series of grace periods for implementing customs checks between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK. Despite these tensions, we expect that the Northern Ireland protocol will remain in place, given the commitments by both sides to not recreate a hard customs border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland. However, tensions will remain high, with the ongoing risk of further violence.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness The next five years are likely to be a period of significant political, institutional and constitutional change in the UK. The government has acquired significant new public health powers to enforce lockdown and social distancing requirements for the duration of the pandemic and developed significant spending schemes for paying workers' wages and supporting businesses during lockdown. This has been backstopped by a robust bond-buying programme from the Bank of England (the central bank). The movement of additional competencies for economic policymaking from the EU to the UK, combined with the aftermath of the pandemic, will lead to significant pressure for change within the UK's political and institutional system and put it under severe strain.
Brexit and Covid have challenged the four UK nations' relationships The pandemic has had significant consequences for devolution-the transfer of powers from the central state to Scottish, Welsh, Northern Irish and regional authorities, which has been an evolving process since the 1990s. Public health is a devolved competency, and the Scottish government, led by the SNP, and Welsh government, led by the Labour Party, have taken public health approaches that often diverged from the policies followed by the central government for England, including in areas such as international travel restrictions, which would normally be handled by the central government. Brexit is also likely to exacerbate this trend, as the disapplication of EU law creates more latitude for policy divergence among the constituent nations.
The future of devolution within the UK is likely to come into question in the coming years. The devolution of public health and education powers to the constituent countries of the UK was highlighted during the pandemic. The lack of a devolved government for England, by far the largest of the constituent countries, has meant that the central UK government has found itself increasingly making policy for England alone, while the Scottish and Welsh publics engaged more with their devolved authorities than the central government. Disparate approaches to handling the pandemic in some areas also highlighted conflict between the central Conservative-led government, and the SNP and Labour party governments in Scotland and Wales respectively, as well as local Labour-led city and regional governments in England.
In the absence of EU rules post-Brexit, the central government will need to provide consistency in the legal framework within the UK's internal market. It has retained or reasserted control over most competencies around product and market regulation at a UK level. However, in Scotland, in particular, such an approach may encourage resentment of the Westminster government among nationalist voters. The UK government can impose legislation on Scotland, but this would overturn two decades (since the latest phase of devolution began in 1997) of constitutional convention and would risk inflaming pro-independence sentiment. The central government still controls most revenue-raising decisions, and funded the furlough and other extraordinary fiscal support schemes centrally, suggesting that future clashes over taxation and spending authority between the central and devolved authorities are likely.
Tensions in Northern Ireland have increased over the Brexit protocol Northern Ireland faces many of the same issues around devolution but these frictions have been exacerbated by tensions over Brexit and lingering sectarian divisions. The erection of customs checks between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK has restricted the ability of traders to remain in the Northern Irish market and prompted rioting by members of the Unionist community. Dissatisfaction with the Northern Ireland protocol among Unionists led to the resignation in May 2021 of the first minister, Arlene Foster, a moderate, who is likely to be replaced by a more radical leader staunchly opposed to the UK-EU protocol. The outbreak of violence has prompted an intensification of negotiations between the UK and EU aimed at making the protocol work more effectively. However, there is a significant risk that these talks will not improve matters, leading to an abandonment of the protocol by the UK. The next elections for the Northern Irish Assembly in 2022 may see additional gains for the Nationalists if the Unionist vote remains fragmented, leading to further political instability.
Constitutional reform over elections appears inevitable. Elections are currently governed by the 2010 fixed-term parliaments act (FTPA), which requires either a two-thirds vote or the loss of a no-confidence vote to hold an election before the five-year term of a parliament elapses. However, in 2019 this had the effect of creating a prolonged impasse in parliament over Brexit, which was resolved by temporarily disapplying the act to hold an election. The Conservative government plans to repeal the law, although it has not yet put forward a replacement mechanism. The boundaries for individual constituencies for the House of Commons are also likely to be changed before the next election-the current boundaries have been in place since 2010, and the government plans to update them in advance of the next election. Given changes in population, demographers estimate that a boundary review would lead to a modest increase in seats for the Conservatives based on 2019 election results.
Political outlook: Election watch Under the Fixed-term Parliaments Act (FTPA), the next general election is scheduled for May 2nd 2024. The government has introduced a bill to repeal the FTPA. However, even if this is passed, a general election must be called within five years of the preceding one; they are usually held in May, to coincide with local elections.
During the course of the pandemic, the Conservative Party's lead in opinion polls over the opposition Labour Party dropped from more than 20 percentage points at the outbreak of the crisis to a near-tie after several scandals and rapid policy reversals reduced faith in the government. Since the success of the vaccine programme, the Conservatives' polling position has improved to 6-10 points ahead of Labour, which may persist if the government is seen to manage the recovery well. Local elections on May 6th saw the Conservative Party make gains on local councils, consistent with this level of national polling lead.
Political outlook: International relations The EU-UK Trade and Co-operation Agreement (TCA) was reached on December 24th 2020. The TCA is a free-trade agreement that succeeds the UK's membership of the EU single market and customs union, following its exit from EU institutions on January 1st 2021. The TCA provides for zero-tariff, zero-quota trade between the UK and EU, at least in the first instance. However, leaving the single market and customs union has created a variety of non-tariff trade barriers in the forms of border checks and product certifications. The agreement also provides a mechanism whereby if the divergence in regulations on labour, the environment or state aid becomes sufficiently great, the other side can implement retaliatory tariffs to compensate, subject to an arbitration period. The regulatory and tariff regimes may therefore drift apart over time. The TCA also leaves several areas unsettled. Negotiations between the UK and EU are ongoing over the UK receiving designations of equivalence on financial services, allowing for greater access to the EU market; and a draft finding of "adequacy" on the UK's data standards, which would allow the free flow of data. The UK has applied to re-join the Lugano convention, which allows legal judgements to be enforced across borders, but this is also opposed by several EU member states.
The UK government has stated its intention to be outward looking, pursuing a "Global Britain" strategy, and unveiled an updated defence and security policy in March 2021 outlining a strategy of greater engagement in Asia, in addition to continued engagement in the Atlantic. The UK holds the presidency of the G7 group of nations in 2021 and will host the UN Climate Change Conference (COP26) in Glasgow in November. It intends to use these platforms to take an enhanced role in global climate change policy. On trade, the UK has achieved continuity agreements with most countries that had agreements with the EU, is seeking an agreement with the US and has applied to join the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), a trade bloc of 11 Pacific nations.

The UK's score in The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings rises slightly, from 7.7 in the historical period (2016-20) to 7.8 in the forecast period (2021-25). The country's global ranking remains unchanged as the 17th most attractive business location, while at a regional level the UK climbs one place to tenth among its 18 peers.
The strongest improvements in the business environment in 2021-25 are in market opportunities and the macroeconomic environment, reflecting the recovery from the coronavirus pandemic after a historic recession in 2020. New economic frictions caused by Brexit are reflected in lower scores for foreign trade and exchange controls and the labour market.
Traditional UK strengths will remain attractive to firms, but are weakening The UK's traditional strengths as a business location have been relatively flexible labour and product markets; a pro-business policy orientation; a low burden of regulation; a welcoming attitude to foreign investment; and a stable institutional framework. Over the past five years, the UK has also made steady improvements to its digital infrastructure and to the resilience of its financial sector. Compared with many countries, these aspects of the business environment should remain attractive to firms in 2021-25, but as a result of Brexit, we expect a deterioration in some areas. The tax burden on income and business will rise over the forecast period as the government seeks to stabilise the public debt accrued during the pandemic. As in the rest of the world, national security concerns around foreign investment are hardening; the burden of regulation is likely to rise; the geopolitical environment appears less stable than in recent decades; and the creation of new trade barriers and a more restrictive immigration policy towards EU nationals limit the upside potential for foreign investors. Persistent structural weaknesses of the business environment, weak productivity and a deficit in intermediate skills are likely to persist, despite attempts at policy intermediation.
