Business environment outlook: United Kingdom's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2021-22: Extraordinary public support for businesses affected by coronavirus. "Super-deduction" of 130% on capital investment.
2023-25: Continued elevated state intervention in investment and innovation. New state aid rules implemented.
Policy towards foreign investment 2021-22: Coronavirus and Brexit uncertainty limits investment opportunities. Continued openness to investment, although increased scrutiny in sectors considered sensitive to national security.
2023-25: Infrastructure plans offer investment opportunities. Possible changes in tax policies to bolster inward investment.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2021-22: Increased trade barriers with EU. New Northern Ireland protocol implemented. Negotiations continue with third countries. Expected decline in UK-EU crossborder trade. Bounce-back in global trade following pandemic.
2023-25: Likely continued UK-EU negotiations. New trade agreements with other countries, including potential accession to Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) trade bloc.
Taxes 2021-22: Tax holidays and deferments throughout the coronavirus crisis. Changes to the value-added tax (VAT) framework.
2023-25: Corporation tax increase from 19% to 25%. Additional tax increases likely to funding public spending and investment, such as equalisation of self-employed and regular income taxes.
Financing 2021-22: Monetary policy remains highly accommodative, with Bank of England (central bank) asset purchases continuing. Loss of "passporting" rights and restrictions on EU services trade. Slow progress in establishing equivalence with the EU.
2023-25: Modest decline in City of London's status. Steady growth in alternative forms of debt financing.
The labour market 2021-22: Increased unemployment as furlough scheme expires. Pandemic-caused departure of expatriates and sharp drop in immigration from EU due to end to free movement of labour. Increased immigration from Hong Kong.
2023-25: Greater emphasis on skills-based migration from outside EU may risk labour shortages in low-skilled occupations.
Infrastructure 2021-22: Modest rise in spending on housing, roads and digital infrastructure. Crossrail service in London begins operation.
2023-25: Increased infrastructure investment, emphasis on "levelling up" regional infrastructure and competitiveness.
Technological readiness 2021-22: High e-commerce penetration and strong research base, but UK research and development (R&D) spending remains below EU average. Continued high threat from cybercrime and cyber-espionage.
2023-25: Modest rise in public R&D spending. Development of state "blue skies" fund, possible weakening of research and innovation framework owing to more restricted access to EU structural programmes (such as Horizon 2020).
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
6.1 6.6 61 47 15 16
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Economic activity will rebound as uncertainty recedes The UK suffered one of the largest contractions in real GDP among European economies as a result of the coronavirus pandemic, despite a sizeable fiscal response. The years 2021-22 will be characterised by a strong recovery in private consumption as lockdown restrictions are lifted and fixed investment spikes, driven by government incentives and the end of Brexit uncertainty. Strong headline GDP figures will reflect catch-up growth rather than a step change in economic trends. From 2023 government support will be largely withdrawn and taxes will rise, and we expect growth to return closer to pre-pandemic rates with the additional friction of the UK's exit from the EU single market, with increased public investment largely balanced out by higher tax burdens.
The UK features flexible product and labour markets relative to its peers, a high employment rate and a more resilient banking sector than a decade ago. The UK's ability to borrow in its own currency offers policymakers more fiscal scope than many of their euro zone counterparts. The average maturity of UK government debt is the longest in the OECD by a considerable margin, which reduces refinancing risks. Room for manoeuvre will nevertheless be constrained in part by an already elevated stock of public debt (forecast to stabilise at around 107% of GDP by 2025) and a sizeable external deficit. Other structural limitations such as a low investment rate and poor productivity, significant skills gaps, high regional inequalities, and a reliance on consumer-facing services to drive growth, viewed alongside the erection of new trade barriers by Brexit, point to comparatively weakened medium-term growth potential.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
8.5 8.5 8 8 4 4
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The UK has long provided one of the world's most favourable environments for private enterprise, having pioneered the liberalisation of product markets and privatisation of state assets in the 1980s and 1990s. Levels of regulation across most services sectors are lower than the OECD average. The number of procedures, time taken and costs involved to start a new business are below the OECD average, and administrative processes involved in the payment of taxes, obtaining credit and utilities, resolving insolvency and the protection of minority investors are modest. Competition policy has been strengthened by reforms and stands up to comparison with other high-income countries. With the exception of the National Health Service (NHS), state ownership in major sectors of the economy has been fairly limited, with the government holding a majority stake in the Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS)-one of the "big four" commercial banks-retaining a presence in the nuclear and rail industries, and having become steadily more involved in the UK's housing market since the 2008 financial crisis. As in most west European countries, the level of state intervention increased sharply in response to the pandemic and is likely to remain elevated in the forecast period, even after the most acute support is withdrawn.
The Conservative government will pursue a more activist policy agenda
- Prior to the pandemic, the government had already signalled its intention to adopt a more activist, state-led policy agenda than previous Conservative administrations in areas such as infrastructure and innovation. This was extended to many other areas of the economy as a result of the crisis. Fiscal support included paying millions of workers' wages, backstopping billions of pounds of business loans and providing targeted aid to badly hit sectors such as rail and bus transport, air travel, hospitality, arts and education. Most measures were designed to be temporary, but the scale of damage from the pandemic, its scarring effects on the labour market and specific sectors, and the impact of Brexit-related disruption imply that state intervention will remain a more prominent feature of the business environment in the coming years.
- From an overall perspective, the policy environment for private enterprise should remain broadly favourable, with low levels of regulation in product and labour markets compared with many countries. However, the UK's exit from the single market and customs union has increased the administrative burden faced by all UK-based companies that engage in cross-border UK-EU trade or are integrated in global supply chains (which mostly flow through the EU).

Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
9.1 9.1 7 4 5 2
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Brexit and global tensions will make the UK a less attractive destination for FDI The UK has traditionally offered one of the world's most liberal environments for foreign investors. Since the 1980s successive governments have been favourably disposed towards inflows of foreign direct investment (FDI), with the UK's deep capital markets, liberalised product markets, modest regulatory burden and well-established institutional and legal framework. Aside from some restrictions in areas related to national security and media plurality, there are comparatively few limitations on foreign control. Once established in the UK, foreign firms are treated on an equal footing with domestic companies, including access to state-backed incentives. In many respects, official policies will remain supportive of attracting FDI over the forecast period, with new incentives likely to be rolled out in targeted sectors. However, amid the global shift towards protectionism in recent years, sentiment in the UK towards inward investment in "strategic" areas of the economy has hardened. In line with trends elsewhere, the government is adopting a more interventionist stance on foreign takeovers and tightening its screening regime for FDI.

- FDI activity has remained largely concentrated around London and south-east England, mainly in the areas of information technology, real estate, finance and knowledge-based professional services. While most sectors have seen reduced inflows since 2017, there has been a marked slowdown in many of the UK's largest manufacturing industries, including automotive, aerospace and pharma-ceuticals. There is substantial existing foreign ownership in these industries (which are more geographically dispersed across the UK) and many companies deferred new investments owing to Brexit-related uncertainty. Given the increase in post-Brexit trade barriers and the additional disruption caused by the pandemic, there is a significant risk that a number of high-profile foreign-owned companies will pursue more limited investment in the UK.

UK will remain open to investment but with more national security scrutiny
- In November 2020 the government published a National Security and Investment Bill (NSIB) that increases its powers to intervene in foreign investment transactions on national security grounds. The NSIB requires foreign investors to notify the UK government about prospective acquisitions of UK companies and intellectual property in 17 "sensitive" industries, including artificial intelligence, civil nuclear, computing hardware, data infrastructure, defence, energy and transport. The government expects the burden on businesses to be minor, but in April 2021 mooted increasing the foreign ownership threshold at which investors are required to notify the government from 15% to 25% and narrowing the definitions of the 17 sensitive industries to avoid deterring foreign investors.
- The government is paying increased attention to the involvement of state-backed foreign actors (such as Chinese firms and Middle East sovereign wealth funds) in strategic infrastructure assets. Similarly to the EU, the US and Australia, in July 2020 the UK banned Huawei, a Chinese telecommunications group, as a supplier for the UK's fifth-generation (5G) mobile network. However, in November 2020 the prime minister's office created a new Office for Investment to attract foreign investment in strategic infrastructure projects. The Office announced its first successful deal in March 2021, consisting of a large investment partnership between the UK government and Mubadala, an Abu Dhabi sovereign fund, in the life sciences, technology, green energy and infrastructure sectors. This suggests that the UK's increased focus on national security will not necessarily deter state-backed foreign investors.

Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
9.1 8.2 14 36 8 17
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The UK will face significant trade barriers with the EU as result of Brexit The UK's foreign trade regime in recent decades had been strongly defined by its membership of the EU; the country's exit from the bloc (by far its largest trading partner) therefore implies a major overhaul in the forecast period. There will be a marked deterioration in trading relations with the EU, and disruption to supply chains of UK-based exporters. The EU and UK agreed a Trade and Co-operation Agreement (TCA) in December 2020, which succeeds the UK's membership of the EU single market and customs union, which it left on January 1st 2021. The TCA primarily addresses issues around trade in goods, providing zero-tariff, zero-quota trade. However, it creates a variety of non-tariff trade barriers in the forms of border checks and product certifications. Although the TCA represents an increase in trade barriers between the EU and UK, it provides greater certainty for business and puts in place a framework for the relationship between the two parties. Talks on several important areas, including data, border controls and financial services, are continuing, but progress in expanding the TCA will be slow. There is a significant risk that the EU and UK regulatory and tariff regimes will drift apart over time.

- To minimise further disruption, the UK and the EU agreed to waive some declaration requirements around rules of origin for the first year of operation. Despite this, goods travelling between the UK and the EU face significant non-tariff barriers. For example, manufactured goods for sale in the UK and EU market have to be certified separately by product regulators in each jurisdiction. Further liberalisation in this area is possible over the forecast period, given the cost to businesses and the limited benefits to divergence in many industries, especially those sectors where the UK is integrated into EU supply chains.
- The end of the Brexit transition period has particularly increased trade frictions in Northern Ireland. The Northern Ireland protocol created distinctions between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK market, with Northern Ireland remaining in the EU's single market for goods, and EU customs rules being enforced at Northern Irish ports-creating a customs border in the Irish Sea. This has resulted in customs declarations and enhanced inspection facilities at Northern Irish ports, while additional sanitary and phytosanitary checks are conducted on some products entering from Great Britain. In early 2021 many customs declarations were waived as part of a grace period outlined in the UK's withdrawal agreement. The ending of the grace period will create greater disruption once the protocol is fully applied. The UK announced a unilateral extension of the grace period to October 1st 2021, in response to which the EU threated legal action. The dispute over the implementation of the protocol suggests that UK-EU tensions will persist over the forecast period, limiting the scope for addressing other challenges over the implementation of the TCA.
- Amid a fraying multilateral trade system; rising protectionist sentiment globally; deepening frictions in US-China, US-EU and Europe-China relations; and a once-in-a-generation negative shock to the world economy from the pandemic, the UK's attempt to develop an independent trade policy faces heightened risks. All official and independent analyses indicate that the economic damage from erecting new trade barriers with the EU will significantly outweigh any potential net gains from new free-trade agreements (FTAs) with non-EU countries. The UK has agreed FTAs with Canada, Japan and South Korea, largely continuing the pre-Brexit status quo with minor adjustments. However, new trade agreements with major economies such as the US, India and China will probably require concessions from the UK on market access and possibly on foreign policy issues.

Business environment outlook: Taxes                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
6.0 5.9 44 60 11 15
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The tax burden will rise over the forecast period We expect the tax regime to become less competitive in 2021-25 owing to a larger and more complex tax burden. We expect the government to need to raise taxes further than it has already announced, given its spending and investment commitments, and overall growth projections. The overall tax/GDP ratio has remained fairly stable over the past decade and at 33% in 2019 was slightly below the OECD average of 33.8%; taxation of labour income is competitive; and the headline corporation tax rate is currently comparatively low at 19% (down from 28% in 2010). However, the Office for Budget Responsibility estimates that by 2025 higher UK corporation tax rates will push the corporation tax revenue/GDP ratio above the OECD average. Marginal tax rates on corporate investment are high (owing to elevated business property taxes and a limited capital allowance regime) and the steady trend in the overall tax take has masked significant structural changes in the composition of revenue. Payment of some indirect taxes for businesses trading with the EU, such as value-added tax (VAT) and customs and excise duties, has become more onerous and complex following Brexit. The tax regime also suffers from an outdated system of residential property taxation, widespread tax avoidance among the wealthy and structures that can encourage aggressive tax-planning practices by multi-nationals.
But there will be tax relief in the near term
- The government provided temporary tax relief for companies and the self-employed in response to the pandemic. It cut the VAT rate from 20% to 5% for businesses in leisure and hospitality until September 2021, which will be followed by an interim rate of 12.5% for six months. It provided business rate holidays until June 2021, to be followed by a two-thirds-reduced rate for the rest of the financial year (April-June). It also cut stamp duty on house purchases until June 2021, with more modest relief until September 2021. To stimulate private investment, the government has introduced a two-year "super-deduction" allowing companies to write off up to 130% of the value of their plant and machinery investment on their taxable profits from 2021-23.
- From 2023 there will be a rise in the tax burden, to address the major deterioration in the public finances from the pandemic. The immediate tax rises are stealthy in nature, via "fiscal drag": the income-tax personal allowance, capital gains tax exemptions and other tax thresholds have been frozen to 2026. More noticeable is a planned rise in the corporation tax rate from 19% to 25% in 2023. This higher rate will apply to company profits over £250,000 (US$350,000), with rates tapering down to profits of £50,000, below which the rate will remain at 19%. This is the first corporation tax increase since 1974, and the UK will remain below the current average corporate tax rate of 27% in the G7 group of nations, but given the UK's broad corporate tax base, the effective tax rate will be higher. Given the March 2021 budget's optimistic productivity and spending assump-tions, we expect further tax increases over the forecast period. These could include changes in less high-profile areas such as self-employment contributions, inheritance and capital gains tax, and environmental levies. However, broader (and more unpopular) tax rises could be implemented if the government seeks, or is pressured, to adopt a faster pace of deficit reduction.
- The UK has a competitive regime for taxation of labour income, with one of the lowest tax wedges in the OECD. The tax burden on households has risen over the past decade, largely in response to various "stealth" taxes (such as on travel and insurance). The standard VAT rate is 20%-slightly higher than the OECD average. Excise duties on fuel, tobacco and alcohol are among the highest in Europe. Crossborder VAT rule changes coincided with the UK's exit from the EU single market at end-2020. All foreign businesses selling to UK customers are now required to register for VAT, collect and pay the tax, causing particular confusion for EU businesses accustomed to charging their domestic VAT rates. Additional complexity results from the £135 threshold at which VAT on imported goods is paid on delivery rather than at point of sale.

Business environment outlook: Financing                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
7.8 7.8 13 20 5 9
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Withdrawal of coronavirus support could affect quality of financial assets Since the 2008 financial crisis, the underlying resilience of the banking sector has improved. On aggregate the Tier 1 capital ratio of the banking sector rose during the pandemic, and was around three times higher than in 2008. Major banks have substantially reduced their reliance on wholesale funding and the non-performing loan ratio is among the lowest in Europe. Annual bank stress tests by the Bank of England (BoE, the central bank) have implied that the sector could withstand a major negative shock. Overall housing debt in the UK is high, but subdued mortgage growth and stabilising house prices in the years preceding the pandemic mitigated near-term risks. House price growth and mortgage activity accelerated in 2020, but the risk of a sharp correction appears low. Recent Financial Stability Reports by the BoE have judged that the financial system is generally resilient, but highlight the risk of rising unemployment and business insolvencies as policy support is withdrawn.

- Brexit will continue to create uncertainty for the financial services sector, given London's deeply integrated role in EU and global financial markets. The UK will remain a leading financial centre, especially in foreign exchange and derivatives, but a loss of influence and greater restrictions on financial services trade with the EU are inevitable, due to the loss of "passporting" (the right for EU- and European Economic Area-based financial companies to conduct business throughout the EU). A future regime is likely to be based on a so-called enhanced equivalence framework, a less stable arrangement than passporting. This is granted unilaterally by EU regulators by sector, and can also be unilaterally revoked. It applies to far fewer transactions, and still represents a significant increase in friction compared with passporting. The UK's process of applying for equivalence in most areas of financial services remains at an early stage.
- The economic fallout from the coronavirus crisis will test the resilience of major banks' balance sheets. Extensive government-backed loan-guarantee schemes, liquidity support, short-term grants and job-retention measures helped to mitigate the near-term damage to private-sector balance sheets from the coronavirus-related slump and bolstered access to financing for businesses. However, significant take-up of "rescue" loans by companies, particularly smaller firms, raises the prospect of a rise in defaults if demand remains weak.
- The pandemic accelerated the growth of online banking and payments services-already well established in the UK-providing opportunities for innovative lenders and financial technology (fintech) companies to compete with the large banking institutions. Growth in non-bank financing will be supported by London's status as the main European hub for private equity and venture-capital investment. Green finance may also experience fast growth, although the number of projects available to finance in the UK lags other north European countries, where the governments have been more proactive in pushing green projects and sovereign green bonds.

Business environment outlook: The labour market                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
7.2 7.1 11 14 4 3
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
High employment rate, but weak trends in wages and productivity will persist The labour market is among the most flexible in the world, with a decentralised system of wage bargaining and fairly liberal laws on redundancy. Coupled with a favourable environment for new business creation, this supported a robust expansion in employment and a steady decline in joblessness in the 2010s. The pandemic partly undid this progress, but government support has limited the damage to the labour market. However, positive headline data disguised weaker aspects of the labour market including depressed earnings growth; comparatively low levels of technical skills and vocational training; and an increased share of less secure employment (agency jobs and temporary or "zero hour" contracts), mostly in low-wage, low-skill occupations that point to a developing two-tier "insider-outsider" labour market. The UK's productivity performance since 2008 has been poor, with growth in output per hour and output per worker considerably weaker than its long-term pre-crisis trend, and than almost all peer economies.

- Relative to the scale of economic disruption from the pandemic, we expect a modest increase in the unemployment rate, peaking at 5.5% in 2021, from a low of 3.8% in 2019. Damage to the labour market has been mitigated by a huge state-backed job-retention scheme, which at its peak in April 2020 subsidised the wages of 9.1m furloughed employees (almost 30% of the working population). It covered just below 4m employees as of early 2021. The scheme is to be phased out by September 2021, although support could be extended if additional restrictions are imposed in the third quarter. We expect unemployment to fall from 2022, as hiring recovers. With online job vacancies already above pre-pandemic levels in April 2021, certain sectors are likely experience recruitment difficulties over the forecast period, particularly in migrant-dependent sectors.

There could be labour shortages in low-skilled sectors
- Net inflows of EU labour have fallen steadily since the Brexit referendum, but this has been largely offset by increased net inflows from outside the EU. During the pandemic, there appears to have been a sizeable net outflow of expatriates, although estimates vary widely. A new immigration policy took effect from January 2021. Under the new policy, EU and non-EU citizens wishing to work in the UK will be assigned points for specific skills, qualifications, salaries and occupations, according to certain thresholds. Work visas are then awarded based on those points. With the exception of a seasonal programme for agricultural workers, the system is explicitly designed to reduce lower-skilled immigration. It has drawn criticism from business groups and the healthcare sector, which have raised concerns over staff recruitment, with the risk of acute labour shortages in sectors such as social care, transport, food manufacturing and construction. If such shortages emerged, we expect that the government would expand its list of shortage occupations and seasonal working schemes.
- Starting end-January 2021 the government eased the path to residency and citizenship for 3m Hong Kong residents who hold British National Overseas (BNO) status. In the first quarter of 2021, 27,000 people applied for BNO visas. The government expects to issue about 300,000 BNO visas by 2025, partly offsetting the decline in EU migration over the forecast period.

Business environment outlook: Infrastructure                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
7.5 7.5 18 24 12 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The quality of network infrastructure is modest by developed-country standards. The government has pledged stronger public infrastructure investment over the forecast period, but uncertain prospects for private-sector financing, weakened public finances and legacy effects from decades of underinvestment will limit improvements. The main shortcomings are severely congested road and urban rail networks (before the pandemic), inadequate plans for new energy-generation capacity and a housing market suffering from issues of affordability and undersupply. Airport capacity has also long been viewed as a weakness, although near-term demand effects from the pandemic mitigate this. In contrast, the UK is among the better-performing countries in the region in terms of digital connectivity, with mobile network penetration and take-up of broadband services above the regional average. The UK lags in full-fibre broadband coverage, but steady improvements are expected in 2021-25. Utility markets are reasonably competitive, but energy costs are slightly above the regional average.
There will be modest efforts to address a legacy of infrastructure underinvestment
- The UK has long suffered from a short-termist approach to infrastructure by successive governments. In 2016 a new National Infrastructure Commission (NIC) was tasked with planning infrastructure priorities over a 30-year horizon. In late 2018 the NIC identified around £600bn of prospective investment projects in the decade to 2030. The government published a formal National Infrastructure Strategy in November 2020, focusing on "levelling up" regional disparities and meeting the UK's net zero emissions target by 2050. The government plans to launch a UK Infrastructure Bank based in Leeds in 2021. The bank will have £12bn in capital and £10bn in guarantees to support private-sector and local government projects in line with this new strategy. We expect a step-up in public infrastructure spending on renewable energy, transport, housing and digital projects, albeit from a modest level, given modifications to the value for money formula to create more regional balance. We also expect the government to increase the level of borrowing for investment from 2% of GDP to 3%. However, overall progress is likely to continue to be hampered by restrictive planning regulations, high land prices, vested interests and funding uncertainty.
- Usage of passenger rail services almost doubled in the two decades to 2020, placing huge pressure on the network. When rail travel collapsed during the pandemic, the government renationalised rail franchises and provided bailouts to public transport operators. The future viability of existing rail and public transport infrastructure and the duration and extent of government support will depend on long-term commuting and travel habits following a normalisation of homeworking during the pandemic. Two new major rail projects are still progressing, but both face significant delays and overruns. An 118-km east-west rail link under central London (Crossrail) is scheduled to begin services in the first half of 2022. A high-speed rail network (HS2) from London to major northern cities was approved in 2017, despite widespread local opposition and spiralling costs. The first-phase from London to Birmingham is due for completion only by 2030.

Business environment outlook: Technological readiness                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
8.9 9.2 9 10 5 3
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The UK scores reasonably well on a regional and global basis, owing to its digital infrastructure; extensive e-commerce and e-business penetration; above-average digital skills levels; and a well-developed framework of research and innovation infrastructure, arising in part from the country's highly regarded scientific and university base. Weaker aspects are comparatively low levels of public and private research and development (R&D) spending, modest linkages between the research and business sectors, and fairly limited scope of e-government services. R&D intensity has remained broadly flat at around 1.7% of GDP, below a recent EU average of 2.1%. The government seeks to increase R&D spending to 2.4% of GDP by 2027, an ambitious target given the challenging fiscal outlook. There is significant regional disparity in R&D spend across the UK, and studies indicate that the share of UK companies using industrial robotics or deploying emerging digital technologies is among the lowest in the OECD. The UK has a comparatively robust cyber-security framework, with a National Cyber-Security Centre (NCSC) established in 2016. There are concerns that Brexit will lead to a weakening of cyber-security collaboration with the EU.
The UK's science and university base will remain a critical strength
- The UK will retain a strong scientific and university base. The government has pledged an increase in public R&D investment and a greater focus on support measures for "higher-risk" start-ups and research in areas such as fintech and life sciences (where the UK is a leading global player). In March 2020 the government announced plans to establish an £800bn "blue skies" research fund, modelled on the US Advanced Projects Research Agency. However, a February 2021 House of Commons report criticised the undefined purpose of the agency.
- The government's 70% cut in official development assistance in 2020-21 has resulted in a £120m funding gap for existing joint overseas research projects, according to UK Research and Innovation. The UK government allocated £650m in 2021 to remain part of the Horizon 2020 EU science programme after Brexit, but it is unclear how the full £1bn-2bn will affect domestic research funding. These disruptions and uncertainties around research funding, will result in gradual weakening of research and innovation activity over the forecast period.
- Since mid-2019 all four main mobile network operators in the UK have launched commercially available 5G services in limited areas. The timetable for a national rollout is uncertain, however, with the government deciding to strip Huawei equipment from the 5G network by 2027. Alternative suppliers to Huawei include Ericsson (Sweden) and Nokia (Finland). The government estimates that the change in stance will delay the UK's 5G rollout programme by two to three years, at a cost of up to £2bn.

Economic forecast: Policy trends Even before the pandemic, the UK faced significant economic policy challenges, including low public investment, wide regional disparities, high housing costs and chronically low productivity growth. However, the scale of the disruption caused by the virus is likely to dominate the government's policy agenda well into 2021. We do not expect UK GDP to return to its pre-crisis level before late 2022.
Since becoming the Conservative Party leader and prime minister, Mr Johnson has advocated greater public-sector investment, including in infrastructure, and additional current spending on the National Health Service, education and the police. The government has also reformed the UK's immigration system to emphasise skilled labour. Long-term social care is an area of health spending that Mr Johnson's manifesto pledged to address, alongside significant investment in green and renewable energy as part of a green recovery plan, although details for both remain vague. The government is also attempting to encourage public and private investment to address the UK's chronic low productivity, most prominently in a two-year tax "super-deduction" allowing companies to write off tax up to 130% the value of their capital investment from 2021-23, as well as expanding the scope of public borrowing for investment from 2% of GDP to 3%.

At the outbreak of the pandemic, the government enforced nationwide shutdowns and developed a series of financial support packages to aid workers and businesses affected by the coronavirus. These included government-backstopped loans; several business tax deferments and holidays; targeted aid to the worst-affected sectors, such as travel and retail; and wage support schemes for salaried and self-employed workers. In the government's March 2021 budget, the government committed to extending most pandemic support measures into the autumn of 2021, only completely phasing them out by March 2022. We expect that this will lead to a fiscal deficit of 12.1% of GDP in 2021, with the debt/GDP ratio peaking at about 111% this year.
The government's most recent budget has committed to greater fiscal consolidation, with a planned increase in corporation tax from 19% to 25% in 2023. However, this budget assumes highly ambitious increases in productivity growth and minimal increases in health, education and welfare spending from pre-pandemic levels after 2022. This is likely to be resisted within the Conservative Party, particularly given the government's campaign promises of greater spending and investment. As a result, we expect that further tax increases are likely between now and the end of the forecast period, with debt declining only marginally, to 107% of GDP, and stabilising at that level in 2022-25.

On March 19th 2020 the Bank of England (BoE, the central bank) cut its main rate to 0.1%-its lowest ever level. It also resumed its quantitative easing programme, committing to £450bn (US$620bn) in asset purchases, which was expanded twice more in 2020, reaching a total of £895bn. From April 2020 until the end of that year the BoE allowed the government access to its overdraft account, the so-called Ways and Means facility, to directly finance day-to-day costs, although this facility was not tapped. The BoE has signalled that negative interest rates would not be technically possible to implement before August 2021, at which point the economy is likely to be recovering sufficiently to not need further cuts. Given the length of the pandemic and the associated downturn, we do not expect the BoE to raise rates before mid-2022.

The coronavirus pandemic and ensuing public health measures caused a severe economic contraction in 2020, with real GDP shrinking by 9.9%. The most recent lockdown is likely to have resulted in a contraction in growth in the first quarter of 2021. A significant bounce-back is likely from the second quarter as restrictions are lifted and government incentives for increased investment kick in, and we forecast growth of 5.3% in 2021 as a whole. We forecast further catch-up growth of 5.6% in 2022, which will probably be the first full year without social distancing restrictions. However, most of this headline growth will stem from favourable year-on-year comparisons with the 2020-21 lockdowns as shut-down activities restart, rather than from robust new economic activity. We expect the level of real GDP to exceed its 2019 peak only in late 2022. In 2023-25 we expect growth to slow as taxes rise and catch-up growth abates, averaging 1.7% per year.
After reaching a low of 3.8% in 2019, unemployment rose in 2020 as the pandemic led to business failures and lay-offs. The spike in unemployment was modest, however, at an estimated average rate of 4.5% in 2020, owing to the government's furlough scheme. We expect the rate to average 5.6% in 2021 as the scheme is withdrawn. Employment will rise gradually and unemployment will begin to fall from 2022, reaching 4% by the end of our forecast period in 2025.
Gross capital formation declined sharply in 2020 as the highly uncertain global business environment depressed investment. We expect a significant bounce-back in investment growth in 2021 and 2022, driven in part by the government's investment tax super-deduction, as well as by a more stable post-pandemic and post-Brexit investment environment. Investment growth should stabilise from 2023 until the end of the forecast period.
Export and import growth turned sharply negative in 2020 as global demand collapsed and coronavirus-related travel restrictions persisted. We expect growth to bounce back in 2021 and 2022, but expect Brexit-related disruption to restrict the pace of growth.

Economic forecast: Sectoral trends The aftermath of the pandemic and Brexit have the potential to significantly change the sectoral profile of the economy. In 2019 services accounted for 80% of GDP-a comparatively high share among advanced economies-with industry contributing 14%, construction about 6% and agriculture less than 1%. These shares have remained broadly stable in the past decade: prior to that, the share of services had increased steadily, mainly at the expense of industry. This trend was upended globally during the pandemic, with consumption and trade of goods being more robust and quicker to bounce back from initial lockdown restrictions than services. This was particularly the case in the UK where the hospitality sector was estimated at 17% of services gross value added, and was most severely affected by lockdown restrictions.
In addition to hospitality (defined as distribution, hotels and restaurants), business services and finance account for an additional 40% of services value added, followed by government and public administration with 28%, with the remainder comprising transport, storage and communications. Business services, communications, and wholesale and retail trade have been the main growth drivers in recent years, and remained relatively robust during the pandemic, although Brexit restrictions on professional services qualifications may reduce their competitiveness in the European market. In contrast, growth in value added in healthcare, education and public administration has been inhibited by government austerity measures, and the decade since the global financial crisis has been a challenging one for the financial services sector, amid widespread cost-cutting and restructuring.
The future of the financial services sector is unclear One sector facing considerable uncertainty is financial services, which accounts for about 6% of GDP and makes a significant contribution to tax revenue. London is one of the two leading global financial centres (with New York) and has the largest share of many international markets. In the event of Brexit, we expect London to retain its position as Europe's leading centre for financial services activity. Many factors that have made the UK a world leader in financial services are not contingent on its membership of the EU, such as its supportive infrastructure in terms of law, culture, language, tax system, sectoral expertise and the regulatory environment. Nevertheless, a loss of influence and post-Brexit restrictions on UK-EU financial services trade will be inevitable. Greater access to the EU market, through a designation of "equivalence" by European regulators may provide more streamlined access, but this process will take some time to negotiate and would still make for significant frictions compared with single-market access. Activities requiring an EU presence have moved out of London, with Amsterdam now becoming the largest centre for stock trading in Europe, but the mobile nature of the sector will limit the impact on jobs.
Governments have attempted to increase the housing supply The construction sector currently accounts for about 6% of GDP. After a brief decline amid the 2008 financial crisis, the 2010s saw a period of fairly robust house price growth accompanied by limited house-building activity. The stringency of planning regulations and vested interests in supporting house price inflation have consistently held back the construction of new homes over recent decades, especially in and around London. A range of policy initiatives have been implemented over the past few years with the stated aim of boosting the housing supply, including revisions to the planning system, relaxation of local authority borrowing rules for housing, and an expanded housing infrastructure fund. However, their relative impact has been modest, with other government measures, such as "help to buy" funding support, continuing to underpin house price growth. Modest growth in house-building has been the main driver of total construction output in recent years, amid an otherwise subdued sector, exacerbated since 2018 by the collapse of Carillion and Interserve, two of the UK's largest construction and outsourcing companies.
The housing market has experienced significant fluctuations during the pandemic, with a one-year holiday on stamp duty leading to an overall increase in house prices, and substantial regional swings, as buyers search for more space away from city centres. The phase-out of the stamp duty holiday, scheduled to last until September 2021, along with changing consumer preferences, will lead to continued volatility in the market.
As in most other developed economies, in recent decades the manufacturing sector has accounted for a falling share of UK GDP. This partly reflects the fact that, with the exception of 2020, households spend a rising share of their income on services as their wealth increases. However, the decline in the UK in the period between 1980 and 2009 was more pronounced than in almost every other industrialised country. The deep recession of the early 1980s and government policies dealt a permanent blow to the country's industrial heartlands, but it is notable that the declining importance of manufacturing was particularly acute from the mid-1990s (when the sector still accounted for almost 27% of output in 1997) up to the global financial crisis. The persistent strength of sterling for much of this period weakened export-oriented manufacturers' competitiveness, at the same time as labour-intensive industries were unable to compete with rising imports from expanding emerging economies with lower wage costs. Industrial investment declined further from already comparatively low levels. The manufacturing sector's share of GDP has remained fairly stable since 2009, at about 10% (out of an industry total of 14%). The two largest subsectors are food and beverages, and transport equipment, which together account for about one-third of all manufacturing output. Within the transport category, motor vehicle production by mostly foreign-owned firms dominates. Brexit disruption looms large in this sector, as supply chains, particularly in the automotive sector, are highly integrated into the EU economy, and the loss of frictionless access to the EU market is likely to make UK factories less competitive. A shift towards electric vehicles will lead to further disruption in European manufacturing supply chains, with the future of a number of major vehicle manufacturing plants in the UK now potentially at risk in 2021-25.

Inflation declined sharply in 2020 as a result of depressed demand owing to the coronavirus pandemic, and we estimate average inflation of 1% in full-year 2020. We expect price pressures to pick up modestly as demand and asset prices rebound, reaching 1.5% and 2% in 2021 and 2022 respectively. From 2023 we expect inflation to decline to a more modest level as pent-up demand is exhausted, stabilising at 1.6% by 2025.

The value of sterling has been volatile in recent years owing to the degree of political uncertainty around Brexit and the pandemic, as well as the UK's large current-account deficit, which requires significant international capital investment to support the currency. Sterling strengthened against the US dollar in 2020 and early 2021 as the uncertainty around a potential no-deal Brexit ended and a flight to safety in dollar liquidity gradually unwound, with sterling peaking at US$1.41:£1 in February 2021. Sterling has similarly begun to appreciate against the euro in 2021 as Brexit uncertainty dissipates and the UK economy unlocks more rapidly.
We expect sterling to continue to appreciate against the euro, rising from EUR1.08:£1 at end-2020 to EUR1.19 by end-2021. We expect sterling to stabilise against the euro from mid-2022, averaging EUR1:22:£1 in 2022-25. We expect both currency pairs to appreciate modestly against the dollar during this period as the demand for the safe-haven currency decreases, with sterling reaching US$1.46:£1 by end-2025.

The coronavirus outbreak caused a sharp fall in global trade as demand declined, travel was disrupted and global supply chains were compromised by national lockdowns. The UK was not exempt from this, with both imports and exports declining sharply in 2020. From 2021 we expect trade to rebound, although this will primarily be the result of a recovery from the 2020 base year, and we expect Brexit to weigh on exports (as well as imports, but to a lesser extent). Most catch-up growth in trade, particularly in exports, will be likely to take place in 2022 as global markets fully unlock and UK firms become more experienced in exporting under new trading rules. The UK has run a persistent current-account deficit since 1985. We expect the deficit to widen from 3.5% of GDP in 2020 to 4.2% of GDP in 2021 as the export sector is weakened by worse terms of trade with the EU, before stabilising thereafter.
Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in the United Kingdom Stocks and flows Since the early 1990s the UK has been one of the top recipients of foreign direct investment (FDI) among the world's advanced economies and the biggest recipient of FDI in the EU. In 2019 the UK held the fourth-largest stock of global FDI, about half of which was from other EU countries, according to figures from the OECD. The stock of FDI in the UK totalled an estimated US$2.4trn at the end of 2019, equivalent to 83.7% of GDP. Relative to GDP, the UK's inward FDI stock is the highest in the G7 group of industrialised countries, although it is well below that of several medium-sized European economies such as Ireland, the Netherlands and Sweden.
Following the slump in global mergers and acquisitions (M&A) at the beginning of the 2000s, annual FDI inflows into the UK rose strongly in 2005-08, peaking at US$253bn. During this period the number and scale of FDI projects into the UK-mostly in the form of M&A-confirmed the country's status as one of the world's top recipients of FDI. The global financial crisis and severe economic recession resulted in a marked slowdown in inflows, as access to all forms of financing was restricted. Since 2010 the trend in FDI inflows has mostly been steady rather than spectacular, averaging an annual US$60.8bn in 2010-15. After a brief surge in 2016, largely as a result of foreign acquisitions of two large UK companies, FDI inflows gradually weakened, then fell sharply to US$2.3bn in 2019 amid Brexit uncertainty, and remained subdued at US$18.2bn in 2020 owing to the pandemic. As the economy recovers, we forecast a rebound from 2021 and especially in 2022.
Origin and distribution US companies have long been the largest inward direct investors in the UK, although taken together the EU27 account for the largest share of the total inward FDI stock. As at the end of 2019 (latest data) the US accounted for 24% of the UK inward direct investment stock. As a region the EU accounted for a cumulative 44%, with the Netherlands and Luxembourg holding the two largest shares-an indication of the significant influence of financial services activity and related changes in multinational ownership structures, often for tax purposes, on the FDI data. The share of Asian countries (primarily Japan) has been fairly stable over recent years, at 10%, similar to the proportion accounted for by UK offshore islands. Financial services, electronics and automotive have traditionally accounted for a large share of inward FDI into the UK and remain important sectors, but the composition is steadily changing, with the UK attracting greater investment in areas such as business services, pharmaceuticals, biotechnology, information technology, software development and energy generation.
Determinants The UK's attractiveness as a location for FDI over the past 20 years has rested on a policy of openness to foreign investors, a relaxed attitude to foreign takeovers of domestic companies, liberalised product markets, a flexible labour market (by European standards in particular), deep and liquid capital markets, external economies of scale in sectors such as financial services (where London's position as a financial centre has developed and fed on a large pool of qualified banking, legal and other business services staff) and membership of the EU (which gave firms located in the UK access to the world's largest trading bloc). Hard data and anecdotal evidence point to weakening inward investment since the Brexit referendum, and there is a clear risk that the withdrawal of the UK from the EU will significantly undermine the country's attractiveness, to foreign investors, given reduced trading opportunities with the large EU market. Less tangible but still important magnets have been the status of English as the world's leading business language, and the preponderance of the English legal system in international transactions law.
Impact FDI has had a positive effect on the economy, even if studies suggest that this is sometimes exaggerated. Inward direct investors employ about 2m workers in the UK, and many of the country's most productive business units, such as the Nissan and Toyota car plants, are foreign-owned. Evidence for broader spillover effects is more mixed. Although foreign companies are often held to improve working practices and quality standards in local companies, empirical evidence suggests that positive spillover effects-if they occur at all-are geographically concentrated, partly because of low levels of labour mobility.
Potential In the long term the UK should continue to be a broadly attractive location for FDI, although continued uncertainty about the country's future trading relationship with the EU will deter some investors, especially from EU countries. Although we expect the UK to remain relatively relaxed about foreign ownership in domestic corporations relative to its peer countries, pressure from the US and domestically will lead to greater national security scrutiny of foreign ownership of key infrastructure, particularly with regard to Chinese companies. Some investors will also remain wary of the UK's macroeconomic imbalances (relatively weak public finances, a sizeable current-account deficit, high levels of private-sector debt and a reliance on consumer spending to drive growth), an increasingly polarised political scene and weak underlying trends in domestic investment and productivity that will weigh on the economy's medium-term growth potential. A major weakness of the UK business environment will remain the congestion and unreliability of its land transport infrastructure, with significant uncertainty regarding future projects in this area over the coming years. Nevertheless, existing clusters and economies of scale in sectors such as pharmaceuticals, financial services, biotechnology and software development will remain powerful magnets for foreign entrants.

Brexit and the pandemic will tighten the labour market The UK population totalled an estimated 67.5m in 2019, up from 63.3m in 2010 and 59m in 2000, with growth averaging 0.7% per year in 2011-19. Up until the mid-1990s the rise in the population was primarily driven by "natural change" (that is, more births than deaths). This remains a significant factor, but over the past two decades the primary driver has been net migration into the UK. According to latest official estimates, net immigration totalled 272,000 in 2019, broadly unchanged from recent years, but down slightly from record levels of net immigration in 2015, when Bulgarian and Romanian migrants were able to come to the UK for the first time. The coronavirus pandemic is believed to have led to substantial net emigration from the UK, as foreign nationals returned home to wait out the crisis as economic and public health conditions deteriorated. Population estimates during the pandemic are subject to greater than usual uncertainty and are unlikely to be reflected in official figures for some time, but estimates put the number of emigres in 2020 at between 400,000 and 1.3m (between 0.6% and 2% of the UK population). We expect these figures to be only partly reversed post-pandemic, leading to tighter labour market conditions than previously.
Even prior to the pandemic, there was a marked decline in net inflows of people from other EU countries after the Brexit vote in 2016. Net migration of EU nationals fell to 49,000 in 2019, the lowest level in a decade. This compared with a net annual inflow of over 200,000 prior to the referendum. The reduced attractiveness of the UK for EU citizens was, however, largely offset by increased arrivals from outside the bloc. In 2019 a total of 282,000 non-EU citizens came to the UK, the highest total since 2004 although this partly reflects a steady increase in recent years in the number of people coming to the UK to study (primarily in higher education), rather than to work. We expect this trend to resume from 2022, as international travel becomes possible again.
In 2021 the UK adopted a skills-based immigration system which favours high-skilled migrants, while abandoning the cap on the number of total work visas issued. We do not expect this to drastically change immigrant numbers, although the composition, in terms of countries and skills, is likely to change. This will lead to greater human capital, but may lead to labour shortages in low-skilled occupations.
In the past decade population growth has been faster in England than in the other constituent nations of the UK, lifting its share of the total to an estimated 84.4% in 2018 (compared with 8.1% for Scotland, 4.6% for Wales and 2.8% for Northern Ireland). The strongest growth has been in London-the destination of more than a third of international migrants in recent years-followed by the east and south-east regions of England. These trends have been disrupted by the coronavirus pandemic, but are likely to resume thereafter, providing a steady stream of labour in and around the capital, but also placing more pressure on already overstretched transport infrastructure and housing supply.
An ageing population will add to fiscal pressures in the forecast period Births are continuing to outnumber deaths. The number of live births has fluctuated in recent decades but has stabilised since the 1960s baby boom and has generally been between 700,000-800,000 since the 1970s. Births peaked recently at 813,000 in 2012, the highest since 1990. The long-term trend in the death rate has been more stable than the birth rate, and the number of deaths declined steadily until 2011, as people are living longer, but since then has begun to rise gradually, reaching 640,370 in 2019. 2020 and 2021 are likely to see a spike in deaths due to the coronavirus pandemic, with the latest estimates for excess deaths owing to the coronavirus as of May 2021 at above 127,000 since March 2020.
As in most developed economies, the UK population is ageing-albeit not quite as rapidly as in some EU countries-as the mortality rate declines (particularly among males). This implies that pension-related spending (the largest single component of UK public-sector expenditure), as well as spending on the social care sector, will continue to account for a rising share of total public spending, adding to budgetary pressure on public services, including healthcare. Since the mid-1970s the median age of the UK population (the age at which half of the population is younger and half is older) has risen from 34 years to about 40 years. The share of the population aged 65 or over is projected to continue to rise steadily, to 19.5% in 2024, up from 18.1% in 2015 The share of the working-age population peaked in 2008-09 and will continue to decline gradually in the 2021-25 forecast period.

Market opportunities available to businesses operating in the UK in the forecast period (2021-25) will evolve as the UK pursues an independent economic policy from the EU and rebounds from the coronavirus pandemic.
The departure of the UK from the EU single market and customs union will lead to increased costs for manufacturers, especially those operating complex supply chains crossing between the UK and EU. The process of phasing in new customs checks and compliance procedures over 2021 and potential tariffs thereafter will lead to increased frictions at the border, limiting UK manufacturers' competitiveness in the EU market, especially for low-margin commodities. Services exporters to the EU will also face greater trade barriers, as mutual recognition of standards and visa-free business travel between the UK and EU will no longer be guaranteed. The UK and EU are likely to normalise and streamline the process of goods and services trade, although this is unlikely to take place until the latter half of the forecast period, as the political salience of Brexit has receded from UK politics.
A pandemic-related glut in household savings will drive consumer growth Prior to the pandemic, solid growth in full-time employment, low inflation and favourable borrowing conditions had supported consumer spending, which has been fairly resilient amid the increased uncertainty over Brexit, in contrast to private investment which grew by an average of 0.7% in 2017-19. As a result, the economy has become highly dependent on increased household spending, particularly in the large hospitality and retail sectors. Household savings had declined in the wake of the Brexit referendum amid slow growth, averaging 6.3% of total income in 2017-19. The pandemic led to a glut in household savings, owing to caution by households and a lack of spending opportunities due to lockdowns, with the savings/income ratio reaching 19.7%. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects there to be a significant drawdown of this glut in 2021 and 2022, stimulating renewed consumer spending, and it will continue to provide more modest support for private consumption growth thereafter.
More active industrial policy will drive growth in new markets The government is likely to continue to provide extraordinary support in the market, even after the most acute phase of the coronavirus crisis has passed. In its budget for fiscal year 2021/22, the government extended support for businesses and households, with reduced business rates for the hospitality sector. The government also plans to pursue a more targeted industrial policy, building on its comparative advantage and increased post-pandemic demand in the life sciences sector, as well as supporting transition to green industries within the electrical, transport, industrial and construction sectors.
Notwithstanding the considerable uncertainty and trading risks posed by Brexit and coronavirus, the UK's large, rich and flexible economy will continue to provide opportunities for inward investors and global exporters. With nominal GDP of US$2.71trn (at market exchange rates) in 2020, the UK is the fifth-largest economy in the world (after the US, China, Japan and Germany). GDP per head at market exchange rates totalled US$39,938 in 2020, ranking the UK in 11th position within the former EU28, between Belgium and France. According to our forecasts, after a sharp decline in 2020 due to the coronavirus pandemic, GDP per head at market exchange rates will return to its pre-crisis levels in 2022 and continue to expand thereafter.

Coronavirus crisis will help online sales, health spending and discount retailers The UK is a mature consumer market. As in many countries, the profile of bricks-and-mortar retail is changing rapidly as a result of online shopping. The UK was one of the world's leading countries for online spend per head even prior to the pandemic, a trend which has since accelerated, with "non-store" retail up by 62% on its year-earlier level in March 2021. We expect many of these gains to persist. Consumers will retain a strong price focus for staple items such as food and clothing, sustaining the increasing market share of discounters. Demographic trends will also shape the consumer market. The UK's population is ageing, albeit less rapidly than other European countries. This will support demand for age-related services, particularly in the healthcare and tourism sectors. Income inequalities across the UK are higher than the regional average, a trend that is likely to persist in the forecast period.

Initial conditions: From the early 1990s up to 2019, with the exception of the 2008 crisis period, the economic performance of the UK improved relative to that of many of its regional peers, owing in part to a sharp rise in labour utilisation, with strong employment growth fuelling strong overall expansion. The pace of economic growth began to soften in 2019, and the economy contracted sharply in 2020 amid the coronavirus pandemic. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects UK GDP to return to its pre-crisis level by 2022 as restrictions are lifted and pent-up consumer demand returns. The recovery will be constrained as corporates face rising debt from the coronavirus crisis and trade frictions from Brexit depress export-oriented industries.
The UK's prospects for growth in the medium term will be highly dependent on government policy formulation in response to these challenges. Both major parties have signalled a willingness to pursue a more interventionist strategy in the economy, and provide more public investment, in an effort to address the UK's regional inequality and weak productivity growth. The current govern-ment has increased its threshold for borrowing for investment from 2% of GDP to 3%, established a national infrastructure bank in addition to the pre-existing British Business Bank, and an £800bn (US$1.1bn) "blue skies" fund to support innovative research.
Despite securing the Trade and Co-operation Agreement with the EU, the UK's relationship with the EU remains unsettled. The UK is likely to diverge in some areas of regulation, particularly in technology and life sciences regulation, while non-tariff barriers put UK firms as a competitive disadvantage within the single market.
The UK faces entrenched regional and sectoral imbalances We expect economic performance to bounce back from the current recession, and reach pre-crisis real GDP levels by 2022. Between Brexit and the pandemic, this is likely to mask significant sectoral disruption, and the UK economy may need to become less reliant on consumer spending relative to investment to support growth.
The UK's structural advantages have traditionally included a comparatively low regulatory burden, a flexible labour market and a business environment that is conducive to foreign investment, which we expect to persist. On the negative side, factors that tend to constrain the UK's long-term outlook include over-reliance on wealth effects generated by the volatile financial and real estate sectors, high levels of private-sector debt and a deficit in "intermediate" labour market skills, which are skewed by significant geographical inequalities. These have contributed to the development of an unbalanced economy. Levels of productivity in the UK, in terms of output per hour worked, lag well behind those in the US, Germany and France. This weak trend is worrying and will weigh on medium- and long-term growth if not reversed, and will play an increasing role in policy debates.
Labour force participation is high, but will be depressed by the coronavirus Demographic trends: The working-age population is forecast to rise gradually over the long-term horizon, and the share of the population aged 65 or over will continue to increase. By 2050 those aged 65 and older are projected to account for 25.4% of the population (up from 18.7% in 2018). The share of the working-age population peaked at 66% in 2008-09 and is forecast to decline steadily, to 58.3% by 2050. Prior to the pandemic, the labour force participation rate was just below 80%- significantly higher than the OECD average. After declining in 2020, we expect it to gradually return to that level. We expect migration will continue to provide a key source of population and human capital growth. Most countries that operate skills-based immigration systems adjust their requirements periodically, a trend that we expect the UK to follow.
EU trade will decline, but it will remain the UK's most important trade partner External conditions: The UK is a highly trade-dependent economy, and thus its departure from the world's largest trading bloc will have implications for its long-term prospects. Despite the UK leaving the single market, the EU is likely to remain the UK's most important export destination, particularly for goods trade, given its proximity and the volume of existing trade. This is likely to be exacerbated if the pandemic leads companies globally to pursue shorter supply chains. Although the UK's departure from the EU will allow the UK to negotiate trade deals with third countries, trade experts have estimated that the total estimated value of trade deals currently in negotiation will not make up for the loss of access to the EU market. However, given the demographic, structural and political headwinds that the bloc faces, we expect the EU's long-term growth rate to remain modest.
The UK is likely to maintain its surplus in services, which is expected to grow as a percentage of total trade value over the course of our long-term forecast period, as e-commerce and trade in intangible goods become more prominent globally.
Institutions and policy trends: The UK is a long-established democracy with well-entrenched rule of law (guaranteeing security of contracts), liberalised product markets and a rigorous competition policy regime. Much of the UK's policy around competition, trade, product regulation and other areas of economic policymaking was informed by its EU membership, as was the governance of its own internal market, much of which is currently being moved to domestic equivalent authorities. It remains too early to gauge how effectively policymakers and institutions will manage these competencies on a national level, and whether any benefits can be realised from regaining direct control.
Long-term performance: Since the 2008 financial crisis the UK has suffered from chronically low productivity growth relative to its OECD peer countries, and relied heavily on moving people into work. Its labour force participation rate peaked at over 79% with unemployment at 3.8% prior to the outbreak of the pandemic. The flexibility of the UK labour market will see unemployment rapidly return to its downward trend as pandemic restrictions are lifted, but the UK's ability to increase its productivity will be the key driver of its performance in the long-term. A number of factors have been cited as possible causes for the UK's persistent productivity gap with its peers. These include the high degree of centralisation of the economy around London; the UK's relatively low share of spending on R&D; the dominance of the volatile financial services sector; and reliance on low-skilled immigration. Successive governments have tried to address the productivity issue, including the current government, which has committed to an increase in public investment to stimulate R&D, a shift in emphasis towards skilled immigration, and supporting investment outside London. Whether these plans will boost productivity remains highly uncertain. Real GDP is forecast to grow by an annual average of 2.4% in 2021-30, owing to rapid post-pandemic recovery in 2021 and 2022, but will moderate to 1.8% in 2031-50.
