Long-term outlook: Long-term trends Climate change and sustainability Climate change policy in the UK has become dramatically more ambitious in the past two decades. The first major climate change policy in the UK, the 2008 Climate Change Act (CCA), established a legally binding target to cut UK greenhouse-gas emissions by 80% from 1990 levels by 2050. In 2019 that threshold was toughened, requiring the UK to reach a net zero target-that is, requiring all carbon emitting activities to be balanced out by activities that reduce emissions by the same amount-by 2050. The most recent carbon budget commits to a 78% cut in emissions from 1990 levels by 2035.
The CCA set out legally binding five-year "carbon budgets" as stepping stones towards the 2050 target. The first three carbon budgets, covering 2008-22, were set out in the original 2008 act, with the fourth and fifth budgets, covering 2023-27 and 2028-32, were enacted in 2011 and 2016. A sixth carbon budget announced on April 20th 2021, covers the period to 2037 and codifies the 78% emissions reduction. The CCA established the Committee on Climate Change (CCC), an independent and statutory body, to advise the government on emissions targets and report to parliament on progress in reducing greenhouse-gas emissions and preparing for climate change. In its most recent assessment, the CCC said that the UK met its first two carbon budgets and is on track to meet the third, but that further reductions are needed to reach the subsequent three budgets.
For the first time, the sixth carbon budget also covered emissions from aviation and shipping, a significant omission in previous budgets. The CCC has advised that the following initiatives will be needed to reach the targets set out in the sixth carbon budget:

- completing the phase-out of coal power, and beginning the phase-out of natural gas, with all electricity to be replaced by renewables;
- significant public investment in mainstreaming low-carbon alternatives, particularly in the areas of electric vehicles and low carbon heating;
- managing gradual demand reduction for carbon-intensive activities such as meat consumption and air travel;
- investment in carbon capture and storage and reforestation of land; and
- incentives for moving industrial processes towards lower emissions, including carbon capture, which was supplemented by an industrial decarbonisation strategy released by the Department of Business Energy and Industrial Strategy in March 2021

The UK will be hosting the COP26 Climate change conference in Glasgow, where all countries will review and expand on their previous commitments to decarbonisation. The government has unveiled a series of initiatives in advance of the conference, including a ten-point plan emphasis zero-carbon energy sources (including renewables, nuclear and hydrogen), changing transportation modes (including electric vehicles, walking and cycling, and green air and shipping), carbon capture and storage, and green finance.
Technological developments The capacity of countries to harness technological change and disruption will have a major impact on their long-term economic prospects. The UK has a relatively strong starting position in terms of the adoption and development of new technology. According to the technological readiness category of our business environment rankings, the UK is reasonably well placed in terms of its openness to innovation, digital connectedness and preparation for technological disruption.
The UK performs well on all the main variables that determine a country's capacity to benefit from technological change. The UK's strengths include its education system, employment policies, ability to attract talented innovators, a sophisticated digital infrastructure, advanced e-commerce and e-business penetration, above-average digital skills levels and a well-developed framework of research and innovation infrastructure as a result of its strong scientific and university base. According to the 2019 edition of the Digital Economy and Society Index (DESI), a composite index published by the European Commission, the UK is one of the highest-performing countries in Europe. The UK ranks ahead of all EU countries but six in the most recent DESI assessment and performs well by global comparison too.
The UK has long been a magnet for foreign direct investment (FDI) into Europe, and industries at the technological frontier such as automotive, aerospace engineering, information and communication technology (ICT), biotechnology and micro-electronics have attracted much investment and international talent. Investment in London's Silicon Roundabout and other regions has helped to make the UK a leading technological hub. Inward investment has weakened since the Brexit vote, however, and there is a risk that the UK's exit from the EU will trigger a permanent reduction in FDI inflows with the UK viewed as a less attractive destination among investors.
The UK lags in other areas. The UK spends comparatively less on research and development (R&D) than its peers; it spent 1.8% of GDP on R&D in 2019, less than the OECD average of 2.5% and far behind the 4%-plus of top performers Israel and South Korea. The application of automation and data exchange in manufacturing technologies in UK industry also lags. The education system will also need to adapt to ensure that skills in ICT, especially in programming and operating robotic systems, are suitably widespread. Links between the science and business sectors will need to be strengthened to support future innovation. The government has announced plans to invest to increase R&D spending to 2.4% of GDP by 2027, invest in an £800m (US$1.1bn) "blue skies" fund to support basic research and provide greater support for bringing technological innovations to market. However, these initiatives are likely to take several years to yield results.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include: LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Guide to the business rankings model Outline of the model The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2016-20) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2021-25). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2016-20. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2021-25 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2016-20 ranges are then used to derive 2021-25 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2021-25, not to the likely situation in 2025 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2018 or 2023). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+Venezuela&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+Venezuela+May+2021&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2021-05-05&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+Venezuela&amp;rft.issn=09669574&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: - Despite Venezuela's socioeconomic collapse and the ongoing coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the civic-military regime, led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela, to retain power throughout the 2021-25 forecast period. Mr Maduro's position will be supported primarily by his grip over a complex security apparatus and the opposition's lack of de facto power. The Maduro regime has managed internal dissent through a patronage system that rewards loyalty, as well as through its strict control over the security forces. The patronage system is fuelled by myriad corruption schemes, enabled by the state's outsized influence over the economy. However, the ultimate source of resources is PDVSA, the state-owned oil firm, the exports of which account for the vast majority of Venezuela's foreign-exchange inflows. Although oil rents-and therefore resources-should pick up from their 2020 trough, they will remain limited in the coming months as a result of US sanctions, raising the risk of a fracture within the regime.

Venezuela--highlights: Business environment outlook                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
3.07 3.09 81 82 12 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.

- Venezuela ranks as the least attractive location of the 82 countries covered in our rankings in the 2021-25 forecast period. The severe macroeconomic crisis is a key constraint, posing challenges for business through its impact on income and purchasing power, the migration of a large share of the population abroad and the destruction of virtually all of the country's non-oil productive capacity. Government policy deters foreign investment through complex regulations, a heavy tax burden and a weak commitment to creating a level playing field. Mr Maduro has indicated a greater acceptance of private (including foreign) invest-ment, but the country's structural problems will go unaddressed. Combined with US sanctions, the investment climate will remain extremely difficult.

Venezuela--highlights: Economic outlook   2020 2021 2022 2023 2024 2025
Real GDP growth (%) -31.0 0.7 8.0 3.5 2.5 2.0
Consumer price inflation (av, %) 3,634 1,799 488.0 233.1 83.5 38.5

Current-account balance (% of GDP) -7.3 1.2 3.6 3.0 2.7 1.9
3-month Treasury rate (av; %) 182.2 162.2 36.3 23.8 22.5 22.5
Exchange rate BsS:US$1 (av) 320,729 4,973,882 30,079,057 104,048,922 191,098,711 261,235,943

- The macroeconomic environment will remain dismal. We expect a seven-year recession to come to an end in 2021 and hyperinflation to ease gradually, but in the context of the prolonged crisis, this will only repair a fraction of the damage incurred in recent years. Higher average oil prices are the main factor preventing a continued recession, but low production volumes will hinder a stronger recovery. Oversupply of local currency and weak exports will yield continued bolívar depreciation and growing use of the US dollar. The current account will shift into surplus, but foreign reserves will remain critically low.

Venezuela--highlights: Demographic outlook Population (m) 2015 2020 2025
Total 30.4 29.7 28.1
 Male 15.1 14.6 13.9
 Female 15.3 15.1 14.3
Period averages (%)   2016-20 2021-25
Population growth   -0.4 -1.1
Working-age population growth   -0.2 -1.2
Labour force growth   -4.3 -2.8

- Amid political and economic crisis, Venezuela's population has declined in recent years owing to outmigration. Close to 6m Venezuelans are estimated to have left since 2014, resulting in population declines in the 2016-20 historical period. We forecast that mass outward migration will continue, given goods shortages and the lack of job opportunities. As many of the refugees and migrants will have been of working age, the old-age dependency ratio will rise. The ratio will remain low by developed-country standards, but population ageing will place growing pressure on the heavily indebted social security system in a context of volatile public finances.

- Years of economic crisis and hyperinflation have decimated the Venezuelan economy; in real terms, it is now two-thirds smaller than in 2013. Given our assumption that Mr Maduro will remain in power into the medium term, a strong economic recovery is unlikely in the next few years. Acute economic inequality will limit opportunities in the consumer market. Although Venezuela is generously endowed with natural resources, extremely challenging conditions will keep private-sector investment well below potential.

- Assuming that international oil prices are relatively supportive, we expect that Venezuela's economy will begin to recover from 2021. Nevertheless, this will not reverse the damage inflicted on the economy in recent years, and economic growth will plateau in the long term. GDP growth will average only 1.3% annually in 2021-30. In 2031-50 we forecast that Venezuela's real GDP growth will pick up to 5.9% as relative macroeconomic stability-a result of (limited) economic reforms by future governments-enables non-oil sector growth and boosts labour productivity, helping to offset deteriorating demographics. Persistent oil dependency will be difficult to undo, and a weak productive base will limit overall economic output.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s, two parties-Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente-alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in support for both parties and culminated in the 1998 election of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but several attempts to remove him from power before his death in March 2013 proved unsuccessful. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, has seen his own popularity plummet, as his macroeconomic mismanagement-aggravated by wide-ranging US sanctions-has plunged the country into a state of economic collapse.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is nominally a federal republic with separation of powers, the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) has systematically eroded institutions. In December 2015 the opposition coalition, Mesa de la Unidad Democrática, won control of the unicameral National Assembly. In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature to be in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. In August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly (ANC) granted itself control over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and sidelining the National Assembly. The ANC was dissolved at end-2020, after the PSUV and its allies regained control of the legislature in an election that was widely regarded as rigged.
Policy issues: The most pressing policy issue is the need to stabilise the crisis-ridden economy. The monetisation of vast public deficits has created an ever-increasing excess of domestic currency, triggering hyperinflation. Mismanagement of PDVSA (the state-owned oil company and originator of practically all foreign-currency inflows into the country) has resulted in a sharp contraction in oil production. Attempts to address these problems through distortionary price and currency controls proved actively counter-productive and led to major shortages of both foreign currency and basic goods. The scarcity of foreign exchange also led to arrears on most of the external debt issued by the sovereign and state-owned firms. The Maduro regime is now changing tack and pursuing incremental pro-market reforms, but its efforts are hindered by chronic economic instability, a lack of confidence in the legal framework and wide-ranging US sanctions.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 50% for oil firms. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that the goods trade surplus fell to US$10.2bn in 2019 as a long-term decline in oil exports deepened. We estimate that the trade account deteriorated in 2020, shifting to a US$3.2bn deficit.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance The ruling party, originally called the Movimiento V República, has been in power since 1999 and transformed into the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) in 2006. The populist-nationalist PSUV was initially ruled by the late president, Hugo Chávez (1999-2013). Since Mr Chávez's death, the party has been led by Nicolás Maduro. Since taking office, the PSUV has wielded practically uncontested power, initially owing to Mr Chávez's immense popularity and later through electoral manipulation and systematic campaigns to disenfranchise opposition parties and exclude them from state institutions. The opposition is diverse and contested the 2015 legislative election as the Mesa de la Unidad Democrática coalition, winning a majority in the unicameral National Assembly (AN).
Political control is nominally disputed, but the PSUV retains de facto power. Following the opposition's 2015 victory, the government convened a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly (ANC)-recognised by the politicised Supreme Court as the de facto legislature-relegating the opposition. The PSUV subsequently retook control of the AN in a sham legislative election in December 2020. The opposition decried the polls as illegitimate and unilaterally extended its own mandate by a year. The leadership of the executive branch is similarly contested. Mr Maduro won re-election in May 2018 in extremely controversial circumstances, with most opposition candidates barred from running. In response, the then head of the AN, Juan Guaidó, declared that, in the absence of a "constitutionally elected" president, he would take up the mantle of caretaker president. A number of Latin American countries and the US recognise Mr Guaidó as the rightful president.

Political outlook: Political stability The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the civic-military Maduro regime to remain in power throughout the 2021-25 forecast period, despite its failure to stem a long-running socioeconomic and humanitarian crisis. A number of factors underpin our forecast; particularly significant is the regime's strict control over the military, the police and paramilitary forces. This control, which depends on a patronage system that rewards the loyalty of high-ranking officials, will allow the regime to manage internal dissent.
Following a sham legislative election in December 2020, in which the PSUV retook control of the AN, the regime enjoys virtually unchecked control over all the levers of power. Meanwhile, the Guaidó-led opposition has been left scrambling without a clear path forward. The opposition's decision to boycott the December election has left it without a voice in any major government institution. Before losing control of the AN, the opposition moved to unilaterally extend its mandate by one year. However, with many lawmakers abstaining from the vote out of fear of reprisals from the Maduro regime, and with some key international players including the EU no longer recognising Mr Guaidó as the interim president (but rather as the main opposition leader), the opposition's attempt to extend its mandate lacks clear support and legitimacy.
In practice, the fallout from the election changes little in terms of policymaking; Mr Maduro has long used the executive's sweeping powers, as well as his influence over the highly politicised judiciary, to approve his policy agenda. However, retaking control of the AN is significant insofar as it all but erases any threat that the Guaidó-led opposition might pose to Mr Maduro.
There is, nonetheless, a high degree of risk attached to our forecast that Mr Maduro will remain in power. The uncontrolled spread of the coronavirus (Covid-19), diminished oil rents-resulting from severe mismanagement of the sector, and more recently from US sanctions-and persistent goods shortages all present hefty challenges to the regime's survival. In our view, there are three main paths to a change of government: military intervention, a negotiated transition or some sort of internal coup. We believe that the prospect of military action by the US or Colombia is very low. Notwithstanding efforts by the US to increase multilateral engagement, a negotiated transition would also be difficult, as trust issues between the two sides are insurmountable. Bearing this in mind, we believe that the most likely scenario for regime change is an internal coup. The regime's main weakness is the fragility of its internal finances. Its patronage system is crucial for sustaining its security apparatus and resisting social unrest. US sanctions will exacerbate the already poor macro-economic environment and limit the country's ability to draw in US dollar finance. The regime will continue to benefit from funds from drug-trafficking and illegal mining activities, but a lack of hard currency could prove fatal to the patronage system, and will test the regime's ability to maintain cohesion among its ranks and control over the security apparatus. The regime's liquidity problems-along with the deepening socioeconomic and humanitarian crisis-could therefore prompt putsch attempts in the near term.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness Venezuela will continue to suffer in the 2021-25 forecast period from the weakest political and institutional framework in the region. Over two decades of rule by the PSUV have engendered low institutional effectiveness and high levels of corruption, largely owing to the centralisation of power within the executive branch. Questions about the credibility of the country's institutions, and a lack of accountability and transparency, will continue. For example, extensive corruption and clientelism in the provision of subsidised goods and utilities will remain a constraint on political and policy effectiveness. Similarly, PDVSA (the state-owned oil company) is an enormous source of direct and indirect profits for regime insiders and will continue to be run by army personnel, rather than by technocrats.
Drug-trafficking will remain a worrisome issue, with criminal networks well established in the country. US authorities have repeatedly accused high-ranking military and civilian government members of drug-trafficking (those accused deny the allegations). Another cause for concern is the high rate of violent crime. According to the latest internationally comparable data produced by the UN Office on Drugs and Crime, the homicide rate in Venezuela was the seventh highest in the world in 2018, at 37 per 100,000 people. The socioeconomic situation has deteriorated dramatically since then, exacerbating some of the drivers of crime. However, anecdotal evidence indicates that fuel shortages and the coronavirus pandemic may have contained violent crime temporarily. Aside from homicides, there have been numerous high-profile kidnappings for ransom in urban areas, a development that has increased concerns about police corruption and mismanagement. This increase in criminality will continue unless measures are adopted to improve the competence and effectiveness of law enforcement agencies and the criminal justice system, to reduce impunity, and to boost youth employment.
In the event of a political transition (not our baseline forecast), there would be little progress in addressing these shortcomings within our forecast period, as approving numerous structural frameworks and eliminating inherent vested interests would require considerable political capital, which would probably be in short supply. A new government would be constrained on the one hand by public demands to punish corruption in the Maduro administration and on the other hand by the practical need to keep at least some of the more pragmatic PSUV regime members and bureaucrats, who have controlled public institutions for decades, onside. A political transition could exacerbate existing problems, such as violent crime, which is currently fuelled by corruption in the judiciary and law enforcement bodies. This could be aggravated by the disbanding of colectivos (armed pro-PSUV civilian groups), as they would probably continue to operate as armed gangs under a future government.
Political outlook: Election watch Venezuela held a legislative election in December 2020 to select the 277 members of the unicameral AN. The vote, which was boycotted by most opposition parties, was widely regarded as neither free nor fair. The results were therefore unsurprising; the Gran Polo Patriótico, an electoral alliance dominated by the PSUV, won an overwhelming supermajority of 256 seats in the legislature.
Next on the electoral calendar are regional elections (to elect governors and state legislative assemblies), due by end-2021, followed by local elections (to elect mayors and councillors) in 2022. However, it appears likely that local elections will be brought forward to 2021 and held simultaneously with the regional elections. In a context where the PSUV already controls more than 85% of governorships and mayoralties, the political benefits of consolidating power at the sub-national level will be modest. Consequently, we believe that the regime will endeavour to use negotiations over electoral conditions as a step towards gaining international legitimacy and some degree of sanctions relief. At present, we remain sceptical that the regime will acquiesce to conditions that would ensure a level playing field, and we consider that prospects for sanctions relief are dim.
Against this backdrop, the main question for the opposition will be whether to participate in elections, with the game rigged against it. We believe that some factions are likely to participate-even under unfair conditions-in a bid to make inroads into a political system from which they have been shut out. However, any gains will be modest and will not alter the fundamental balance of power.
Political outlook: International relations The Maduro regime's main foreign policy challenge will centre on managing its combative ties with the US. The administration led by the former US president, Donald Trump (2017-21), instituted several rounds of crippling oil sanctions as part of a "maximum pressure" campaign designed to undermine the regime. Although the aggressive sanctions policy did not produce its intended outcome, it did accelerate the decline of Venezuela's oil industry. Mr Maduro will look to reset ties with the US under the new president, Joe Biden, but we expect little progress. US policy towards Venezuela has bipartisan support in the US, and Mr Biden is unlikely to provide significant sanctions relief absent major political compromises and commitments to democratic reforms from the Maduro regime (which remain highly improbable). Any changes to US sanctions policy will therefore be only on humanitarian grounds, aimed at improving the lives of the poorest Venezuelans. For instance, we expect the Biden administration to reverse course on recently instated sanctions on crude-for-diesel swaps, which are mainly used by the regime to shore up diesel supplies for power generation, agricultural activity, water pumps and public transport.
Russia and China have previously extended major financial support, but this has been scaled back in recent years following non-payment of liabilities by Venezuela. Despite ongoing diplomatic support from Russia and China and preferential access to their state-developed coronavirus vaccines, neither will be willing to provide game-changing amounts of finance during 2021-25. Instead, Venezuela will continue to rely more heavily on Iran, which has become the regime's main international backer, sending its refined petroleum to alleviate the country's severe petrol shortages. Relations will remain close in the short term, although there is a risk in the medium term that the US may place pressure on Iran to stop providing support to Venezuela as part of possible US-Iranian peace talks.

The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings put Venezuela among the world's least attractive investment locations for the historical period (2016-20). The country's underlying score stagnates in the forecast period (2021-25), but as Angola (the lowest-ranked country in 2016-20) will register some moderate improvements in 2021-25, Venezuela's position slips, making it the worst place to do business among the 82 countries covered by our rankings.
The poor score reflects a combination of political conflict, a dismantling of the legal framework for investors, and a corrupt, poorly managed state-led model that hampers private enterprise and competition. Highly distortionary macroeconomic policy measures have created critical economic problems that have paralysed the investment climate, most noticeably through extreme difficulties in purchasing foreign exchange and remitting profits. Recurrent goods shortages, combined with the regime's highly expansionary fiscal and monetary policy stance, have generated hyperinflation.
The country's socioeconomic crisis has major implications for the various facets of the business environment. The government's desire to maintain political control means that, despite official rhetoric being more welcoming to private investment (both by domestic and foreign players), policy predictability will be weak and the risk of ad hoc interventionism will be high in 2021-25. US sanctions, weak respect for contract rights and the dearth of market opportunities will all limit inbound foreign capital. The labour market will continue to deteriorate as mass outmigration worsens skills shortages. Meanwhile, physical infrastructure will remain in a critical state as the cash-strapped government fails to make necessary investments in the transport network and in the water and electricity systems.
Our underlying forecasts for the business environment are based on the political assumption that the current regime, led by Nicolás Maduro, remains in place, but there is a high level of uncertainty regarding this projection. However, even if the regime were overthrown and a more market-friendly administration came to power, the extent of dislocation means that it would take several years to put the country on a firmer footing.

Business environment outlook: Venezuela's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2021-22: Enforcement of price controls remains lax, but risk of state intervention remains high. Corruption and selective application of regulations are common and continue to undermine free competition.
2023-25: Contract rights remain weak, and red tape and ad hoc interventionism continue.
Policy towards foreign investment 2021-22: Government efforts to revive foreign investment fail owing to US sanctions and political and economic instability.
2023-25: Investment flows remain low amid ongoing economic volatility. Intellectual property protection and private property rights deteriorate.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2021-22: Currency controls are weakened, but access to foreign currency remains limited. US sanctions hamper trade.
2023-25: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, and de facto dollarisation advances. Domestic supply of foreign currency remains limited as oil prices decline.
Taxes 2021-22: Risks of further unrest and political instability reduce probability of central government increasing taxes. However, municipal authorities hike taxes owing to funding shortfalls.
2023-25: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but risk of discriminatory, ad hoc tax measures declines.
Financing 2021-22: Inflation remains high and concerns surrounding economic instability restrict financing to only short term.
2023-25: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid, sustainable growth in credit to private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market 2021-22: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage costs. Firms prohibited from firing workers until end-2022. Ongoing emigration of skilled labour aggravates skills shortages.
2023-25: Labour-market rigidities persist despite some increased flexibility in hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure 2021-22: Underinvestment in water network and electricity grid leads to continued rationing and unpredictable blackouts.
2023-25: Investors remain highly cautious about committing to long-term capital projects. Infrastructure deteriorates even further.
Technological readiness 2021-22: E-government services remain almost non-existent. Telecommunications sector is opened to foreign investment, but with little interest. Local use of cryptocurrency expands among middle- and high-income households.
2023-25: Limited regulatory capacity and years of underinvestment continue to restrict internet and mobile coverage.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
The macroeconomic environment will remain very weak Venezuela's macroeconomic environment ranks as the least attractive of all 82 countries covered in our rankings in the historical and forecast periods. The economy has contracted sharply for seven consecutive years, aggravated by three years of hyperinflation and a sizeable drop in oil production, from 2.4m barrels/day in 2015 to an average of 500,000 b/d in 2020. This reflects a combination of long-running underinvestment in PDVSA (the state oil firm), little private investment, deep-seated corruption and, since 2019, the impact of US oil sanctions and nationwide power cuts.

- The coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic has placed huge strains on the sinking economy. Shrinking oil revenue has exerted significant pressure on the regime's finances, aggravating food and fuel shortages, and sustaining hyperinflation and sharp currency adjustment. The country has been disproportionately negatively hit by the pandemic because of the legacy of years of incompetent policymaking, which will also hamper the pace of recovery in 2021-25. Most countries in the region will recover from coronavirus-related losses in 2022-23, but we do not expect Venezuela to do so even by 2025. As Venezuela will remain in default on its external debt, no sources of external finance will be available to engineer a firmer domestic recovery. Although average global oil prices will be higher in 2021-25 than in 2016-20, oil export volumes will be less than half of what they were in the historical period, which will maintain pressure on the public finances and external accounts. Unless the Maduro regime is replaced by a more market-friendly government (which is not our central forecast), there is no prospect of a material improvement in macro-economic conditions in 2021-25.

Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
1.5 1.8 81 82 11 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Distortionary measures and price controls will remain the regime's norm The score for policy towards private enterprise and competition will remain extremely weak in 2021-25, with Venezuela ranking as the least business-friendly of the 82 countries assessed in the business environment rankings. Although Mr Maduro has hinted that he favours a shift towards privatisation of some state assets in a bid to address the ongoing economic crisis, little concrete progress is likely. Investors will be deterred by the challenging operating conditions and the regime's refusal to alter its underlying approach-characterised by bias against free markets and politicised and inefficient institutions. Price controls remain in place; they are currently less rigorously enforced than in recent years, but government policy is inconsistent and a renewed crackdown on retailers flouting the regulations is possible. Uncertainty about contract and property rights, limited access to hard currency (despite the recent relaxation of capital controls) and the cumbersome burden of govern-ment regulation will continue to restrict private businesses' freedom to compete. Given institutional decay in recent years and significant centralisation of power, improving competition policy (as well as restricting lobbying and addressing corruption) would require an overhaul of regulatory bodies and legal frameworks. This will not occur under Mr Maduro; even if his regime is replaced by a more market-friendly administration (not our baseline forecast), the process of improving competition policy would take several years.
New legislation signals a shift in policy towards private investment
- Under the former leader, Hugo Chávez (1999-2013), the government nationalised private enterprises run by both domestic and foreign investors, undermined private-property rights and violated contractual agreements, all of which severely constrained private-sector activity. There were far fewer state takeovers under Mr Maduro in the late 2010s, reflecting growing fiscal constraints. Since 2020 there has been a shift in official policy, with Mr Maduro adopting an increasingly equivocal approach to private investment. This is likely to reflect a tacit acknowledgement that productivity at nationalised firms has plummeted and that the state is hugely overstretched, lacking the resources to reverse this trend. The anti-blockade law passed in October 2020 includes provisions designed to encourage private-sector investment, including in joint operations with public companies. The legislation allows such agreements to be fast-tracked and classified without recourse to a public-bidding process, which effectively enables the regime to privatise firms under the radar, without full public disclosure. However, this legislation is unlikely to improve the attractive-ness of the Venezuelan market for private investors. The classification of information is designed to provide anonymity to foreign investors-to persuade them that they will be able to circumvent US sanctions-but these will remain a significant deterrent. Even if there were no sanctions, the dire state of the economy and distrust of the government's respect for contract rights would vastly reduce the pool of potential investors (domestic and foreign).
- Official rhetoric has been more supportive of private-sector investment in recent months. New measures mean that small businesses that begin operations in 2021 will be exempt from paying tax on earnings in that year and will benefit from a waiver on company registration fees. However, we do not expect a significant increase in the number of formal sector startups, and there is little sign that the drive towards encouraging private-sector activity will be matched with a reduction in state interference in the private sector. Sectors with access to foreign exchange (including energy and financial services) and those selling goods that are prone to shortages (including food retailers) remain particularly vulnerable. The regime has used accusations of black-market transactions and of overly aggressive increases in retail prices as pretexts for state intervention. Raids, fines and confiscations on retailers violating maximum prices are common and will continue during the forecast period.
- Price controls on a wide range of goods have been in place for most of the past 17 years. Under the 2014 Law of Fair Prices, the government established an open-ended price-control regime and created a regulatory body responsible for analysing product prices and company cost structures to determine fair prices and profit-margin levels. Price controls affect food manufacturers and retailers, with a broad range of food staples-including meat, dairy, cooking oil, flour and rice-featuring on the regime's list of price-controlled goods. Price controls also apply to domestic petrol sales and utility rates. Although controls theoretically remain in place, enforcement has lapsed recently (partly reflecting a growing government acceptance of US dollar transactions in the retail sector, which complicates management of retail prices). Weaker enforcement of price controls is positive for businesses, as many have struggled with profitability owing to soaring input costs. However, given the unpredictability of official policy, it is possible that the government may seek to tighten compliance with price controls during 2021-25 in a bid to address hyperinflation. This uncertainty will continue to undermine the business environment.

Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment
