2.8 2.8 80 80 12 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Foreign investment will remain scarce Venezuela's score and ranking for policy towards foreign investment stagnate in the forecast period. Assuming that the Maduro administration remains in power, there is little prospect of a significant improvement in the underlying approach towards foreign investment, even though investment is desperately needed to rebuild decimated domestic productive capacity. Although the 1999 constitution establishes national treatment for foreign capital, the Maduro administration has prioritised investment from firms tied to (or owned by) friendly governments. However, as funding from China has dried up, economic necessity has forced the regime to be less selective about sources of investment. On the face of it, the regime is also open to investment in a greater range of sectors, including industries that were nationalised under Mr Chávez (including oil). However, this shift in rhetoric is not being matched by policy reforms that would afford foreign investors greater security. Given extreme economic instability and US sanctions, we do not believe that Mr Maduro's aim of increasing foreign investment will result in a significant increase in inflows. As the government is in default on its external debt obligations, firms will not be able to access investment protection schemes, adding a further disincentive.

- The World Bank's International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID) is currently considering 16 cases lodged by firms affected by government nationalisation, most of which have dragged on for several years. This will deter foreign investment, particularly as there is little indication that the Maduro regime has the desire or the funds to make compensation payments. The ICSID has already concluded 33 cases, but the regime has only agreed payment plans on a limited number of these, and only under threat of seizures in foreign courts. However, this process has been drawn-out, with many claimants still pursuing payments from ICSID rulings made in 2015-16. In recent cases the Venezuelan government has argued that US sanctions prohibit pay-ment transfers, but a US federal court rejected that argument in March in the case of Tenaris (Luxembourg), a steel-pipe maker that is seeking enforcement of a US$234m arbitration award.
- The government has indicated that it would welcome fresh foreign invest-ment in the oil sector, as part of an overall drive to lifting production back to 1.5m b/d (2016-17 levels), from 500,000 b/d in 2020. This is an acknowledgement that PDVSA remains in a critically poor state and is in no position to revive production. Mr Maduro has indicated that he will table an oil reform bill to allow foreign firms to control majority stakes in new projects (foreign investors can currently hold a maximum 49% stake, giving PDVSA effective control). However, we do not expect any significant foreign investment to materialise while US sanctions remain in place.

Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
4.2 5.1 75 74 11 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Easing currency controls will prove difficult and will progress only slowly This category is one of the only areas of the business environment in which we expect a slight improvement in conditions, leading to a small uptick in Venezuela's global and regional ranking. This mainly reflects an easing of exchange-rate controls in 2019; individuals and companies can now buy or sell foreign currency at private and state-run banks, as well as use foreign currency for a broader range of daily transactions, which has brought the bolívar closer to its black-market value. Notwithstanding the improvement, Venezuela still ranks extremely poorly in this area. Despite the relaxation of currency controls, there are significant barriers to accessing US dollars in the context of limited supply, and the regime still intervenes in foreign-exchange markets if necessary. Moreover, we do not rule out the possibility that controls could be tightened again on the off chance that the external sector sees more material improve-ment than we anticipate. Although we expect higher average global oil prices in 2021-25 than in 2016-20, this effect will be more than offset by lower oil export volumes, meaning that the supply of foreign currency is likely to remain restricted, which will in turn hamper foreign trade. Trade policy will remain incoherent, and Venezuela will continue to be an unreliable partner, racking up significant debt in unpaid invoices to suppliers. The country has been subject to increasingly tight US sanctions on financial transactions and on the country's oil trade. Our baseline forecast is that these restrictions will remain in place.

- There has long been on-off speculation that the country's deep currency distortions might force Mr Maduro to replace the currency with the US dollar. Given the long-running cycle of hyperinflation and currency devaluation, this speculation is rising. De facto dollarisation has been expanding, both in terms of day-to-day cash transactions and also in financial transactions (facilitated by growing use of foreign-currency bank accounts, which are now permitted by the authorities). Mr Maduro's previous hostility towards the use of the US dollar has also been replaced by a more welcoming attitude. Although we believe that dollarisation will continue to expand in 2021-25, we do not believe that a wholesale replacement of the bolívar with the US dollar is likely; abandoning the bolívar would deprive the authorities of the ability to use monetary stimulus to finance the gaping budget deficit. There are also significant questions about the feasibility of shifting to full dollarisation while tight US sanctions are in place and oil production is so low, as the country already has a huge shortage of US dollars. In order to increase US dollar inflows, US sanctions would need to be eased, but this would require political compromises from the government and some sort of co-governance agreement with the opposition, which in our view is highly unlikely. In addition, currency distortions have enabled the government to expand a system of political patronage, propping up its own support by facilitating access to the US dollar.
- Difficulty in remitting profits earned in Venezuela will remain one of the most significant challenges of doing business for foreign companies operating in the country. Official permission is required to remit profits, but with critical shortages of foreign exchange, remittances face long delays. Many foreign-owned companies have not been able to remit their profits for years. In the context of huge local-currency depreciation, the US dollar value of waitlisted profit remittances has eroded significantly.
- Foreign trade will continue to suffer from US sanctions that have been in place for several years against several government figures. These have been ramped up significantly since 2017 and now also target the country's commercial infrastructure, including its financial and energy sectors. There has been speculation that sanctions policy might be re-examined under the new US administration, led by Joe Biden, but our baseline forecast is that there will be little change. Any changes to US sanctions policy would be on humanitarian grounds and would focus on facilitating swap agreements (such as exchanging unrefined crude for refined petroleum, which would ease pressure on power generation and help the agricultural sector). The Biden administration may also explore the option of allowing exchanges of oil for basic commodities such as food and medicine. However, we do not expect the wholesale lifting of sanctions; as such, foreign investors will remain wary, which will suppress both trade and investment with Venezuela.

Business environment outlook: Taxes                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
4.2 4.1 80 82 12 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Improvements in the tax regime are unlikely given fiscal constraints The tax regime will remain a barrier to investment, with fiscal constraints prompting a further deterioration in this area during the forecast period. Rates of direct corporate taxation are currently moderate, with a top corporate income tax rate of 34% (excluding oil companies, for which the rate is set at 50%), but tax laws, regulations and procedures are complicated, inconsistent and subject to frequent arbitrary adjustments. The system is extremely complex; compliance with tax requirements requires businesses to make dozens of separate payments each year, which is hugely time-consuming (on both measures, Venezuela is about three times worse than the Latin American average). The tax burden is heavy, accounting for 73% of profits (the regional average is 47%). A series of new taxes introduced in 2009 doubled the effective tax rate on earnings in many cases. These taxes formed part of wider reforms such as a sports law, a new science and technology law, a worker-training law, and a municipal law, but included new fiscal charges on businesses-some of which are levied on gross revenue rather than net earnings.

- It is difficult to assess exactly how narrow the tax base is; according to the latest official data disclosed by the Servicio Nacional Integrado de Administración Aduanera y Tributaria (Seniat, the tax authority), tax income accounted for just 12% of GDP in 2012. Seniat regularly reports large increases in tax collection, but given hyperinflation, tax collection is actually shrinking in real terms, which implies that the tax base has shrunk even further since 2012. Despite this, the central government has shown little interest in raising tax rates, as Mr Maduro has financed the huge fiscal deficit through public debt issuance, which is monetised. However, municipal authorities have been raising effective tax rates in recent months, which has increased the tax burden on businesses. Municipalities have traditionally relied on central government transfers for funding, but these have dried up in recent years. Legislation passed in August 2020 to harmonise various municipal taxes included a provision that allowed municipal authorities to use the petro (a state-issued crypto-currency) as a unit of account for tax calculation. The provision has in effect allowed municipalities to base their tax calculations in US dollar terms (as the price of the petro is pegged to the dollar value of a barrel of oil). As a result, businesses have faced huge increases in their local tax bills, but with many still earning revenue in the increasingly worthless bolívar, they have become overleveraged. We expect the central government to eventually step in to repeal the petro-related provision (or pass a law that caps municipal tax rates), but this is unlikely to occur until the central government's own finances are on a better footing.
- The fiscal regime will do little to encourage new investment in 2021-25. In theory, Venezuela offers both foreign and domestic investors a full and equal range of investment incentives, including tax exemptions, special credit financing and export incentives. The federal government also operates a number of state-run lending institutions that focus on micro, small and medium-sized businesses. The Corporación Venezolana de Guayana, the state industrial-holding company, offers investment incentives, as do many states and municipalities. However, there is no evidence that the Maduro regime is actually making the benefits of these investment incentives available to businesses.

Business environment outlook: Financing                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
1.4 1.4 82 82 12 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Financing conditions will remain difficult Venezuela's score and ranking for financing remain dismal in the forecast period. The banking sector is weak and will struggle to provide reliable access to medium-term finance for the private sector. Financial sector distortions will remain severe, with the regime set to continue its policy of directed lending, which requires private banks to channel credit to specific sectors (including agriculture, mortgages and tourism) at preferential rates. Despite huge increases in nominal lending in local-currency terms, this reflects captive domestic liquidity, hyperinflation and deeply negative real interest rates. In both real and US dollar terms, the financial sector has shrunk dramatically in recent years, resulting in an extremely shallow credit market. We do not expect any significant improvement in underlying conditions in the financial sector during 2021-25; as such, financing will remain a major weakness of the business environment throughout the forecast period.

- The soundness of the financial system and the quality of regulation will remain significant concerns. Legislative changes in recent years have not resulted in a tighter regulatory framework but have simply established new layers of bureaucracy. There has been no concerted effort to tackle the patchy enforcement of existing regulations. Weak skills in regulatory agencies and political meddling in oversight will remain problems and will continue to undermine efforts to identify ailing banks at an early stage. The quality of financial sector regulation is unlikely to improve, given a lack of political will.
- State intervention will continue to have an impact on the health and profitability of the banking industry. The state already has a substantial direct presence in the industry through full ownership of three of the top ten banks and is prone to intervention in private-sector lenders.

Business environment outlook: The labour market                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
5.7 5.2 57 75 7 11
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Large-scale emigration will hamper the labour market in 2021-25 The labour market was the strongest area of the business environment in the 2016-20 historical period, but we expect conditions to deteriorate in 2021-25, with Venezuela's global and regional ranking slipping significantly. This mainly reflects increased skills shortages following the departure of large numbers of Venezuelans in recent years. Few of the skilled Venezuelans who have left the country are likely to return until the economy is on a much firmer footing, if at all. Although several governments in the region (including Chile, Peru and Ecuador) have clamped down on illegal immigration from Venezuela, the US and Colombian governments have granted Venezuelan migrants legal status. Outward migration will continue, as the domestic economic situation remains critical. The economy's informal sector is large and employs the vast majority of the country's workers. The highly distorted exchange-rate system makes it difficult to assess wage costs in US dollar terms compared with the rest of the region. Venezuela's labour laws were already among the most rigid in the world, even before a highly restrictive labour reform came into effect in 2012. This increased non-wage costs considerably: obligatory non-wage costs, employers' social security contributions, mandatory profit sharing, and childcare and food allowances added more than 70% to the basic wage costs for large and medium-sized companies, and 30% for smaller companies. As part of the government's coronavirus response, firms are prohibited from firing workers until December 2022.

- The mass exodus of Venezuelans from the country will put significant constraints on the labour market during 2021-25, particularly in terms of companies' ability to find skilled labour. According to the UN, an estimated 5.6m Venezuelans-nearly a fifth of the population-had fled the country as at April. Although outward migration virtually halted with the arrival of the coronavirus pandemic, with some reports of Venezuelans even returning across land borders as informal sector work in Colombia and Brazil dried up, the number of Venezuelans leaving the country has started to pick up again in recent months. This will worsen skill shortages further. The situation will be aggravated by the fact that chronic underinvestment in education in recent years means that even basic skills are scarce in much of the workforce, while political interference in universities and technical colleges has damaged the quality of the country's tertiary education system.
- Even once current coronavirus-related restrictions (which bar firms from firing workers until the end of 2022) are lifted, the labour market will remain extremely inflexible. Staffing levels (excluding managers, short-term workers and high-income earners) can be reduced only via collective agreement. Many workers cannot be fired at all, even in cases of stealing company property or failing to come to work. In practice, companies looking to shed staff are forced to negotiate "voluntary redundancy" agreements with workers; these typically centre on extremely generous severance payments, further adding to employ-ment costs. Employment tribunals are generally hostile to private-sector employers, a factor used by workers and union representatives to their advantage. Moreover, companies that make recourse to voluntary redundancies have at times been targeted for nationalisation, representing a further disincentive for the private sector.

Business environment outlook: Infrastructure                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
3.5 2.5 74 81 12 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Electricity provision will remain a critically weak area of infrastructure Following years of mismanagement and underinvestment, Venezuela's infra-structure has fallen into critical disrepair, and we expect further slippage in 2021-25. Repeated pledges by the regime to implement ambitious infrastructure projects have come to nothing, and state-funded investment has dried up entirely in recent years. Even routine maintenance has not been completed, with current prolonged power shortages and limited access to running water the most visible manifestations of the failure to sustain basic service provision. A combination of fiscal constraints and US sanctions means that it is difficult to attract long-term foreign direct investment (FDI) into capital projects, which will compound the dismal state of the country's infrastructure. Given pervasive corruption in state institutions and the fact that the sovereign remains in default on external debt commitments, even multilateral assistance is unlikely to be forthcoming. Even if a new, more market-friendly government took office during the forecast period (not our baseline scenario), reversing the long-term underinvestment in infrastructure would take many years.

- Reliable access to electricity will be one of the most significant challenges for businesses operating in Venezuela in 2021-25. Although the country has long faced sporadic power outages, the situation has deteriorated sharply in recent years, which on occasion has forced the government to request that workers remain at home while the authorities try to restore power. Some companies have opted to install backup generators, but this is a costly solution that does not solve all operational problems, as it can be difficult to find fuel. The supply of fresh water has been seriously affected, and communication, financial and transport networks have also been interrupted. Insufficient investment in maintaining the generation and transmission systems in recent years are to blame. Water levels at the Guri dam, which generates most of the country's hydropower (which in turn accounts for more than 50% of total electricity generation), have recovered from critically low levels in 2020, but power generation at the dam is considerably lower than the total installed capacity of 24,000 MW, owing to recent damage to several transformers. Even if the government had the funds, overhauling the entire system would take years, meaning that blackouts and electricity rationing will persist throughout the forecast period.

Business environment outlook: Technological readiness                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
3.3 2.7 74 80 10 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Venezuela is ill-prepared for technological disruption As in most areas of the business environment rankings, Venezuela's weak technological readiness ranking worsens in 2021-25. The crisis will take its toll on the telecommunications sector, with falls in disposable income adding to a decline in mobile-phone penetration (which has fallen from 102% in 2013 to about 60% currently). Internet penetration has been more stable (at about 60% since 2014), but there are major discrepancies across regions. Given that these areas are crucial drivers of wider technological developments, including mobile apps and cloud computing, declines are important factors in Venezuela's weak score.
Skills shortages will undermine Venezuela's long-term growth
- Chronic underinvestment in scientific and technical skills and extensive "brain drain" limit Venezuela's technological readiness. Acute skills shortages in technology will not be resolved in the short term, and private investors will wait for the political and economic situation to improve significantly (which is unlikely in 2021-25) before making substantial capital expenditure commitments.
- Local use of cryptocurrencies (or digital currencies) has rocketed in recent years amid declining confidence in the increasingly worthless bolívar. Adjusted for GDP, Venezuela engages in more cryptocurrency trading than any other country. As well as its primary functions as a store of value and a medium of exchange, cryptocurrency is attractive for Venezuelans because it is virtually impossible for the government to regulate the market. In this context, crypto-currency adoption is likely to expand in 2021-25. Nonetheless, cryptocurrency will not supersede the US dollar given the untested fundamentals of the crypto market. Adoption will be hindered by extremely poor internet infrastructure (especially outside the capital, Caracas); Venezuela ranks 79th in The Economist Intelligence Unit's Inclusive Internet Index, which measures indicators of internet inclusion, such as accessibility and affordability across 120 countries.

Economic forecast: Policy trends The immediate policy priorities of the regime led by Nicolás Maduro will be to contain the public health crisis caused by the coronavirus (Covid-19) outbreak and to halt a long-running economic collapse, but progress on both will be uneven. To combat the coronavirus pandemic, a "Fórmula 7+7 Plus" strategy remains in place, which involves alternating between a week of tighter restrictions and a week of more relaxed restrictions. However, this has failed to prevent fresh waves of the virus, increasing pressure on Venezuela's decrepit medical infrastructure. Efforts by the regime to procure vaccines are making slow progress; so far, Venezuela has received 380,000 doses of Russia's Sputnik V vaccine and 500,000 doses of China's Sinopharm vaccine, but the rollout has been slow (as at mid-April less than 1% of the population had received at least one dose). Mr Maduro says that a total of 10m Sputnik V doses will arrive this year, but deliveries have been intermittent and quantities low. The government hopes to obtain 11m vaccine doses through the WHO-led COVAX Facility. Following payment in mid-April, some of these vaccines should start arriving, but the politicisation of distribution and rampant corruption will hinder the vaccination campaign. Against this backdrop, The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect that enough doses of the vaccine will be distributed to have a significant impact on local transmission until 2023.
Addressing the long-running economic decline will be a similarly difficult task. Given that the public sector is completely overstretched, lacking the resources to increase productive capacity, Mr Maduro is seeking to boost private investment in order to generate an economic recovery. To this end, in October 2020 the regime promulgated an anti-blockade law, which gives the executive branch the unchecked authority to sign confidential new deals with private firms and countries (in an attempt to skirt international sanctions) without going through public tender processes.
In November the regime used the law to sell Agropatria, a state-owned agri-cultural firm, to Grupo Agrollano, a private company of unknown origin. We expect that the regime will similarly seek to reprivatise a number of other businesses that had been nationalised by Mr Maduro's predecessor, Hugo Chávez (1999-2013), but were run aground by cronyism and mismanagement. The regime will also encourage greater private-sector participation in the oil industry, but it will refrain from outright privatisation of PDVSA (the state oil company). These efforts are unlikely to yield significant results; even assuming that the regime manages to sidestep financial sanctions, it will struggle to attract new investment, given the abysmal business environment and a lack of confidence in the rule of law.

The authorities have not published complete data on the fiscal accounts since 2011. However, we expect that a high level of inefficient current expenditure, combined with an extremely weak revenue intake, will keep the budget deficit wide and the public debt/GDP ratio astronomical throughout the 2021-25 forecast period. The sovereign's default on most of its interest and principal repayments will continue to shut off access to external finance, leaving the regime reliant on monetisation to fund its deficits. Even if the government reaches an agreement with some of its creditors (including China) to restructure debt liabilities during 2021-25, we still expect the public debt burden to remain huge particularly as considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing-mainly PDVSA-issued debt and development funds-understate the true size of total public liabilities.

Economic forecast: Monetary policy Interest rates
(%)
  2020 2021 2022 2023 2024 2025
Commercial banks' prime rate (av) 13.9 21.3 20.1 20.7 19.8 21.8
Monetary policy will remain subservient to fiscal policy, as the Banco Central de Venezuela (BCV, the central bank) continues to print money to finance the government's gaping budget deficits. The BCV has, in recent years, taken steps to control growth of monetary aggregates. For instance, in early 2019 it lifted the cash reserve ratio (CRR) to 100%; although it has relaxed the CRR slightly since that peak, to 85% currently. Moreover, far from taming inflation, these measures have led to the complete destruction of private-sector credit, which stands at less than 1% of levels recorded four years ago.
These factors have accelerated the trend towards greater use of US dollars in the economy. According to private-sector estimates, two-thirds of all financial transactions are now made in US dollars. This share is likely to rise further following Mr Maduro's January announcement that banks would be authorised to expand the use of foreign-currency bank accounts. The regime has even allowed private companies to issue debt in hard currency in order to raise finance; in November 2020 Ron Santa Teresa, a domestic rum producer, became the first company in more than two decades to issue dollar-denominated bonds (worth US$300,000) on the Caracas Stock Exchange; there are reports that some other firms are planning similar issuance. Although progress will be gradual, we believe that Venezuela is ultimately headed towards greater de facto dollarisation.

After an estimated contraction in real GDP of 31% in 2020 (and a cumulative contraction of almost 77% since 2013), we forecast marginally positive growth of 0.7% in 2021. GDP is now strongly correlated with oil production. Having plummeted to an average of 500,000 barrels/day in 2020-its lowest level in several decades-crude production will stabilise in 2021 as global energy demand starts to recover. PDVSA's ability to ramp up oil production more significantly will be limited, given the absence of any active oil rigs in the country. Moreover, prospects for investment are bleak: at present, Venezuela's average break-even price is about US$15-20/barrel. However, US sanctions on the regime raise the risks involved in dealing with Venezuela, forcing the country to offer a hefty discount on its crude. That said, there are some upside risks to our assumptions. Oil prices have recovered following losses in 2020, giving potential buyers stronger incentives to find ways around US sanctions. Moreover, even in the absence of active rigs, it is possible that PDVSA could extract more crude than we anticipate from existing oil wells. For its part, the non-oil economy will experience little improvement, especially as an uncontrolled pandemic limits prospects for services activities.
We expect growth to pick up in 2022, assuming that oil prices remain supportive and that producers continue to adapt to post-sanctions export markets. However, serious operational problems (such as difficulties in obtaining equipment for repairs and finding qualified staff), a limited pool of buyers of Venezuelan crude and the weak long-term fundamentals of the oil market will cause growth to taper off towards the end of our forecast period. The non-oil economy will also make modest gains in 2022-25, assuming that continued dollarisation supports relative macroeconomic stability. Nonetheless, we expect that Venezuela's GDP (in real terms) will be only about half its 2018 level, even in 2025.


Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends With proven levels surpassing 300bn barrels, Venezuela has the largest oil reserves in the world, making it a major oil producer and exporter. However, the energy sector has suffered from disinvestment and mismanagement owing to political interference. The state is accorded exclusive ownership of PDVSA and its subsidiaries. Since 2007 oil exploration, extraction and storage activities have been reserved for state-owned enterprises or companies in which the state holds a stake of at least 60%.
Venezuelan oil production, which has been in a downward spiral for several years now, plunged further in 2020. OPEC data indicate that oil output averaged just 500,000 b/d in 2020, down from 796,000 b/d in 2019 and the weakest result in 77 years. Oil production has been in freefall for over a decade, but the decline in output in the past five years has been particularly stark, falling from 2.4m b/d in 2015. Initially, this reflected severe operational constraints at PDVSA that made it increasingly difficult for the firm to maintain production, let alone invest in exploration in order to lift future capacity. The steady exodus of foreign players, which were mainly in the oil services subsector, continued amid an extremely hostile business environment. More recently, a tightening of US sanctions has aggravated problems by hindering imports of diluents required for the blending of Venezuela's predominantly heavy and extra-heavy oil. US sanctions have also sharply reduced the pool of potential buyers, making Venezuela reliant on selling crude exports via third-party intermediaries in order to evade sanctions, at a sharp discount.
We remain pessimistic about prospects for the oil sector. The number of active oil-drilling rigs in Venezuela fell from 25 in the first quarter of 2020 to just one mid-year, and since August there have been no active rigs in the country. Although this does not mean that production will cease (or even continue to decline), given that existing platforms can theoretically extract crude, it still suggests that output will not recover significantly. The government is targeting a recovery in oil production to 1.5m b/d this year and has indicated that it would welcome fresh private investment. This acknowledgement is a reflection of the fact that PDVSA remains in a critically poor state, with failure to maintain facilities contributing to frequent oil spills and accidents at processing facilities. In recent years the company has also been affected by a loss of technical capacity, as many skilled workers have left the country. Moreover, given that its finances are stretched to the limit-PDVSA is in arrears on all of its global bonds and state efforts to obtain fresh financing from allies such as China and Russia have stalled-the company can ill afford to invest in capacity upgrades by itself.
However, we do not expect any significant private investment to materialise as long as US sanctions remain in place. In our view, the US administration, led by Joe Biden, is unlikely to provide significant sanctions relief in the absence of major political compromises and commitments to democratic reforms on the part of the Maduro regime, which remain highly unlikely. Mr Maduro has indicated that he will look to revive the Venezuelan oil industry by promoting private investment in the sector. The president has also suggested that he will seek to evade sanctions by taking advantage of a recently passed anti-blockade law, which gives the executive branch the unchecked authority to sign confidential new deals with private firms and countries. The Maduro regime has signalled that it will table a reform to the hydrocarbons law that would, among other things, abolish PDVSA's 60% equity requirement in joint ventures, flexibilise labour rules, reduce oil royalties and provide exemptions for municipal taxes. Reportedly, regime officials have already begun meeting with some domestic firms to propose allowing them to operate oilfields owned by PDVSA. However, we remain sceptical about prospects for large-scale invest-ments given the discretionary legal framework, the abysmal state of local infrastructure and the high costs of doing business. Against this backdrop, we expect oil production to be severely constrained even in the medium term, averaging only about 580,000 b/d in 2021-25.

A severely reduced domestic goods supply, constraints on import capacity and the monetisation of large public deficits will impede the disinflationary process in 2021-25. The regime has shown little inclination to take on the fiscal and macroeconomic reforms that would address the root causes of inflation. It has, however, lent its support to an ongoing process of de facto dollarisation, which will help to ease price pressures over time.

Hyperinflation will sustain bolívar depreciation in 2021. Given incessant inflation and its effect on nominal values, we believe that another currency redenomination (as in March 2018) or a new currency is a strong possibility. Even though a number of currency regulations officially remain on the books, the regime has largely stopped enforcing them in its recent embrace of dollarisation. Although a black market for US dollars continues to operate, the premium is modest compared with previous years (mainly because the authorities have let the official bolívar rate depreciate more substantially). On April 23rd the black-market exchange rate stood at BsS2,780,444:US$1, only marginally above the official exchange rate of BsS2,506,330:US$1.

Balance-of-payments pressures will remain severe in 2021-25, contributing to goods shortages and economic inequities. Foreign reserves stood at US$6.2bn in March-their lowest level in three decades. The steep decline in reserves, which has been several years in the making, reflects poor policymaking and a lack of economic diversification in the country's external sector.
Under our baseline forecast, we expect reserves to rise modestly over the forecast period, reaching US$7.8bn by end-2025. We expect this increase to be driven entirely by trends on the current account, as Venezuela's access to foreign capital will remain extremely limited. We expect the current-account balance to shift from an estimated deficit of 7.3% of GDP in 2020 to a surplus of 1.2% of GDP in 2021. Thereafter, it will remain in surplus, averaging 2.8% of GDP in 2022-25. Our forecast rests on the assumption that export earnings will pick up from a nadir in 2020 as international oil prices recover and the country steps up trade with new buyers in Asia. We also expect that workers' remittances from abroad will play a crucial role in propping up the current-account balance as Venezuelan emigrants are gradually absorbed into the labour markets in their host countries.
Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Venezuela Stocks and flows According to the IMF (whose figures differ somewhat from local sources), the stock of foreign direct investment (FDI) in Venezuela stood at US$30.1bn in 2016, the last year in which actual data have been provided. This is about a third less than a peak of US$48.9bn in 2007, primarily owing to significant disinvestment, notwithstanding the government's long-standing capital controls. Based on data released by the UN Conference on Trade and Development since then, The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that the FDI stock has increased marginally, to US$32.2bn in 2020. Following a precipitous decline in GDP in recent years, we estimate that the FDI stock stood at 63% of GDP in 2020. Overall, FDI inflows have been extremely volatile in the past 20 years, affected by both political and macroeconomic factors. During the oil opening of 1996-98, inward FDI peaked at an annual average of US$4.5bn per year. By historical standards, inward FDI held up well in the first three years of the presidency of Hugo Chávez (1999-2013), averaging US$3.8bn per year in 1999-2001. As political conflict intensified, FDI inflows began to decline in 2002-08 (averaging US$1.8bn per year), and in 2009-a year of great volatility in the world economy and adverse domestic developments in Venezuela-the country registered disinvestment of US$1.1bn (some negative inflows were also the result of compensation for nationalisations). Inward FDI recovered afterwards, averaging an estimated US$4.3bn per year in 2011-13, because of greater investment from China in energy and housing. Inward FDI weakened considerably after Nicolás Maduro, the current leader, took power, averaging US$1.1bn in 2014-20, reflecting a much weaker international oil price environment, as well as foreign investors' growing disillusionment with the government's inability to comply with investment agreements and manage the economy. Outbound FDI in Venezuela is considerable but is largely dominated by investments abroad by PDVSA, the state oil company. According to the IMF, the stock of outward FDI stood at US$32.7bn in 2016; we estimate that it to rose to US$36.8bn in 2020.
Origin and distribution The energy sector, and oil in particular, remains the main magnet for FDI. US and European oil companies have major investments in the country, even after forced changes to the ownership structure of most contracts. After oil, banking and communications have been the main recipients of FDI. Spanish banks have the largest foreign presence in the financial sector, although the Venezuelan state has bought back some operations. Other notable FDI inflows come from Chile (in forestry activities) and Canada (in the mining industry). Owing to wide-ranging US sanctions and restricted access to external finance, short-term efforts will focus on courting investment from China, Russia and Iran, although these efforts are likely to yield limited success.
Determinants Following a period of booming FDI inflows in the 1990s, driven by oil and telecommunications openings, an uncertain political and policy environment-including threats of nationalisation-and a volatile macroeconomic climate have kept FDI well below potential, particularly in the non-extractive sectors. In the extractive sector, FDI inflows have been affected by the government's restrictive hydrocarbons investment regime, which mandates that PDVSA must hold a minimum 60% stake in the oil and gas sector, and levies high taxes and royalties on private partners. The vast reserves of extra-heavy oil in the Orinoco Belt require substantial technical know-how and massive investment to be put to production, an environment where major oil companies would thrive. Many major companies are already present via joint ventures or were already present before nationalisation drives. Venezuela's oil sector would continue to be a major draw for FDI under more sustainable economic and regulatory policies.
Impact Foreign investment in oil brought accelerated growth in output, from 2.4m barrels/day in 1994 to a peak of 3.4m b/d in 1999. Foreign investment in the extractive sector has fallen since then, contributing to a decline in oil output, reinforced by PDVSA's inability to drive production. Foreign involvement has had a less dramatic impact in other sectors, such as domestic manufacturing and services, resulting in high levels of import dependence. As FDI has flowed mostly into capital-intensive industries, its impact on employment and skills levels has been limited.
Potential Given the scale of economic mismanagement and poor maintenance of existing infrastructure and productive capacity, there is large potential for investment opportunities in Venezuela. Potentially attractive opportunities for FDI exist in an array of sectors, such as oil and gas, petrochemicals, coal, aluminium, gold, forestry, power, tourism, and telecoms. There is additional potential in some manufacturing and agricultural niches (for example leather goods, cocoa and rum). However, FDI inflows will be severely curtailed by concerns about the government's policy stance, difficulties in accessing foreign exchange, the weak macroeconomic environment and the fragility of the legal framework. A recovery in investment is unlikely under Mr Maduro, as exchange-rate distortions and controls on local prices will remain unaddressed. A more noticeable upturn in FDI inflows will have to wait until after a political transition takes place, and only if the new government were to engage in structural economic reforms.

As long as the current regime is in place, mass emigration will continue Population growth will remain weak because of a falling birth rate and large-scale emigration. Annual population growth has been slowing steadily, from 2.6% in the 1980s to 2.1% in the 1990s and 1.6% in 2000-10. The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that the population declined by an average of 0.4% per year in the 2016-20 historical period as the economic crisis worsened. The UN High Commission for Refugees estimates that 5.6m Venezuelans have left the country since 2014, with about 1.7m residing in neighbouring Colombia. However, the onset of the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic brought a halt to the incessant outmigration; the Colombian authorities estimate that more than 120,000 Venezuelans left Colombia in 2020 and returned to their home country owing to a pandemic-led dearth of economic opportunities Nonetheless, the inversion in migration flows will be short-lived. Regional economies will gradually reopen in 2021-22; this, together with a lack of employment and goods shortages at home, will cause migrants to continue leaving Venezuela. Our projections for population growth in the 2021-25 forecast period therefore assume that outward migration will continue. We expect the total population to decline to 28.1m by 2025 (from an estimated peak of 30.9m in 2016), with just under a quarter of the population aged 14 and under, and two-thirds of the population between 15 and 64 years of age. Population density is low, at 33 people/sq km, according to World Bank estimates from 2018. Distribution between urban and rural areas is highly uneven, with about 90% of the total population living in urban centres. Underdeveloped rural infrastructure and limited job opportunities in the countryside will result in a continuing trend of urbanisation in 2021-25.
Official statistics belie the destruction of the labour market Analysis of the labour market is complicated by a lack of credibility in official statistics. Based on official numbers, the labour force participation rate declined from 75% in 2004 to 70% in 2013 (owing to increased uptake of education, linked to the government's social programmes). Since then, the participation rate has reportedly been on an upward trend, reaching 73% in 2018. The labour market data, however, are at odds with official figures for economic activity, which show that real GDP has been on a downward spiral since 2014. In our view, labour force participation is likely to have declined in recent years, as deteriorating economic conditions are likely to have discouraged potential job-seekers from entering the market. Our own projections assume that the labour force participation rate fell from 70% in 2013 to 65% in 2018 and to 56% in 2020. We believe that the long-running economic depression, combined with a steep decline in real wages (we estimate that, in real terms, the minimum wage plus food vouchers has lost over 99% of its value since mid-2013), will have had a pronounced impact on the size of the workforce. We expect participation rates to remain subdued in 2021-25. A poor business environment, economic malaise and extremely restrictive labour regulation will limit job creation, forcing more people to depend on the informal sector, which is already estimated to account for more than half of employment.
According to the national statistics institute (INE), the unemployment rate fell from 15% in 2010 to 7% in 2018. Although the INE has not produced unemploy-ment statistics since 2018, a recent publication by the Ministry of Planning indicates that the official unemployment rate stood at 8.8% in the first half of 2020. Even accounting for extremely inflexible labour laws, these data seem extremely detached from the country's economic realities. Our own projections assume that the unemployment rate stood at almost 50% in full-year 2020.
Public services will remain under strain from a lack of resources The old-age dependency ratio will remain low by developed-country standards but, in the context of volatile public finances, population ageing will place growing pressure on the heavily burdened social security system. Public hospitals will continue to suffer from crumbling infrastructure and a lack of supplies (including medicines) and equipment. Equipment is mainly imported or assembled from imported parts, and supplies have fallen victim to a lack of US dollars. Programmes to build and rebuild hospitals have failed owing to mismanagement of funds and shortages of building materials. Even a parallel welfare system, the Sistema Nacional de Misiones, is struggling to function as the government makes cuts and inflation erodes purchasing power. Overall, we therefore expect the provision and quality of public healthcare and education services to deteriorate further, exacerbated by the rampant Covid-19 pandemic. The continued worsening will also reflect long-running problems, including a pronounced deficit of technical and basic skills, and the continued emigration of professionals (particularly doctors and nurses).

The scale of Venezuela's economic crisis has led to a rapid decline in living standards, with GDP per head falling by more than two-thirds, from a peak of US$12,921 in 2012 to an estimated US$1,719 in 2020. Estimates using purchasing power parity (PPP) give a higher figure, of US$4,114. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects only a modest improvement in both GDP per head at market exchange rates and at PPP by 2025, driven largely by increased oil production and improved macroeconomic stability (facilitated by the expansion of dollarisation in the economy). The scope for further enhancement of living standards during the 2021-25 forecast period will be constrained by structural economic deficiencies, which are unlikely to be remedied under the current regime, led by Nicolás Maduro.
Several factors will restrict purchasing power, including rampant inflation and persistently high poverty and income inequality. Official statistics show dramatic and sustained improvement across myriad social indicators in recent years, but these data have been disputed. According to the government, the multi-dimensional poverty rate has fallen consistently, from 29.6% in 2004 to 20.4% in 2014 and to 17% in 2018. However, these data contrast starkly with independent measures of multidimensional poverty. According to the Encuesta Nacional de Condiciones de Vida (Encovi, an annual survey conducted by three well-regarded local universities), the poverty rate rose from 39% in 2014 to 68% in 2019.
The government does not produce separate statistics on measures of inequality, but Encovi data indicate extremely wide income gaps in the country. Based on Encovi figures, Venezuela's Gini index score-a measure of income inequality that ranges from 0 (perfect equality) to 100 (complete inequality)-rose from 40.7 in 2014 to a peak of 68.7 in 2017, before falling to 51 in 2019, probably driven by the exodus of middle- and high-income Venezuelans. Despite this, Venezuela remains one of the most unequal countries in the region and in the world.
Investment potential will only be tapped after a political transition Venezuela is a reasonably sized consumer market and has the potential to become an attractive investment location. However, any benefits from this will not materialise until a more market-friendly administration takes over (not our baseline forecast). The country has vast reserves of natural resources (including oil, gas, coal and precious metals), an array of spectacular natural tourist attractions, relatively good physical infrastructure and a fairly favourable geographical location (given its proximity to the US). However, poor economic policies have contributed to a volatile GDP profile and deteriorations of public services and human capital over the past two decades. The unattractiveness of the business environment is compounded by inadequate contract and property rights. Moreover, a deterioration in the quality of healthcare and education provision in the past three decades have contributed to an erosion of skills and productivity, exacerbated by an exodus of talented individuals to work abroad.

Retail sales volumes will be subdued in 2021-25 As in the rest of Latin America, spending on food, beverages and tobacco accounts for the largest share of total consumer expenditure; this will remain the case throughout the forecast period. Most consumer goods industries will remain underdeveloped owing to government controls and the country's severely damaged productive capacity. Moreover, limited availability of foreign exchange has resulted in a scarcity of consumer goods that are not produced domestically. The weak outlook for economic recovery will subdue retail sales volumes throughout the 2021-25 forecast period.

Although The Economist Intelligence Unit assumes that the leader of the regime, Nicolás Maduro, will retain power in the short to medium term, we expect successive governments to put forth structural reforms to the oil sector and to make limited inroads in diversifying the economy in the longer term. On this basis, we anticipate that Venezuela's real GDP per head will grow by an annual average of 2.2% in 2021-30 (following a steep contraction of 13.5% in the preceding decade). Growth will average a healthier 4.2% in 2031-50, but the country's population is unlikely to reach a high standard of living in those years. Indeed, by 2050 we forecast that per-head GDP at purchasing power parity (PPP) will be US$21,767-low for a country with Venezuela's endowment of national resources. Although we expect the business environment to improve, the country's weak institutions, dependence on the extractive industry and a weak productive base will remain significant barriers to growth.
The macroeconomic collapse will impair the long-term productivity capacity Initial conditions: After averaging growth of 10% in 2004-08, real GDP fell sharply in 2009-10. Although the economy recovered in 2011-12 on the back of aggressive fiscal spending, growth slowed sharply again in 2013, with the economy slipping into a deepening recession in late 2014. We estimate that, by the time the economy returns to growth in 2021, real GDP will have fallen by almost 75%, making the recession the country's most severe since compilation of national statistics data began. The heterodox policy framework that has been in place for over a decade has been a major factor in hampering GDP growth, and an opaque and distorted exchange-rate system has provided opportunities for large-scale corruption, further undermining the institutional framework and maintaining income inequality. Institutional deterioration is deep-rooted and will prove harder to reverse. On a more positive note, a higher skills base and reasonably good road infrastructure by regional standards provide scope for faster overall growth and a rise in personal incomes. Nevertheless, under-investment in human capital and infrastructure, as well as the emigration of most skilled labour, is eroding these advantages and, given fiscal difficulties, this trend will take time to reverse. Successive governments have failed to take advantage of Venezuela's proximity to developed US and European markets relative to its South American neighbours, as internal geography and a lack of infrastructure investment in the interior have limited its chances of becoming a regional hub for transport and commerce.
Demographic trends: As in most other emerging markets, growth in the working-age population will slow in the long term while rising participation rates will drive brisker growth of the labour force. Venezuela will continue to enjoy supportive population dynamics, with the dependency ratio of old to young low by OECD standards, even in 2050. Despite a steady rise in life expectancy, the share of the population aged 65 years and over will be only about 11% in 2050, whereas the share of the population at working age will remain high, at 69%. A particular risk to productivity is the "brain drain" of recent years, as many experienced professionals have left the country to work abroad with no guarantee of returning.
Oil will remain crucial to Venezuela's economic prospects External conditions: We estimate that oil accounts for close to 95% of export revenue at present and expect it to continue to dominate the Venezuelan economy. Although there will be a limited drive to diversify the productive base in the long term, Venezuela will remain highly dependent on exports of oil and other commodities. Under Hugo Chávez (1999-2013) and now under Mr Maduro, Venezuela and its allies have taken a confrontational stance against US policy and US-led efforts at economic integration. In the medium term, we expect Venezuela to continue to rely heavily on oil and extractive industries, and to strengthen economic links with Asian markets and existing political allies (such as Russia, Turkey and Iran). In the longer term, however, we assume that successive governments will implement a number of structural economic and political reforms, which will allow Venezuela to diversify away from oil to some degree, breathing life back into trade with the US.
Institutions and policy trends: We assume that some of the most distortionary elements of the current policy framework (including price and exchange controls) will be scaled back gradually, as the regime considers that doing so is essential to its survival. However, prospects for improvements in other areas of the business environment are low, as structural microeconomic reforms will not be forthcoming. For example, improvement in the public finances will prove unfeasible unless international crude prices reach pre-2014 levels. Given that the economy will remain highly vulnerable to oil price fluctuations, the fiscal position will be highly procyclical. Reforms to social security or labour legislation will only be possible under a future administration. In 2031-50 we assume that successive governments will bring in policy improvements, but gains will be slow to materialise given the country's institutional weakness.
Long-term performance: Even once the most distortionary elements of current economic policy have been abandoned, Venezuela's GDP growth potential will be constrained by the deterioration of the skills base over the past decade. However, there is still scope for recovery in 2031-40, when growth will average a respectable 5.9%, before slowing to an average of 4.3% in 2041-50. Higher GDP growth rates would be possible in the long term under new, more market-friendly administrations, which we expect would pursue reforms to the country's long-standing economic and political policies. The overall economy will remain vulnerable to continuing boom and bust cycles, with negative consequences for macroeconomic stability and growth. This will hamper prospects for catch-up with more developed economies, despite some solid projected growth later in the 2021-50 long-term forecast period.

Long-term outlook: Long-term trends Venezuela is vulnerable to the adverse effects of climate change, owing both to its geographical limitations and the government's inadequate focus on preparedness. Venezuela is deemed extremely vulnerable to climate change, given its population distribution along coastal lines on unstable terrains. About 75% of the country's population is estimated to live in the 20% of the territory facing the Caribbean Sea. Given low infrastructure maintenance and little disaster preparedness, the population centres there are exposed to torrential rains, mudslides and flash floods. According to a recent study by a local and internationally recognised expert, Juan Carlos Sanchez, even within established rainfall patterns, variance has resulted in a rising number of extreme events per year in the past decade. Longer-term trends in rainfall will also affect the country. A study by the Universidad Simón Bolívar, a well-regarded local university, concluded that rainfall in the northwest of the country could fall by 25% by 2060. This would not only cause internal migration, but would also drive the country into further food insecurity (Venezuela is already heavily reliant on imports of foodstuffs). In addition, changing rain patterns may disrupt hydroelectricity generation, a major problem given that this represents more than 50% of the country's electricity.
The government has done little to address these challenges. Its public works programmes concentrate on traditional infra-structure projects, and minimal attention is given to disaster preparedness. Official data on carbon emissions and pollution in the country are scarce, but environmental policies are generally deemed poor by specialised observers. PDVSA, the state-owned oil firm, has been routinely accused of poor environmental protection in both its oil and gas operations. The Economist Intelligence Unit has developed a model to calculate the impact of climate change on long-term growth; we find that the Venezuelan economy will be almost 5% smaller in 2050 than it would have been without this hit to growth.
Migration and urbanisation Venezuela experienced rapid urbanisation through the majority of the second half of the 20th century, when the country's oil wealth was developed. According to data from the World Bank, the percentage of the population living in urban centres grew from 60% in 1960 to almost 90% by the late 1990s-high by global standards but in line with most large Latin American countries. Oil exports, especially at the start of this process, funded large-scale real-estate developments and infrastructure works in budding urban centres, attracting prospective workers from the countryside. In addition to a growing middle class fed by spillover from the country's oil wealth, the exodus from rural areas to cities created sprawling shanty-towns across major metropolises, which public-housing programmes have been unable to eradicate. Income inequality in urban centres is especially acute, feeding crime and political tension. This is perhaps best exemplified in Caracas, the capital, where income and wealth disparities have correlated with voter preferences for either the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) or for opposition parties.
Emigration, previously a limited phenomenon, has become a major issue. According to the UN High Commissioner for Refugees, a total of 5.6m Venezuelans (representing about a fifth of the current population) have left the country since 2013, with most having left in the past four years. These migrants were initially primarily driven by political reasons, but the exodus is also driven by criminal violence (Venezuela has one of the world's highest murder rates) and woeful economic conditions. Anecdotal evidence suggests that those leaving have been primarily young, well-trained professionals, which has harmed the country's economic prospects further. Under our expectation of no political transition in the short term, outward migration will continue (albeit at a slower pace than in 2018-20). Skilled workers in particular will seek to move abroad, further dampening Venezuela's long-term growth potential.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include: LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Guide to the business rankings model Outline of the model The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2016-20) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2021-25). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2016-20. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2021-25 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2016-20 ranges are then used to derive 2021-25 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2021-25, not to the likely situation in 2025 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2018 or 2023). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: - The tenure of the president, Muhammadu Buhari, will last until 2023 and be blemished by a decline in living standards caused by recession in 2020, a rise in unemployment and (paradoxically) high, policy-induced inflation.
- The administration will struggle to tackle high levels of poverty and the country's ethnic and religious divisions. This potent mixture has the potential to cause protests that could halt the advancement of pro-market reforms.
- A decline in living standards under Mr Buhari, whose tenure has been marked by two recessions, as well as frustrations over rising insecurity and poor governance, means that the opposition, the People's Democratic Party (PDP), is forecast to win the 2023 election.
- Efforts to improve the business environment will continue to be hindered by the slow pace of market-oriented structural reforms, the ongoing problem of corruption, the absence of effective government institutions, poor infrastructure and the weak capacity of the civil service to implement changes.
- The Economist Intelligence Unit expects some reregulation of electricity pricing under a PDP government. This would be bad news for the power sector, but we do not expect a return to distortive pricing in the petroleum sector.
- Still-weak revenue inflows in 2021 will coincide with large recurrent government spending commitments and result in another substantial fiscal deficit (by Nigerian standards). The budget shortfall will then broadly narrow as external conditions improve, the domestic economy picks up and revenue rises.
- Given a crippling infrastructure deficit, high inflation, instability in crucial agricultural regions and high unemployment, we expect real GDP growth of just 1.2% in 2021. Only when the exchange rate and inflation stabilise will there be a more meaningful recovery.
- Inflation will stay high in 2021 as devaluation of the naira, price deregulation, instability in agricultural growing areas, monetary loosening and exchange-rate restrictions for staple imports feed into consumer prices. Monetary tightening is expected to start from 2022 to tackle the issue.
- We expect a current-account deficit for a third consecutive year in 2021 (something that has not been seen since the 1990s) despite a substantial rebound in oil prices. The current account will return to surplus in 2022-25 as the oil market recovers and petrol import volumes decline.
