- Nigeria's business environment score worsens slightly for the forecast period (2021-25) as the macroeconomic and security environment remains highly challenging. As a result, its global and regional rankings fall.

Country forecast overview: Nigeria's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2021-22: The overarching policy objective is to promote self-sufficiency and local industrialisation through protectionism. As a result, the non-oil sector will be largely shielded from external competition.
2023-25: A new government (which is likely to be opposition-led) is likely to remain wary of opening up the economy.
Policy towards foreign investment 2021-22: Royalties for offshore oil activity that were introduced in 2020 are reduced in an attempt to prevent divestment from oil majors operating in Nigeria. Outside the oil sector, concerns over the foreign-exchange regime deter investment.
2023-25: Energy firms remain hesitant about increasing their presence in a difficult operating environment, especially onshore, but concerted efforts are made to clean up the national oil company (which is in joint venture with oil majors).
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2021-22: Movement of goods is highly regulated to prevent smuggling, but people will be allowed to cross land borders once the coronavirus pandemic is brought under control.
2023-25: A spread between the official and the parallel-market exchange rates persists as oil prices rise and the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) is again able to defend an overvalued official exchange rate.
Taxes 2021-22: The focus on boosting tax compliance intensifies, but the weak state of the economy and upcoming elections prevent tax increases.
2023-25: Value-added tax (VAT) is raised from 7.5% to cut the budget deficit amid persistently high debt-servicing costs.
Financing 2021-22: The government returns to the sovereign debt market, and capital projects are restarted.
2023-25: Credit conditions become tighter as the CBN moves to control high inflation.
The labour market 2021-22: Employers face major problems, including a shortage of skilled manual workers, restrictive visa regulations and poor health indicators.
2023-25: Employers continue to struggle to find qualified staff; unemployment stays high and the labour market loose.
Infrastructure 2021-22: A reduction in consumer subsidies (for petrol) frees up resources for higher public capital investment, but government spending remains small relative to the size of the economy, at less than 7%.
2023-25: A large private refinery starts up, reducing Nigeria's near-total dependency on imported petrol.
Technological readiness 2021-22: Nigeria retains a vibrant technology sector for an economy at its stage of development, but infrastructure is weak outside urban hubs.
2023-25: Research spending remains low compared with global averages, but some home-grown technology firms looking to adapt global technology trends to the Nigerian market continue to do well.

Background: Nigeria gained independence in 1960, and multi-party democracy was restored in 1999 after a protracted period of military rule. The first two presidential elections (in 1999 and 2003) were both won by a former military ruler turned civilian politician, Olusegun Obasanjo. Mr Obasanjo was unable to change the constitution to allow him to serve a third term in office, so in the 2007 election power passed to his handpicked successor, Umaru Yar'Adua. After Mr Yar'Adua's death in May 2010, his vice-president, Goodluck Jonathan, assumed the presidency and went on to win the 2011 presidential election. In 2015 Mr Jonathan was defeated by Muhammadu Buhari, who secured a second term in early 2019.
Political structure: Under the constitution adopted in May 1999, a strong executive presidency appoints a Federal Executive Council, comprising government ministers and ministers of state from each of Nigeria's 36 states. The executive is accountable to the bicameral National Assembly. Political parties tend to lack clear ideologies; in practice, personal and ethnic ties predominate. The People's Democratic Party (Mr Jonathan's party) had historically been the predominant political force, but the merger in 2013 of three large opposition parties to form the All Progressives Congress gave them, with Mr Buhari at the helm, the reach that they needed to take power in 2015 and secure re-election in 2019.
Policy issues: Successive governments have sought to improve macroeconomic stability and develop the nation's dire infrastructure, with mixed results. The government is struggling to end insecurity in various parts of the country. These tensions are stoked by the underlying problems of poverty and unemployment. Management of the naira by the authorities is a contentious issue, with important subsidy programmes hinging on an overvalued official exchange rate.
Taxation: Corporate profits in most non-oil sectors are taxed at 30%. Planned changes to the tax system for the oil and gas sector have been repeatedly delayed, creating uncertainty. Most other taxes are low, reflecting the fact that most revenue comes from the oil sector, with the total tax take small as a share of GDP. With oil prices far lower than they were in 2010-14, it is likely that amendments to consumer taxes will be made, specifically in value-added tax (VAT, currently 7.5%).
Foreign trade: Exports are dominated by oil. The slump in oil prices from the second half of 2014 wiped out what had historically been a large current-account surplus. The non-oil export base has been rendered globally uncompetitive by massive infrastructure deficiencies.

Outlook for 2021-25: Political stability The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the president, Muhammadu Buhari, to stay in power until his second (and final) term expires in 2023. He will be under immense pressure to stabilise Nigeria, but myriad security threats will prove unmanageable. The military and police are overstretched and unable to tackle simultaneous security crises. Emergencies will be triaged, with military resources deployed to whichever is considered the most pressing.
This shaky system will keep the government in power but leave the country highly dysfunctional and, in many regions, extremely insecure. The government will remain embroiled in a drawn-out conflict with two Islamist terrorist groups, Boko Haram and Islamic State of West Africa Province. In recent years both groups have been confined mainly to north-eastern Nigeria, but there have been recent reports that Boko Haram has expanded into central Nigeria, sparking concerns about potential insecurity close to the capital, Abuja. Although this agricultural "Middle Belt" has been affected by violent conflict between farmers and herdsmen over increasingly scarce land and water resources, it is relatively new territory for Boko Haram. Security challenges will also increase in other areas of the country, with unrest in the south-east attributed to Biafran secessionist groups and a broader surge in kidnappings by established groups such as Boko Haram and by organised criminal networks.
The security forces will attempt to address all these threats, but with resources increasingly stretched, the security situation will remain extremely volatile. The north-east-particularly Borno state-will remain a low-level conflict zone, and banditry and kidnapping will remain pervasive. Over 2021-25 other areas of the country could begin to resemble the highly insecure north-east as, in essence, "no-go" zones. Broader problems such police corruption and judicial impunity will remain unaddressed and compound the precarious security situation.
Nigeria's federal government has weathered severe but localised (largely rural) security problems for several decades without overall stability being jeopardised. However, the near- to medium-term outlook is made more uncertain by the scars of recession in 2020 and by rising unemployment (which reached 33% in the fourth quarter of 2020, one of the highest levels in the world) and poverty. Declining living standards arguably exacerbated and prolonged the protests over police brutality that broke out in cities across southern Nigeria in October 2020. The risk of fresh bouts of violent protest will be elevated in the near term given growing security problems and the still-weak economy. We currently do not expect this to jeopardise Mr Buhari's leadership; there have been sporadic rumours that elements of the military may be plotting a coup, but the president appears to retain solid support from the army. A more likely scenario is that violent bouts of protest will force concessions from the government, potentially placing some of its pro-market reform agenda on hold in order to extend price controls and increase subsidisation on utility rates.
Outlook for 2021-25: Election watch The next national elections are due in 2023. In the most recent presidential election, in 2019, the candidates of both main parties were from the north, and custom dictates that the candidates in 2023 will be from the south. This should lead to an improvement on the abysmally low turnout in 2019 in the south, which is a stronghold of the main opposition party, the People's Democratic Party (PDP). Frustration with high prices, declining living standards and perpetual instability will be directed at the ruling party, the All Progressives Congress, giving the PDP a winning edge.
Outlook for 2021-25: International relations Nigeria will remain a major player in Africa, given its size, but its domestic challenges tend to keep policymakers inwardly focused. Land borders that were closed to goods since late 2019 have reopened, but recent instability in Chad has meant increased restrictions, with only Nigerians allowed to enter the country from Chad. Nigeria's approach to encouraging regional trade will be minimalist, beyond its obligations under the African Continental Free Trade Agreement (AfCTFA). The trade pact compels Nigeria to eliminate 97% of tariff lines over the next five to ten years. This deadline will not be met early, given high prices in Nigeria and declining external competitiveness for industries that could otherwise benefit from regional market access.
Outlook for 2021-25: Policy trends Nigeria's government and the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) will aggressively promote local industry, but some elements of policy are contradictory and will contribute to macroeconomic imbalances. An important theme for inward investment will be management of the naira. A ban on foreign-exchange access for imports of certain manufactures and agricultural goods (covering 47 items) is being enforced to protect local industry and support the currency, but has some major flaws. Most notably, restrictions are elevating inflation and undermining the currency regime through sustained real effective exchange-rate (REER) appreciation. Despite this, currency restrictions are expected to last throughout the forecast period, being central to the CBN's economic development strategy.
The government has announced that henceforth it will conduct official foreign-exchange transactions using the Nigerian autonomous foreign-exchange fixing (NAFEX) rate, which was previously used only by exporters and investors. This is tantamount to devaluation and has been touted by officials as the adoption of a "market-determined" currency. However, a wide spread between the NAFEX and parallel-market rates confirms overvaluation of the former, and the CBN continues to insist that the structure of the foreign-exchange market is unaltered. The adoption of a fully market-determined currency is not expected in 2021-25, with the CBN adamant that such a move would lead to an overshoot and an inflationary spiral.
Faced with hard-currency shortages in 2020, the CBN has allowed a backlog of foreign-exchange orders from investors and importers to accumulate. Market turnover has broadly increased in 2021, but the backlog will only be cleared slowly to modulate capital outflows, further undermining the currency regime's reputation. A pattern of inflexibility by the CBN in the wake of oil price shocks (with similarly severe foreign-exchange shortages in 2015-16) will have a long-term impact on confidence, and partly explains our projection that foreign direct investment (FDI) will equal 1% of GDP or less throughout 2021-25.
Over time the contradiction between protectionism and the AfCFTA's principles will grow increasingly conspicuous, but we do not expect an immediate change in strategy given that non-tariff barriers will be phased out over several years. Developing manufacturing and agriculture is likely to be viewed as a means of preparing for the eventual elimination of tariffs, with currency controls expected to play a role in hastening the process. However, an infrastructure deficit, REER appreciation and instability in agricultural heartlands mean that Nigeria will struggle to acquire new comparative advantages in 2021-25, leaving the fiscal and external accounts and the naira exposed to oil price swings.
Price controls will be another important area of economic policy. Astonishing strides towards the deregulation of petrol and electricity pricing were made in 2020, but the goal of reaching market prices has already been scaled back, in the face of political pressure and now that crude oil prices are rising. A permanent reinstatement of petrol price controls is made unlikely by a new Petroleum Industry Bill (PIB) that we expect to be passed later in 2021. The legislation is likely to streamline sector-wide regulation in the process of creating a new, profit-oriented national oil company, which by definition could not be weighed down by subsidising the retail market. The downstream industry should become commercially viable from this reorganisation of the sector, allowing Nigeria to wean itself off petrol imports, with a new 650,000-barrel/day refinery expected to come on stream in 2022. The PIB will also encourage upstream oil investment by making fiscal terms clearer for multinationals. However, we do not expect the sustained electricity price increases that are needed for the power sector to become financially sound, and pricing in the sector remains regulated de jure. Electricity undersupply will therefore continue to hinder industrialisation.
Outlook for 2021-25: Fiscal policy We expect that the public finances will stay in deficit in 2021-25, but that the shortfall will ease over the forecast period. Crude oil receipts make up more than 50% of the federal government's retained income, and an average global oil price of US$63.8/barrel in 2021-25 will be insufficient to balance the budget.
The federal government's tax take is among the world's lowest given widespread evasion and a large informal sector. The authorities view value-added tax (VAT, currently at 7.5%) as the most effective means of increasing fiscal receipts, and we expect three equal VAT rate increases, taking the rate to 15% by 2025. The first is expected in 2022, prior to the next elections but seemingly inevitable given a rising debt burden, with further rises in 2024 and 2025. Even then, we expect fiscal revenue to peak at just 4.4% of GDP in 2024, which also assumes a lack of fuel subsidies (costs for which are deducted from revenue) after 2021. Set against this, high debt-servicing costs, a large public wage bill and healthcare commitments, including purchase of coronavirus (Covid-19) vaccines, will elevate expenditure. Capital investment will be emphasised to compensate for the ending of petrol subsidies once the PIB is enacted (which is expected in late 2021). The government justified price deregulation by promising to invest the savings in infrastructure and will face pressure to match rhetoric with action.
We expect the fiscal deficit to decline to 3.3% of GDP in 2021 (from 3.7% of GDP in 2020) as international oil prices rise. VAT increases will lead the ratio to fall to 2.3% of GDP in 2024, but a decline in average global oil prices in 2025 will cause the shortfall to widen to 2.5% of GDP in 2025. The government has raised its public debt limit to 40% of GDP to incorporate higher budget shortfalls over the medium term and to accommodate securitisation of CBN deficit financing as long-term debt. We expect the ratio to reach only 31% of GDP in 2025.
Outlook for 2021-25: Monetary policy The CBN will fail to keep inflation below a target ceiling of 9%, and its policy decisions are likely to remain erratic. After a cumulative increase of 100 basis points in May and September 2020, the policy interest rate has been kept at 11.5% despite an upward trend in annual inflation (which reached 18.2% in March). The current strategy is to boost the supply side of the economy and thereby control inflation. We believe this is misguided; high and rising inflation will frustrate an economic recovery, and issues such as inadequate public infrastructure, direct funding of the fiscal deficit, hard-currency shortages and rampant instability need to be addressed before the supply side can moderate the price level. We expect high inflation to persist, compelling the CBN to raise interest rates in 2022, despite still-weak economic growth. There is a distinct possibility that the CBN may tighten earlier, given escalating inflation. Easing will resume only in 2024, when inflation has fallen appreciably.
Outlook for 2021-25: Economic growth The economy is expected to exit recession in 2021 as the impact of lockdown in 2020 fades, but high inflation will impede improvements in business sentiment and dampen real purchasing power amid high unemployment (at more than one-third of the labour force) and low wage growth. Fiscal stimulus will be an inadequate counterforce, given budget constraints, and loose monetary policy will put pressure on the naira, creating foreign-exchange scarcity and further undermining macroeconomic stability. Oil export volumes will rise slightly, however, as quotas agreed by OPEC+ (comprising OPEC and a group of non-OPEC countries) are relaxed, contributing to real GDP growth of 1.2% in 2021.
The CBN is expected to tighten monetary policy from 2022, circumscribing the nascent economic recovery, but the exchange rate should stabilise and cause inflation to ease, allowing stronger growth. As non-business financial penetration is low, private consumption will recover in the second half of 2021-25 alongside disinflation even as interest rates rise. New refining capacity is expected to come on stream in earnest, boosting net exports (with some output for the regional market, and Nigeria's import dependency for fuel falling). Crude oil exports are also expected to grow as prices rise. As refinery output continues to ramp up, inflation falls and real spending power recovers, growth will pick up to an annual average of 4% in 2023-24. However, these rates of growth are well below potential. The economy will continue to lack dynamism given high interest rates, low FDI, high unemployment, pervasive instability in agricultural regions and infrastructure deficiencies, particularly regarding stable power supply. A more challenging year is forecast for 2025 as oil prices fall and macroeconomic uncertainty rises, with growth slipping to 1.9%.
Outlook for 2021-25: Inflation We expect inflation to average 17% in 2021, with increases on both core and non-core levels. High inflation will stem from past increases in petrol prices and the lingering pass-through of raised electricity tariffs in 2020, foreign-exchange restrictions on various imported goods, including staple foods, and devaluation of the naira. Assuming that the exchange rate stabilises and the CBN tightens monetary policy, we expect the annual inflation rate to begin to fall from 2022, to an average of 10% in 2024. Foreign-exchange controls on imported goods, conflict in the Middle Belt-Nigeria's breadbasket-and an eventual return to pricing petrol at the market rate will prevent a faster fall. Currency devaluation in 2025 will cause the average rate to increase again, to 12.5% that year.
Outlook for 2021-25: Exchange rates Nigeria's government has declared that official transactions have shifted from the CBN rate (N379:US$1) to the NAFEX rate (N412:US$1 in late April), in essence consolidating the two via devaluation and in effect making the official rate obsolete. The NAFEX rate-which was established in 2017-is more flexible than the official rate but is nonetheless tightly managed by the CBN and overvalued, as demonstrated by a parallel rate of N485:US$1.
Foreign reserves are again declining after a brief rise in early April and the CBN is yet to clear a backlog of hard-currency orders, indicating that the drawdown is partly being caused by a net outflow on current transactions, despite firmer oil prices. REER appreciation is a leading factor behind the external imbalance, and in the CBN's defence of reserves, we expect the naira to end 2021 at N422:US$1. Following this we expect the current account to return to surplus in 2022-25 while monetary tightening in Nigeria attracts hot-money inflows. This should allow the CBN to keep the exchange rate broadly stable. Unceasing currency misalignment means that REER appreciation will nonetheless resurface and, with oil prices expected to slide again in 2025, another devaluation is expected in that year, to N485:US$1.
Forecasting the naira The Economist Intelligence Unit began forecasting the Nigerian autonomous foreign-exchange fixing (NAFEX)rate from March 2021, following the government's adoption of that rate for official transactions. In the interest of continuity, data in previous periods will be for the official exchange rate before its merger with the NAFEX rate.
Outlook for 2021-25: External sector Assuming that devaluation moderates import demand for goods and services, and with global crude prices rising and inward transfers increasing as the global economy returns to growth, we expect a current-account deficit equal to 0.9% of GDP in 2021, down from 3.9% of GDP in 2020. Over the remainder of the forecast period we expect a small current-account surplus. Oil prices are projected to remain relatively high in 2022-23, supporting exports. Lower petroleum import volumes as new domestic refinery capacity comes on stream will constrain growth in the import bill (which is otherwise driven by real naira appreciation). Remittances from the large Nigerian diaspora should also recover to pre-pandemic levels. This will all contribute to an annual average current-account surplus of 1.7% of GDP in 2022-24. The surplus will then narrow to 1.2% of GDP in 2025 as falling oil prices push down export earnings. The deficit in 2021 will be financed largely by debt, with investment inflows limited by a dysfunctional foreign-exchange market.

Data sources and definitions The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; the source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: IEA average import price
Non-oil commodity prices: IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IFS
EUR 3-month interbank rate: IFS
Domestic data Population: UN
Trade by country: IMF, Direction of Trade Statistics
Balance of payments: IFS and CBN, Annual Report and Statement of Accounts
Inflation: IFS, CBN and Federal Office of Statistics
Exchange rate: IFS; principal rate expressed as naira:US dollar
Interest rate: IFS; year-end lending rate
GDP growth and expenditure breakdown: World Bank, World Tables; 1987 prices
US$ GDP: IFS; in current prices converted from local currency at annual average market exchange rate
GDP per head: US dollar GDP divided by population
Oil production: IEA; m barrels/day
Oil price: The Economist Intelligence Unit; dated Brent Blend
FDI: IFS, UNCTAD, World Investment Report and CBN
Total external debt: sum of long- and short-term debt and IMF credits
Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end medium- and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding, with an original maturity of more than one year
Short-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end debt outstanding, with an original maturity of less than one year
IMF credits: IFS and country page on website
Total debt service: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges on total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations CBN: Central Bank of Nigeria
IEA: International Energy Agency
IFS: International Financial Statistics
IMF: International Monetary Fund
NPC: National Population Commission
OECD: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
UNCTAD: UN Conference on Trade and Development

Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+South+Africa&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+South+Africa+April+2021+Updater&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2021-04-13&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+South+Africa&amp;rft.issn=09668683&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: - The president, Cyril Ramaphosa, is facing a challenging period for the remainder of his term, which ends in 2024. This includes a possible challenge for the leadership of the ruling African National Congress (ANC) in December 2022 in the absence of an economic rebound.
- As South Africa emerges from the global coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic, the economic damage, alongside the need for urgent action, will help to build support within the ANC for the president's reformist agenda, albeit reluctantly in some cases. The fightback against corruption is also gaining momentum, and The Economist Intelligence Unit expects significant developments in 2021.
- A post-pandemic recovery plan will focus on a vaccination rollout, infrastructure investment (led by the private sector), a mass public works programme to create jobs and combating electricity shortages. Fiscal constraints point to an increased reliance on public-private partnerships to drive forward key projects.
- We expect a modest recovery to growth of 2% in 2021. Power supply constraints, still-weak tourism and jobs lost to the pandemic will preclude a more rapid rebound, despite low interest rates. We envisage growth quickening to an average of 2.7% a year in 2022-25, underpinned by structural reforms, but unemployment will continue to weigh on aggregate demand.
- The budget deficit soared to 14% of GDP in fiscal year 2020/21 (April-March), but will trend lower, helped by wage restraint and revenue gains from higher commodity prices. Cumulative interest-rate cuts in 2020 reduced the benchmark rate to 3.5%, providing relief to borrowers, but another reduction is unlikely. We expect interest rates to remain on hold until a small rise in late 2021 or early 2022.
- After easing to a multi-year low of 3.2% in 2020, average inflation will rise to 3.7% in 2021, owing to costlier oil and electricity, but weak demand will keep price growth subdued. Inflation will quicken to 4.6% a year on average in 2022-25 as economic growth stages a gradual post-pandemic recovery.
- South Africa recorded a rare current-account surplus in 2020, of 2.2% of GDP, as exports fell more slowly than imports, pushing up the merchandise trade surplus. We expect the return of a current-account deficit in 2021-25 as imports recover and the deficit on invisible trade (services, income and current transfers) widens.

- South Africa's business environment score improves for 2021-25, although its global ranking drops by one place and its regional ranking is unchanged. Market opportunity and infrastructure gains will be partly offset by deteriorations in macroeconomic stability and taxation.

Country forecast overview: South Africa's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2021-22: A post-pandemic investment drive, focused on infrastructure, facilitates public-private partnerships. Challenges include tighter competition laws and stricter black economic empowerment (BEE) rules.
2023-25: Expropriation without compensation, to speed up land reform, applies in limited circumstances only, reducing the threat to property rights. Investment incentives in selected industries (such as automotive manufacturing) remain in place.
Policy towards foreign investment 2021-22: A reworked mining charter offers some concessions to business. A new foreign investment law limits access to international arbitration by giving local courts the primary responsibility for handling disputes.
2023-25: The government continues to encourage foreign investment and public-private partnerships, but resists the full privatisation of state assets in most cases.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2021-22: The government implements a further relaxation of capital controls on outward investment and other flows.
2023-25: Progress towards regional economic integration in Southern Africa makes some advances, but barriers persist.
Taxes 2021-22: Despite tough fiscal conditions, the government avoids major tax increases to shield households and firms.
2023-25: Efforts to streamline and modernise the tax system and expand the tax base continue.
Financing 2021-22: Cuts in the benchmark interest rate and other liquidity-boosting measures help to support banks and firms during the pandemic. Local banks remain sound and a major source of corporate financing, despite profits being squeezed.
2023-25: The continued independence of the South African Reserve Bank (the central bank) helps to preserve financial system stability. Monetary policy remains prudent and interest rates edge higher. The proposed nationalisation of the central bank is symbolic.
The labour market 2021-22: Pandemic-induced job losses oblige trade unions to accept a mild relaxation of currently inflexible labour laws.
2023-25: The labour market remains tough, owing to skills shortages and BEE targets.
Infrastructure 2021-22: Investment in transport and electricity, led in many cases by private firms, boosts capacity.
2023-25: Private-sector-led investment in renewable energy gathers momentum under the government's long-term energy plan, adding diversity to power supplies and cutting reliance on coal. Rising power tariffs drive energy efficiency.
Technological readiness 2021-22: The rollout of domestic fibre-optic cables boosts capacity and cuts costs. Investment in digital technology gathers momentum, including in cloud computing and high-end data analysis. The allocation of new spectrum boosts capacity
2023-25: Work advances on the Square Kilometre Array-a powerful radio telescope with multinational support-giving a wider boost to science and to information and communications technology.

Background: South Africa became a full democracy in 1994, when it first held all-race elections. The African National Congress (ANC) won, and has dominated all subsequent elections-in 1999, 2004, 2009, 2014 and 2019. However, support ebbed steadily from a peak of nearly 70% in 2004, to 62.1% in 2014 and 57.5% in May 2019. The ANC feared a worse result in May 2019, but the installation of Cyril Ramaphosa as president in February 2018, replacing the scandal-tainted Jacob Zuma, provided a mild bounce. Mr Ramaphosa will now serve a full five-year term and will be eligible for a second term.
Political structure: South Africa is a constitutional democracy with a bicameral parliament and a president elected by parliament. The constitution is the supreme law. The National Assembly is elected by proportional representation; the National Council of the Provinces consists of indirectly elected representatives of the nine provinces. The judiciary is independent and includes an 11-member Constitutional Court. The constitution provides for an independent corruption watchdog-the Public Protector-and commissions on human rights, gender equality and restitution of land rights.
Policy issues: The main policy focus in 2021-25 will be to facilitate recovery from a severe recession in 2020, caused by the damaging impact of the coronavirus pandemic. The need to boost post-pandemic growth will allow Mr Ramaphosa to push ahead more forcefully with his reformist agenda. A new economic recovery and reconstruction plan, released in October after consultation with business and labour unions, will focus on investment in critical infrastructure (such as housing and transport), led by the private sector, alongside a large-scale public works programme to create jobs. Tackling power shortages by commissioning new capacity from independent power producers, and by restructuring Eskom, the highly-indebted electricity parastatal, is another key objective. Fiscal constraints point to an increased reliance on public-private partnerships, despite resistance from vested interests. A new draft expropriation bill in October sets clear limits on when compensation is not payable, thus diminishing the threat to property rights and investor confidence. Challenges include skills shortages, stricter competition laws and the perennial risk of strikes.
Taxation: Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at a flat rate of 15%-after a rise from 14% on April 1st 2018-although some essentials are zero-rated. Corporation tax (of 28%), income tax and VAT were left unchanged in the 2020/21 budget. Some tax concessions are available, including in special economic zones.
Foreign trade: South Africa has a relatively open economy, with foreign trade (imports plus exports) accounting for about 52% of GDP. China, the EU, the US and Japan are among its largest trading partners. Trade with the rest of Africa has become progressively more important, and it is the only region with which South Africa has a trade surplus.

Outlook for 2021-25: Political stability Recovery from the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic will confront South Africa with unparalleled challenges, but the growing authority of the president, Cyril Ramaphosa, has positive implications for political stability and economic reform. Politics in 2021 will be influenced by the ongoing pandemic. Recent developments are encouraging: new cases and deaths fell to 5,518 and 280, respectively, in the week-ending April 9th-the lowest for almost a year. After a slow start, current plans are for vaccination rollout to gain momentum in May and June, before a more widespread inoculation programme in July-December. Given a range of global bottlenecks in the vaccine production supply chain that have left several countries short of contracted volumes, the slow initial pace of vaccination raises the risk of a third wave during the southern hemisphere winter (June-August), which could stifle the economic recovery and increase social unrest.
Since being elected for a five-year term in May 2019 Mr Ramaphosa has struggled to unite the disparate factions of the ruling party, the African National Congress (ANC), behind a reformist agenda, but a severe recession in 2020, accompanied by heavy job losses and rising poverty, is changing the political dynamic. After several years of policy fudges to appease powerful interest groups (such as labour unions), the urgent need for action to repair the economy-and working more closely with the private sector-is boosting the president's influence and sidelining his critics.
The two main sources of resistance to Mr Ramaphosa within the ANC will be left-wing interventionists, including labour unions-which will remain wedded to a strong state role in the economy-and the so-called radical transformation movement that emerged during the presidency of Jacob Zuma (2009-18), which is blamed for facilitating corruption and patronage under the guise of black economic empowerment. The left, although still clamouring for wage rises, is now resigned to a more prominent role for the private sector and the restructuring of dysfunctional parastatal firms, in view of the state's financial and technical capacity constraints. Heavy job losses will inevitably weaken trade unions' influence in both the private and the public sectors, obliging them to compromise in many cases. The president's economic recovery package, devised with business and labour input, combines an infrastructure investment plan-to be led by the private sector-with a major job-creating public works programme to provide temporary relief to the unemployed.
Resistance from the radical transformation faction will fade, given an escalating crackdown on corruption and the rising prospect of Mr Zuma being convicted on graft charges dating from before his presidency: a full trial will start in May. Mr Zuma could also be jailed for defying a Constitutional Court order to appear before a judge-led corruption inquiry in February. A pending corruption trial facing the ANC's secretary-general, Ace Magashule-one of Mr Zuma's allies-now scheduled for August, will further weaken the radical transformation faction, especially if Mr Magashule is suspended from his post in line with party policy. A conviction in 2021 for Mr Zuma, who presided over institutional weakening during his tenure, would symbolise a fightback against impunity.
Outlook for 2021-25: Election watch The next major political event is the ANC's five-yearly National General Council (NGC)-a policy implementation review-which will give a clearer indication of the balance of forces in the party and the extent of Mr Ramaphosa's control. After being delayed by more than a year by the pandemic, the NGC's timing is still uncertain, although we expect it to take place in advance of the next municipal elections, which are scheduled to be held during an August-October 2021 window. The nationwide ballot will give voters the first chance to judge the government's pandemic response and will be a test of Mr Ramaphosa's and the ANC's popularity. A vote share for the ANC in 2021 of less than the 57.5% won in 2019 would be a setback for Mr Ramaphosa, heralding a potential challenge by radical forces for the ANC leadership in December 2022; a share above 57.5% would help to cement the president's position. We expect the ANC, under Mr Ramaphosa, to retain power at the next general election (in 2024), but with reduced electoral support. The phased implementation of a new Political Party Funding Act from April 2021 will strengthen transparency.
Outlook for 2021-25: International relations South Africa-the most advanced economy in Africa and a major business hub-will remain deeply engaged in the continent, particularly in Southern and East Africa. Despite a challenging environment, South Africa will continue to attract international companies, including from the US, Europe and Asia, owing to strong institutions, sound banks and its role as continental gateway. South Africa's commercial involvement in other African markets will remain broad-based, covering mining, banking, telecommunications, retail and hospitality. The pandemic is causing temporary disruption to regional relations because of border closures and flight bans, aggravated by a second wave of infections, but regional access for South Africa-based firms will improve in 2021, helped by vaccine rollouts.
Outlook for 2021-25: Policy trends The most immediate policy challenges facing the government are to revive the economy caused by the pandemic's impact on activity and health. Containment measures have been alternatively tightened and loosened since the pandemic erupted-with the last move, to level one, the most relaxed, taking place on March 1st-but the cost of the pandemic in terms of lost jobs and income remains heavy. A second wave of infections, driven by a new, more transmissible variant of the virus, led to more cases and deaths in December/January than during the first peak in July/August 2020, but the figures have continued trending lower in recent weeks. A vaccine rollout will gather pace during the second quarter of 2021, but widespread immunisation is unlikely in South Africa until July-December, given supply shortages and logistical challenges, which increases the risk of a third wave of Covid-19.
The government will attempt to engineer a rebound in growth in 2021-25, via targeted measures and deeper structural reforms, although the scope for additional monetary and fiscal intervention is limited. With the benchmark interest rate at a record low of 3.5%, there is little room for further cuts, and several years of heavy spending and rising budget deficits preclude a broad-based fiscal stimulus. Even before the pandemic South Africa was trapped in a low-growth trajectory, not for the want of pro-growth plans, but because of policy fudges between left-wing and pro-business factions and weak implementation. The pandemic, by exposing underlying weaknesses (such as widespread poverty and inequality) and by highlighting the need for urgent action, should be a catalyst for deeper and more rapid structural reforms, including a greater role for the private sector.
Devised in consultation with business and organised labour, an economic recovery and reconstruction plan will focus on job creation-via large-scale public works programmes-and infrastructure investment. The plan aims to channel R100bn (US$6.8bn) over ten years into an infrastructure fund with the aim of attracting a ten times greater sum from the private sector via public-private partnerships. Projects already identified include housing and network infrastructure. Restoring energy security by adding new capacity (mostly solar and wind) from independent power producers is a key target, as is the planned auction of new broadband spectrum in 2021, which will boost communication and digitisation. Restructuring dysfunctional parastatal firms is another central priority. Implementation remains a challenge, but the political will to act is now stronger. Commitments to the IMF in return for a rapid financing instrument (RFI) in July 2020 will add impetus to reforms in the face of resistance from vested interests. We expect economic policy to support medium-term growth momentum and help the country to emerge from secular stagnation.
Outlook for 2021-25: Fiscal policy Further pandemic-related fiscal support in 2021 will be needed, but fiscal consolidation will eventually need to take priority in the medium term. We expect the fiscal deficit for 2020/21 (April-March) to hit a record 14% of GDP, although this is lower than the 15.7% of GDP shortfall predicted in last October's medium-term budget policy statement, helped by a revenue boost from a recent commodity price upswing. The planned tax hikes in 2021/22 are now on hold and a vaccine rollout costing an initial R9bn (US$620m) over two years is fully funded. The combination of stronger revenue-aided by an overhaul of the South African Revenue Service-alongside spending curbs, especially on public-sector wages, will see the deficit shrink during the forecast period. We expect the shortfall as a percentage of GDP to ebb to 9.2% in 2021/22 and 7.4% in 2022/23, before easing to 3.4% in 2025/26. The biggest risk to fiscal consolidation is a fightback by labour unions against wage restraint via a combination of legal action, political pressure and possible strikes.
After surging to 80% in 2020/21, owing to pandemic-related support measures, currency depreciation and recession, the public debt/GDP ratio will rise more slowly, as fiscal revenue recovers, peaking at 88.9% of GDP in 2025/26. Speedier fiscal consolidation reduces South Africa's risk of debt distress, as does its heavy reliance on deep and liquid domestic capital markets to finance most of the budget shortfalls, but debt-servicing costs will continue rising, and there is limited scope for slippage on both the spending and the revenue fronts. A failure to meet debt targets could oblige South Africa to undertake a formal IMF programme with strict conditions attached.
Outlook for 2021-25: Monetary policy Policy accommodation during the 2020 pandemic crisis will give way to a normalisation process later in 2021, with interest rates edging higher as the economy begins to recover. The South African Reserve Bank (SARB, the central bank) cut the benchmark interest rate (repo rate) five times in 2020-most recently in July-by a cumulative 300 basis points to 3.5%, to help to shield the economy from the pandemic. However, the rate has since remained on hold, reflecting limited scope for additional loosening. We expect the SARB to maintain its current stance throughout most of 2021, but the expected resumption of real GDP growth and a mild inflation upswing point to a small rate rise in either late 2021 or early 2022. Additional small increases will follow in 2023-25, broadly tracking US trends.
Outlook for 2021-25: Economic growth Following a contraction of 7% in 2020, we expect real GDP to grow by 2% in 2021. The near-term recovery will depend on three main factors: control of the pandemic; the extent of fiscal and monetary policy support; and the pace of the national vaccine rollout, which so far has been slow to take off. A vaccination programme will support economic activity and confidence in the second quarter, but the rollout will be slow initially, before gathering pace in July-December, which leaves the possible risk of a third wave of infection during the southern hemisphere winter (June-August). The phased reopening of borders will provide some impetus, but pandemic risks will keep international tourism and the hospitality sector in the doldrums. Other factors curbing annual growth are a probable year-on-year contraction in real GDP in January-March, because of the pre-pandemic baseline, and elevated strike risks because of a public-sector pay freeze.
Prospects for 2022 are slightly brighter; we expect growth to quicken to 2.2%, helped by a relaxation of power-supply constraints and by stronger private investment in response to favourable policy initiatives, such as moves to facilitate public-private partnerships. We expect more frequent and heavier load-shedding (power rationing) to persist ahead of the planned commissioning of new generating capacity in mid-2022. Factors weighing on domestic growth will include a slowdown in global growth (after an initial rebound in 2021), alongside still-fragile tourism and elevated unemployment, which will sap aggregate demand. We expect growth to strengthen to 2.9% a year on average in 2023-25, underpinned by long-delayed reforms (such as parastatal restructuring) and the spread of digital technology, but the global backdrop will remain subdued in terms of economic growth and trade flows.
Outlook for 2021-25: Inflation After dipping to a multi-year low of 3.2% in 2020, owing to recession, cheaper imported oil and a bumper food harvest, inflation will edge up to 3.7% in 2021, but will remain comfortably within the SARB's 3-6% target range. The primary sources of inflation in 2021 will be higher oil prices and costlier electricity tariffs, although the prospect of a second consecutive bumper harvest in the 2020/21 season will offset higher global food prices. Other factors curbing inflation are mild rand appreciation in 2021, weak aggregate demand (owing to unemployment and income losses), spare industrial capacity and strong retail competition. We expect inflation to quicken to an average of 4.6% a year in 2022-25, spurred by a modest revival in GDP growth, but the level will stay within the SARB's target range, temporary breaches aside.
Outlook for 2021-25: Exchange rates Stronger commodity prices and global liquidity injections will support the rand in 2021, as shown by a 10% year-on-year appreciation of the local unit to R14.99:US$1 in March. Being commodity-dependent, widely traded and an emerging-market proxy, the rand will benefit from a positive global backdrop, but remains vulnerable to any adverse shifts in global sentiment and to negative domestic developments. We see the rand weakening from current levels, in view of South Africa's large fiscal deficit and sluggish growth outlook-alongside potential global tensions-to end 2021 at R16.61:US$1. On an annual average basis, we predict strengthening to R15.77:US$1 in 2021 (revised from R16.53:US$1) as markets normalise after disruption in 2020. The rand will remain volatile, often experiencing large daily movements in response to shifting sentiment, although South Africa's modest external debt stock and healthy foreign-exchange reserves are protective. Our forecast assumes gradual depreciation from 2022 onwards, with the rand weakening to R18.62:US$1 in 2025, although the pace of decline will be close to the inflation rate, implying a relatively stable REER.
Outlook for 2021-25: External sector Following a tumultuous 2020, we still consider that the main risks to the economy in 2021 are domestic, rather than external. Notwithstanding lingering uncertainty surrounding global trade, stemming from countries' ability to emerge from coronavirus-related containment measures, trade prospects will be particularly favourable. On balance, however, we expect the trade surplus (which reached record highs in 2020) to shrink in 2021-25. The gradual recovery in total consumption and investment, combined with stronger oil prices, will increase imports, causing the current account to shift back into deficit in 2021, following a temporary shift into surplus in 2020 amid the pandemic. Although robust demand and prices for gold and platinum-group metals and China's return to near-normality will support exports, a continued narrowing of the trade surplus (together with a widening primary income deficit as a result of rising external debt-service obligations and a pick-up in profit repatriation abroad) will sustain a current-account deficit over the forecast period.
Foreign direct investment (FDI) and portfolio inflows will be slow to recover in 2021, but will pick up in 2022-25. The recovery will be supported by renewed investment in infrastructure and privatisation of state assets. We expect net inflows of US$5.2bn a year on average (just under 10% of gross financing needs). South Africa will remain a key base for multinational companies with pan-African operations by offering a range of services, including banking, capital-raising and trade-related functions

Data sources and definitions The sources for global and domestic data refer to historic data; the source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data US & OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US & OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: Dated Brent Blend
Non-oil commodity prices: IMF, IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Dollar effective exchange rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data Trade by country: IMF, Direction of Trade Statistics
Population: Based on UN data for both the historical and the forecast periods
Balance of payments: IMF, IFS
Inflation: Statistics South Africa. Based on CPIX (consumer price inflation less mortgage costs)
Exchange rate: IMF, IFS; principal rate expressed as R:US$
Real effective exchange rate index: based on consumer price index; trade partner weighted index with base period 2000=100
Interest rate: IMF, IFS; average lending rate
US$ GDP: SARB, Quarterly Bulletin; in current prices converted from local currency at annual average market exchange rate
GDP per head: US$ GDP divided by population
Foreign direct investment: IMF, IFS; UNCTAD, World Investment Report
Total external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; sum of long-term debt, short-term debt and IMF credits
Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics, year-end medium- and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding, with an original maturity in excess of one year
Short-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end debt outstanding, with an original maturity of less than one year
Total debt service: principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges paid against total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Interest payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations IFS: International Financial Statistics
IMF: International Monetary Fund
OECD: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
SARB: South African Reserve Bank
UNCTAD: UN Conference on Trade and Development

Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+Brazil&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+Brazil+April+2021&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2021-04-05&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+Brazil&amp;rft.issn=09669361&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: - The populist, right-wing government of the president, Jair Bolsonaro, lacks a majority in Brazil's highly fragmented Congress but has reached out to centrist parties to bolster governability amid impeachment risks. Tensions with the judiciary will persist while the authorities investigate the affairs of the president and his sons. There are internal tensions in the government resulting from a power struggle between various wings: an ideological wing; retired military officials in the cabinet (including the vice-president); and the free-market economy minister and members of centrist parties (which have three cabinet posts). The Economist Intelligence Unit expects that negotiations with Congress will be challenging-especially with the president's popularity under increasing pressure-but that they will advance where there is common ground with centrist parties.

Brazil--highlights: Business environment outlook                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
5.73 6.26 52 51 6 5
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.

- Brazil remains in the lower half of the global ranking in the 2021-25 forecast period, but improvements have lifted its regional and global positions by one place. Economic crisis management pushed back reforms in 2020, and there is now only a narrow window before Brazil gears up for the 2022 general election. Several areas of the business environment-including foreign trade and exchange controls, and policy towards foreign investment and towards private enterprise-will improve, but only moderately. There will be improvements in the labour market and infrastructure, but these will remain weak areas of the investment climate. Assuming broad continuity under the next administration (from January 2023), there will be further piecemeal advances, but a shift to more statist policies is a risk.

Brazil--highlights: Economic outlook   2020 2021 2022 2023 2024 2025
Real GDP growth (%) -4.1 3.2 2.3 1.9 2.0 2.0
Consumer price inflation (av, %) 3.2 6.7 4.0 3.6 3.5 3.5
Budget balance (% of GDP) -13.8 -7.6 -6.1 -6.5 -6.8 -6.6
Current-account balance (% of GDP) -0.9 -1.0 -2.2 -2.8 -3.1 -3.5
3-month Treasury rate (av; %) 2.8 4.0 5.8 5.8 5.5 5.5
Exchange rate R:US$ (av) 5.2 5.4 5.1 5.1 5.0 5.0

- After a 4.1% GDP contraction in 2020 and an expected renewed technical recession in first-half 2021 amid a resurgence in coronavirus (Covid-19) infections and mobility restrictions, GDP will recover with the rollout of vaccines. Our 2021 growth forecast of 3.2% reflects carryover effects from 2020, rather than sequential growth. GDP growth will average 2% in 2022-25. Fiscal, monetary and credit stimulus was hefty in 2020, leaving considerable consolidation challenges in the recovery period. The fiscal deficit reached almost 14% of GDP in 2020, lifting the public debt/GDP ratio to 90%. Assuming recovery and consolidation thereafter, we expect the public debt ratio to stabilise; otherwise, domestic debt sustainability issues will come to the fore, lifting interest rates and inflation.

Brazil--highlights: Demographic outlook Population (m) 2015 2020 2025

Labour force growth   0.8 0.4

- The population growth rate will fall to 0.7% in 2021-25. However, this is still above the world average and well above western European rates. The population will remain younger than in most industrialised countries, and the rise in the number of people of working age will outpace population growth as a whole. However, Brazil's demographic dynamics will deteriorate, which will heighten pressure on the pension system, despite the 2019 pension reform.

Brazil--highlights: Market opportunities   2020 2021 2022 2023 2024 2025
GDP (US$ bn at market exchange rates) 1,445 1,517 1,662 1,764 1,868 1,972
GDP per head (US$ at market exchange rates) 6,822 7,110 7,736 8,155 8,582 9,004

Household consumption per head (US$) 4,280 4,420 4,850 5,150 5,450 5,750

- Brazil is Latin America's largest market and has the fifth-largest population in the world. Although it has dropped out of the top ten largest economies, partly owing to a weaker currency, it will continue to offer big investment opportunities. Brazil faces a tepid recovery from the 2020 recession; growth prospects are modest amid rising fiscal constraints, and it will be difficult to replicate the gains achieved in the decade preceding the 2014-16 recession in terms of reducing income inequality (which reflected job creation in low-skilled sectors, minimum wage rises and a consumer credit boom). Deepening capital markets will boost credit availability for businesses during the recovery phase.

Brazil--highlights: Long-term outlook   2021-30 2031-50 2021-50
Growth and productivity (% change; annual av)
Growth of real GDP per head 1.4 1.7 1.6
Growth of real GDP 2.0 1.9 1.9
Labour productivity growth 0.9 2.0 1.6
From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.

- Our long-term growth forecast anticipates annual average GDP growth of 1.7% in 2021-50. Improvements in infrastructure and education, trade expansion, a broader presence of multinational business, and the development of huge oil reserves will mitigate slower labour force growth and will help to sustain labour productivity growth. If improvements in policymaking and the business environment were to exceed expectations, growth rates would be higher. For many years, performance will continue to fluctuate with commodity cycles, as agriculture and natural resource extraction will continue to play important roles in the economy. Climate change will crimp agricultural growth despite technological advances to make crops resistant to warmer temperatures.

Background: A new constitution was ratified in 1988 after more than 20 years of military rule. The government of Fernando Henrique Cardoso (1995-2002) ended hyperinflation and advanced reforms to liberalise the economy. Under a former president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva (2003-10), Brazil reaped the benefits of the reforms and enjoyed a consumer-led, commodities-fuelled boom. When this cycle ended, discontent with a weak economy, corruption and poor public services led to street protests. Lula's successor as president, Dilma Rousseff (2011-16), nonetheless won a second four-year term in 2014, but was impeached in 2016 over budget irregularities. Her vice-president, Michel Temer (2016-18), finished her term. Jair Bolsonaro won the October 2018 election and took office as president in January 2019.
Political structure: The president executes policy approved by the 513-seat Chamber of Deputies (the lower house) and the 81-seat Senate (the upper house). Constitutional review is conducted by an independent judiciary. Although the president can resort to temporary decrees to push through legislation, the constitution gives Congress ample scope to check the executive. In the lower house, nearly 30 political parties are represented, and party discipline has traditionally been weak.
Policy issues: The benefits and entitlements established under the 1988 constitution have contributed to a doubling in central government primary spending, to over 28% of GDP. Congress approved a federal spending cap in 2016, a robust pension reform in October 2019 and central bank independence in March 2021. The coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic led to expansionary fiscal, monetary and credit policies to offset the hit to the economy and financial system, lifting the public debt/GDP ratio to 90% in 2020. After cutting the Selic policy rate to 2% in August 2020, the Banco Central do Brasil (the central bank) began a partial front-loaded normalisation in March, lifting the rate by 75 basis points.
Taxation: Brazil has a poorly structured revenue system characterised by a heavy tax burden, a narrow tax base, complicated levies and widespread evasion. Both foreign and domestic companies employ tax professionals and devote considerable resources to managing their tax affairs. The corporate and indirect tax systems are particularly complex, porous and unwieldy; the income tax system is considered to be relatively efficient, with a top rate of 27.5%.
Foreign trade: The pandemic-induced recession and a weaker Real narrowed the current-account deficit to an 0.9% of GDP in 2020. Agricultural exports support a moderate structural trade surplus.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance Brazil is a federal republic composed of 26 states and the capital district of Brasília, each with its own legislature and administration. Jair Bolsonaro, a far-right populist, took office as president in January 2019 for a four-year term after winning the October 2018 election. In November 2019 he left the right-wing Partido Social Liberal (PSL) and has not yet joined another party, although he may well do so before the next election, in 2022. For his first 18 months in office, Mr Bolsonaro governed without a multiparty coalition in Brazil's highly fragmented Congress-there are nearly 30 parties in the Chamber of Deputies (the lower house). As his position weakened and impeachment risks came to the fore in mid-2020, Mr Bolsonaro allied with a bloc of centrist parties (the centrão), which controls about 40% of the seats in the lower house, offering them government jobs overseeing large budgets and three cabinet posts (out of 22).
Next elections: Presidential, congressional and state elections (which are held every four years) are due in October 2022. Municipal elections took place in October 2020, and will next take place in 2024.

Political outlook: Political stability The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the political environment in the near term to be shaped by the dynamics of the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic and vaccine rollout. Attention will subsequently turn to the October 2022 election campaigns, when Mr Bolsonaro will bid for re-election. Over 6% of the population have received at least one vaccine dose (above the Latin American average), but the "second wave" of the pandemic is worse than the first, with daily deaths exceeding 3,000 in late March and many hospitals lacking ICU capacity. A recent poll by Datafolha, a research institute, shows that 61% of voters disapprove of Mr Bolsonaro's handling of the pandemic-he has long been a virus denialist, flouted social distancing norms, criticised local governments for imposing mobility restrictions and, crucially, waited too long to purchase vaccines from overseas. He is therefore now fighting a rearguard action, promising to vaccinate all Brazilians by year-end.
The centrão is growing concerned about the political fallout from the handling of the pandemic, given that it is now in government with Mr Bolsonaro. Before the second wave of the pandemic, Mr Bolsonaro's position had in fact strengthened, following the election in February 2021 of his allies in the centrão to key leadership posts in both the upper and lower houses of Congress. The leader of the lower house, Arthur Lira of the Progressistas party, shelved opposition calls to open an impeachment trial against the president. This was previously a risk, owing to the president's confrontational attitude towards Congress and the Supreme Court in early 2020. Even so, to ensure governability by retaining the centrão's support, Mr Bolsonaro will need to grant party members political favours, including government posts and budget allocations. Provided Mr Bolsonaro also takes steps to improve his poor handling of the pandemic and vaccination advances, he should retain sufficient support from the centrão to retain his position. The creation of a national co-ordinating crisis committee at the behest of Mr Lira between the executive, congress and other stakeholders in late March is a positive step, but there is a high risk that it could break down, given Mr Bolsonaro's defiance over mobility restrictions taken by local governments.
Return of Lula will put Mr Bolsonaro's re-election bid under pressure The president is also under pressure following the re-emergence of a former president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva (2003-10) of the Partido dos Trabalhadores (PT). A surprise Supreme Court ruling in March quashed Lula's 2017 corruption conviction, restoring his political rights. Although the anti-PT voter sentiment that swept Mr Bolsonaro to power in 2018 persists, Lula currently poses more of a challenge to Mr Bolsonaro's re-election ambitions than any other candidate, especially given a disunited centre. Although he will attempt to sway middle-ground voters (as well as legislators from the centrão, which formed part of his own government), Lula's return to politics reignites the left versus right-wing polarisation of recent years.
Mr Bolsonaro's proximity to the military (he is a retired army captain) has fuelled tensions, especially with the judiciary, as well as broader concerns over where his authoritarian streak could lead. We expect calm relations for now, but tensions could resurface, given the president's impetuousness and investigations into both him (relating to alleged political interference in the federal police in 2020) and his sons, Carlos (a local councillor, involved in "fake news" campaigns against political opponents) and Flávio (a senator, implicated in a local assembly graft scheme). Not only has the president put retired military officers in important cabinet positions (including Hamilton Mourão as vice-president), appointed them to run a third of Brazil's state-controlled companies and stacked lower-ranking officials in the state bureaucracy, but in early 2020 he actively supported bolsonaristas who attacked opponents in Congress (as well as in the judiciary and media) and called for military intervention. Tensions around election time are likely. However, a rupture of constitutional rule is unlikely, as voters would protest; polls suggest that 75% of Brazilians support democracy as the best form of government. In addition, most high-ranking, active military officials are reluctant to pander to Mr Bolsonaro's political ambitions and would not get involved if the president disputed the election results, for instance.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness Mr Bolsonaro faces governability problems similar to those that have plagued previous administrations. With nearly 30 parties represented, Congress is as unwieldy as ever; on top of this, Mr Bolsonaro faces challenges keeping together the disparate factions of his own political movement. This is composed of an ideological right-wing group revolving around the president and his three politically active sons; a military wing of mostly retired generals (including the vice-president, Mr Mourão, who plays a moderating role in national security and public affairs, although other members-such as Augusto Heleno, the intelligence chief-are more aligned with Mr Bolsonaro's confrontational rhetoric); and the team around the free-market economy minister, Paulo Guedes. In his first year, Mr Bolsonaro was reluctant to negotiate with the myriad parties in Congress as he continued his anti-establishment campaign rhetoric, criticising the "old-style politics" under which deals between Congress and the executive often involved patronage and "give and take" horse-trading, contributing to pervasive corruption. However, having been a legislator for nearly 30 years, the president knows how to appeal to lawmakers; he has a pragmatic side that has allowed him to curry favour at important times. For example, he was able to get a landmark pension reform passed in 2019, partly by offering legislators special budget allocations for pet projects in their constituencies-just the sort of pork-barrel politics that he used to criticise regularly. As his position weakened in 2020 and risks of a potential impeachment trial emerged, the president shifted to a more "politics as usual" approach, awarding roles in the cabinet and state agencies to members of centrist parties, allowing them to oversee huge budgets in return for support. Allied centrão figures won the leadership posts in the upper and lower houses of Congress in 2020, cementing Mr Bolsonaro's position with the bloc. The centrão now exerts more influence than before and has three cabinet members.
The coronavirus pandemic has brought to the fore strains between the branches of government at the federal, state and local levels. This is partly because of Mr Bolsonaro's negationist views about the severity of the virus and opposition to local governments' mobility restrictions. The country's large informal sector has complicated stay-at-home policies. To its advantage, Brazil's public hospital system is good by developing-country standards, and it has the resources and systems to make cash transfers to poor people. The government waited too long to purchase vaccines from global pharmaceutical companies when it had the opportunity to do so; combined with production bottlenecks, this is causing the vaccination programme to be slower than it could have been.
Political and institutional weakness persist Other than the handling of the Covid-19 pandemic and vaccine rollout, politics continues to be shaped by developments going back to 2014 that highlighted political and institutional weaknesses. These include: a deep and wide-ranging corruption scandal centred on kickbacks at Petrobras (the state-controlled oil company) that emerged in the Lava Jato (Car Wash) investigations; the impeachment of a former president, Dilma Rousseff of the Partido dos Trabalhadores (PT); subsequent corruption investigations into Ms Rousseff's successor, Michel Temer (Movimento Democrático Brasileiro); and the corruption conviction of Lula. These developments eroded confidence in Brazil's political system and helped to catapult Mr Bolsonaro to the presidency in October 2018 on an anti-establishment, anti-corruption populist discourse. Many of these issues remain unresolved, and in the absence of political reform (to drastically reduce the number of parties represented in Congress), there is little prospect of a meaningful renewal. The decisive action taken during the Car Wash investigations and the independence of the judiciary appeared to be a sign that Brazil was beginning to tackle endemic corruption. However, confidence in legal stability and due process suffered a blow when the Supreme Court found that Sérgio Moro, the judge overseeing the most high-profile cases in the Car Wash investigations (which officially ended in early 2021), had not acted impartially and had liaised too closely with federal prosecutors to secure Lula's conviction. Although Lula could face a retrial (which in practice would take years), he has regained his political rights and is set to run for president in October 2022. Despite these setbacks to the Car Wash investigations in particular, prosecutors and the police will remain active more broadly in their efforts to combat corruption. Most large companies have strengthened their corporate governance mechanisms since the beginning of the Car Wash investigations, which is positive.
A major problem related to government effectiveness and corruption is the deep fragmentation of Congress, which encourages pork-barrel politics. Since democracy was restored to Brazil in 1985, governments have struggled to hold together multiparty coalitions. Low voter-registration thresholds have contributed to the large number of parties, and their leaders behave opportunistically. This dysfunctional system has become known as "presidential coalition" politics. Since 1985 two of the five directly elected presidents have been impeached by Congress-undermining the presidency and reflecting the powers of the legislature. To hold together a working majority, past governments have resorted to a range of legal (but politically dubious) pork-barrel behaviours such as offering ministerial positions, awarding spending programmes and constantly adjusting and diluting their legislative programmes to meet the demands of smaller parties and regional special-interest groups.
Tensions simmer as Mr Bolsonaro clashes with other branches Mr Bolsonaro's nationalist populism, his nostalgia for Brazil's military dictatorship (1964-85) and his awarding of cabinet positions to several retired military officials sustain concerns about whether he could potentially trample on the country's fairly young democratic institutions. As his position weakened in 2020 amid police investigations into his family's affairs, Mr Bolsonaro dialled up his authoritarian rhetoric and often appeared with his radical supporters, protesting against Congress and the Supreme Court and calling for military intervention. A rupture of constitutional rule (in the form of the president disobeying Supreme Court rulings) appears unlikely, although it seems that institutions will remain under attack from Mr Bolsonaro as he seeks to exert his influence over them (for example over police and Supreme Court investigations into his sons' business and political activities). A recent survey by Datafolha, a local pollster, showed that 75% of voters support democracy as the best form of government-even though they are disillusioned by the record of parties in power and corruption-and would not acquiesce in the event of an unexpected shift to military rule, reducing the probability of such a scenario. Nor do the active generals running the armed forces show signs of wanting to overthrow the constitution and govern in order to defend the Bolsonaro government.
Even so, tensions between the three branches of government have come to the fore under Mr Bolsonaro. Although the president's removal from office remains improbable, his efforts to discredit the Supreme Court-alongside a longer-term strategy to exert control over its judges (he appointed one in early 2021 and will appoint a second in July, when another judge retires)-could result in sustained tensions between the executive and the judiciary, as well as gradual institutional erosion.
Political outlook: Election watch Assuming that the Supreme Court plenary confirms the recent ruling by a single justice, restoring his political rights, Lula is likely to be the PT candidate in the 2022 presidential election. As Lula will be a stronger rival than Fernando Haddad (who was previously lining up to be the PT candidate), it will be harder for Mr Bolsonaro to win a second term, although the benefits of incumbency still favour him slightly. The election campaign will be even more polarising than previously expected, making it hugely difficult for a centrist candidate to gain traction and make it to a probable second round (more than 50% of valid votes are required in the first round to avoid a run-off). It is still early, but we believe that the election will be a close contest. Both Mr Bolsonaro and Lula suffer from high rejection rates. Winning over middle-ground voters will be the key to success. Mr Bolsonaro is vulnerable, owing to his poor management of the pandemic and vaccine rollout, economic conditions, and any potential adverse news in the event of corruption scandals involving his sons or links to militias. Markets will fret about a Lula victory, even though he will pitch himself as a moderate and would need support from the centrão to build a working majority should he win power.
Political outlook: International relations The president's anti-globalist rhetoric and facilitation of illegal deforestation in the Amazon is tarnishing Brazil's international standing. However, as one of the world's ten largest economies and a major commodity exporter, Brazil will remain a significant global player. Under the administration of the new US president, Joe Biden, bilateral relations will be cooler while Mr Bolsonaro is president, given their divergent stances, particularly on climate change and deforestation. The relationship got off to a bumpy start, as Mr Bolsonaro was the last major world leader to congratulate Mr Biden, but we assume that a pragmatic approach will prevail, with common ground on anti-Chinese sentiment.
Brazil will remain one of the battlegrounds in US-China rivalry; a 5G licence auction scheduled for 2021 will prove tricky for the government, given the local presence of Huawei, a Chinese telecommunications company. Anti-Chinese rhetoric by nationalist government figures is stirring bilateral tensions, but more pragmatic cabinet members will encourage the president to be more welcoming of China's acquisition of assets, as Brazil needs investments in major infrastructure and energy projects. Moreover, Brazil's reliance on the Chinese coronavirus vaccine, Sinovac, will temper anti-Chinese rhetoric. We do not expect a free-trade agreement (FTA) between the EU and Mercosul (the Southern Cone customs union comprising Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay) to be ratified soon, owing to EU concerns over Mr Bolsonaro's environmental policies. Now that there is also pressure from Mr Biden on environmental issues, Brazil's efforts to join the OECD face delays.
