Brazil remains in the lower half of the business environment global ranking in the 2021-25 forecast period; its score improved, but only enough to lift its regional and global positions by one place. Crisis management in 2020 pushed back reforms, and there is now only a narrow legislative window before campaigning picks up ahead of the October 2022 general election. Still, there will be improvements in some categories of the business environment, such as foreign trade and exchange controls (as the economy becomes slightly more open), as well as policy towards foreign investment and policy towards private enterprise (owing to privatisation). There will be progress in the labour market (more flexibility) and infrastructure (through concessions and better rules), but these will remain weaknesses in the business environment. Notwithstanding the possible unification of some business taxes, The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect any significant improvement in the unwieldy and time-consuming tax system for businesses; Brazil's score in this area is unchanged, and it is the weakest aspect of the overall investment climate by some degree.
Brazil's large and diversified economy makes it attractive for investors, but its recovery from the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic will be tepid, dampening foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows. With the public debt/GDP ratio so high (at 90%), consolidation measures will be needed, crimping growth. The business environment will be shaped by the outcome of the general election, which is highly uncertain at this early stage. Our current view is that the race is Mr Bolsonaro's to lose; our forecasts are based on the assumption of broad continuity under the next administration, implying further piecemeal advances. However, even if a former president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva (2003-10), wins the election, a swing to the far left would be unlikely, as he would need the support of the political centre to govern. Given structural improvements (including an independent central bank and fiscal responsibility legislation), there is less scope for a dramatic shift in macroeconomic policy, but privatisations would be halted.

Business environment outlook: Brazil's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2021-22: Vested interests slow economy ministry's ambitious privatisations programme, but some divestments materialise.
2023-25: Privatisations continue slowly. Fiscal pressures encourage private capital in infrastructure projects. Investment Partnerships Programme (PPI) advances further, with improved legal framework and regulatory agencies.
Policy towards foreign investment 2021-22: Slow progress on new bilateral international investment treaties. New legislation to streamline bidding and procurement comes into effect, spurring investor interest in infrastructure concessions.
2023-25: Ideological issues within government put nationalist politics before economic pragmatism in some cases.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2021-22: Deal between EU and Mercosul (Southern Cone customs union comprising Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay) not expected to be ratified by EU parliaments.
2023-25: Steps taken to make Brazilian Real a fully convertible currency.
Taxes 2021-22: Tax system remains unwieldy and time-consuming. No significant measures to ease the corporate tax burden.
2023-25: Tax simplification unifies three federal, state and municipal taxes into one value-added tax (VAT).
Financing 2021-22: Financial system survives coronavirus (Covid-19) crisis, but emergency credit lines from 2020 are dialled down, dampening credit growth. Central bank gains independence; improved efficiency and competitiveness lowers borrowing costs.
2023-25: Renewed growth in domestic equity and bond issuance as state banks reduce subsidised credit lines.
The labour market 2021-22: Unemployment remains high despite efforts to boost job creation. Government implements measures to reduce cost of labour.
2023-25: Steps to boost long-term labour productivity complicated by continued weak education policies.
Infrastructure 2021-22: Infrastructure concessions advance but coronavirus and political and institutional constraints may cause delays. Corruption and recession weigh on established construction companies, opening industry up for newcomers.
2023-25: Industry newcomers' lack of experience causes project delays.
Technological readiness 2021-22: 5G frequencies to be auctioned in 2021. Quality of communications rises as demand expands.
2023-25: Building of 5G infrastructure network commences and is rolled out to consumers.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c

5.5 5.8 67 65 10 9
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Despite a clouded economic outlook, Brazil's regional and global ranking for the macroeconomic environment is slightly better for the 2021-25 forecast period than for the 2016-20 historical period. This partly reflects the fact that Brazil fares relatively well in comparative terms; many similarly ranked countries have been even more severely hit than Brazil by the economic effects of the coronavirus pandemic, and they have therefore lost ground in the rankings for the forecast period. Brazil will be among the fastest of the major Latin American economies to recover to pre-pandemic GDP levels, doing so in 2022. However, this largely reflects the large-scale fiscal stimulus that was deployed in 2020, which will damage other areas of Brazil's macroeconomic environment. For example, the country's scores in areas relating to the public finances deteriorate on the back of a huge increase in the fiscal deficit and the public debt stock (now at 90% of GDP). Although we expect the deficit to narrow in 2021-22, we anticipate that it will widen again in the second half of the forecast period, to more than 6% of GDP (in contrast with many other countries, where we expect a sustained period of fiscal consolidation) as debt-servicing costs rise in line with higher interest rates. This will keep public debt high.

- Notwithstanding the slight overall improvement, the macroeconomic environment remains one of the weakest areas of the country's business climate. Brazil scores reasonably for some areas, including inflation; despite risks associated with a resurgence in commodity prices, inflation will generally be better controlled than in the past. The Banco Central do Brasil (BCB, the central bank) gained formal independence in February 2021 and began a partial normalisation of the policy interest rate in March (ahead of many emerging markets), after cutting the Selic to a record low of 2% in August 2020 and following a reduction of distortions in credit markets. However, the bright spots are relatively few. There are concerns about the overall quality of policymaking as Mr Bolsonaro gears up for what is likely to be a closely fought re-election bid in October 2022. In turn, the Real will remain vulnerable to bouts of renewed volatility driven by political and fiscal risks. We expect the current-account deficit to widen later in the forecast period as imports rebound and Brazilian tourists venture overseas again. That said, FDI will pick up and match the current-account deficit, lifting the already large stock of international reserves.

Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
6.3 6.8 37 33 2 2
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
We expect some improvements to be made in policy towards private enterprise and competition in 2021-25, mainly reflecting a firmer government commitment to promoting competition. Although progress will be slow, it will nevertheless contribute to a moderate improvement in Brazil's underlying score in this area, as well as a rise of four places in the global ranking. Starting a business has become less cumbersome in recent years, but Brazil remains below average for this metric. Regulations are pervasive, and compliance imposes considerable costs for businesses. The competition regime is equipped with strong powers and enforcement tools. However, weaknesses in institutional capacity at the Conselho Administrativo de Defesa Econômica (CADE, the antitrust body) partly explain why there have been few investigations since the introduction of new competition legislation in 2011 and even fewer decisions by its tribunal. In 2020 it imposed R142m (US$25m) in fines, down sharply from nearly R793m (US$140m) in 2019. Mr Bolsonaro's government originally vowed to reduce political interference in state-controlled companies and appointed chief executive officers (CEOs) chosen by his free-market economy minister, Paulo Guedes. However, Mr Bolsonaro intervened in Petrobras (the state oil firm) in February 2021 by firing its CEO over fuel price policies, and the CEO of Banco do Brasil (a large state-owned retail bank) recently resigned after encountering resistance from the president over restructuring policies. The CEO of Eletrobras (the state-controlled electricity firm) also resigned amid resistance to privatisation efforts from vested interests in Congress.
Privatisation drive will yield limited results amid congressional pushback
- Many important sectors remain dominated by major state players, such as oil and gas (Petrobras), energy (Eletrobras), postal services and distribution (Correios), and-to a lesser degree-banking (Banco do Brasil, Caixa Econômica Federal (Caixa) and BNDES). Upon entering office in January 2019, Mr Guedes advocated a sweeping privatisation programme to reduce public debt and encourage private and foreign investment. The programme sought to divest up to 130 federal state companies by 2022. Although a Supreme Court ruling in June 2019 confirmed that the privatisation of subsidiary companies did not require legislative approval-in theory giving the government considerable leeway to proceed with its plans-progress has been slow. The government has tried to expedite processes, sending a bill to Congress in February 2021 designed to accelerate the sale of part of the government's holding in Eletrobras and pledging a similar bill for Correios. However, progress in 2021-22 will be slow. Legislators still tend to view state-owned companies as a way of exchanging political support for lucrative posts. Even though Mr Bolsonaro has begun to pivot from his initial promises to refrain from "give-and-take" politics (giving cabinet posts and jobs in state agencies to members of centrist parties), legislators may resist divestments in order to keep some power. This will make privatisation of Eletrobras especially challenging. There is a chance that the privatisation of Correios could move forward, but it will still face difficulties.
- Prospects for privatisation in 2023-25 will partly depend on the next government's position on the issue; there is likely to be some continued progress, assuming that Mr Bolsonaro remains in office, although "crown jewel" companies such as Banco do Brasil, Caixa and Petrobras are highly unlikely to be divested. Should Lula win the October 2022 election, privatisation prospects would be weaker. As president in 2003-10, Lula sent mixed signals about his willingness to further open the economy to private-sector participation, with privatisations mainly occurring only at the state level. It is highly likely that the privatisation agenda would be halted altogether if Lula were to take office, reflecting his preference for a strong state role in strategic sectors. However, public-private partnership (PPP) concessions, which were a feature in 2003-16 under governments led by the Partido dos Trabalhadores (PT), would continue.

Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
7.3 7.8 32 16 4 2
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
We expect policy towards foreign investment to be the strongest area of Brazil's business environment in 2021-25. Despite the coronavirus pandemic, Brazil is still one of the top ten recipients of FDI globally; inflows fell in 2020, but not as sharply as for some other large recipients of FDI. The government's pro-market orientation and the fiscal and governance crisis that have affected many local firms since 2014 create opportunities for higher participation of foreign capital in sectors such as transport, logistics, power generation, sanitation, construction and housing, oil and gas, renewable energy, and the airline industry. Brazil's proposed accession to the OECD is likely to face delays owing to concerns about the government's environmental policy stance, but membership is likely later in the forecast period, which will also boost FDI. On the downside, the Bolsonaro government's confrontational leadership style risks making Western foreign investors more cautious about Brazil. Brazilian governments signed a spate of international investment agreements in 2018-19, but no new deals have been signed since one with India in January 2020, largely because of the outbreak of the pandemic. The risk of expropriation remains low.
Infrastructure concessions offer attractive opportunities
- The government has repeatedly adapted the regulatory and legal framework for concessions (particularly in infrastructure) to allow a higher share of foreign funding. In mid-2019 Congress approved a presidential decree authorising aviation companies headquartered in Brazil to have unlimited participation of foreign capital (previously capped at 20%). The coronavirus pandemic delayed the planned auction of several infrastructure concessions (including in the aviation sector), but these are likely to go ahead in 2021-22. The government is seeking to spur investor interest through revised auction terms (lowering fees in a number of airport concession blocks, for example) or by offering risk hedges. In the case of a railway project, the authorities have gone as far as to offer the future concession winner R2.2bn in public money to cover "non-manageable risks". The government has also proposed a series of bills designed to boost private-sector participation, including measures to simplify environmental licensing and encourage foreign-company participation.
- A government bill to update and streamline bidding and procurement laws, as well as to provide additional judicial security for concessionaires (the New Public Procurement Law), was approved by the Senate (the upper house) on December 10th 2020 and now awaits presidential approval. This legislation, combined with other substantial measures-including the government's landmark sanitation regulation, which effectively opened water and sewerage provision to private companies at the state and municipal level-will improve the business environment.

Bureaucracy hampers PPPs
- Legislation passed in 2004 under the Lula government facilitated the development of a PPP strategy and aimed to overcome fiscal constraints by lifting private-sector investment, particularly in infrastructure projects. The law allowed the state to guarantee some level of profitability to the private partner. Subsequent legislation in 2016 created an Investment Partnerships Programme designed to bring together all levels of government and the private sector. However, bureaucratic delays in approving projects and issuing permits have hindered the success of PPPs.
- Foreign investors are guaranteed national treatment by law, but restrictions apply to activities involving nuclear energy, postal and telegraph services (except parcel delivery), some aerospace activities (such as launching and deployment of satellites), acquisition or rental of rural property, media (including television networks, magazines, newspapers and radio broadcasting stations), and mining.
- Although there is a risk that ideological factors will obstruct FDI from some countries, our baseline forecast is that government policy will remain relatively pragmatic. There have been concerns that Mr Bolsonaro would be more inclined to establish alliances with advanced Western countries run by right-wing parties rather than with countries under left-wing governments, affecting commercial and investment relations with China in particular. Notwithstanding some ongoing anti-Chinese rhetoric from the government, the need for Chinese investment so far appears to be outweighing ideological concerns; we expect this to remain the case in 2021-25, assuming that Mr Bolsonaro remains in office. If Lula wins the October 2022 election, there would be less anti-Chinese rhetoric (bilateral relations advanced significantly when Lula was in office). There would nevertheless be an ongoing risk of ideological factors obstructing FDI from some countries, although in this scenario, it would affect advanced Western economies, reflecting a probable shift towards "South-South" trade and investment.

Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
7.3 7.8 50 45 6 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Brazil's score and global ranking improve slightly in 2021-25, although its regional position remains unchanged, reflecting our expectation of moderate improvements elsewhere in Latin America. The mild uptick in Brazil's score is based on a growing openness to foreign trade; exports and imports will still account for a comparatively small share of total GDP, but this share will be higher in the forecast period than in the historical period. Also supporting Brazil's score in this area is the fact that it puts no major restrictions on current- and capital-account flows or on foreign-exchange transactions. However, other areas of foreign trade relating to government policy are much weaker. The free-market agenda espoused by Mr Guedes involves seeking trade deals with overseas countries, opening the economy and removing or lowering existing barriers to imports, as well as restoring the strategic importance of Mercosul (the Southern Cone customs union comprising Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay) as a regional trading bloc. However, not only is there domestic resistance to some of this agenda (including from manufacturers and businesspeople who will lobby to delay liberalisation in the context of the 2020 recession and weaker Real), but the external situation is also not particularly conducive to progress. The ongoing pandemic and anti-globalisation movements in the developed world are likely to pose some limits to FTAs between countries and regional blocs, and Mr Bolsonaro's permissive approach to illegal Amazon deforestation will cause relations with the EU and the new US administration to sour further.
EU concerns over environmental policies will delay EU-Mercosul FTA
- Initial celebrations by trade negotiators on both sides following the conclusion of the EU-Mercosul FTA deal in 2019 (after 20 years of on-off talks) soon fizzled out. The deal would bring together a combined population of 780m people and eliminate nearly 100% of EU tariffs and 90% of Mercosul tariffs, assuming that a signed deal were ratified by all Mercosul and EU member parliaments. However, a surge in deforestation of the Amazon rainforest under Mr Bolsonaro has added to protectionist sentiment in some EU food-producing countries, and EU parliaments are unlikely to ratify the deal until after the end of the forecast period, if at all. For Brazil (and Argentina), this provides time for reforms to boost competitiveness in the manufacturing and services sectors. South America's agro-industry has competitive advantages and would benefit from greater EU market access.
- Although the Real is not fully convertible, Brazil puts no major restrictions on current- and capital-account flows or on foreign-exchange transactions. The country's strong international reserves position (about US$352bn as at mid-March, equating to about 18 months of import cover), combined with its solid external sector, provides some support. Prior to the pandemic, policymakers signalled that they wanted to make the Real a convertible currency and turn it into a regional reference currency. However, given recent volatility, we do not expect any significant steps in this direction until conditions settle (later in the forecast period, at best).

Business environment outlook: Taxes                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
4.7 4.7 74 80 10 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Brazil has one of the most time-consuming and complex tax systems in the world; with little significant improvement likely during 2021-25, its score and ranking in this area will remain dismal. Brazil's tax burden (33% of GDP) is on a par with the OECD average, but it is very high by developing-country standards, especially given the poor quality of public services and physical infrastructure. Headline tax rates for most companies are not excessive, but a multitude of indirect taxes raise costs, with drawn-out processes increasing compliance costs. As a result, the total corporate tax burden as a share of profits is close to 65%, which is well above regional and OECD averages (47% and 40% respectively). The huge array of sectoral benefits and tax exemptions is a further cause of inefficiency that hampers competition. Tax simplification, to lower Brazil's high costs of doing business, has been on the agenda for 20 years, but after gaining momentum in 2019, progress stalled given myriad competing interests. The only potential reform in the near term relates to consumption taxes-there are proposals to unify a number of separate taxes into a single value-added tax (VAT)-but even this is far from assured, as the window for pushing legislation through before the 2022 election is narrowing.

- In July 2020 Mr Guedes presented the first part of the government's long-awaited tax reform to congressional leaders. In a planned multiphase rollout, it seeks to unify the federal PIS/Pasep and Cofins consumption taxes on goods and services into a single VAT, known as the Contribuição Social sobre com Bens e Serviços (CBS), levied at 12%. Banking and health insurance sectors would have their rate set at 5.8%. However, the government has yet to submit other elements of the planned tax reform, which could include a 0.2% financial transactions tax, intended to facilitate a reduction in payroll tax contributions (which in turn is designed to boost formal sector job creation). Our baseline forecast is that the first part of the reforms (the simplification of consumption taxes) will be passed in the second half of 2021, but there are growing risks to this projection. We do not expect any progress on other phases of the package, including changes to corporation and income taxes, or payroll contributions.

Business environment outlook: Financing                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
7.0 7.0 24 27 2 2
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa  Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Brazil's score in this area remains unchanged in 2021-25, keeping Brazil second-ranked regionally, although it slips by three places globally. The BCB rolled out a battery of measures to ensure the smooth functioning of the financial system in response to the pandemic, injecting liquidity and-together with the Treasury-providing loan guarantees through the banking system to companies. Large companies found it easier to secure credit lines than small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), but conditions for SMEs have improved since late 2020. The Federal Reserve (the US central bank) gave Brazil a US$60bn swap line, which will provide continued support with US dollar funding. The BCB also benefits from huge foreign-exchange reserves (US$352bn as at mid-March).

- As the economy recovers, attention will return to BCB measures to improve efficiency and competitiveness, and to reduce the cost of credit. The BCB has started to raise the Selic rate in response to emerging inflationary pressures; it is likely to continue to increase the rate gradually, towards a neutral rate of 2-3% in real terms. In order to dissuade commercial banks from passing on rate hikes to borrowers via higher lending rates, the authorities will focus on ways of increasing liquidity and fostering competition in the banking sector. These efforts are likely to be moderately successful; although the overall cost of credit (for both consumers and companies) will remain fairly high, it should ease, despite a period of moderate monetary policy tightening at the BCB.
- Before the Covid-19 crisis the government scaled back the availability of subsidised and abundant lending from state banks, especially from BNDES, the national development bank. However, state banks became part of lending support measures during the pandemic. In the long run, these loans will be reduced again. Still, state banks will continue to exercise an important role as sectoral lenders, such as in infrastructure (BNDES), agriculture (Banco do Brasil) and housing (Caixa).

The formalisation of BCB autonomy will support stability in the financial system
- Through its "BC# Agenda", the BCB is promoting modern regulations to strengthen the financial system, reduce the cost of credit and promote the regulation of credit fintechs (including facilitating foreign investors' entry into the market). Recent measures include the creation of Pix, an instant payments system that was launched in November 2020, and initial steps to adopt open-banking regulations, which began in February 2021.
- In February 2021 the lower house passed a bill that legally protects the central bank's autonomy, following approval by the Senate in 2020. Although the central bank had de facto autonomy, it was not legally protected. As such, the legislation reduces the risk of political interference in monetary policy. This bodes well for monetary stability and should help to reduce price volatility in the long term, as well as ensuring financial system stability.

Business environment outlook: The labour market                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
5.2 5.6 73 66 11 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Alongside the tax system, the labour market has traditionally been one of the weakest areas of Brazil's business environment. However, we expect a slight improvement in Brazil's underlying score and ranking in this area in the forecast period (in contrast to our less positive expectations for the tax system). This mainly reflects an expected increase in the availability of skilled labour (historically a weak point) and an improvement in the language skills among the workforce. However, both areas will improve from a low base; overall, standards will remain comparatively weak on both a regional and global basis. Despite fairly low wages, the overall cost of labour for employers is still high, with social security obligations and labour benefits adding an extra cost of close to one-third of salaries.

- The 2017 labour legislation was expected to spur job creation by making the labour market more flexible and dynamic. The changes weakened collective bargaining, regulated remote work and gave businesses more control over workers' hours and holiday time. However, the persistently high unemployment rate (12% even before the coronavirus pandemic, rising to over 14% in early 2021) suggests that the legislation had not helped that much, although economic conditions were still weak in 2018-19. Nevertheless, there has been a huge fall in the number of labour lawsuits entering courts, reducing the high and unpredictable legal costs to firms. Under the 2017 legislation, employees who sue an employer and lose the case must pay lawyers' fees.
- In what is seen as the government's new labour reform, Mr Guedes has revived plans for a more flexible labour contractual arrangement via the Carteira de Trabalho Verde Amarela (Green and Yellow Labour Register). The legislation was enacted by presidential decree (MP 905) in November 2019 but expired after Congress failed to approve it before the 120-day validity period elapsed in April 2020 owing to a combination of coronavirus-related disruption to legislative business and pushback from lawmakers over the erosion of labour rights. In response to the pandemic, the government launched the Programa Emergencial de Manutenção do Emprego e da Renda (BEm), which served as a job retention scheme for companies, providing transfers to supplement lost income for workers. Although unemployment has risen, the government claims that it saved 11m jobs in 2020. The BEm expired at the end of 2020, and the government is now hoping to revive the Labour Register in the hope that it will stimulate job creation. The proposal creates a new type of employment agreement to incentivise companies to offer people between 19 and 29 years old their first formal job in exchange for benefits relating mainly to payroll taxation. However, given some resistance from legislators, it is unclear whether this measure will be adopted. Even if it is passed, other structural constraints will hamper job creation.
- Measures to reduce the cost of labour in the short to medium term may well be implemented. First, the government seems inclined to alleviate the burden of formal labour by exempting or reducing payroll contributions. Secondly, the rules defining the monetary value of the minimum wage may change after wage rises in the past far surpassed productivity gains. Up until 2019, the minimum wage increased every year, according to past inflation (as defined in the constitution) plus the real GDP growth rate of two years earlier. The 2011 law formalising this framework expired in 2019. For 2020-21 the government set the minimum wage according to past inflation only, suggesting that this might remain official policy. A Lula government would probably seek to revert to the terms of the 2011 law.

Business environment outlook: Infrastructure                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
3.8 5.3 68 62 10 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Infrastructure concessions will result in some progress Brazil's infrastructure has suffered from a lack of investment in recent decades, contributing to a particularly weak score for the historical period. We expect some moderate improvements in 2021-25, reflecting the government's focus on infrastructure projects as a way of attracting investment and engineering a recovery from the 2020 recession. The coronavirus pandemic delayed planned auctions of infrastructure concessions, but these are likely to restart soon. The scope for growth, the size of the market and new regulations in some sub-sectors offer investors attractive opportunities, which are likely to translate into some progress in infrastructure over the forecast period. However, political and policy uncertainty will persist, and unresolved questions about the allocation of public expenditure may hamper the pace of progress. The deleveraging of BNDES will also result in more selective lending by the national development bank, which is traditionally a big funder of infrastructure projects in the energy and logistics sectors.

- The infrastructure ministry has built up an ambitious backlog of concession plans. Although the pandemic delayed a number of projects-partly owing to drops in road and air traffic-the Tribunal de Contas da União (TCU, the federal accounts court) pushed ahead, approving concession plans and green-lighting auctions to begin in 2021. Among other plans, the government is focusing on drumming up investor interest around three major auctions, namely the new Dutra highway connecting Rio de Janeiro and São Paulo, the Ferrogrão grain railway from the state of Mato Grosso to Pará, and the sixth round of airport concessions. Overall, 2021 concession plans include 17 ports, 11 major highways, three railways, and 23 airports, altogether expected to draw in R137bn in investment. A seventh round of airport concessions, including Rio de Janeiro's Santos Dumont and São Paulo's Congonhas, is scheduled for 2022.
- The infrastructure minister, Tarcísio Gomes de Freitas, is well regarded by the private sector and has framed the concessions issue as a question of circumventing fiscal limitations; freeing up funds from cumbersome maintenance costs on state-run roads (for example) will provide his ministry with the budget needed to expand the government's public works projects. As such, government commitment to the concessions programme will remain firm in the first half of the forecast period. We do not expect the government's policy towards infrastructure to alter in the second half of our forecast period regardless of the election outcome; even if Lula were to win the presidency, he promoted investment in infrastructure during his tenure, and fiscal constraints mean that private-sector investment in the sector will be necessary.

Business environment outlook: Technological readiness                
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25 2016-20 2021-25
5.5 6.1 53 50 5 4
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Brazil scores reasonably well in terms of technological readiness. The government views information and communication technology (ICT) as a strategic area. It introduced a National Plan for the Internet of Things (IoT) in mid-2019, designed jointly by the Ministry of Science, Technology, Innovation and Communications (in June 2020 the government moved communications into a separate ministry), the economy ministry and BNDES. The plan implements actions across several other ministries (agriculture, health and regional development) in areas such as innovation support, international outreach, infrastructure for connectivity and data privacy regulations. Universities have an important role in innovation. Links with the industry are weak but will continue to grow. In 2019 Brazil registered the highest number of patent applications of low- and middle-income countries, according to the World Intellectual Property Organisation.

- Brazil is Latin America's largest internet market in terms of users but lags Chile, Argentina and Mexico in terms of penetration. A digitalisation drive brought about by the pandemic has caused internet user penetration to rise, a trend that we expect to continue in 2021-25. We expect the ongoing rise in fibre investment and adoption of broadband connections to support overall growth.

5G auctions are likely in 2021
- Nearly 75% of mobile subscriptions use 4G technology. The Agência Nacional de Telecomunicações (Anatel, the telecommunications agency) is likely to hold auctions for 5G frequencies in mid-2021. The government would like these to become operational in 2022, although local operators are pressing for a five-year transition. The launch of 5G technology would be the first major step towards the IoT, providing a broad and direct connection of devices, computers and machines.
- Electronic commerce (e-commerce), which was already becoming more prominent before the pandemic, soared in 2020. Over 30% of Brazilians are regular online shoppers, with most online transactions completed on smartphones and tablets. Much of the recent growth is attributable to consumers making online purchases of groceries and staples (rather than just consumer electronics and non-food products, as was the case previously).
- The digital revolution has fostered over 13,400 start-ups, according to the Associação Brasileira de Startups (the start-ups association), especially in banking and finance, education, transport and logistics, and food delivery. Eighteen Brazilian start-ups have become local "unicorns"-each worth over US$1bn-although stockmarket losses in the first half of 2020 reduced their value.

Economic forecast: Policy trends Policymaking in 2021 will focus on the worsening coronavirus pandemic and the structural reform agenda. Policymaking will be more unpredictable and populist, as the president, Jair Bolsonaro, seeks to avoid unpopular measures ahead of the 2022 elections and panders to his various groups of supporters. This was evident in his recent interference in the state oil firm, Petrobras (to appease truckers' unions, who paralysed the country during a strike in 2018), after it raised fuel prices in line with international increases. Market risks include a change in Petrobras's pricing regime and possible efforts to reduce electricity tariffs by changing some rules of the game. If the economy fails to pick up after a recession in the first half of 2021, a more expansionary fiscal stance than expected in the 2022 election year cannot be ruled out, although it would encounter resistance in Congress.
After a lull ahead of the February congressional leadership elections, there has been a flurry of legislative activity, as the new leader of the lower house, Arthur Lira presided over the landmark approval of formal central bank independence (some 20 years in the making) and the so-called Emergency PEC (a constitutional amendment) that provides greater flexibility in budget management by triggering automatic cuts, should overall spending put Brazil's 2016 expenditure cap rules (zero growth in spending in real terms)-a key anchor for fiscal policy-in jeopardy. The bill excluded R44bn in emergency cash payments to the poor (around a tenth of that disbursed last year) between April and July.
The next legislative priority will be to pass the (delayed) 2021 budget. Thereafter, attention will turn to public-sector reforms, which aim to reduce the costly public-sector wage bill over the long term, where there is political consensus for approval. Other economic reforms will encounter more difficulties, although The Economist Intelligence Unit still expects some progress by end-2021. Among them is a revenue-neutral tax simplification reform to unify three or more consumption taxes into a single value-added tax (VAT). Likewise, progress on the privatisation agenda will be slow, owing to weak support from the centrão, as many of its members have vested interests in state companies. If any privatisations move forward, we expect them to be of smaller, non-strategic assets, such as the state-owned postal service; privatisation of Eletrobras, the state electricity company, is unlikely.
Economic forecast: Fiscal policy Fiscal indicators

After surging to 90% in 2020, owing to pandemic-related support measures, currency depreciation and recession, the public debt/GDP ratio will inch up, as fiscal revenue only partly recovers and the government provides emergency cash payments for the poor, albeit on a more limited scale than last year. Stopping a more substantial rise will require consolidation; otherwise, concerns about debt sustainability will re-emerge among investors, raising the country risk premium. The government will seek to avoid raising taxes ahead of the 2022 elections, but tax increases thereafter cannot be ruled out. The fiscal hit from the crisis is apparent in the widening of the 12-month rolling overall deficit, to 13.7% of GDP in January 2021. We expect measures to be mostly retracted in 2021; the deficit will narrow to 7.6% of GDP as revenue increases. Consolidation of these trends will keep the deficit smaller than 7% of GDP throughout 2022-25. We anticipate that public debt will stabilise within the forecast period, helped by privatisation proceeds and currency revaluation, but there is a risk that debt will exceed 100% if the president yields to an election-related increase in spending.

As the economy recovers in 2021-25, we expect policy normalisation, which began in March with a 75-basis-point hike, to take the Selic policy rate from 2.75% currently to 6% by 2022 (a real interest rate of 2-3%, which we consider neutral, up from over -2% currently). The mid-point inflation target will fall by 25 basis points each year in 2021-23, from 3.75% to 3.25% (the 2024 target will be set in 2021 and could fall further). The most significant risk to the environment of low interest rates and inflation is an unexpected abandonment of spending cap rules, which could trigger a market sell-off that may force the Banco Central do Brasil (BCB, the central bank) to tighten policy by more than expected.

Following a 4.1% contraction in 2020, real GDP will recover partly in 2021, expanding by 3.2%, and grow at rates averaging 2.1% in 2022-25. Our forecasts assume the approval of fiscal reforms and progress on other microeconomic reform agenda items, but we recognise that governability risks could hamper advances. Growth in 2021 overall will be mostly due to strong "carry-over" statistical effects from the 2020 rebound, as sequential growth will be curbed by the withdrawal of most fiscal stimulus and rising interest rates and inflation. Moreover, we expect real GDP to contract in the first half of 2021 amid renewed mobility restrictions as the public health crisis worsens. A gradual pick-up thereafter assumes a wider distribution of coronavirus vaccines, along with a recovering global economy. However, lasting damage to the productive sector and jobs, as well as corporate and household balance sheets, means that we do not expect output to return to pre-coronavirus levels until 2022.
On the demand side, the upturn in 2021-25 will be driven by stronger investment (buoyed by infrastructure concessions and notwithstanding a normalisation in interest rates) and by private consumption. The re-introduction of (more limited) emergency cash transfers for the poor in April-July (another extension cannot be ruled out) will prop up consumption slightly until the jobs market strengthens later in the year. On the supply side, commodity exports will accelerate in 2021-25, in line with a recovery in global demand. Manufacturing has already rebounded, owing to stimulus for consumers and a weaker currency, which could continue to make goods more competitive against imports in 2021-25. Positive vaccine news should boost consumer and business confidence, but the recovery of the services sector will not materialise fully until vaccines have been distributed beyond vulnerable groups, which should happen from mid-2021.




Enlarge this image.
Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends Forecast growth rates for agriculture (which accounts for 7% of GDP), industry (accounting for 20%) and services (accounting for 73%) will be influenced by their recoveries from the 2020 pandemic-induced shock, structural factors and sectoral dynamics. Agriculture was barely affected in 2020 and grew by 2%, supported by external demand. Output levels in industry (and retailing) showed a V-shaped recovery (although they ended full-year 2020 in negative territory because of lost output in the second quarter). Services was hit the hardest (particularly services related to interactions with households; business services and public administration were not as badly affected) and will not return to pre-pandemic output levels until mobility restrictions are fully lifted.
Agriculture has a crucial role that belies its small share of GDP, owing to its significance as an employer in rural areas and the importance of agribusiness industries and food processing for the domestic market and exports. Favourable weather has led to rising grain harvests in the past five years, reaching an estimated 272,000 tonnes in the 2020/21 harvest. The sector will remain vulnerable to adverse weather (particularly the cyclical El Niño weather phenomenon), but will be supported by technological improvements and more intensive land use, as well as by fair fundamentals for soft-commodity exports, owing to rising demand in the developing world.
Manufacturing is constrained by competitiveness weaknesses Despite piecemeal reform efforts, the post-pandemic outlook for manufacturing will be hindered by competitiveness shortcomings that have plagued the sector for many years, contributing to a decline in its share of total GDP, from 15% in 2000 to less than 10% currently. These include a high tax burden, poor infrastructure and high labour costs. Import competition was also a factor: the Real was overvalued during the commodity boom (2005-12) and because of Brazil's high interest rates. However, since 2016-17 these latter factors have eased and the Real no longer appears overvalued, providing some respite. However, light-manufacturing industries in particular have lost market share in recent years, owing to a surge in Chinese imports. Capital goods industries will face similar problems, but will be supported by domestic demand. Higher investment will enable some labour-intensive manufacturing activities to move up the value chain, but many will struggle to cope with rising import competition. Brazil's manufacturing sector has been mostly inward-looking and-with a few exceptions-companies have failed to develop linkages with global production systems. The government wants to change this through liberalisation, but policymakers are likely to dial down their ambitious plans because of the hit to manufacturing from Covid-19 and the probable long recovery from the crisis.
The vehicles and parts industry accounts for about one-fifth of manufacturing. The Covid-19 pandemic brought Brazil's automotive industry temporarily to a halt; automotive plants shut down as a result of quarantine measures, causing production to fall by 31.6%. The Associação Nacional dos Fabricantes de Veículos Automotores (Anfavea, the vehicles industry body) expects a partial recovery in 2021, with output growing by 25%. The recovery in demand will depend on the success of quarantine exit strategies, with the potential for further waves of the virus (such as an ongoing one that began in February) to cause renewed disruptions to economic activity. We expect the rebound in consumer and business confidence and credit to be modest, as Brazil's labour market and productive sector will struggle to recover over the medium term. We expect annual vehicle output to recover to its 2019 level of 2.8m by 2025, but to remain well below the peak of 3.8m units produced in 2012, at the height of Brazil's boom.
Extractive industries should perform reasonably well in the medium term. Although the secular slowdown in China dampens the outlook for Brazil's export commodities, demand growth will continue to support mining activity, notably of iron ore. Investment in other mining activities will be boosted following reforms to the mining law in 2018 (lifting royalties for the government and improving the regulatory framework).
Huge reserves of oil and gas could turn Brazil into one of the world's top ten oil exporters. Local production of oil, gas, coal and electricity in 2020 was contained owing to unplanned and maintenance outages, skeletal staffing and limited demand. The government postponed tenders that were scheduled to take place for developing oil and gas concessions, and for power-generation capacity. We expect a surge in oil and gas production later in the forecast period, with investments in Brazil's pre-salt areas-where significant reserves are held beneath thick layers of salt under the seabed-boosting output.
Services sector is unlikely to recover much dynamism Most components of the services sector, which accounts for over 70% of GDP, are unlikely to recover much dynamism in the medium term, as they are impaired by low productivity and skills shortages. When credit growth recovers (in the medium term), it is expected to be 5-10% weaker in real terms than during Brazil's credit boom in 2006-12. It will also be weaker than in 2020, when government crisis support led to a 12% real gain. However, retail, financial services, ICT and trade will outperform the sector average during the recovery phase.
Growth in retail volumes will pick up slightly in 2021-22, before slowing again in 2023 as economic growth decelerates. Improved underlying economic conditions in 2024-25 are likely to spur firmer growth in retail volumes. Many consumers have traded down, but will continue to shop across different channels, which poses challenges for retailers. Convenience stores will remain popular across income groups in urban areas, but mobile-internet shopping is gaining popularity among young adults.
Economic forecast: Inflation % 2020 2021 2022 2023 2024 2025

A stronger policy framework than in the past will help to anchor inflation expectations, and minimum-wage increases are unlikely to be much above inflation (if at all). Even with an aggressive pace of monetary policy normalisation now under way, there is a risk that inflation expectations will become unanchored if the government's commitment to fiscal consolidation wavers. Inflation reached 5.2% in February (above this year's 3.75% midpoint target); we consider that the rise in inflation since mid-2020-related to higher food and commodity prices, a weaker currency and higher demand created by emergency cash transfers last year-will lift the 12-month rate over 7% in the second quarter, before moderating thereafter. Assuming a gradual economic recovery in 2021-25, and barring periodic weather-related food shortages, an unexpected surge in oil prices or fiscal slippage, inflation should fluctuate close to the (lower) midpoint targets of 3.5% in 2022 and 3.25% in 2023.

Swings in global conditions and jitters over fiscal risks will keep the Real volatile, but it should continue to regain some of its 2020 losses over the medium term, as policy rates rise and the economy recovers. The Real was trading at R5.6:US$1 in late March, amid renewed depreciation pressures reflecting deteriorating economic expectations and market jitters over fiscal risks. We expect the Real to strengthen to R5:US$1 by 2025, fluctuating in line with Brazil's terms of trade, interest-rate differentials and global risk sentiment. A deeper local capital market for long-term debt will discourage corporate external borrowing, reducing capital inflows. The main risk to the forecast is the possibility of a market sell-off if confidence in debt sustainability evaporates.

Risks to Brazil's external position will be assuaged by its modest current-account deficit and external debt ratio, comfortable reserves cushion and a Real no longer overvalued by high interest rates (as in the past). Public external debt is low, and most companies have some sort of currency hedge, despite moderate private external debt. The trade balance will post a large structural surplus in 2021-25, owing to stable commodity exports to China, but this will narrow gradually, as imports rise following recession-related compression in 2020.
After narrowing in 2020, the current-account deficit will widen gradually in 2021-25, as imports recover in line with the economy, and will reach 3.5% of GDP in 2025. However, inflows of foreign direct investment (FDI) will match this, averaging 3.6% of GDP in 2021-25, reflecting sizeable market opportunities.


Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Brazil Stocks and flows Brazil is one of the largest foreign direct investment (FDI) recipients and preferred investment destinations in Latin America. Globally, Brazil usually ranks as one of the top ten recipients of FDI in the world. In 2020 total FDI inflows (including intercompany transfers and reinvested profits) fell to an estimated US$34bn, or 2.4% of GDP. Foreign investments had previously shown some resilience during difficult economic times: average FDI inflows of US$72bn during the 2015-16 crisis and the 2017-19 post-crisis period were not that far below the US$88bn average during the boom 2010-14 years. By end-2020 the FDI stock had reached US$854bn (59% of GDP).
Origin and distribution Companies from the US and Europe have traditionally been the biggest investors, but in recent years Chinese companies have entered the market, acquiring assets in electricity, infrastructure, oil and services. Other relevant countries investing in Brazil are Mexico, Japan, Singapore and Argentina. Distribution of incoming FDI is fairly broad-based across agriculture, extractive industries, manufacturing and services, reflecting opportunities in Brazil's broad-based economy.
Determinants Brazil's attractiveness to foreign investors has generally been determined by a combination of its market size, regional influence, macroeconomic stability, richness of natural resources and diversified industrial base. The country is a major global player in agribusiness, mineral commodities and bioenergy. However, its complex tax system, relatively unstable legal framework and high borrowing costs have precluded a more abundant inflow of foreign investments.
Impact FDI has played an increasingly important role in recent infrastructure concessions and in the "pre-salt" oil rounds. In this sense, FDI is considered a key success factor in the promotion of higher capital productivity and sustained long-term growth. From a balance-of-payments perspective, FDI has fully covered the current-account deficit in recent years, allowing a healthy and balanced exchange between Brazil and the rest of the world. Although it is hard to measure the direct effects of FDI on productivity, it is clear that there is a positive correlation between the presence of international companies operating in Brazil and research and development activity: patents filed by non-residents through the Brazilian offices amounted to 20,200 in 2017, far exceeding the 7,500 patents filed by residents.
Potential As the economic crisis caused by the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic eases, a gradual recovery in FDI is likely to emerge, and the opening of the economy should make the country an interesting investment opportunity in the 2021-25 forecast period. There is a moderate chance of changes in the tax system that would combine five taxes (federal, state and municipal) into one single value-added tax (VAT), which would greatly simplify the country's complex tax system, considered one of the major barriers to investment. However, privatisation opportunities will be more disappointing than they appeared when the current president, Jair Bolsonaro, took office, as he has little appetite to take on vested interests in Congress who obstruct divestments.

Brazil is undergoing a rapid demographic transition marked by a reduction in birth rates and an increase in life expectancy that is dampening GDP growth potential. In 2000 there were 52.1m people in the country aged 0-14 (corresponding to 30% of the population), according to the national institute of statistics (IBGE). By 2020 this age group accounted for 44.2m people (21.1% of the population), equivalent to a 9.1-percentage-point fall over 20 years. In the same period the share accounted for by the elderly population (those aged over 65) rose by 4.2 points, from 5.6% in 2000 to 9.2% in 2020. The 2020 census was postponed to 2021 because of the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic. Given IBGE's projections for 2030, the share of the elderly population should reach 13.5%, an increase of 5.2 percentage points from 2020.
Rapid demographic transition will hit the workforce The ratio of the working-age population (15-64 years) to the total population is peaking; it rose from 68.9% in 2015 to 69.7% in 2020, and is expected to fall again to 69.4% in 2025. This will increase the old-age dependency ratio (the degree to which elderly population depends on the working-age population). In 2025 the old-age dependency ratio is forecast to reach 0.16, meaning that there will be 16 old-aged people depending on 100 people of working age (in 2002 this ratio was 0.10). Future workers will therefore suffer much more acute pressure to finance the increasing number of pension beneficiaries. This is unlikely to be resolved by productivity gains in the labour market, as the current education and skills levels of the workforce are low, and we do not expect them to advance significantly over the next decade.
Solving the pension system imbalance by raising taxes or labour contributions would be costly and counterproductive. Given the already relatively high tax burden in Brazil, additional tax increases would increase production costs, reduce the level of employment and ultimately limit consumption, growth and revenue collection. In sum, Brazil's demographic transition challenges the fiscal and financial sustainability of the country's current "pay-as-you-go" pension system, even after the landmark pension reform in 2019. Another attempt at reform will be needed in the next five to ten years.
The pandemic will stretch the public healthcare system even further Population ageing affects not only the social security system, but also the healthcare system, as it increases medical and hospital costs. The country has one of the largest public healthcare systems in the world; the 1988 constitution made healthcare universal and decentralised, according to the degree of treatment complexity (municipalities are responsible for basic care and states for medium to high levels of care). However, even before Covid-19, the system was already overstretched owing to growing demand, an effect that had been boosted by the 2014-16 economic crisis, which caused many people to migrate from private healthcare insurance (mostly through company schemes) to public health services. Demand will only increase, stretching budgets.
Despite its young population (the average age is just under 30), Brazil spends 13-14% of GDP on pension-related payments and benefits. In comparison, the total sum of public spending on health and education is not much above 10% of GDP.
Given the speed of the demographic transition and the pressure that it puts on the pension and health systems, labour productivity would have to rise to levels that are probably unthinkable in the long run. Although immigration could be a potential driver for promoting labour productivity, there has not been a policy designed to attract skilled labour, nor is there likely be one in the near future. Most of the recent immigrants (primarily from South Korea, China, Bolivia, Haiti and Venezuela) have been absorbed by low-skill functions in the retail sector rather than in industry, where most of the demand for high-skilled labour is found.

A tepid recovery from the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic-together with currency volatility caused by rising fiscal and political risks-will cause larger than normal fluctuations in Brazil's market size, and it will take several years for the country to recover to pre-crisis output levels. Indeed, in 2020 Brazil fell out of the top ten world economies: in 2019 it was the ninth-largest economy in the world, with total GDP of just over US$1.8trn, but it now has fallen to 12th place owing to the crisis, with total GDP of just over US$1.4trn. Given its large population (more than 210m people, the fifth-largest in the world), GDP per head was US$8,753 (at market exchange rates) in 2019, falling in 2020 to US$6,822. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects Brazil's GDP per head to recover to US$9,004 by 2025, making it an upper-middle-income country and the 60th-70th richest in the world (depending on the metrics used).
Market recovery from the Covid-19 crisis will take several years Nonetheless, when measured by purchasing power parity, per-head income is higher (falling to US$12,112 in 2020, then rising to US$17,999 by 2025). The divergence between the GDP per head measured by market rates and purchasing power parity reflects the fact that, in emerging economies such as Brazil, lower wages make the price of services and non-traded goods relatively cheap compared with richer countries. Given that services represent more than 70% of GDP, per-head income measured by the purchasing power parity exchange rate tends to be higher than at the market exchange rate.
The relatively low median monthly personal income (about US$440 at current exchange rates) results in a low marginal propensity to save and high marginal propensity to spend. According to 2019 research by the Associação Brasileira das Entidades dos Mercados Financeiro e de Capitais (Anbima, the financial and capital market entities' association), 56% of Brazilians do not have any financial investments; in the long term, this could improve as financial technology "fintech" platforms become more widespread. Although sizeable fiscal stimulus in 2020 in the form of cash transfers has led to an increase in savings, this is likely to prove temporary. The share of households earning over US$10,000 fell to an estimated 46% in 2020 and is unlikely to return to the 59% reported in 2019 during the 2021-25 outlook period.
Household consumption is high, but savings are low The high share of income diverted to consumption means that household consumption represents about 67% of the country's total GDP. Government consumption is fairly high for a developing country, at about 20% of GDP. The flipside of this is that savings and investments are very low, with gross fixed investments representing only 15% of GDP. Even in families who save some of their income, most allocate it in conservative instruments, primarily in savings accounts with low interest rates, sometimes even below-inflation rates (real savings interest rates are negative). A low level of knowledge about financial products also explains the low levels of savings, so most families do not get much extra income from financial returns.
Low levels of savings reduce the amount of financial guarantees and collateral available to households to borrow from banks. This helps to explain why total domestic credit extended by banks to the private sector represents a little over 60% of GDP in Brazil. Most of the consumption is therefore diverted to goods and services that are less dependent on credit, such as non-durable goods (food and beverages, health and beauty) and semi-durable goods (clothing, household goods and electronic equipment). Consumption of durable goods, such as automobiles and housing, which are based on lending, seems to have been too dependent on government stimulus in the past; the boom and bust cycle between 2003 and 2014 illustrates these consumer and credit trends. These trends are reflected in electronic commerce (e-commerce) as well. Even though the Covid-19 pandemic has propelled digital growth, consumer behaviour has changed little. We estimate that online sales, which were growing steadily until 2019, jumped by more than 50% in 2020, to about R156bn (US$30bn), accounting for about 9% of total retail sales. Much of this growth is attributable to consumers making online purchases of groceries and staples.

Corporate and household balance sheets will suffer amid a tepid recovery The Covid-19 crisis caused a steep 4.1% decline in GDP in 2020, and we expect a partial recovery in 2021, as the economy continues to suffer. The damage to the public finances, and to corporate and household balance sheets, means that the recovery will generally be "swoosh-shaped", although we anticipate some bumps along the way, including a technical recession in first-half 2021, as the public health crisis is still raging amid a slow vaccine rollout. The impact of the recession will vary between regions owing to pronounced disparities in income and growth; incomes will rise slowly in the coming years, but southern states will do better than the rest, especially as they depend more on agriculture, which has held up better than industry and services amid the pandemic. Brazil is made up of 26 states-plus the federal district-divided into five regions. The North and North-east are home to 36% of the population, represent 23.6% of national income and almost 20% of GDP. Strengths are the industrial production of durable and semi-durable goods in the Manaus Free-Trade Zone (in the North) and agriculture and mining (in the North-east). The South-east region accounts for 42% of the population, 51% of income and 53% of GDP, and has a diversified industrial, agricultural and services base, especially in the state of São Paulo. The Central-west, Brazil's agricultural belt, specialises in livestock, grains (soybean and corn) and cotton, and accounts for 7.7% of the population, 8.5% of income and 10% of GDP. Finally, the South has 14.3% of the population, 17% of income and 17% of GDP, and mostly specialises in agro-industry.

From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.
The economic impact of the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic will dampen annual GDP growth rates in 2021-30, which will average only 2%. Based on The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth model, annual GDP will pick up to 1.9% on average in 2031-50, lower than in 1991-2014 (3% growth on average). The uptick in 2031-50 assumes that labour productivity growth will accelerate beyond recent historical levels, which have been poor. This will be needed if worsening demographic factors are to be offset. If policy improvements and structural reforms exceed expectations, faster growth would be achievable.
Initial conditions: Brazil's advantages of vast natural-resource potential and a young labour force are mitigated by a series of structural constraints, including weak political effectiveness, a generally low level of education and skills, income disparities, low savings rates, chronic underinvestment in infrastructure, and heavy public debt. Other than in the agricultural sector, productivity growth has been disappointing in recent years, despite the manufacturing sector taking advantage of exchange-rate appreciation in 2005-14 to increase imports of more advanced machinery and equipment. Gradual improvements in the quality and availability of primary and secondary education, as well as efforts to address infrastructure deficiencies, simplify the convoluted tax system and reduce red tape, will underpin stronger productivity growth in the long term. Our projections are based on expectations that a commitment to macroeconomic discipline will prevail.
Demographic trends: Brazil's demographic profile will become less supportive of growth prospects further into the long-term period. Even though a declining birth rate and a relatively static mortality rate will push up the median age of the population, the median age will remain low compared with major economies such as the US, western European countries and Japan. Given that population growth will begin to outpace working-age growth early in the 2020s, Brazil's "demographic dividend" is close to ending, and policymakers will have the challenge of addressing the fiscal burden of an ageing population.
External conditions: Structural external vulnerabilities have declined, but the Brazilian economy remains exposed to changes in external financial market conditions owing to its low domestic savings rates, and the volume of external capital inflows is strongly correlated with risk aversion. Although the public sector has been cautious about external borrowing, corporates have borrowed overseas and can be affected by sudden stops in capital flows. Increasing trade openness and continued diversification of export partners will allow the country to continue benefiting from global trade growth. Brazil's strong competitive advantage in agricultural production and its large industrial export base provide some insulation from commodity price shocks. Global trade liberalisation is expected to make little headway; combined with rising international pressure to contain deforestation, this will prevent Brazil from realising its full export potential, particularly in the agricultural sector.
Institutions and policy trends: Democracy has consolidated since the return to civilian rule in 1985. However, many political institutions are still ineffective; in particular, the political spectrum is fragmented into several relatively weak parties, producing a legislature dominated by vested interests. This will improve slightly, assuming that efforts to enhance party loyalty and electoral measures to reduce the number of political parties in Congress eventually materialise. Fiscal pressures will continue to mount despite watered-down efforts to pass reforms to cap the benefits and entitlements enshrined in the 1988 constitution and limit public-sector spending. Spending commitments will rise as the population ages. Tax revenue is already high, at 34% of GDP, so adjusting the public finances to stabilise and reduce Brazil's high public debt/GDP ratio (which rose to 90% in 2020) will prove challenging. A heavy debt burden will keep interest payments high, crowding out the private sector. With much public expenditure characterised by poor effectiveness, fiscal policy will not make a major contribution to long-term growth. Our long-term growth forecasts assume slow improvements in the business environment as a result of the gradual (albeit uneven) implementation of structural reforms, which will help to ease other constraints on GDP growth, including the convoluted tax system, infrastructure shortcomings and labour market weaknesses. We expect these measures to start to improve Brazil's relative attractiveness for investors only after 2030. Regulatory issues will be addressed gradually, and the judiciary should become more efficient over time.
Long-term performance: Brazil will struggle to gain much ground on the US, with GDP per head (in US dollars at purchasing power parity) amounting to 25% of that of the US in 2050. Macroeconomic stability will continue to reduce volatility in economic growth, and our forecast for GDP expansion of 1.9% per year in 2021-50 will be weaker than the average in 1991-2014 (3%). Improvements in infrastructure, trade expansion, a broader presence of multinational business and a reduction in the debt-service burden will mitigate slower labour force growth and should help to lift labour productivity growth throughout the long-term outlook period. This is dependent on progress in the politically difficult process of institutional reforms. Our outlook is based on the assumption that governments will remain broadly committed to pushing through changes in the long term. Otherwise, productivity growth and average GDP growth rates will fall short of our forecasts. The country's political system makes it hard to advance structural reforms. Political reforms could alter this, although these appear intractable. The commercial exploitation of the proceeds of Brazil's huge reserves of deepwater oil is factored into our baseline forecasts, and major setbacks in this regard would therefore pose a downside risk to our long-term forecasts. Our forecasts now capture the impact of climate change; we believe that Brazil's GDP in 2050 will be 4% smaller than what it would have been without climate change.
