Long-term outlook: Long-term trends Environmental policies present downside risks to growth Since taking office, the president, Jair Bolsonaro, has pursued a combination of hands-off rhetoric and anti-environmental policies, mixing talk of national sovereignty rights over the huge portion of the Amazon forest that falls within Brazil's borders with efforts to strip environmental controls. Data from the Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas Espaciais (INPE, the space research institute) show that deforestation in Brazil's Amazon rainforest increased by 13% between August 2019 and July 2020 (when it hit a 12-year high); this is over 180% higher than the legal target laid out in the 2009 National Policy on Climate Change. A round of mass firings has constrained efficiency at the Instituto Brasileiro do Meio Ambiente e dos Recursos Naturais (Ibama, the environmental protection agency), meaning that seizures of illegal timber and issuances of fines have plummeted since Mr Bolsonaro took office. The government has obscured agricultural ministry data on cattle movement and pushed through a decree that critics say increases illegal land grabs and sales. Mr Bolsonaro's more recent efforts to control deforestation-including deploying the armed forces to police the Amazon in place of Ibama agents-has achieved only lacklustre results.
International pressure has risen in response to Mr Bolsonaro's policies as climate change increasingly becomes a global policy priority. There had already been some backlash in 2018-19 against Mr Bolsonaro's policies against raging forest fires and deforestation, including freezes on funding from the Norwegian and German governments to an Amazon preservation fund, although the former US president, Donald Trump (2017-21), provided Mr Bolsonaro with some political cover. Nonetheless, the election of Joe Biden in the US is bringing new impetus to global efforts to combat climate change and will place Brazil's environmental policies at the centre of the bilateral agenda. Moving forward, Brazil will face rising diplomatic isolation amid higher deforestation rates, which will have ripple effects on the country's foreign policy agenda and will bring economic consequences. For instance, Mr Bolsonaro's environmental policies are providing a political platform to European green parties, as well as farm lobbies, to block the ratification of the trade agreement between the EU and Mercosul (the Southern Cone customs union comprising Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay) that was signed in mid-2019. It could also result in temporary boycotts by European importers. Moreover, the Biden administration has discussed incorporating deforestation goals into other areas of bilateral relations, such as Brazil's efforts to secure OECD membership, which is one of the key ambitions of Mr Bolsonaro's government. Pressure from the private sector (both foreign and domestic) is also rising, as some European investment funds are threatening to pull their assets out of Brazil. Overall, the rising popularity of environmental, social and governance (ESG) investment frameworks could increasingly affect investment flows into Brazil.
Notwithstanding this international pressure, and the economic implications that they entail, it appears that an about-turn in environmental policy and improvements in environmental indicators may only materialise after Mr Bolsonaro's tenure ends, especially as he is ramping up his nationalist rhetoric in the run-up to the 2022 presidential election. This means that climate policy is unlikely to change for however long Mr Bolsonaro remains in office. Now that a former president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva (2003-10), is permitted to run again, the October 2022 presidential election will be more competitive. If Lula were to win, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects that his government would take a more active role in promoting climate policy on the global stage, in line with Brazil's traditional foreign policy focus as a promoter of green policy as the "guardian of the Amazon" under previous Lula governments as well as other administrations headed by his Partido dos Trabalhadores (PT). However, in practice, Lula's track record on the environment is questionable: he oversaw record-high deforestation rates. Overall, institutional capacity to combat deforestation is limited, and Brazil's high deforestation rates will therefore remain a major roadblock in its trade and investment agenda in the long term.
New innovations in fintech offer opportunities for growth and financial inclusion A technological revolution in Brazil's financial sector will support the country's long-term recovery from the coronavirus (Covid-19) recession and open up new avenues for innovation in electronic commerce (e-commerce). Open banking reforms and the creation of Pix (a new electronic payments system) by the central bank will provide new opportunities in Brazil's highly concentrated system and promote financial inclusion by increasing bankarisation rates among the poor. Financial technology (fintech) activities have the potential to boost competition and put pressure on margins, alleviating the adverse consequences of highly concentrated banking systems.
The Banco Central do Brasil (BCB, the central bank) has made inclusion and competition central pillars of its agenda. Since the launch of Pix in November 2020, about 134m user accounts have been registered, reflecting strong demand. The daily average volume of transactions is R5bn-6bn (US$930m-1.12bn). In February 2021 alone, more than 270m Pix transactions were made, according to BCB data. On its own, Pix, which allows individuals to make instant digital payments and money transfers for free (companies pay a small fee), will dent traditional bank profits by almost eliminating fees gathered on wire transfers, still widely used in Brazil. Conversely, Brazil's unbanked population, estimated at 45m-60m people, should shrink as a result, piggybacking on a general shift to digital payment and banking services during the pandemic (over 40m Brazilians received their Covid-19 assistance payments digitally, through their Caixa Econômica Federal bank accounts). Rather than stoking zero-sum competition between brick-and-mortar operations and digital start-ups, the implementation of open banking should drive synergies between the two as traditional banks share data and collaborate with third-party institutions.
Looking ahead, open banking regulations are likely to follow, and the BCB governor, Roberto Campos Neto, has gone as far as to suggest the creation of a digital currency in 2022. Nonetheless, there are some risks to that should be considered. Fintech firms, which have been allowed to provide direct credit services since 2018, may not have the risk management systems and practices in place that incumbent financial firms have, which could present risks to financial stability. Moreover, increased digitalisation and connectivity exposes operators and consumers to cyber-security risk; active risk management is required so that measures related to cyber-security are commensurate with the underlying risk.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include: LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Data sources and definitions Sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; unless otherwise stated, The Economist Intelligence Unit is the source for all forecast data
Global data Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
Non-oil commodity prices: IFS
Oil prices: Dated Brent import price
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
US consumer price inflation: OECD
US$ effective exchange rate: IFS; nominal weighted index, 1990=100
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IFS
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
Domestic data Balance of payments: IFS, various issues
Budget balance: refers to nominal public-sector borrowing requirement
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services; World Bank, International Debt Statistics
Demographic indicators: IBGE website, www.ibge.gov.br
Exchange rate: IFS, various issues; market rates expressed as Reals per US$1
GDP growth by demand component: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; 1995 prices
GDP per head: US$ GDP divided by population
Foreign direct investment: UNCTAD, World Investment Report; IFS
Inflation: Índice de Preços ao Consumidor Ampliado (IPCA, a national consumer price index based on surveys in ten cities, December 1993=100), calculated by the IBGE; IBGE website, www.ibge.gov.br
PPP: purchasing power parity, average ratio of prices in Brazil to prices in the US
Real exchange rate: ratio of estimated annual average PPP for tradeable products to annual average exchange rate
Real GDP growth per head: growth in real GDP divided by population growth
Total external debt: sum of long-term and short-term debt, plus arrears; World Bank, International Debt Statistics
US$ GDP at PPP: IFS, various issues; local currency GDP, converted to US$ at the estimated annual average PPP for consumer products
US$ GDP: IFS, various issues; in current prices, converted from local currency at annual average market exchange rates

Guide to the business rankings model Outline of the model The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2016-20) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2021-25). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2016-20. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2021-25 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2016-20 ranges are then used to derive 2021-25 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2021-25, not to the likely situation in 2025 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2018 or 2023). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+Venezuela&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+Venezuela+April+2021+Updater&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2021-04-01&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+Venezuela&amp;rft.issn=09669574&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: - Despite Venezuela's socioeconomic collapse and the ongoing coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the civic-military regime, led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela, to retain power throughout the 2021-25 forecast period. Mr Maduro's position will be supported primarily by his grip over a complex security apparatus and the opposition's lack of de facto power. On this basis, we expect continued deterioration of the economy, sustained outward migration, and a poorer and more violent Venezuela. Despite US sanctions (and their impact on oil production), the Maduro regime has managed internal dissent through a patronage system that rewards loyalty, as well as through its strict control over the security forces.
- The scale of the socioeconomic collapse and the elevated level of political instability will ensure that the Maduro regime continues to be challenged both economically and politically. In particular, there is a significant risk of regime change stemming from a possible breakdown in the patronage system that sustains the security forces' support of the regime. Under our baseline forecast, we assume that Mr Maduro will avoid this, as oil revenue should pick up from a trough in 2020. However, there are substantial risks to this assumption, given the scale of operational difficulties and the lack of incentives for investment in the Venezuelan oil industry.
- De facto dollarisation of the economy is expanding. Concurrently, the government has taken measures that have allowed the official exchange rate to float. These measures have aided price stability and therefore increased the availability of some basic goods. However, the measures are not a product of economic orthodoxy, but rather of policy decisions to ensure the regime's survival. We do not expect to see the comprehensive economic and institutional reforms that would be required to resolve Venezuela's economic crisis within the forecast period.

- Venezuela ranks 82nd of 82 countries in the global business environment rankings for 2021-25, having been 81st in the 2016-20 historical period, as the economic crisis is deepening despite minor improvements in some areas. Reforms to institutions, economic policy and the business environment are unlikely.

Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2021-22: Expansion of interventionist measures, including price controls. Corruption and selective application of regulations remain common and continue to undermine free competition.
2023-25: Contract rights remain weak, and red tape and ad hoc interventionism continue.
Policy towards foreign investment 2021-22: Most attempts to attract investment prove unsuccessful, owing to political and economic instability.
2023-25: Investment flows remain low amid ongoing economic volatility. Intellectual property protection and private property rights deteriorate.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2021-22: Currency controls are weakened, but access to foreign currency remains limited.
2023-25: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, and de facto dollarisation advances. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves as oil prices rise, albeit slowly.
Taxes 2021-22: Risk of further unrest and political instability reduces probability of tax increases, despite fiscal deficits. Severity of economic crisis precludes major rise in public spending.
2023-25: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but risk of discriminatory, ad hoc tax measures declines.
Financing 2021-22: Inflation remains high and concerns surrounding economic instability restrict financing to only short term.
2023-25: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid, sustainable growth in credit to private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market 2021-22: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage costs. Past emigration of skilled labour aggravates skills shortages.
2023-25: Labour-market rigidities persist despite some increase in flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure 2021-22: Underinvestment in water network and electricity grid leads to continued rationing and unpredictable blackouts.
2023-25: Investors remain highly cautious about committing to long-term capital projects. Infrastructure deteriorates even further.
Technological readiness 2021-22: E-government services remain almost non-existent. Deteriorating infrastructure limits adoption of new technologies. Telecommunications sector is opened to foreign investment, but with little interest.
2023-25: Limited regulatory capacity and years of underinvestment continue to restrict internet and mobile coverage.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s, two parties-Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente-alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in support for both parties and culminated in the 1998 election of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but several attempts to remove him from power before his death in March 2013 proved unsuccessful. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, has seen his own popularity plummet as his macroeconomic mismanagement, combined with strict sanctions on trade from the US, has plunged the country into a state of economic collapse.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is nominally a federal republic with separation of powers, the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) has systematically eroded institutions. In December 2015 the opposition coalition, Mesa de la Unidad Democrática, won control of the unicameral National Assembly. In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature to be in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly granted itself a remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and sidelining the National Assembly. In December 2020 the PSUV and its allies regained control of the legislature in an election that was widely regarded as rigged.
Policy issues: The most pressing policy issue is the need to stabilise an economy that remains mired in a long-standing economic crisis. The monetisation of vast public deficits has created an ever-increasing excess of domestic currency, triggering hyperinflation. Mismanagement of PDVSA (the state-owned oil company and originator of practically all foreign-currency inflows into the country) has resulted in a sharp contraction of oil production. This has restricted foreign-currency supply, giving way to currency controls, the rationing of imports, and the emergence of black markets for both foreign currency and basic goods. The scarcity of foreign exchange has also led to arrears on most of the external debt issued by sovereign and state-owned firms.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 50% for oil firms. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: The goods trade surplus fell to US$10.2bn in 2019 as a long-term decline in oil exports deepened. The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that the trade account deteriorated further in 2020, shifting to a deficit of US$3.2bn

Outlook for 2021-25: Political stability The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the civic-military regime, led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV, the Chavistas), to remain in power throughout the 2021-25 forecast period, despite its failure to stem a long-running socioeconomic and humanitarian crisis. A number of factors underpin our forecast; particularly significant is the regime's strict control over the military, the police and paramilitary forces. This control, which depends on a patronage system that rewards the loyalty of high-ranking officials, will allow the regime to manage internal dissent.
Following a sham legislative election in December 2020, in which the Chavistas retook control of the National Assembly, the regime enjoys virtually unchecked control over all the levers of power. Meanwhile, the domestic opposition, led by Juan Guaidó (the former head of the legislature and self-declared interim president), has been left scrambling without a clear path forward. The opposition's decision to boycott the December election has left it without a voice in any major government institution. Before losing control of the National Assembly, the opposition moved to unilaterally extend its mandate by one year. However, with many lawmakers abstaining from the vote out of fear of reprisals from the Maduro regime, and with key international players including the EU no longer recognising Mr Guaidó as the interim president (but rather as the main opposition leader), the opposition's attempt to extend its mandate lacks clear support and legitimacy.
In practice, the fallout from the election changes little in terms of policymaking; Mr Maduro has long used the executive's sweeping powers, as well as his influence over the highly politicised judiciary, to approve his policy agenda. However, retaking control of the National Assembly is significant insofar as it all but erases any threat that the Guaidó-led opposition might pose to Mr Maduro.
There is, nonetheless, a high degree of risk attached to our forecast that Mr Maduro will remain in power. The uncontrolled spread of the coronavirus (Covid-19), diminished oil rents-resulting from severe mismanagement of the sector, and more recently from US sanctions-and persistent goods shortages all present hefty challenges to the survival of the regime. In our view, there are three main paths to a change of government: military intervention, a negotiated transition or some sort of internal coup. We believe that the prospect of military action by the US or Colombia is very low. Notwithstanding efforts by the US to increase multilateral engagement, a negotiated transition would also be difficult, as trust issues between the two sides are insurmountable. Bearing this in mind, we believe that the most likely scenario for regime change is an internal coup. The regime's main weakness is the fragility of its internal finances. Its patronage system is crucial for sustaining its security apparatus and resisting social unrest. US sanctions will exacerbate the already poor macroeconomic environment and limit the country's ability to draw in US dollar finance. The regime will continue to benefit from funds from drug-trafficking and illegal mining activities, but a lack of hard currency could prove fatal to the patronage system, and will test the regime's ability to maintain cohesion among its ranks and control over the security apparatus. The regime's liquidity problems-along with the deepening socioeconomic and humanitarian crisis-could therefore prompt putsch attempts in the near term.
Outlook for 2021-25: Election watch Venezuela held a legislative election in December 2020 to select the 277 members of the unicameral National Assembly. The vote, which was boycotted by most opposition parties, was widely regarded as being neither free nor fair. The results were therefore unsurprising; the Gran Polo Patriótico, an electoral alliance dominated by the PSUV, won an overwhelming supermajority of 256 seats in the legislature.
Next on the electoral calendar are regional elections (to elect governors and state legislative assemblies), due by end-2021, followed by local elections (to elect mayors and councillors) in 2022. However, we now believe that the local elections will be brought forward to 2021, following a move in early March by lawmakers to repeal the law that regularises the constitutional terms of state and local governments. In a context where the PSUV already controls more than 85% of governorships and mayoralties, the political benefits of consolidating power at the sub-national level will be modest. Consequently, we believe that the regime will endeavour to use negotiations over electoral conditions as a step towards gaining international legitimacy and some degree of sanctions relief. At present, we remain sceptical that the regime will acquiesce to conditions that would ensure a level playing field, and we consider that prospects for sanctions relief are dim.
Against this backdrop, the key question for the opposition will be whether to participate in elections, with the game rigged against it. We believe that some factions are likely to participate-even under unfair conditions-in a bid to make inroads into a political system from which they have been shut out. However, any gains will be modest and will not alter the fundamental balance of power.
Outlook for 2021-25: International relations The Maduro regime's main foreign policy challenge will centre on managing its combative ties with the US. The administration led by the former US president, Donald Trump (2017-21), instituted several rounds of crippling oil sanctions as part of a "maximum pressure" campaign designed to undermine the regime's finances (and therefore its patronage system) in order to force Mr Maduro to hold free and fair elections. Although the aggressive sanctions policy did not produce its intended outcome, it did accelerate the decline of Venezuela's oil industry. Mr Maduro will look to reset ties with the US under the new president, Joe Biden, but we expect little progress. US policy towards Venezuela has bipartisan support in the US, and Mr Biden is unlikely to provide significant sanctions relief absent major political compromises and commitments to democratic reforms from the Maduro regime (which remain highly improbable). Any changes to US sanctions policy will therefore be only on humanitarian grounds, aimed at improving the lives of the poorest Venezuelans. For instance, we expect the Biden administration to reverse course on recently instated sanctions on crude-for-diesel swaps, which are mainly used by the regime to shore up diesel supplies for power generation, agricultural activity, water pumps and public transport.
Iran recently became Mr Maduro's main international backer. In 2020 Iran sent more than 2.5m barrels of petrol to Venezuela (in exchange for gold shipments) to alleviate the country's severe petrol shortages. An additional 677,000 barrels have already been sent in 2021 (mostly in exchange for jet fuel).
Venezuela's other major allies, including Russia and China, seem unwilling to provide the financing-amounting to tens of billions of US dollars per year-required to stabilise the economy and secure the long-term future of PDVSA (the state oil company). Mr Maduro has openly courted both countries but has had little success in securing finance for investment.
Outlook for 2021-25: Policy trends The Maduro regime's immediate policy priorities will be to contain the public health crisis caused by the coronavirus outbreak and to halt a long-running economic collapse. In January, in order to address the community spread of the coronavirus, the regime reintroduced the "Fórmula 7+7 Plus" strategy, which involves alternating between a week of tighter restrictions (when non-essential shops and services are closed) and a week of more relaxed restrictions (when those businesses may open). However, this will not prevent Venezuela's decrepit medical infrastructure from being overwhelmed, and the regime will therefore be forced to implement even stricter mobility restrictions intermittently. Concurrently, efforts by the regime to procure vaccines are making little headway. So far, Venezuela has received 200,000 doses of Russia's Sputnik V vaccine and 500,000 doses of China's Sinopharm vaccine. Mr Maduro says that a total of 10m Sputnik V doses will arrive this year, but the Russian authorities have not confirmed a purchase agreement. The government hopes to obtain 1.4m-2.4m vaccine doses through the WHO-led COVAX Facility, but funding issues and the politicisation of vaccine distribution will hinder procurement. Against this backdrop, we do not expect that enough doses of the vaccine will be distributed to have a significant impact on local transmission until 2023.
Addressing the long-running economic decline will be a similarly difficult task. Mr Maduro will continue a process of gradual economic liberalisation in order to draw in private investment. In October 2020 the regime promulgated an anti-blockade law, which gives the executive branch the unchecked authority to sign confidential new deals with private firms and countries (in an attempt to skirt international sanctions). In November the regime used the law to sell Agropatria, a state-owned agricultural firm, to Grupo Agrollano, a private company of unknown origin. We expect that the regime will similarly seek to reprivatise a number of other businesses that had been expropriated by Mr Maduro's predecessor, Hugo Chávez (1999-2013), but were run aground by cronyism and mismanagement. The regime will also encourage greater private-sector participation in the oil industry, but it will refrain from outright privatisation of PDVSA. These efforts are unlikely to yield significant results; even assuming that the regime is able to sidestep financial sanctions, it will struggle to attract new investment, given the abysmal business environment and a lack of confidence in the rule of law.
Outlook for 2021-25: Fiscal policy The authorities have not published complete data on the fiscal accounts since 2011. However, we expect that a high level of inefficient current expenditure, combined with an extremely weak revenue intake, will keep the budget deficit wide and the public debt/GDP ratio astronomical throughout the 2021-25 forecast period. The sovereign's default on most of its interest and principal repayments will curb government spending. The regime relies heavily on monetisation to fund its deficits, driving hyperinflation and the rationing of foreign currency. Money printing will continue to finance the government's deficits in 2021-25. The sovereign is in arrears on virtually all of its interest and principal repayments, and we do not expect any debt restructuring in 2021-25. Moreover, the existence of considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing-mainly PDVSA-issued debt and development funds from China-understates the true size of total public liabilities.
Outlook for 2021-25: Monetary policy Monetary policy will remain subservient to fiscal policy, as the Banco Central de Venezuela (BCV, the central bank) continues to print money to finance the government's gaping budget deficits. The BCV has, in recent years, taken steps to control growth of monetary aggregates. For instance, in early 2019 it lifted the cash reserve ratio (CRR) to 100%; although it has relaxed the CRR slightly since that peak, as at January 2021 it remained at an extremely high 85%. Moreover, far from taming inflation, these measures have led to the complete destruction of private-sector credit; in January the stock of real private-sector credit was less than 1% of what it was four years ago.
These factors have accelerated the trend towards greater use of US dollars in the economy. According to private-sector estimates, two-thirds of all financial transactions are now made in US dollars. This share is likely to rise further following Mr Maduro's January announcement that banks would be authorised to expand the use of foreign-currency bank accounts. The regime has even allowed private companies to issue debt in hard currency in order to raise finance; in November 2020 Ron Santa Teresa became the first company in more than two decades to issue dollar-denominated bonds (worth US$300,000) on the Caracas Stock Exchange. Although progress will be gradual, we believe that Venezuela is ultimately headed towards overall de facto dollarisation.
Outlook for 2021-25: Economic growth After an estimated contraction in real GDP of 31% in 2020 (and a cumulative contraction of almost 77% since 2013), we forecast marginally positive growth of 0.7% in 2021. GDP is now strongly correlated with oil production. Having plummeted to an average of 500,000 barrels/day in 2020-its lowest level in several decades-crude production will stabilise in 2021 as global energy demand starts to recover. PDVSA's ability to ramp up oil production more significantly will be limited, given the absence of any active oil rigs in the country. Moreover, prospects for investment are bleak: at present, Venezuela's average break-even price is about US$15-20/barrel. However, US sanctions on the regime raise the risks involved in dealing with Venezuela, forcing the country to offer a hefty discount on its crude. This means that, at current market prices, Venezuela is making only a limited profit (its oil basket traded at an estimated US$43/b in February). That said, there are some upside risks to our assumptions. Oil prices are rising, giving potential buyers stronger incentives to find ways around US sanctions. Moreover, even in the absence of active rigs, it is possible that PDVSA could extract more crude than we anticipate from existing oil wells. For its part, the non-oil economy will see little improvement, especially as an uncontrolled pandemic limits prospects for services activities.
We expect growth to pick up in 2022, assuming that oil prices remain supportive and that producers continue to adapt to post-sanctions export markets. However, serious operational problems (such as difficulties in obtaining equipment for repairs and finding qualified staff), a limited pool of buyers of Venezuelan crude and the weak long-term fundamentals of the oil market will cause growth to taper off towards the end of our forecast period. The non-oil economy will also make modest gains in 2022-25, assuming that continued dollarisation supports relative macroeconomic stability. Nonetheless, we expect that Venezuela's GDP (in real terms) will be only about half its 2018 level, even in 2025.
Outlook for 2021-25: Inflation A severely reduced domestic goods supply, constraints on import capacity and the monetisation of large public deficits will impede the disinflationary process in 2021-25. The regime has shown little inclination to take on the fiscal and macroeconomic reforms that would address the root causes of inflation. It has, however, lent its support to an ongoing process of de facto dollarisation, which will help to ease price pressures over time.
Outlook for 2021-25: Exchange rates Hyperinflation will sustain bolívar depreciation in 2021. Given incessant inflation and its effect on nominal values, we believe that another currency redenomination (as in March 2018) or a new currency is a strong possibility. Even though a number of currency regulations officially remain on the books, the regime has largely stopped enforcing them in its recent embrace of dollarisation. Although a black market for US dollars continues to operate, the premium is modest compared with previous years. On March 18th the black-market exchange rate stood at BsS1,835,391:US$1, only marginally above the official exchange rate of BsS1,804,994:US$1.
Outlook for 2021-25: External sector Balance-of-payments pressures will remain severe in 2021-25, contributing to goods shortages and economic inequities. Foreign reserves stood at US$6.3bn in February-their lowest level in three decades. The steep decline in reserves, which has been several years in the making, reflects poor policymaking and a lack of economic diversification in the country's external sector.
Under our baseline forecast, we expect reserves to rise modestly over the forecast period, reaching US$8.2bn by end-2025. We expect this increase to be driven entirely by trends on the current account, as Venezuela's access to foreign capital will remain extremely limited. We expect the current-account balance to shift from an estimated deficit of 7.2% of GDP in 2020 to a surplus of 1.8% of GDP in 2021. Thereafter, it will remain in surplus, averaging 2.6% of GDP in 2022-25. Our forecast rests on the assumption that export earnings will pick up from a nadir in 2020 as international oil prices recover and the country steps up trade with new buyers in Asia. We also expect that workers' remittances from abroad will play a crucial role in propping up the current-account balance as Venezuelan emigrants are gradually absorbed into the labour markets in their host countries.

Full text: - The tenure of the president, Muhammadu Buhari, will last until 2023 and be blemished by a decline in living standards caused by recession in 2020, a rise in unemployment and (paradoxically) high, policy-induced inflation.
- The administration will struggle to tackle high levels of poverty and the country's ethnic and religious divisions. This potent mixture has the potential to cause protests that halt the advancement of pro-market reforms.
- A decline in living standards under Mr Buhari, whose tenure has been marked by two recessions, as well as frustrations over pervasive insecurity and poor governance means that the opposition People's Democratic Party (PDP) is forecast to win the 2023 election.
- The Economist Intelligence Unit expects some reregulation of electricity pricing under a PDP government. Although this would be bad news for the power sector, we do not expect a return to distortive pricing in the petroleum sector.
- Official currency transactions will migrate over to a more market-led exchange rate used by investors and exporters, simplifying the multiple exchange-rate regime. However, the naira will be overvalued by the central bank and subject to periodic corrections, as expected in 2021 and 2025.
- Large recurrent government spending commitments will result in another substantial fiscal deficit in 2021, by Nigerian standards. The budget shortfall will then broadly edge down as external conditions improve, the domestic economy picks up and revenue rises.
- Given a crippling infrastructure deficit, high inflation, instability in crucial agricultural regions and high unemployment, we expect growth of just 1.2% in 2021. Only when the exchange rate and inflation stabilise will there be a more meaningful recovery.
- Inflation will stay high in 2021 as devaluation of the naira, instability in agricultural growing areas, monetary loosening and exchange-rate restrictions for staple imports feed into consumer prices. Monetary tightening is expected to start from 2022 to tackle the issue.
- We expect a current-account deficit for a third consecutive year in 2021 (something that has not been seen since the 1990s), despite an increase in world oil prices. The current account will return to surplus in 2022-25 as the oil market recovers and petrol import volumes decline.

- Nigeria's business environment score worsens slightly for the forecast period (2021-25) as the macroeconomic and security environment remains highly challenging. As a result, its global and regional rankings fall.

Country forecast overview: Nigeria's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2021-22: The overarching policy objective is to promote self-sufficiency and local industrialisation through protectionism. As a result, the non-oil sector is be largely shielded from external competition.
2023-25: A new government (which is likely to be opposition-led) is likely to remain wary of opening up the economy.
Policy towards foreign investment 2021-22: A reduction is made to royalties for offshore oil activity introduced in 2020 in an attempt to prevent divestment from oil majors operating in Nigeria. Outside the oil sector, concerns over the foreign-exchange regime deter investment.
2023-25: Energy firms remain hesitant about increasing their presence in a difficult operating environment, especially onshore, but concerted efforts are made to clean up the national oil company (which is in joint venture with oil majors).
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2021-22: Movement of goods is highly regulated to prevent smuggling, but people will be allowed to cross land borders once the coronavirus pandemic is brought under control.
2023-25: A spread between the official and the parallel-market exchange rates persists as oil prices rise and the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) is again able to defend an overvalued official exchange rate.
Taxes 2021-22: The focus on boosting tax compliance intensifies, but the weak state of the economy and upcoming elections prevent tax increases.
2023-25: Value-added tax (VAT) is raised from 7.5% to cut the budget deficit amid persistently high debt-servicing costs.
Financing 2021-22: The government returns to the sovereign debt market, and capital projects are restarted.
2023-25: Credit conditions become tighter as the CBN moves to control high inflation.
The labour market 2021-22: Employers face major problems, including a shortage of skilled manual workers, restrictive visa regulations and poor health indicators.
2023-25: Employers continue to struggle to find qualified staff; unemployment stays high and the labour market loose.
Infrastructure 2021-22: A reduction in consumer subsidies (for petrol) frees up resources for higher public capital investment, but government spending remains small relative to the size of the economy, at under 7%.
2023-25: A large private refinery starts up, reducing Nigeria's near-total dependency on imported petrol.
Technological readiness 2021-22: Nigeria retains a vibrant technology sector for an economy at its stage of development, but infrastructure is weak outside urban hubs.
2023-25: Research spending remains low compared with global averages, but some home-grown technology firms looking to adapt global technology trends to the Nigerian market continue to do well.

Background: Nigeria gained independence in 1960, and multi-party democracy was restored in 1999 after a protracted period of military rule. The first two presidential elections (in 1999 and 2003) were both won by a former military ruler turned civilian politician, Olusegun Obasanjo. Mr Obasanjo was unable to change the constitution to allow him to serve a third term in office, so in the 2007 election power passed to his handpicked successor, Umaru Yar'Adua. After Mr Yar'Adua's death in May 2010, his vice-president, Goodluck Jonathan, assumed the presidency and went on to win the 2011 presidential election. In 2015 Mr Jonathan was defeated by Muhammadu Buhari, who secured a second term in early 2019.
Political structure: Under the constitution adopted in May 1999, a strong executive presidency appoints a Federal Executive Council, comprising government ministers and ministers of state from each of Nigeria's 36 states. The executive is accountable to the bicameral National Assembly. Political parties tend to lack clear ideologies; in practice, personal and ethnic ties predominate. The People's Democratic Party (Mr Jonathan's party) had historically been the predominant political force, but the merger in 2013 of three large opposition parties to form the All Progressives Congress gave them, with Mr Buhari at the helm, the reach that they needed to take power in 2015 and secure re-election in 2019.
Policy issues: Successive governments have sought to improve macroeconomic stability and develop the nation's dire infrastructure, with mixed results. The government is struggling to end insecurity in various parts of the country. These tensions are stoked by the underlying problems of poverty and unemployment. Management of the naira by the authorities is a contentious issue, with important subsidy programmes hinging on an overvalued official exchange rate.
Taxation: Corporate profits in most non-oil sectors are taxed at 30%. Planned changes to the tax system for the oil and gas sector have been repeatedly delayed, creating uncertainty. Most other taxes are low, reflecting the fact that most revenue comes from the oil sector, with the total tax take small as a share of GDP. With oil prices far lower than they were in 2010-14, it is likely that amendments to consumer taxes will be made, specifically in value-added tax (VAT, currently 7.5%).
Foreign trade: Exports are dominated by oil. The slump in oil prices from the second half of 2014 wiped out what had historically been a large current-account surplus. The non-oil export base has been rendered globally uncompetitive by massive infrastructure deficiencies.

Outlook for 2021-25: Political stability The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the president, Muhammadu Buhari, to stay in power until his second (and final) term expires in 2023. He will be under immense pressure to stabilise Nigeria, but myriad security threats will prove unmanageable. The military and police are overstretched and unable to tackle simultaneous security crises. Emergencies will be triaged, with military resources deployed to whichever is considered the most pressing.
This shaky system will keep the government in power but leave the country highly dysfunctional and, in many regions, extremely insecure. The government will remain embroiled in a long drawn-out conflict with Boko Haram and Islamic State of West Africa Province (ISWAP), two Islamist terrorist groups firmly ensconced in north-eastern Nigeria. As the region is a stronghold of the ruling party, the All Progressives Congress (APC), the president will be committed to asserting control, irrespective of how difficult this will be. Boko Haram and ISWAP will be aggressively countered, but the north-east-particularly Borno state-will remain a low-level conflict zone, and the campaign there will divert security forces away from other insecure parts of Nigeria.
The military and police will be poorly equipped to suppress pervasive banditry and kidnapping, particularly in the north-west. There is also evidence of terrorist groups operating more openly in that region, highlighted by recent mass school kidnappings. Over 2021-25 the north-west could begin to resemble the highly insecure north-east as, essentially, a "no-go" zone.
One hotspot that will remain neglected is the agricultural Middle Belt, where violent conflict between farmers and herdsmen over increasingly scarce land and water resources has killed thousands in recent years. Formal land-titling is often touted as a solution to the crisis; however, as it would in effect alienate one group from communal holdings in favour of another, it would prove too contentious. As with the north-east, the direct effects of the conflict will be localised, but the entire country will feel the fallout in the form of reduced local food production and high prices.
Nigeria's federal government has weathered severe but localised (largely rural) security problems for several decades without overall stability being jeopardised, but the near- to medium-term outlook is made more uncertain by the scars of recession in 2020 and by rising levels of unemployment and poverty. Declining living standards arguably exacerbated and prolonged protests over police brutality that broke out in cities across southern Nigeria in October 2020. Avoiding a repeat of these will be paramount for Mr Buhari's administration, and a pro-market reform agenda that made impressive headway in 2020, with subsidies reduced on fuel and electricity, is judged to have slowed. Should protests break out again, concessions can be expected.
Outlook for 2021-25: Election watch The next national elections are due in 2023. In the most recent presidential election, in 2019, the candidates of both main parties were from the north, and custom dictates that the candidates in 2023 will be from the south. This should lead to an improvement on the abysmally low turnout in 2019 in the south, which is a stronghold of the main opposition party, the People's Democratic Party (PDP). Frustration with high prices, declining living standards and perpetual instability will be directed at the APC, giving the PDP a winning edge.
Outlook for 2021-25: International relations Nigeria will remain a major player in Africa given its size, but its domestic challenges tend to keep policymakers inwardly focused. Land borders that were closed to goods since late 2019 have reopened, but Nigeria's government is unlikely to show much enthusiasm over encouraging regional trade, beyond its obligations under the African Continental Free Trade Agreement (AfCTFA). The trade pact compels Nigeria to eliminate 97% of tariff lines over the next five to ten years. This deadline will not be met early, given high prices in Nigeria and declining external competitiveness for industries that could otherwise benefit from regional market access.
Outlook for 2021-25: Policy trends Nigeria's government and the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) will aggressively promote local industry, but some elements of policy are contradictory and will contribute to macroeconomic imbalances. An important theme for inward investment will be management of the naira. A ban on foreign-exchange access for imports of certain manufactures and agricultural goods (covering 45 items) is being enforced to protect local industry and support the currency, but has some major flaws. Most notably, restrictions are elevating inflation and undermining the currency regime through sustained real effective exchange-rate (REER) appreciation. Despite this, currency restrictions are expected to last throughout the forecast period, being central to the CBN's economic development strategy.
The government has announced that henceforth it will conduct official foreign-exchange transactions using the Nigerian autonomous foreign-exchange fixing (NAFEX) rate, which was previously used only by exporters and investors. This is tantamount to devaluation and has been touted by officials as the adoption of a "market-determined" currency. However, a wide spread between the NAFEX and parallel-market rates confirms overvaluation of the former, and the CBN continues to insist that the structure of the foreign-exchange market is unaltered. The adoption of a fully market-determined currency is not expected in 2021-25, with the CBN adamant that such a move would lead to an overshoot and an inflationary spiral.
Faced with hard currency shortages in 2020, the CBN has allowed a backlog of foreign-exchange orders from investors and importers to accumulate. Market turnover has recently edged up, but the backlog will only be cleared slowly in 2021 to modulate capital outflows, further undermining the currency regime's reputation. A pattern of inflexibility by the CBN in the wake of oil price shocks (with similarly severe foreign-exchange shortages in 2015-16) will have a long-term impact on confidence, and partly explains our projection for foreign direct investment to equal 1% of GDP or less throughout the forecast period.
Over time the contradiction between protectionism and the AfCFTA's principles will become increasingly conspicuous, but we do not expect an immediate change in strategy given that non-tariff barriers will be phased out over several years. Developing manufacturing and agriculture is likely to be viewed as a means of preparing for the eventual elimination of tariffs, with currency controls expected to play a role in hastening the process. However, an infrastructure deficit, REER appreciation and instability in agricultural heartlands mean that Nigeria will struggle to acquire new comparative advantages in 2021-25, leaving the fiscal and external accounts and the naira exposed to oil price swings.
Price controls will be another important area of economic policy. Astonishing strides towards the deregulation of petrol and electricity pricing were made in 2020, but electricity price increases have already been scaled down in the face of political pressure, and the same process is beginning with petrol subsidies, now that crude oil prices are rising. A permanent reinstatement of petrol price controls is made unlikely by a new Petroleum Industry Bill (PIB) that we expect to be passed in 2021. The legislation is likely to streamline sector-wide regulation in the process of creating a new, profit-oriented national oil company, which by definition could not be weighed down by subsidising the retail market. The downstream industry should become commercially viable from this reorganisation of the sector, allowing Nigeria to wean itself off petrol imports, with a new 650,000-barrels/day refinery expected to come on stream in 2022. The PIB will also encourage upstream oil investment by making fiscal terms clearer for multinationals. For the PIB to make sense, petrol price subsidies will need to end before it is enacted. However, we do not expect the sustained electricity price increases that are needed for the power sector to become financially sound, and pricing in the sector remains regulated de jure. Electricity undersupply will therefore continue to hinder industrialisation.
Outlook for 2021-25: Fiscal policy We expect the fiscal account to stay in deficit in 2021-25. Receipts from crude oil make up more than 50% of the federal government's retained income, and an average international oil price of US$64.3/barrel in 2021-25 will be insufficient to balance the budget. The federal government's tax take is among the worlds lowest, owing to widespread evasion and a large informal sector. Value-added tax (VAT, currently of 7.5%) is viewed by the authorities as the most effective means of increasing fiscal receipts, and we expect three equal VAT rate increases, taking the rate to 15% by 2025. The first is expected in 2022, prior to the next elections but seemingly inevitable given a rising debt load. Further increases are expected in 2024 and 2025. Even then, our federal revenue projection peaks at just 4.9% of GDP in 2024, which also factors in no fuel subsidies after 2021 (costs for which are deducted from revenue). Set against this, high debt-servicing costs, a large public wage bill and healthcare commitments-including procurement of coronavirus (Covid-19) vaccines-will elevate expenditure. Capital investment will also be emphasised to compensate for the ending of petrol subsidies. The government justified price deregulation by promising to invest the savings in infrastructure and will be under pressure to match rhetoric with action (assuming that the PIB is enacted and subsidies end in 2021).
Overall, we expect the fiscal deficit to decline to 3.2% of GDP in 2021 (from 3.7% of GDP in 2020) as international oil prices rise. VAT hikes will lead the ratio to fall to 2.5% of GDP in 2024, but a fall in average international oil prices in 2025 will lead to the shortfall widening to 2.8% of GDP in 2025. The government has raised its public debt limit to 40% of GDP to incorporate higher budget shortfalls over the medium-term and to accommodate securitisation of CBN deficit financing as long-term debt. We expect the ratio to reach only 32% of GDP in 2025.
Outlook for 2021-25: Monetary policy The CBN will fail to keep inflation below a target ceiling of 9%, and its policy decisions are likely to be erratic. In 2020, given a probable recession and limited fiscal firepower, it decided to cut the policy rate by a cumulative 100 basis-points. The rate has been kept at 11.5% despite an upward trend in annual inflation (which reached 17.3% in February). The strategy in place is to boost the supply side of the economy and thereby control inflation. We believe this is misguided; high and rising inflation will frustrate an economic recovery, and issues such as inadequate public infrastructure, direct funding of the fiscal deficit, hard-currency shortages and rampant instability need to be addressed before the supply side can moderate the price level. We expect high inflation to persist, compelling the CBN to raise interest rates in 2022, despite still-weak economic growth. There is a distinct risk (to this forecast) of the CBN tightening earlier, given escalating inflation, but we expect a reversion to price subsidies in early/mid-2021 to provide space for the CBN to hold steady. Easing will resume only in 2024, when inflation has fallen appreciably.
Outlook for 2021-25: Economic growth The economy is expected to exit recession in 2021 as the impact of lockdown in 2020 fades, but high inflation will impede improvements in business sentiment and dampen real purchasing power amid high levels of unemployment (at about one-third of the labour force) and low nominal wage growth. Fiscal stimulus will be an inadequate counterforce given budget constraints, and loosened monetary policy will pressurise the naira, creating a scarcity of foreign exchange and further undermining macroeconomic stability. Oil export volumes will rise slightly, however, as quotas agreed by OPEC+ (comprising OPEC and a group of non-OPEC countries) are relaxed, encouraging growth of 1.2% in 2021.
The CBN is expected to tighten monetary policy from 2022, which will circumscribe the nascent economic recovery, but the exchange rate should stabilise and cause inflation to ease, allowing for stronger growth. As non-business financial penetration is low, private consumption will recover alongside disinflation even as interest rates rise. New refining capacity is also expected to come on stream in earnest, boosting net exports (some output will be for the regional market, and Nigeria's import dependency for fuel will decline). Crude oil exports are also expected to increase as prices rise, resulting in growth of 3% in 2022. As refinery output continues to ramp up, crude oil exports rise, inflation falls and real spending power recovers, growth will pick up to an annual average of 3.8% in 2023-24. However, these rates of growth are well below potential. The economy will continue to lack dynamism owing to high interest rates, low foreign direct investment, high unemployment, pervasive instability in agricultural regions and infrastructure deficiencies, particularly regarding stable power supply. A more challenging year is forecast for 2025 as oil prices fall and macroeconomic uncertainty rises, with growth slipping to 1.7%.
Outlook for 2021-25: Inflation In 2021 we expect inflation to average 17%, with increases on both core and non-core levels. Although our projection for oil prices has increased, a covert return to subsidies over part of the year will delay the impact. High inflation will nonetheless stem from past increases at the pump and the lingering pass-through of raised electricity tariffs in 2020, foreign-exchange restrictions on various imported goods, including staple foods, and devaluation of the naira. Assuming that the exchange rate stabilises and that the CBN tightens monetary policy, we expect the annual inflation rate to fall to an average of 10% in 2024. Conflict in the Middle Belt-Nigeria's breadbasket-foreign-exchange controls on imported goods and an eventual return to pricing petrol at the market rate will prevent a faster fall. Currency devaluation in 2025 will cause the average rate to increase again, to 12.5% that year.
Outlook for 2021-25: Exchange rates Nigeria's government has declared that official transactions will shift from the CBN rate (N379:US$1) to the NAFEX rate (N409:US$1 in late March), essentially consolidating the two via devaluation and in effect making the official rate obsolete. The NAFEX rate-established in 2017-is more flexible than the official rate but is nonetheless tightly managed by the CBN and overvalued, as evidenced by a parallel rate of N483:US$1.
Foreign reserves have been declining since January, and the CBN is yet to clear a backlog of hard-currency orders, indicating that the draw-down is partly being caused by a net outflow on current transactions, despite firmer oil prices. REER appreciation is a leading factor behind the external imbalance, and in the CBN's defence of reserves, we expect an adjustment to N422:US$1 by end-year. Following this we expect the current account to return to surplus in 2022-24, while monetary tightening in Nigeria will attract hot-money inflows. This should allow the CBN to keep the exchange rate broadly stable. Unceasing currency misalignment means that REER appreciation will nonetheless resurface and, with oil prices expected to slide again in 2025, another devaluation to N485:US$1 is expected.
Outlook for 2021-25: External sector Assuming that devaluation moderates import demand for goods and services, and with global crude prices rising and inward transfers increasing as the global economy returns to growth, we expect a current-account deficit equal to 0.7% of GDP in 2021, down from 3.9% of GDP in 2020. Over the remainder of the forecast period we expect a small current-account surplus. Oil prices are projected to stay relatively high in 2022-23, supporting exports, while lower petroleum import volumes (as new domestic refinery capacity comes on stream) will constrain growth in the import bill (which is otherwise driven by real naira appreciation). Remittances from the large Nigerian diaspora should also recover to pre-pandemic levels, together with global GDP gains. This will all contribute to an annual average current-account surplus of 1% of GDP in 2022-24. The surplus will then narrow to 0.6% of GDP in 2025 as falling oil prices push down export earnings and continued REER appreciation encourages imports. The deficit in 2021 will be financed largely by debt inflows, with investment inflows limited by a dysfunctional foreign-exchange market.

FDI: IFS, UNCTAD, World Investment Report and CBN

Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end medium- and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding, with an original maturity of more than one year
Short-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end debt outstanding, with an original maturity of less than one year
IMF credits: IFS and country page on website
Total debt service: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges on total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services

Abstract: The European Central Bank (ECB) has its policy rate set at -0.5%, and has expanded its net asset purchases to EUR1.85trn (over 10% of euro zone GDP) as part of its emergency programme. Full text: - At the federal election on September 26th Angela Merkel will step down from her 16-year tenure as chancellor, and The Economist Intelligence Unit's core forecast is that a coalition will be formed between the Christian Democratic Union (CDU) and The Greens, although risks to this have risen in recent weeks, as a variety of issues have dampened CDU support. We expect Markus Söder, the minister-president of Bavaria and leader of the CDU's sister party, the Christian Social Union (CSU), to be chosen as the CDU's chancellor-candidate.
- The top policy goal at present is to stimulate the economic recovery, which requires the pandemic to be controlled and vaccinations rolled out. Following the federal election, we expect policymaking to remain centrist, consensus-oriented and pro-Western, with a strong degree of continuity from the current administration. However, green policymaking will gain additional importance.
- After a 5.3% fall in real GDP in 2020, we forecast 3.5% growth in 2021, with the recovery gaining pace in the second half of the year and the economy returning to its 2019 size by 2022. Germany's large manufacturing sector, which has close export links with the rapidly recovering Chinese market, has proved a structural advantage during the pandemic. Forced savings, pent-up demand and an extended wage support scheme will boost private consumption once the lockdown ends. We forecast 2.4% annual average growth in 2022-25.
- Monetary and fiscal policy levers are being used to the full to limit the fallout from the crisis. The European Central Bank (ECB) has its policy rate set at -0.5%, and has expanded its net asset purchases to EUR1.85trn (over 10% of euro zone GDP) as part of its emergency programme.
- Germany's fiscal policy response in 2020 was the largest in Europe. Provisional data indicate a 4.8% of GDP deficit in 2020 (although this does not reflect substantial loan guarantees from the state development bank, KfW), and fiscal support will continue in 2021. We expect political pressure to ensure a return to fiscal consolidation from 2022, although rising pension and healthcare commitments will maintain small deficits (around 1% of GDP) in 2023-25.
- Germany's large-and often controversial-current-account surpluses will persist, owing to huge trade surpluses and large domestic savings invested abroad. The current-account surplus dipped slightly in 2020, to an estimated 6.9% of GDP, and we expect it to remain a broadly similar size as a share of GDP.

- The business environment ranking improves strongly as the economic context stabilises. Germany benefits from political stability, a skilled labour force, openness to external trade and investment, and developed infrastructure.

Country forecast overview: Germany's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2021-22: Significantly increased levels of state involvement in the economy decline only gradually, with pockets of market distortion. Likely review (and gradual tightening) of recently loosened EU state aid rules amid "level playing field" concerns.
2023-25: Limited prospects for reforming regulated service professions. State intervention pushes green and digital goals.
Policy towards foreign investment 2021-22: Policy still broadly welcoming towards greenfield foreign direct investment, but further tightening of foreign takeover rules and investment screening (particularly for non-EU inflows), amid concerns over intellectual property leakage.
2023-25: Geopolitical fallout from the pandemic encourages support for "strategic sectors" and industrial sovereignty.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2021-22: Moderate bounce-back in world trade, but pressure on German export sector eases only gradually, given subdued global demand, ongoing US-China trade tensions and supply-chain disruption. EU-Mercosur trade deal delays continue.
2023-25: Steady decline in post-Brexit UK-EU crossborder trade. EU makes further gradual progress on bilateral trade deals.
Taxes 2021-22: No changes planned to headline tax rates. New modest tax-relief measures in 2021 (higher tax-free allowance and benefits) amid wider accommodative stance. Value-added tax (VAT) cut in hospitality sector extended to end-2022.
2023-25: Increased focus on environmental taxes. Comparatively high labour tax burden persists. Possible new digital taxes.
Financing 2021-22: Monetary policy remains highly accommodative, holding down banks' funding costs but also margins and profitability. Most business lending risk during the pandemic assumed by state-backed loan-guarantee schemes.
2023-25: Operating conditions for banks remain challenging. Ongoing efforts to attract financial services firms from the UK.
The labour market 2021-22: The Kurzarbeit wage-subsidy scheme remains in place until at least end-2021. Gradual tightening of some parameters.
2023-25: Risk of unequal scarring effects hitting less-protected labour market groups, such as young and older workers, and part-time female cohort. Rising structural challenges posed by ageing demographics and increasing share of migrant workers.
Infrastructure 2021-22: Higher investment in healthcare. Focus on improvements to rail network and digital infrastructure, such as ultra-fast broadband. Ongoing energy transition focuses on emissions and coal-usage reduction, and improvement of power grid.
2023-25: Steady rollout of policy measures to meet medium-term climate targets, including gradual phase-out of coal.
Technological readiness 2021-22: The government prioritises upgrading the country's digital infrastructure and investing in artificial intelligence.
2023-25: Efforts continue on the Industry 4.0 initiative, which focuses on upgrading manufacturing prowess through increased use of automation and connected systems. Increasing threat from cybercrime and cyber-espionage.
