Background: The modern German state was founded in 1870. After the second world war (1939-45), Germany was divided into two parts: a liberal parliamentary democracy in the west and a totalitarian communist regime in the east. On October 3rd 1990, after the end of the Soviet Union's hegemony in central and eastern Europe, Germany was reunified.
Political structure: Germany is a federation of 16 states, or Länder, each of which has its own constitution, government and parliament. The states are primarily responsible for policing and education. The federal parliament comprises the directly elected Bundestag (the lower house) and the Bundesrat (the upper house) of representatives of the state governments. The federal chancellor, the head of the executive, is elected by the Bundestag and can be brought down only by the election of a successor. In March 2018 a grand coalition was once again formed, comprising the centre-right Christian Democratic Union (CDU), its Bavarian sister party, the Christian Social Union (CSU), and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPD).
Policy issues: Short-term priorities focus on the response to the coronavirus pandemic, the resulting economic crisis and the rollout of the vaccination programme. Medium-term priorities include managing the transition of the automotive sector towards lower-emission vehicles; building industrial sovereignty and increasing the resilience of supply chains; managing rising tensions with Russia and China; implementing the rollout of fifth-generation (5G) technology, alongside continuing progress on the Industry 4.0 initiative; and transitioning the energy sector away from coal and nuclear power. Investment spending will increase in our forecast period (2021-25) compared with recent years.
Taxation: The federal corporation tax rate was cut from 25% to 15% in 2008. The effective corporate tax rate, including a municipal trade tax and a solidarity tax, is about 30-33%. The solidarity tax will be phased out from 2021. The top marginal personal income tax rate is 45%. Social security contributions are shared equally between employers and employees. The main value-added tax (VAT) rate is 19%, but was temporarily reduced to 16% during the second half of 2020.
Foreign trade: The goods trade surplus came to US$248.4bn in 2019, with export earnings at almost US$1.5trn and import costs at just over US$1.2trn. Germany's single largest goods export market is still the EU, but the country has been more successful than most in diversifying its markets and selling into fast-growing emerging markets over the past decade.

Outlook for 2021-25: Political stability Angela Merkel, the chancellor, leads a grand coalition comprising the centre-right Christian Democratic Union (CDU)-along with its Bavarian sister party, the Christian Social Union (CSU)-and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPD). At the September federal election, Mrs Merkel will step down from her 16-year tenure as chancellor-a turning-point for Germany's political landscape. However, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects policymaking to remain centrist and consensus-oriented.
Mrs Merkel's already high approval ratings rose during the coronavirus pandemic, with voters reassured by her calm demeanour, respect for scientific advice and recognised ability to manage crises. Germany's response to the public health crisis has been notable for stronger testing than its European peers, and for a more localised response-both made possible by the country's decentralised administrative structure. Excess hospital capacity also proved an advantage. However, the second wave over the winter has seen tensions rise between federal and state-level authorities over the appropriate level of restrictions. Social unrest and "pandemic fatigue" have also emerged, with protests against social distancing and mask-wearing rules, especially in Berlin, the capital. The latest extension of the lockdown, from March 7th to April 18th, proved chaotic, with tough "circuit-breaker" measures over Easter announced and then cancelled in quick succession, giving the sense of a loss of control.
We forecast that the September federal election will lead to a CDU/CSU-Greens coalition, with the CDU's chancellor candidate succeeding Mrs Merkel, although the risks to this have risen in recent weeks (see Election watch). Armin Laschet, the centrist governor of North Rhine-Westphalia, was chosen as the CDU's new party leader in January, but we do not expect him to become the party's chancellor candidate, given his poor poll ratings and disappointing results for the CDU in the first state elections under his tenure, in March. Markus Söder, the CSU leader and governor of Bavaria, has won increasing support among party members and the public during the pandemic. Although he has not yet declared his intention to run, we consider him the most likely choice. The decision on a candidate will be taken in the coming weeks, either by the CDU/CSU leadership or its parliamentary deputies.
We would expect a CDU/CSU-Green coalition to be less fractious than the current coalition, leading to increased political stability. The parties share similar views on economic and climate change policies, and on policy towards Russia. Frictions could be expected on fiscal policy and the controversial debt brake, however, where the CDU/CSU will seek a more hawkish stance, and relations with China, where The Greens will be more openly critical.
Outlook for 2021-25: Election watch The next federal election is scheduled for September 26th, and will result in a change in chancellor for the first time since 2005. In the state elections on March 14th the CDU performed poorly and failed to oust the popular incumbent minister-presidents: Winfried Kretschmann (The Greens) in Baden-Württemberg and Malu Dreyer (SPD) in Rhineland-Palatinate. The CDU/CSU's standing with voters was also damaged in March by the revelation of a corruption scandal around mask procurement in 2020, and a growing sense that the federal government has failed to get a grip on the pandemic's second wave and is presiding over a sluggish vaccination rollout. In the wake of the state elections, public support for the CDU/CSU fell below 30% for the first time since the pandemic emerged, and media speculation about alternatives to the widely expected CDU/CSU-Green coalition in September spiked.
At the federal level, opinion polls from late March show the CDU/CSU polling around 28% (down from 35% in February), The Greens 20%, the SPD 17%, the Alternative for Germany (AfD) 11%, the liberal Free Democratic Party (FDP) 10% and the Left Party 8%. This suggests that a coalition between The Greens, the SPD and the FDP (the so-called traffic-light grouping) could be a feasible possibility, should the polls remain stable. Our core forecast remains that a CDU/CSU-Green coalition is the most likely outcome, as a fall in coronavirus cases, a pick-up in vaccination rates and the selection of Mr Söder as chancellor candidate will ease criticism of the CDU/CSU in the coming months. However, the election looks more open now than previously.
Voter fragmentation will continue in 2021, but parties on the political extremes (the Left Party, and the AfD on the far right) are likely to remain excluded from mainstream debate and from any governing coalition. An SPD-Green-Left Party coalition might be a mathematical possibility, but the uncompromising stance of the Left Party makes this highly unlikely.
Outlook for 2021-25: International relations The European economic recovery fund clears the way for joint debt issuance (worth EUR750bn) to be channelled to EU member states with lower living standards and those hardest hit by the pandemic. From mid-2021 about EUR390bn is to be transferred in grants and the remainder through loans. The size of the fund is modest, but it will help to increase fiscal space in highly leveraged countries; Germany's U-turn on joint debt issuance in May 2020 was crucial to the agreement. The fund is a landmark step for the bloc, as it establishes a precedent for the EU to issue debt to fund common needs.
We expect US-EU relations to improve under the new US president, Joe Biden. Mr Biden will prefer diplomacy to tariffs, reducing the threat of a US-EU trade war (although existing US tariffs will remain in place). He is already returning the US to a number of multilateral platforms, including the Paris Agreement on climate change. However, on other issues-including OECD-level negotiations on a digital services tax, and EU links with China-relations will remain tense.
Various other EU external relations have come under strain. The poisoning and subsequent arrest of Alexei Navalny, a Russian opposition activist, led to new EU sanctions on Russian officials in February; and following the expulsion of European diplomats (including Germans) from Russia, Germany expelled Russian diplomats in response. The EU and China agreed in principle to conclude negotiations on a Comprehensive Agreement on Investment in December, but the ratification process by the European Parliament will be challenging, given European concerns about human rights and labour standards in China, and restrictions on allowing Huawei, a Chinese telecommunications firm, to build fifth-generation (5G) telecoms infrastructure.
Outlook for 2021-25: Policy trends Germany is now experiencing a third wave of the pandemic, which has come hard on the heels of the second wave across Europe. This is putting strains on hospital capacity and rendering the test and trace system ineffective. A new stringent lockdown has been in place since December 16th and has been extended to April 18th. Thereafter, we expect a gradual phase-out of most restrictions in line with quicker progress in Germany's vaccination programme. The vaccine rollout has been sluggish: 13.7 people had been vaccinated per 100 by March 23rd, which is marginally behind the EU average of 13.8, and compares poorly with the UK's 45.9 and the US's 38.3. Nevertheless, we expect that 70% of the population will be vaccinated by September 2021.
The European Commission has temporarily relaxed its state-aid rules, given the exceptional circumstances. We do not expect their reimposition until 2022 or 2023. Germany's state-aid disbursements comprise about half of the EU total. Firms in receipt of state aid may come under pressure to promote sustainability and to pay taxes in Germany rather than in lower-tax jurisdictions.
Other ongoing areas of policy debate include how to build industrial sovereignty, raise the resilience of supply chains and support transformation of the automotive sector towards low-emission vehicles. With The Greens all but certain to join the next federal coalition, the CDU and the SPD will both present policy programmes with a green agenda in 2021. The government's decision to support electric vehicles but not the automotive sector more generally in 2020, despite the industry's large lobby and the fact that it accounts for about 830,000 jobs, is an indication of the policy direction.
Outlook for 2021-25: Fiscal policy After six years of fiscal surpluses, the budget shifted into deficit in 2020. Germany's fiscal support and stimulus programmes are the largest in Europe, with key components including the following:

- the Kurzarbeit programme, a furlough scheme that allows firms to cut employees' working hours without having to lay them off, with the state paying at least 60% of the lost net wage payments until end-2021;
- a EUR50bn solidarity fund to help small businesses and the self-employed, and liquidity support for companies that need assistance in paying loans, irrespective of their size, totalling EUR500bn;
- a EUR3.5bn cash injection into the healthcare system, and transfers to local governments to help to manage the crisis;
- a value-added tax (VAT) cut from 19% to 16% for July-December 2020, and a reduction in VAT for the hard-hit hospitality sector to 7% until mid-2021 and until end-2022 for meals in restaurants and cafés.
- cash transfers to businesses that are forced to close under the winter lockdown, along with new tax deductions announced in February.

Germany's expansionary fiscal policy will persist during 2021; we forecast a deficit of 4% of GDP, compared with 4.8% of GDP in 2020. The Kurzarbeit programme will remain in place throughout the year and capital expenditure will be higher than before the pandemic. Over the next four years, investment will be channelled to a wide range of sectors, from artificial intelligence (AI), to the 5G rollout, to innovation in automotive manufacturers. The health fund will receive a significant boost and a large chunk of the money will go to Germany's national hydrogen strategy, as part of its energy transition.
We expect Germany's public debt to peak at about 71% of GDP at end-2021, from around 60% at end-2019. The government is taking advantage of an exception clause in the country's constitutional debt brake for crisis periods, lifting limits on new borrowing. The brake will remain suspended this year, but fiscal consolidation will then return-bringing the public debt/GDP ratio back to about 65% by end-2025, which is likely to lead to renewed tensions with southern EU members.
Outlook for 2021-25: Monetary policy The monetary policy of the European Central Bank (ECB) will remain highly accommodative until at least the end of 2023. The overnight interbank rate has been negative since October 2014 and averaged -0.48% in February. With policy rates at their effective lower bound, monetary policy is now conducted primarily through quantitative easing (QE). The ECB restarted asset purchases in November 2019 at an average monthly pace of EUR20bn, as the euro zone economy was slowing. In 2020 the bank adopted further stimulus measures to contain the economic disruption caused by the coronavirus: an extra round of QE worth EUR120bn, a EUR1.85trn pandemic emergency purchase programme (PEPP), liquidity injections at negative rates, and easier capital and collateral requirements for banks.
We expect the ECB to use the PEPP envelope in full. Therefore, after EUR1.1trn of total asset purchases in 2020, we expect additional purchases worth around EUR1.1trn in 2021 and EUR460bn in 2022. The bank will maintain its QE programme into 2023, when we forecast that inflation will continue to undershoot its target of just below 2%. We do not expect policy rates to increase by the end of 2025.
In March the ECB committed to front-loading asset purchases in the second quarter of 2021, to offset rising sovereign yields and preserve favourable financing conditions. Euro zone banks tightened credit standards for businesses in the second half of 2020, owing to increased risk perception. However, borrowing costs remain at historically low levels, and we expect this to continue.
Outlook for 2021-25: Economic growth The economy contracted by 5.3% in 2020-the first annual fall since the 5.6% contraction in the wake of the global financial crisis. This was a less severe downturn than in the other major economies in western Europe; real GDP fell by 8.3% in France, 9.9% in the UK and 11% in Spain. Germany's better outturn reflects less stringent lockdowns, high levels of government support and a large manufacturing sector-equivalent to 20% of gross value added, and closely tied to the strongly recovering Chinese market-which was able to continue operating with social-distancing measures in place.
We expect real German GDP to return to 98.1% of its 2019 full-year size in 2021, a quicker recovery than the west European average, with annual growth of 3.5%. The industrial sector has been hit less severely by the second lockdown, and Germany's export-oriented manufacturing firms are benefiting from growing demand in China and other Asian markets. China overtook France as Germany's second-largest export destination in 2020, and our forecast of 8.5% GDP growth in China in 2021 will keep demand for German exports elevated. Consumers will maintain high precautionary savings this year, but much of the forced savings resulting from lockdowns and deferred investment will be drawn down to satisfy pent-up demand in the second quarter, once restrictions are lifted. The Kurzarbeit scheme has been extended to end-2021, which will support disposable incomes. However, in-person services will take longer to recover, and the immediate outlook is not promising. After a decrease in 2020, owing to deferred reporting obligations and massive government financial support, we expect a rise in bankruptcies this year.
In 2022 we expect strong carryover effects and improving macroeconomic conditions across emerging markets to drive growth of 4%. We then forecast a moderation to 1.9% annual average growth in 2023-25. Germany's poor demographic outlook will constrain potential growth as the working-age population declines, exacerbated by a fall in net immigration during the pandemic. Technological disruption to the automotive sector also represents a structural risk: Germany has been slow to shift emphasis towards electric vehicles. Efforts to reduce supply-chain dependence on China may result in some reshoring of production, but as labour costs in Europe are higher, we do not expect this to result in a surge in job creation. Instead, automation and digitisation will gain pace, and supply-chain linkages with existing suppliers in central and eastern Europe will strengthen.
Outlook for 2021-25: Inflation Consumer prices rose by just 0.4% in 2020, reflecting low oil prices, the hit to demand from the coronavirus and the cut to the VAT rate in July-December. January 2021 saw a change in trend, with annual inflation rising to 1.6% as a consequence of the end of the VAT cut, new carbon emissions certificates raising transport and heating costs, and a minimum-wage rise. Annual price growth will remain above the euro zone average in 2021 as a consequence of these changes in administered prices, averaging 1.8%, and exceeding 2% in the second half of the year (when the base period will include the 2020 VAT cut). We expect inflation to moderate to an annual average of 1.6% in 2022-25, allowing for a continuation of the ECB's accommodative monetary policy.
Outlook for 2021-25: Exchange rates The euro experienced high volatility throughout 2020. A depreciation against the US dollar in the early months of the year, when the coronavirus forced European countries into lockdowns, was followed by a rapid appreciation after the EU announced the establishment of a new recovery fund worth EUR750bn. After ending the year at US$1.23:EUR1, we expect the euro to depreciate gradually against the US dollar in 2021-23, owing to a protracted economic recovery and continued monetary accommodation from the ECB, which will maintain its ultra-loose policy stance for longer than the Federal Reserve (the US central bank). The euro will strengthen from 2024 onwards, supported by the gradual unwinding of the ECB's asset purchases and by the euro zone's structural current-account surplus.
Outlook for 2021-25: External sector Germany's current-account surpluses were the largest in the world in nominal terms in the four years to 2019, and we expect them to be so again from 2021, after temporarily falling below China last year. They are underpinned by huge trade surpluses, reflecting the competitiveness of the manufacturing sector. This will continue to generate large domestic savings that are mainly invested abroad, leading to a solid primary income surplus.
We expect the 2020 recession to have caused a decline in Germany's trade surplus, as the fall in exports outstripped the fall in imports. We estimate the current-account surplus at the equivalent of 6.9% of GDP-down from an annual average of 7.8% in the previous six years. Trade and primary income surpluses will comfortably outweigh narrow structural deficits on the services and secondary income accounts throughout our forecast period. In 2021-25 we forecast that the external surplus will average 6.7% of GDP as world trade volumes and investment flows recover.
